SUGGESTED BIBLIOGRAPHY FOR FURTHER READING

指数

INDEX

阿隆·科普兰(1900-90) 的作品举世闻名，备受推崇，在世界各地广泛演出和录制，其中包括获得普利策奖的芭蕾舞剧《阿巴拉契亚之春》，以及《比利小子》、《牛仔竞技》、《林肯肖像》以及电影《我们的小镇》和《女继承人》的配乐。1986 年，科普兰荣获国会金质奖章，并被誉为“独特的美国音乐，反映了我们民族的灵魂和经历”。在职业生涯中，科普兰曾在哈佛大学和伯克希尔音乐中心教授作曲，在美国各地演讲，并创作了《我们的新音乐》和《音乐与想象》。

Aaron Copland’s (1900-90) well-known and highly regarded compositions, performed and recorded extensively throughout the world, include the Pulitzer Prize-winning ballet Appalachian Spring, as well as Billy the Kid, Rodeo, Lincoln Portrait, and the film scores of Our Town and The Heiress. On being awarded a Congressional Gold Medal in 1986, Copland was praised for his “uniquely American music that reflects the very soul and experience of our people.” During his career, Copland taught composition at Harvard and the Berkshire Music Center, lectured all over the United States, and wrote Our New Music and Music and Imagination.

 

 

艾伦·里奇， 《洛杉矶周刊》音乐评论家，曾担任《纽约先驱论坛报》、《纽约》杂志和《新闻周刊》等多家出版物的首席音乐评论家。里奇曾在哈佛大学、伯克利大学及海外学习音乐。他著有多部书籍，并发行了一系列音乐史CD。

Alan Rich, music critic for L.A. Weekly, has been chief music critic for the New York Herald Tribune, New York magazine, and Newsweek, among other publications. Rich studied music at Harvard, Berkeley, and abroad. He is the author of a number of books, as well as a series of CD-ROMs on music history.

 

 

伦纳德·斯拉特金是底特律交响乐团的音乐总监，同时也是匹兹堡交响乐团的首席客座指挥。此前，他曾担任华盛顿特区国家交响乐团的音乐总监多年，此前他曾担任圣路易斯交响乐团的音乐总监，现为圣路易斯交响乐团的桂冠指挥。他几乎与所有重要的国际乐团都有过定期合作，他的歌剧表演也让他在世界各地的顶级歌剧公司中崭露头角。他荣获过许多荣誉和奖项，包括2003年美国国家艺术奖章，这是美国政府授予艺术家的最高奖项。

Leonard Slatkin is Music Director of the Detroit Symphony Orchestra and also serves as Principal Guest Conductor of the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra. He previously served many years as Music Director of the National Symphony Orchestra in Washington, D.C, and before that of the Saint Louis Symphony, where he is now Conductor Laureate. He has made regular appearances with virtually every major international orchestra, and his performances of opera have taken him to leading opera companies around the world. He is the recipient of many honors and awards, including the 2003 National Medal of Arts, the highest award given to artists by the United States government.

 

 

威廉·舒曼于1910年8月4日出生于纽约市，在投身古典音乐创作（包括管弦乐和合唱）之前，他曾为广播、歌舞杂耍和夜总会表演创作流行歌曲。1943年，他获得了首个普利策音乐奖。他是一位备受赞誉的教师和管理者，曾先后担任茱莉亚学院和林肯中心的院长。他于1992年2月15日去世。

William Schuman was born in New York City on August 4, 1910, and wrote popular songs for radio, vaudeville, and nightclub acts before devoting himself to classical music, both orchestral and choral. In 1943 he received the first Pulitzer Prize ever given for music. A highly acclaimed teacher and administrator, he served as president of the Juilliard School and then of Lincoln Center. He died on February 15, 1992

亚伦·科普兰：美国音乐之声

Aaron Copland: America’s Musical Voice

他代表着美国西部，代表着纽约的脉搏。他不仅仅是美国音乐史上的一位人物。阿隆·科普兰是这个充满创新者的国家的先驱。当我们想到对世界舞台产生重大影响的美国作曲家时，我们脑海中浮现的只有几个名字：艾夫斯、格什温、巴伯和伯恩斯坦。但科普兰永远位居榜首。

He was the American West. He was the heartbeat of New York. He was more than simply a figure in American musical history. Aaron Copland was a pioneer in a country full of innovators. And when we think of composers from the States who made a significant impact on the world scene, only a few names come to mind: Ives, Gershwin, Barber, and Bernstein. But at the top of the list it is always Copland.

为什么排在首位？我觉得是科普兰带领我们度过了二十世纪的音乐风暴。当然，可以说艾夫斯（1874-1954）是第一个赋予美国音乐真正民族特色的人。但他的愿景孤立，当时很少有人追随，也为大多数人误解。格什温赋予了这个国家一种大众认同感，但他为音乐厅创作的作品展现了一种模仿天赋，而这种天赋在他短暂的一生中（他39岁去世）未能得到充分发挥。

Why at the top? I feel that it was Copland who saw us through the musical turmoil that was the twentieth century. Certainly it can be argued that Ives (1874-1954) was the first to give a truly national flavor to the music of America. But his was an isolated vision, followed by few at the time and misunderstood by most. Gershwin gave the nation a sense of popular identity, but his works for the concert hall showed an imitative gift that was not allowed to develop in his all too brief life (he died at the age of thirty-nine).

塞缪尔·巴伯（1910-1981）重塑了浪漫主义时代，但他的作曲风格却鲜有真正美国化。而本应继承科普兰衣钵的伯恩斯坦，或许更令人铭记的是他的演奏能力，而非创作成果。

Samuel Barber (1910-81) reinvented the romantic era, but he rarely strayed into a truly American style of composition. And Bernstein, who should have inherited Copland’s mantle, is probably best remembered more for his performing abilities rather than his creative output.

我无意对这些大师过分苛刻，当然也并非出于不敬。他们都是巨擘，如果没有他们至关重要的贡献，我们无法想象美国音乐的景象。但科普兰代表着我们的音乐史和集体的音乐良知。他表达了一个国家在战争与和平时期的情感。他的个性几乎体现在他创作的每一部作品中。人们始终意识到，他的任何作品都无法被他人创作。

I do not mean to be unduly harsh on these masters. It is certainly not out of lack of respect. They were all giants and it is impossible to envision the American musical landscape without their vital contributions. But Copland is our musical history and collective musical conscience. He gave voice to the feelings of a country in times of war and peace. His individuality came through in virtually every work he wrote. One is always aware that no one else could have created any of his pieces.

本书的再版也提醒我们，他是音乐教育领域的领军人物。但作曲家的生命首先在于乐谱上的音符，而非歌词。而这位能够为我们所有人创造如此多不同世界的人，正是如此。

With the republication of this volume, we are also reminded that he was a leader in music education. But a composer lives first and foremost by the notes on a page, rather than the words. And here was a man who could create so many different worlds for all of us.

首先，是一位刚从巴黎学成归来的傲慢年轻人。他的老师纳迪亚·布朗热（Nadia Boulanger）嘱咐他要真正建立一种“美国式”的音乐会音乐。在他的第一部大型作品《管风琴与管弦乐队交响曲》中，指挥家瓦尔特·达姆罗施（Walter Damrosch）惊呼：“如果一个25岁的人能写出这样的音乐，五年后他就能去杀人了。” 伦纳德·伯恩斯坦（Leonard Bernstein）过去常常在派对上演奏科普兰的《钢琴变奏曲》，并自豪地说这首作品“保证两分钟内就能让全场沸腾”。

First, there was the brash young man, fresh from his studies in Paris. His teacher, Nadia Boulanger, charged him to truly establish an “American” style of concert music. In his first large-scale work, the Symphony for Organ and Orchestra, the conductor, Walter Damrosch exclaimed, “If a man of twenty-five can write music like this, in five years he’ll be ready to commit murder.” Leonard Bernstein used to play Copland’s “Piano Variations” at parties, proudly saying that the work was “guaranteed to clear out the room in two minutes.”

如今听来，很难找到能引起如此共鸣的作品。当然，那首曲子的确有些前卫，但几乎无人能出其右。或许是因为科普兰的演奏带有浓厚的美式风格，乐句中充满了爵士节奏和尖锐的和声。

Listening today, it is hard to find much that could engender these reactions. Certainly there was an edge to the music, but it was hardly anything that was not being done by others. Perhaps it was because Copland was doing it with a firm American style, phrases filled with jazz rhythms and spiky harmonies.

但随着国家陷入冲突，他本人和他的音乐也发生了改变。芭蕾舞界为我们带来了他为《比利小子》、《牛仔竞技》和《阿巴拉契亚之春》创作的令人难忘的配乐。他的《第三交响曲》似乎深入探究了潜意识和抽象，但同时也帮助一个国家找到了交响乐的立足点。

But as the country was drawn into conflict, both the man and his music changed. The world of ballet gave us his memorable scores to Billy the Kid, Rodeo, and Appalachian Spring. And his Third Symphony seemed to delve deeply into the subconscious and abstract but at the same time help a country find its symphonic foothold.

他为影视、广播和戏剧创作。虽然只有一部大型歌剧，但它似乎也概括了只有美国才能创作的情感。在他作曲生涯的最后几年，由于他的爱国主义和政治立场受到质疑，他转向了更为严肃的写作风格。他的风格转变再次令人震惊，但这始终体现着他独特的声音。阅读这本书也是了解这种声音的一种方式。

He wrote for the screen, radio, and theater. Although there is only one large-scale opera, it too seems to sum up feelings that could only be created in the United States. In the final years of his composing life, having had his patriotism and political affiliations called into question, he turned to a more severe form of writing. Once again, his change of style was shocking, but it always spoke in his distinctive voice. To read this book is also a way to find out about that voice.

指挥他的​​音乐，从简洁的《静谧之城》到喧嚣的《大城音乐》，让人百听不厌。像《古巴舞曲》这样的短篇作品，与像《交响颂》这样的长篇作品一样令人回味无穷。如同贝多芬一样，科普兰似乎总是知道下一个音符是什么。他有一种必然性，一种只有少数人才能获得的天赋。而且，他总是知道何时该收手。

It is not possible to get tired of conducting his music, from the simplicity of “Quiet City” to the bustle of “Music for a Great City.” Short works, such as the “Danzón Cubano,” are just as rewarding as the longer pieces, such as the “Symphonic Ode.” Like Beethoven, Copland always seemed to know what note came next. There is a sense of inevitability, a gift granted to only a select few. And he always knew when to stop.

我只见过科普兰几次。从20世纪60年代末开始，他开始放弃作曲，转而指挥，但指挥的不仅仅是他自己的作品。作为圣路易斯的助理指挥，我有幸与他一起探讨音乐的平衡和力度。他的曲目引人入胜。他不仅支持年轻的美国作曲家，也支持那些被忽视的作曲家。他或许并非指挥台上最优秀的倡导者，但他的慷慨却意义非凡。有人说，作为指挥家，他是一位伟大的作曲家。

I met Copland only a few times. Starting in the late 1960s, he began to forsake composition for conducting, but not just of his own music. As the assistant conductor in Saint Louis, I had the privilege to work with him on balances and dynamics. His repertoire was intriguing. Championing younger American composers as well as neglected ones, he may not have been the best advocate on the podium, but his largesse carried great weight. It has been said that as a conductor, he was a great composer.

重读这本书，我不禁想起科普兰如何能够阐述复杂的音乐概念，却又清晰简洁地传达，从不向读者灌输文字。没错，那是一个不同的时代，人们认为大多数人都对音乐的基本要素有一定的了解。但即使现在情况并非如此，理解他所言也并非难事。最终，关键在于专注和享受。科普兰邀请我们去聆听，而不仅仅是听到。

In rereading this book, I was reminded of the way Copland could expound on complex musical matters and yet deliver them with clarity and simplicity, never writing down to the reader. Yes, it was a different time and it was assumed that most people had some working knowledge of the fundamental elements of music. But even if that is not true now, it is easy to grasp what he is saying. Ultimately it comes down to concentrating and enjoying. Copland invites us to listen, rather than just hear.

因此，他作为一名作家的作品让我们有机会听到这位非凡音乐家的另一种声音。

And so his work as an author gives us all a chance to hear yet another voice of this extraordinary musician.

 

 

—伦纳德·斯拉特金

—Leonard Slatkin

前言

Foreword

时光倒流。那是1939年。阿隆·科普兰，这位世纪之交（1900年11月14日）出生于布鲁克林的作曲家，已被广泛誉为第一位真正的美国作曲家。如今，他出版了一本虽小却极具价值的书，汇集了他在曼哈顿社会研究新学院的讲座，书名为《音乐中聆听什么》。这并非他首次尝试将古典音乐的体验转化为文字，但正如众多热情读者很快意识到的那样，这无疑是他首次从音乐内部进行这样的尝试，首次表达了真正参与音乐创作的人如何看待周围艺术世界的视角。

Turn back the clock. The year is 1939. Aaron Copland, Brooklyn-born at the turn of the century (November 14, 1900), is already being widely hailed as the first genuinely American composer. Now he has produced a small but immensely valuable book, a compilation of lectures he had given at Manhattan’s New School for Social Research under the title “What to Listen for in Music,” not the first attempt to translate the experience of classical music into words but—as hordes of enthusiastic readers soon recognized—surely the first such attempt from the inside, the first to express the way someone actually involved in creating music regards the artistic world around him.

科普兰十几岁时就被公认为钢琴和作曲方面的神童。很快，他便和许多同行一样，被吸引到所有严肃音乐的传统发源地——欧洲，去发展自己的音乐技能。令人敬畏的纳迪亚·布朗热，一位作曲家、管风琴家兼教师，在巴黎附近枫丹白露新成立的美国音乐学院，为有抱负的年轻美国作曲家设立了课程。二十岁的科普兰是第一批来到布朗热家门口的作曲家之一。布朗热是美国乐坛一代又一代杰出音乐家的教母，他们曾尝试着崭新的音乐风格——从20世纪20年代的科普兰、维吉尔·汤姆森和罗伊·哈里斯，到20世纪60年代的菲利普·格拉斯。布朗热向她那些初出茅庐的学生们灌输音乐基础知识：如何聆听过去的音乐（以及聆听什么），以及如何将这些技巧运用到现在和未来的音乐中。最重要的是，她倡导作曲家们在周围的世界中寻找新的音乐源泉，而不是仅仅对过去的音乐进行刻板的模仿——而应该无畏地探索新的未知领域。

Recognized as a prodigy—at the piano and as a composer—while in his teens, Copland was soon lured, as were many of his colleagues, to develop his musical skills at the traditional fountainhead of all serious music, Europe. The formidable Nadia Boulanger, composer, organist, and teacher, had set up a curriculum for aspiring young American composers at the newly formed American Conservatory at Fontainebleau, near Paris. The twenty-year-old Copland was one of the first to arrive at Boulangerʹs doorstep. Godmother in all but name to generations of the most distinguished names in American music as they tested their new wings—from Copland, Virgil Thomson and Roy Harris in the 1920s to Philip Glass in the 1960s—Boulanger drilled her fledgling charges in musical basics: how to listen to (and what to listen for) in the music of the past, and how to make those techniques work in the music of the present and future. Most of all she preached the need for composers to seek new musical sources in the world around them, rather than grinding out slavish if proficient rip-offs of the music of the past—and to venture fearlessly into new and unknown regions.

1921 年，科普兰成为布朗热在枫丹白露的第一个学生，当时音乐界仍为伊戈尔·斯特拉文斯基的《春之祭》所震撼。这部作品于 1913 年 5 月 29 日首次公演，许多人认为这一天是现代音乐的诞生日。这部划时代乐曲的首演让观众为之疯狂，作曲家竟然大胆地将管弦乐中的弦乐用作打击乐器，让通常表现良好的木管乐器发出怪异的哀嚎，并建立起一连串令人痛苦的冲击和变化的节奏。音乐从此发生了翻天覆地的变化。当时胆怯的听众很可能会将斯特拉文斯基的乐谱视为音乐界的末日审判；即使现在，这部里程碑式的作品已成为大多数交响乐团熟悉的保留曲目，而且库存充足的唱片店可能会提供五十场该乐谱的竞争演出，但当斯特拉文斯基的鼓声开始猛烈冲击时，您仍然会偶尔看到一位痛苦的观众匆忙撤离音乐厅。

In 1921, when Copland became Boulangerʹs first student at Fontainebleau, the musical world was still quivering from the impact of Igor Stravinsky’s The Rite of Spring, first heard on May 29, 1913—which many take as the birth date of modern music. The premiere of that epochal score—whose composer had had the gall to use his orchestral strings as percussion instruments, elicit unearthly wails from the usually well behaved woodwinds, and set up an agonizing chain of pounding, shifting rhythms—had stirred its audience to riot; music would never again be the same. The timid listener of the time might well have looked on Stravinsky’s score as music’s Armageddon; even now, when that milestone work counts as familiar repertory to most symphony orchestras and when a well-stocked record store might offer fifty competing performances of that one score, you’ll still occasionally witness a suffering patron beating a hasty retreat from the concert hall as Stravinsky’s drums begin their onslaught.

1922年3月， 《春之祭》在无所畏惧、勇于创新的利奥波德·斯托科夫斯基的带领下传入美国。它（如同九年前在巴黎一样）受到了大多数人的愤怒和勇敢者的欢呼。第一次世界大战结束后，美国的音乐品味基本趋于保守，其主要作曲家——例如创作了甜美钢琴曲集（《致一朵野玫瑰》等）的爱德华·麦克道威尔——都以半个世纪前的欧洲模式创作交响曲、协奏曲和歌曲。查尔斯·艾夫斯是一位充满音乐创新热情、致力于在其音乐中注入美国民族意识的作曲家，到1914年，他已经创作了大量规模宏大、风格大胆的作品；这些乐谱中的佼佼者随后被束之高阁三十多年，直到新一代音乐家——其中包括在美国接受教育和训练的伦纳德·伯恩斯坦——才姗姗来迟却欣喜地发现了它们的价值。

The Rite of Spring arrived in America in March 1922 led by the fearless, innovative Leopold Stokowski, greeted (as in Paris nine years before) with outrage from the majority and with cheers from the courageous. Basically, America’s musical tastes at the end of the First World War tended toward the conservative, with its major composers—Edward MacDowell, say, of the sugary piano pieces (“To a Wild Rose,” etc.)—fashioning their symphonies, concertos, and songs on the European models of half a century before. Charles Ives, one composer imbued with a passion for musical innovation, and for instilling into his music a sense of American nationality, had by 1914 already created a legacy of large-scale, daring works; the best of these scores then sat on the shelf for another three decades or more, until a new generation of musicians—among them the American-educated, American-trained Leonard Bernstein—made a belated but exhilarated discovery of their worth.

纳迪亚·布朗热引导她的美国学生加深对自身出身的认知，并培养将这种认知转化为伟大音乐的技能。在她的推动下，美国音乐开始回归本真：中西部的民谣和舞曲融入了罗伊·哈里斯的交响曲，南方浸信会的赞美诗旋律在维吉尔·汤姆森的小型钢琴曲和大型歌剧中焕然一新。

Nadia Boulanger led her American students toward a heightened recognition of their own origins, and toward the skills that would translate this awareness into great music. American music, thanks to her urgings, began to sound like itself: Midwestern ballads and dances that found their way into Roy Harris’s symphonies, the Southern Baptist hymn tunes transfigured in Virgil Thomson’s small piano pieces and full-scale operas.

1924 年，科普兰回到美国后，他的首批成功作品之一就是他的《剧院音乐》，这是一套舞曲和音画组曲，借鉴了美国对拉格泰姆音乐的部分曲调和节奏的狂热。1927 年 1 月，这位自豪的作曲家弹奏钢琴，谢尔盖·库塞维茨基指挥波士顿交响乐团，科普兰的钢琴协奏曲在观众和评论家中激起了反响，其程度堪比十四年前巴黎的“春之骚动”。为什么？因为这位大胆的年轻美国作曲家敢于从自己国家的音乐中汲取灵感——它的眩目、它的争论，以及——可怕的！——在风格熔炉中自由加入新潮的爵士乐。波士顿神圣的交响乐厅里演奏爵士乐？那一天，大地一定震动了。

One of Copland’s first successes, after his return to the United States in 1924, was his Music for the Theater, a suite of dances and tone-pictures that drew on America’s ragtime craze for some of its tunes and rhythms. In January 1927, with the proud composer at the piano and Serge Koussevitzky conducting the Boston Symphony, Copland’s Piano Concerto stirred up a reaction among the audience and critics comparable to the “Riot of Spring” in Paris fourteen years before. Why? Because this audacious young American composer had dared to draw inspiration from his own country’s music—its dazzle, its wrangle and—horror!—a liberal dose of the newfangled jazz stirred into the stylistic melting pot. Jazz in Boston’s hallowed Symphony Hall? The earth surely shook that day.

十年后，阿隆·科普兰的名字被广泛认可，成为美国四季皆宜的作曲家。他不断创作的交响乐、室内乐和钢琴独奏作品，确立了他作为令人敬畏的不和谐音世界中创新者的权威。他敏锐的听觉，能够捕捉到本土音乐的旋律颤动和动态节奏——这些音乐源于他自身的俄罗斯犹太移民背景，从在名为“墨西哥沙龙”（El Salón México）的歌舞表演中回荡的狂野拉丁节奏，到比利小子（Billy the Kid）在静谧的夜晚可能听到的萦绕心头的牛仔风格曲调——扩展了这一传承，似乎在宣告音乐的伟大与平易近人并非势不两立。他创作于1938年的《比利小子》（Billy the Kid）是一系列芭蕾舞乐谱中的第一部，这些乐谱将高雅艺术与通俗艺术巧妙地融合在一起：《牛仔竞技》（Rodeo）和《阿巴拉契亚之春》（Appalachian Spring）至今仍位列世界杰作之列。

Ten years later, the name Aaron Copland was everywhere recognized as the American composer for all seasons. A growing legacy of symphonic works, chamber music, and piano solos confirmed his credentials as an innovator in the fearsome world of dissonance. A fine ear for the melodic throb and the dynamic rhythms of indigenous music—from his own Russian-Jewish immigrant background, from the frenzy of Latin rhythms as they might resound in a cabaret called “El Salón México,” to a haunting, cowboyish tune that Billy the Kid might have heard on a quiet night—expanded that legacy and seemed to proclaim that greatness and accessibility in music need not be sworn enemies. His 1938 Billy the Kid was the first of a series of ballet scores that enchantingly mingled high and low art: Rodeo and Appalachian Spring abide among the world’s fund of masterpieces.

1936年和1937年的冬天，科普兰举办了一系列讲座，两年后，这些讲座成为了本书的基础。这些讲座也使用了相同的标题：“在音乐中聆听什么”或许在语法上显得有些笨拙，但它的精准程度远胜于“如何聆听音乐”。“这些正是我在这部作品中发现的非凡之处，具有决定性的意义，”科普兰用他那优美而精妙的措辞不断提醒我们。“这就是作曲家运用这些元素的方式，以及它们对我的影响。如果你愿意，可以把我当作榜样，或者不。你只能靠自己。”这可不是一个痴迷于自我辩护的作曲家会说的话。（如果说本书有什么不足之处，那就是缺少“在阿隆·科普兰的音乐中聆听什么”这一章。）

In the winters of 1936 and 1937, Copland delivered the series of lectures that became the basis, two years later, for this book. The lectures, too, bore the same title; “What to Listen for in Music” may seem a bit clumsy grammatically, but it is accurate in a way that “How to Listen to Music” would not be. “These are the things that I find remarkable, defining, in this particular piece,” Copland constantly reminds us in his beautifully well chosen words. “This is what the composer does with these things, and what they do to me. Accept me as a role model, if you wish, or don’t. You’re on your own.” That is hardly the sentiment of a composer obsessed with the need for self-justification. (If there is a weakness here, it is the absence of a “What to Listen for in Aaron Copland’s Music” chapter.)

科普兰的话语中持久的力量在于，它们描绘了一位为自己的音乐感到自豪的音乐家，为自己作品周围的音乐世界感到自豪，渴望深入这个世界，找到描述无言现象的词语，让这些词语的最终接收者——换句话说，你和我——更接近我们能够听到并想要更好地听到的音乐的神奇奥秘。

The enduring strength in Copland’s words is the portrait they create of a musician proud of his music, proud of the musical world surrounding his own work, eager to delve into that world and find the words for its wordless phenomena that can bring the ultimate recipient of those words—you and me, in other words—closer to the magical mysteries of the music we can hear and want to hear better.

自从阿隆·科普兰编纂了这本我喜欢称之为“音乐拥有者手册”的书以来，聆听音乐的过程发生了巨大的变化，而且大多是变得更好了（尽管它显然也是一本被音乐拥有的手册）。我有一本世界各地可用录音的百科全书，出版于科普兰开始讲课的同一年；将其列表与著名的施旺目录的最新一期进行比较令人震惊。放眼望去：约瑟夫·海顿的 104 部交响曲（今天都可以找到四五遍的录音版本），而 1936 年只有 10 部。理查德·瓦格纳的《尼伯龙根的指环》的四部伟大的音乐剧中，没有一部被完整录制；在撰写本文时，《尼伯龙根的指环》完整版已有 8 个版本。面对当前巴洛克大师安东尼奥·维瓦尔第的协奏曲泛滥成灾的局面，1936 年只有三部——而且全都是现代化的“非原版”编曲；约翰·塞巴斯蒂安·巴赫创作了超过两百部教堂康塔塔，其中只有一部是其中的一部，这些康塔塔都是任何时代创作的最有影响力的音乐剧之一。

The very process of hearing music has changed enormously, and mostly for the better, since Aaron Copland compiled this “ownerʹs manual for music,” as I like to call it (although it’s just as clearly a manual to being owned by music). I have an encyclopedia of available recordings worldwide, published the same year Copland began his lectures; it’s astonishing to compare its listings with the latest issue of the renowned Schwann Catalogue. Look anywhere: out of 104 symphonies by Joseph Haydn (all of them available today in recorded versions four or five times duplicated), only ten were available in 1936. Of the four mighty music dramas of Richard Wagnerʹs Ring of the Nibelung, not one had been recorded complete; at this writing there are eight versions of the complete “Ring.” Against the current deluge of concertos by the Baroque master Antonio Vivaldi, there are but three—all of them in modernized, “inauthentic” arrangements—listed in 1936; there was but a single one of the more than two hundred church cantatas by Johann Sebastian Bach, some of the most powerful music dramas composed in any era.

此外，唱片都是装在12英寸的硬质（有时易碎）虫胶唱片上，每分钟旋转78圈，每面最长可播放4.5分钟；每张唱片零售价2美元（以1936年的美元计算！）。考虑到通货膨胀率约为20%，比如一张贝多芬第五交响曲的唱片，装在四张双面唱片上，按今天的零售价约为160美元；而现在，你只需不到10美元，就能在一张CD上听到完美无瑕、不间断的第五交响曲——或许还会额外加一首交响曲——最长可容纳80分钟的音乐。1936年的留声机通常是客厅里的一件大件家具。真正富裕的人买得起唱片换碟机，这样就不用每4.5分钟走到唱机前换碟了，但机器的运转周期大约是10秒，所以你仍然只能听到短片段的音乐。长放唱片发明五十年后，CD问世二十年后，我的潜意识里仍然能听到这些音乐片段中贝多芬第五交响曲的声音，还能听到慢乐章第二面开头的刮擦声。（当然，这并非我“聆听”音乐的目的，但我无力避免。）

Recordings, furthermore, came on twelve-inch, hard (and sometimes agonizingly breakable) shellac discs, rotated at seventy-eight revolutions per minute, with each side lasting up to 4½ minutes; each disc retailed for two dollars (1936 dollars!). Figuring an inflation factor of about twenty, a recording of, say, Beethoven’s Fifth Symphony, on four double-sided discs, would retail at about $160 at today’s rates; instead, you can now get a perfectly good, uninterrupted performance of the Fifth—with, perhaps, another symphony tossed in for good measure—on a single compact disc, holding up to eighty minutes of music, for under ten dollars. The 1936 phonograph was usually a massive piece of parlor furniture. The truly affluent could afford a record changer, thus saving the walk to the turntable every 4½ minutes, but the machinery operated on about a ten-second cycle, so you still only got to hear the music in short segments. Fifty years after the invention of the long-playing record, twenty years after the compact disc, part of my subconscious still hears the Beethoven Fifth Symphony in these musical lumps, and also hears the scratch at the start of the second side of the slow movement. (This is not, of course, what I “listen for” in the music, but it’s something beyond my power to avoid.)

科普兰的这本书帮助人们克服了这种零碎的家庭听歌方式的困难，而且随着音乐通过广播的魔力变得越来越容易以合适的、不间断的形式传播开来，这本书成了我的良伴。纽约爱乐乐团每周在卡内基音乐厅现场直播的音乐会，让全国各地的周日下午都成了神圣的仪式。大都会歌剧院每周的午间演出也同样神圣。1937 年圣诞节，阿图罗·托斯卡尼尼和他新成立的 NBC 交响乐团进行了他们的首次广播，此后的十七年里，他们一直在进行一系列的广播演出。其他大城市的管弦乐队也向当地观众转播他们的演出。即使没有当今广播媒体提供的丰富选择和如今唱片商场惊人的资源，1939 年的人们也能接触到相当多的音乐。

A copy of Copland’s book helped bridge the difficulties in this piecemeal kind of home listening, and it served as boon companion as music became more and more accessible in its proper, uninterrupted form through the magic of radio. Sunday afternoons across the land became sacred observances, the weekly concerts by the New York Philharmonic, broadcast live from Carnegie Hall. Saturday afternoons were equally hallowed, the weekly matinee performances by the Metropolitan Opera. On Christmas Day 1937, Arturo Toscanini and his newly formed NBC Symphony Orchestra had their first broadcast in a series that was to stretch over seventeen years. Other orchestras in major cities broadcast their performances to local audiences. Even without the luxury of choice offered in today’s world of the broadcast media and the staggering resources of today’s recordings emporiums, people in 1939 had access to a fair amount of music.

二战结束后不久，聆听音乐的过程发生了翻天覆地的变化，这或许是好事，或许是坏事。长时间播放的唱片转速只有每分钟33.3转，但单曲播放时间却长达32分钟：比如说，一整张贝多芬第五交响曲，中间只有作曲家指定的间歇！更重要的是，录音制作的流程也精简到任何一个唱片制作人，只要带上几个麦克风和一台录音机，就能在音乐库中漫游，发现那些被音乐行业忽视的隐秘角落。到了20世纪50年代初，唱片目录上充斥着巴赫的康塔塔、海顿的交响曲、瓦格纳的音乐剧，以及包括科普兰本人作品在内的大量新音乐，所有这些作品都以前所未有的方式，以共鸣和连续的方式呈现。突然之间，似乎整个音乐爱好者的世界都能听到整个音乐创作世界的动静了。如果说有什么不同的话，那就是对“听什么音乐”这一指导的需求变得更加迫切了。

Not long after the end of World War II, the listening process underwent a drastic change, for better or for worse. The long-playing record turned at a pokey 33⅓ revolutions per minute, but held up to thirty-two minutes on a side: a whole Beethoven Fifth, say, with only the breaks in continuity ordained by the composer! What’s more, the processes behind the production of recordings had slimmed down to the point where any record producer, armed with a couple of microphones and a tape recorder, could roam the musical repertory and discover the hidden nooks and crannies that the industry had previously overlooked. By the early 1950s the catalogues swelled with Bach cantatas, Haydn symphonies, Wagnerian music dramas, grand quantities of new music including works by Copland himself, all available in resonant, continuous performance where none had been available before. Suddenly it seemed as if the entire music-loving world could tune in on the entire music-creating world. If anything, the need for guidance in What to Listen for in Music became even more profound.

1957年，科普兰对《听什么音乐》进行了温和的修订，增加了一章探讨在1957年的新音乐中应该听什么，以及另一章探讨电影音乐——他本人也曾涉足这个领域并取得了巨大成功，包括凭借1948年为《女继承人》配乐荣获奥斯卡奖。“听音乐的数量和质量都发生了变化，但……‘听什么音乐’的基本问题依然存在。因此，正文只需要进行细微的修改……”

Copland subjected What to Listen for in Music to a gentle revision in 1957, adding one chapter on what to listen for in new (1957!) music and another on film music—a field that he himself had invaded with great success, including an Academy Award for the 1948 score to The Heiress. “Both the quantity and quality of music listening have changed, but ... the basic problems of ʹwhat to listen forʹ have remained the same. For that reason, only minor corrections were needed in the body of the text. . . .”

四十年后，同样的保证还能适用吗？不能。1957 年，科隆的一个电子工作室正在创作音乐，声音不是来自乐器，而是来自一系列大小和熟练程度各异的发声设备。在加利福尼亚，作曲家科林·麦克菲和卢·哈里森的灵感不是来自法国和德国的传统模式，而是来自印度尼西亚甘美兰音乐的声音和节奏。1952 年，作曲家约翰·凯奇创作了一部作品，其中唯一的声音是一位静静地坐在钢琴前的钢琴家周围的房间噪音。一些作曲家——其中包括美国的米尔顿·巴比特和法国的皮埃尔·布列兹——将安东·韦伯恩音乐的极端形式主义扩展为一种完全由系统统治的音乐风格。其他人——凯奇、德裔美国人卢卡斯·福斯、德国的卡尔海因茨·施托克豪森——则从相反的角度出发，允许他们的音乐家完全自由地选择任何特定表演的形式。

Could that same reassurance apply forty years later? No, it could not. In 1957 there was music being created at an electronic studio in Cologne in which the sounds came not from instruments but from an array of tone-generating devices of various sizes and proficiency. In California the composers Colin McPhee and Lou Harrison drew their inspiration not from the traditional models of France and Germany but from the sounds and rhythms of Indonesian gamelan music. In 1952 the composer John Cage produced a work in which the only sounds were the room noises around a pianist sitting silently at a piano. Some composers—among them the American Milton Babbitt and France’s Pierre Boulez—expanded the extreme formalism of Anton Webern’s music into a musical style totally ruled by systems. Others—Cage, the German-born American Lukas Foss, Germany’s Karlheinz Stockhausen—worked from an opposite point of view, allowing their musicians totally free choice over the shape of any given performance.

毫不夸张地说，自1957年以来，音乐在各个边缘领域都经历了彻底的重塑，尽管核心依然保留。我大胆地在科普兰的文本中添加了一章，探讨这充满冒险精神的四十年里发生了什么，以及从中可以聆听到什么。

One could say without exaggeration that music in the years since 1957 has been totally reinvented around each and every fringe, even though the center has held. I have taken the extreme presumption of adding one chapter of my own to Copland’s text, on what has happened in those adventurous four decades, and what to listen for in the results.

科普兰的书刚出版时，接触音乐杰作还是一个充满不确定性的话题。他生动而专注的语言，以一种令人欣慰的方式，展现了当时音乐的奥秘与奇迹。他的文字指引我们认真对待音乐，同时又不失沉浸于交响乐团或钢琴演奏家的演奏之中。他丝毫没有意识到，接触他如此生动描述的那些音乐，往往需要通过78转唱片这种断断续续、刮擦声不断的媒介，或是FM收音机里持续不断的静电干扰；科普兰清晰地阐明，聆听音乐是一种值得付出努力的特权。

Access to musical masterpieces was a chancy proposition when Copland’s book first appeared. His vivid, dedicated language offered a comforting survey of the mysteries and miracles of whatever music was at hand. His words suggested ways to take music seriously, without denying ourselves the sheer indulgence in the sound of a symphony orchestra or a piano virtuoso at work. It disturbed him not at all to realize that access to the music he so vividly described was often through the scratch-infested stop-and-start medium of the 78-rpm disc, or through a barrage of static on a pre-FM radio; listening, Copland makes wonderfully clear, is a privilege well worth the effort.

如今，音乐无需费力便可演奏。翻看最新的CD目录，不禁让人怀疑，从古老教堂圣歌的朴素旋律到上周刚完成的鼓乐锣鼓，所有曾经创作的音乐作品，如今都已刻录成CD，有时甚至有无数个（我是不是觉得“浪费”了？）的复制版本。现代科技已能录制出令人叹为观止的录音，其音质堪比音乐厅或歌剧院的现场演出；当然，它也让我们不再需要以四分钟为单位来聆听音乐。如今的CD播放器无需人工干预，即可接收并播放多达一百张CD，每张CD的播放时长超过一小时。大多数大城市也设有广播电台，提供24小时不间断的古典音乐播放。换句话说，音乐的传播已经变得像壁纸行业的一个分支。

And now there is music without effort. A look at the latest compact-disc catalogue leads one to suspect that every piece of music ever composed, from the austere melodies of ancient church chant to the drums and gongs of something finished just last week, is now available on discs, sometimes in numerous (and did I hear “wasteful”?) duplicate versions. Modern technology has produced recordings amazingly like the sound of live performances in a concert hall or opera house; it has also, of course, eliminated the need to hear our music in four-minute segments. Compact-disc players exist that will accept and then play—without human intervention—a load of anywhere up to one hundred discs, each lasting more than an hour. There are also radio stations in most large cities that offer a twenty-four-hour steady flow of classical music. The spread of music, in other words, has come to resemble a branch of the wallpaper industry.

科普兰的书出现在一个相对匮乏的时代；它对于那些只能偶尔接触到一批伟大作品的潜在听众来说，充满了魅力和安慰。到 1936 年，贝多芬的所有弦乐四重奏、协奏曲和交响曲都已录制完成，勃拉姆斯的所有作品也都已录制完成，但莫扎特、海顿、巴赫或文艺复兴时期大师的作品却很少录制——本世纪的音乐作品就更少了。今天的听众不会面临这样的匮乏。贝多芬的交响曲已经制作完成（并复制了 75 遍），约阿希姆·拉夫和爱德华·图宾的交响曲、克努迪格·里萨格的室内乐、凯霍斯鲁·沙普尔吉·索拉布吉的钢琴曲也都制作完成：这些作曲家直到最近才被“发现”成为 CD 行业的素材，才为人所知。关于阿隆·科普兰的音乐，最新目录列出了八栏小字印刷的曲目，其中包括 1927 年那首“引起轩然大波”的钢琴协奏曲的五个版本。

Copland’s book appeared at a time of relative famine; it spoke words of charm and comfort to potential audiences with sporadic access to a central corps of great works. By 1936 all of Beethoven’s string quartets, concertos, and symphonies had been recorded, as well as all of Brahms’s, but few of the works of Mozart, Haydn, Bach or the great masters of the Renaissance—and far less of the music of this century. Today’s listener faces no such deprivation. The Beethoven symphonies have been produced (and reproduced seventy-five times over), and so have the symphonies of Joachim Raff and Eduard Tubin, the chamber music of Knudige Riisager, the piano music of Kaikhosru Shapurji Sorabji: composers virtually unknown until their recent “discovery” as grist for the compact-disc industry. Of music by Aaron Copland, the latest catalogue lists eight columns’ worth of very small print, including five versions of that “scandalous” Piano Concerto of 1927.

如今光盘宝库的浩瀚的确令人惊叹。然而，遗憾的是，其中很多都遭遇了前面提到的壁纸般的命运：在餐厅、书店或高楼电梯里，它被用作背景音乐；在厨房忙碌或准备晚餐时，它被用作收音机；在百碟播放器上，一两个小时后，它的音乐开始形成无定形的音雾。“你听不听重要吗？”这是一篇著名杂志文章的标题，该文章探讨了如何让观众参与到音乐体验中。可惜的是，答案是“并非总是如此”。科普兰听到这个消息肯定会惊恐万分，而且很可能不止一次。正因如此，这本书的书名才如此贴切：我们聆听西贝柳斯交响曲中独特的结构，聆听肖邦哪怕是一首短短的前奏曲中也蕴含的戏剧性惊喜，聆听柴可夫斯基音诗中故事情节与音乐的融合。我们把这些例子铭记在心，并学会在这本薄薄的书中，从未提及却同样珍贵的作品中寻找相似（或对比）的事件。沉浸在大师作曲家的音乐创作核心中，我们成为了聆听大师。晚餐可以等一等。

The vastness of today’s compact-disc treasury is indeed fabulous. Unfortunately, however, much of it suffers the fate of the aforementioned wallpaper: as background for smart conversation in restaurants, bookstores or the elevators of tall buildings; on the radio at home as we do our puttering in the kitchen or serve dinner; on the 100-disc player, where after an hour or two its music begins to form an amorphous fog of sound. “Does It Matter if You Listen?” read the title of a famous magazine article about involving an audience in a musical experience. The answer, alas, is “not always.” Copland would rise up in horror at this news, and probably did more than once. That’s why the title of the book is so appropriate: we listen for the structural peculiarities in a Sibelius symphony, the dramatic surprises in even a tiny Chopin Prelude, the wedding of story-line and music in a Tschaikovsky tonepoem. We take those instances to heart, and learn to find similar (or contrasting) events in works unmentioned, but no less valuable, in this one slim volume. Plunged into the creative heart of the music of the master composers, we become master listeners. Dinner can wait.

 

 

 

 

关于精选录音的说明

A Note on Selected Recordings

 

 

《音乐聆听指南》之前的版本长达八页，罗列了科普兰在文中讨论过（或者更多时候只是点名提及）的音乐录音。这份清单冗长得令人咋舌，说实话甚至有点吓人。我大幅精简了这份清单，并将其分解成每章末尾的推荐曲目。如今录音繁多，我认为没有必要在书里每个专有名词下都标注其对应的标志性曲目；我相信，如果听众在第三章中迷上了巴托克的《弦乐、打击乐和钢片琴》，他们一定会受到启发，继续聆听巴托克的更多作品——如果我可以建议的话，就从《第四弦乐四重奏》开始吧。我还建议，拥有至少一套贝多芬的九部交响曲（最新光盘目录中列出了几十部），将是与阿隆·科普兰的精彩书籍建立任何形式合作关系的起点。

The previous editions of What to Listen for in Music contained up to eight pages listing recordings of music that Copland had discussed—or, more often, merely mentioned by name—in his text. It added up to a staggering list, somewhat intimidating if truth be known. I have pruned the list drastically and broken it down into segments of recommended listening at the end of each chapter. Living as we do in times of recording redundancies, I don’t think it makes sense to underline every proper name in the book with its appropriate signature tune; I would trust a listener who gets hooked on, say, Bartók’s Music for Strings, Percussion and Celesta in Chapter Three to be inspired to move on toward more Bartók—starting, if I may suggest, with the Fourth String Quartet. I would also suggest that ownership of at least one set of the nine Beethoven symphonies—of the several dozen listed in the latest compact-disc catalogue—would be ground zero for forming any kind of partnership with Aaron Copland’s marvelous book.

科普兰的文本中多次提到他1939年时珍视的录音，例如阿尔图罗·托斯卡尼尼录制的贝多芬第七交响曲，或者当时尚未有录音的曲目。托斯卡尼尼1936年的录音至今仍可听到，而且听起来依然美妙；当然，也有一些以更现代的音色演绎的版本。阿诺德·勋伯格的《钢琴曲集》（作品19），在1939年时尚未有录音，现在却有五个不同版本。我不会触及科普兰的文本，无论是其主要内容还是其中那些无关紧要的时代错误；就其本身而言，它代表了一位伟大的音乐思想家，这一点超越了其他任何考量。

Copland’s text includes a number of references to recordings that were obviously dear to him in 1939—Arturo Toscanini’s recording of Beethoven’s Seventh Symphony, for one—or of pieces for which no recording existed at the time. Well, Toscanini’s recording, made in 1936, is still available and still sounds wonderful; still, there are also other performances in more up-to-date sound. And the Piano Pieces, Opus 19, of Arnold Schoenberg, of which no recording existed in 1939, can now be had in any of five different versions. I will not touch Copland’s text, not its major substance nor its trifling anachronisms; as it stands, it stands for one of music’s great minds, and that transcends any other considerations.

 

 

—AR

—A.R.

介绍

Introduction

对于纯真的音乐爱好者来说，阅读一本关于如何聆听音乐的入门书确实显得有些奇怪。从什么时候开始，聆听音乐也成了问题？音乐的存在就是为了享受。为什么人们需要学习或指导如何聆听自己所听到的音乐？为什么我们伟大的作曲家会抽出时间创作一本关于音乐的入门书？答案很简单。聆听音乐是一项通过经验和学习获得的技能。知识能够提升享受。

For the innocent music lover it must seem strange indeed to read a how-to book on the subject of listening to music. Since when are there problems in listening to music? Music is there to be enjoyed. Why should one have to learn or need guidance on how to listen to what one is hearing? And why would one of our great composers take time from composing to write a primer on music? The answer is simple. Listening to music is a skill that is acquired through experience and learning. Knowledge enhances enjoyment.

音乐家们早已习惯了作曲家们作为评论家和学术论文作者的散文式论述（柏辽兹、勋伯格、施特劳斯，以及更贴近我们身边的巴比特、皮斯顿、佩尔西切蒂，这些只是众多名字中的几个），但在科普兰之前，从未有作曲大师尝试向外行人讲解音乐创作的技巧。这本书独一无二，事实上，独一无二。不了解的人可以想象一下伦勃朗的《绘画中寻找什么》一书，来理解它的意义。

Musicians are accustomed to the prose of composers as critics and as writers of learned theses on technical subjects (Berlioz, Schoenberg, Strauss and, closer to home, Babbitt, Piston, Persichetti are but a few of the many names that come to mind), but before Copland no master composer had ever attempted to explain the craft of music composition to the layperson. This book is one of a kind, in fact, unique. The uninitiated can gauge its significance by imagining a book by Rembrandt called What to Look for in Painting.

要开始欣赏《音乐的聆听意义》，我们最好先回顾一下这本书的作者是谁。阿隆·科普兰的音乐被公认为我们文化遗产的一部分。科普兰独特的声音丰富了我们所有人。这是一种前所未有的音乐，其表达方式如此个性化，以至于他的众多模仿者中，没有一个人能够令人信服地将其转化为自己的作品。然而，阿隆·科普兰长期以来一直是我们国家音乐界的熟知人物，以至于他和他的作品很容易被视作理所当然。我们当然为他的成就感到自豪，并庆幸能与他共事，但我们是否充分意识到他的独特之处？是什么让科普兰如此特别？任何一位杰出的创意艺术家当然都是特别的，但科普兰创作了一系列作品，以可识别的方式与他的同胞对话——而这种识别正是民族的共性。无论如何描述，科普兰的艺术都能唤起基于我们共同经历的共鸣，并赋予我们一种归属感。但科普兰的《音乐中应该听什么》是科普兰多年来发挥广泛领导作用的又一例证。

To begin to appreciate What to Listen for in Music it is well to remind ourselves of just who the author of this book is. The music of Aaron Copland is recognized as part of our heritage. That special Copland sound has enriched us all. It is a sound that was not in music before, and so personal an expression that not one of his many imitators has been able to make it convincingly his own. Yet Aaron Copland has so long been a familiar figure in our national musical life that he and his work are too easily taken for granted. Surely we glory in his achievements and count our good fortune in his presence, but are we sufficiently aware of his singular qualities? What makes Copland so special? Any outstanding creative artist is, to be sure, special, but Copland has created a body of works that speaks to his countrymen in identifiable terms—and this identification is national commonality. By whatever description, Copland’s art evokes a response based on our shared experiences, and gives us a sense of belonging. But Copland’s What to Listen for in Music is yet another example of the broad leadership that Copland has exercised these many years.

包括我在内的许多同事都曾多次谈论和撰写关于阿隆·科普兰的文章。回想起一些先前的论述，同样的感想再次浮现在我的脑海中。对我来说，最重要的是我坚信他代表了在民主社会中工作的艺术家的理想。科普兰的角色多种多样——公民、作曲家、演奏家、教师、讲师、委员会成员、发言人，以及我们不得不提的他最喜爱的角色之一——指挥家。《 聆听音乐的意义》展现了科普兰作为教授的特质，并精准地展现了他的教学理念。

A number of his colleagues, myself included, have had many opportunities to speak and write about Aaron Copland. In recalling some previous statements the same observations recur. Foremost for me is my firm conviction that he represents the ideal for artists functioning in a democratic society. Copland’s roles are many and varied—citizen, composer, performer, teacher, lecturer, committee member, spokesperson, and lest we forget one of his favorites, conductor. What to Listen for in Music represents Copland the professor and gives us an accurate indication of his teaching philosophy.

作为作曲教师，作曲家往往倾向于将自己的观点强加于学生，并灌输他们遵循自身技法的习惯。科普兰是一位罕见的作曲家，他帮助学生找到表达自我的方式，而不是掌握他独创的技巧，因为这些技巧可能与他们的特定才能息息相关，也可能毫无关联。科普兰将自己对过去音乐的渊博知识与对所有当代音乐的百科全书式理解相结合。由于他非凡的知识和清晰的教学理念体现在他的教学方法中，他的学生创作出了多种风格的音乐作品。很难想象会有比他更不教条主义的态度。科普兰的本质是：一位卓有成效的教师可以拥有自己坚定的信念，同时又感到有义务向学生传授他本人可能并不特别认同但似乎适合学生的美学教条和技术技巧。这与权威主义截然相反——关注个人的天性，而非强加先验的结论。

As teachers of composition, composers more often than not tend to impose their own views on their students and to instill adherence to their own technical procedures. Copland is that rare composer who helps his students find their own means of expressing themselves, rather than mastering his own techniques, which may or may not be germane to their particular talents. Copland combines the scholarʹs knowledge of music of the past with an encyclopedic understanding of all contemporary music. As an outcome of his extraordinary knowledge and clear philosophy reflected in his approach to teaching, his pupils compose in a variety of styles. A less doctrinaire attitude would be difficult to imagine. In essence, Copland is saying that an effective teacher can have his own strong convictions, yet feel it an obligation to expose his pupils to esthetic doctrines and technical procedures with which he himself may not be in particular sympathy, but which seem right for the pupil. Here is the opposite of the authoritarian—concern for the nature of the individual and not with the imposition of a priori conclusions.

诚然，科普兰是民主社会中典型的艺术家，但我常常希望我们能授予他一个帝王般的头衔。在英国，他早就被尊称为亚伦爵士，并被正式指定为国家作曲家了。但这些头衔与科普兰家族的魅力和直率实在不符。我还记得二十五年前有人称他为“美国作曲家协会主席”，当时他是多么困惑。如今，他依然风度翩翩地保留着这个头衔。

Granted that Copland is the quintessential artist in a democratic society, I have often wished nevertheless that we could bestow a regal title. In England he would long since have been referred to as Sir Aaron and have been designated an official national composer. But titles simply do not go with the charm and directness of the Copland makeup. I can recall over twenty-five years ago referring to him as the Dean of American Composers, and how bemused he was. He continues gallantly to bear this title.

如果我们缺乏一个正式成立、有权授予荣誉头衔的国家机构，那么我们还有另一个更有意义的机制：同行的评判。科普兰是杰出的，是我们爱戴和尊敬的对象。告诉他这一点让我们感到满足。他以始终如一的优雅和幽默接受了同事和公众的赞誉。当我问他是否终于对这些荣誉感到满意时，他说：“比尔，你低估了我的能力！”

If we lack a duly constituted national entity empowered to grant honorific titles, we have another mechanism that is even more meaningful: the judgment of one’s peers. Copland is preeminent and the object of our affection and esteem. It gives us satisfaction to tell him so. He accepts the accolades of his colleagues and public with unfailing grace and good humor. When I asked him if at long last he wasn’t sated with all the honors he said: “Bill, you underestimate my capacity!”

《聆听音乐的意义》带领读者从最简单的音乐元素，逐渐领略其最复杂的面向。这本书在某种程度上与作者的音乐作品相得益彰，因为科普兰的音乐作品涵盖了从通俗易懂的流行作品到精炼深奥的室内乐。

The contents of What to Listen for in Music take the reader from the simplest elements of music through the gradual unfolding of its most complex aspects. The book in a way is analogous to the authorʹs music, for Copland’s repertory ranges from the most accessible popular works to chamber music of the most distilled and esoteric erudition.

例如，在《阿巴拉契亚之春》等脍炙人口的作品中，科普兰以独特的音乐视角，诠释了一种显而易见的本土情感。在《林肯肖像》中，音乐框架不仅体现了文本，还为林肯富有同情心的言辞增添了新的维度。在这些作品以及《牛仔竞技》和《比利小子》等作品中，科普兰通过洞察简单音乐中蕴含的潜力，将传统的美国民间素材转化为最精妙的艺术，而这种潜力只有拥有非凡想象力的艺术家才能领悟。

In the popular works, for example, “Appalachian Spring,” Copland provides a special musical insight into a sentiment recognizably indigenous. In “A Lincoln Portrait” the musical frame embodies the text and gives an added dimension to Lincoln’s compassionate utterances. In these works, and compositions such as “Rodeo” and “Billy the Kid,” Copland transforms traditional American folk materials into the most sophisticated art by discerning the potentialities in simple music that could be perceived only by an artist with extraordinary imagination.

对于不熟悉的人来说，这些流行作品中的科普兰和所谓的“严肃”科普兰几乎像是两位不同的作曲家。但事实并非如此，因为科普兰的声音不仅体现在流行音乐中，也体现在更为复杂的杰作中。他涉猎各种媒介：从歌曲、室内乐、合唱到戏剧、电影、歌剧和交响乐。

To the uninitiated it could almost seem as though the Copland of these popular works and the so-called “serious” Copland were two separate composers at work. Not so, for the same Copland sound that informs the popular music is present also in the more complicated masterworks. He has created in every medium: from songs, chamber music, and chorus to theater, film, opera, and symphony.

再次提醒大家，《聆听音乐的乐趣》出自一位历史上最伟大的作曲家之手。现在，请翻开这本书，你将明白自己是一位大师的荣幸之徒。如果你仔细研读目录，你将观察到一个复杂主题是如何一步步展开的。本书清晰地秉持着这样一个前提：你对音乐了解得越多，聆听音乐的乐趣就越大。聆听音乐的首要前提显而易见，甚至略显荒谬，然而，它却常常被忽略：作为一名积极的聆听者，全神贯注地聆听音乐。

With a reminder again that What to Listen for in Music has been written by one of the great composers of history, turn now to its pages, knowing you are the privileged student of a master. If you will study the Table of Contents, you will observe the gradual unfolding of a complicated subject in stepby-step fashion. The book is clearly based on the premise that the more you know about the subject of music, the greater will be your joy in listening to it. The first prerequisite for listening to music is so obvious that it almost seems ludicrous to mention, yet it is often the single element that is absent: to pay attention and to give the music your concentrated effort as an active listener.

将剧院观众的行为与交响乐观众的行为进行比较是很有启发性的。在剧院里，观众全神贯注地聆听戏剧的每一句台词，他们知道如果错过重要的台词，理解就会受到影响——而这种本能的注意力在音乐厅里往往是缺乏的。只要观察一下音乐会上的听众，就能发现他们因为说话、阅读或只是发呆而分心。只有一小部分人真正关心积极倾听的重要作用。这种缺乏是严重的，因为听众对于音乐的过程至关重要；毕竟，音乐是由作曲家、演奏者和听众组成的。这三个要素都应该以最理想的方式呈现。我们期待优秀的作品能被精彩地演奏出来，但我们有多少次想到它也应该被精彩地聆听呢？

It is revealing to compare the actions of theater audiences to those of symphonic audiences. In the theater the audience listens with full attention to every line of the play, knowing that if important lines are missed understanding can be diminished—this instinctive attention is too often lacking in the concert hall. One has but to observe listeners at a concert to witness the distractions of talking or reading or simply staring into space. Only a small percentage is vitally concerned with the essential role of active listening. This lack is serious because the listener is essential to the process of music; music after all consists of the composer, the performer, and the listener. Each of these three elements should be present in the most ideal way. We expect a fine composition brilliantly performed, but how often do we think that it should also be brilliantly heard?

一首乐曲的命运，虽然基本上掌握在作曲家和演奏家手中，但也取决于听众的态度和能力。从更广义上讲，听众决定了人们最终是接受还是拒绝这部作品和这位演奏家。音乐家们从经验中深知，同一首乐曲由同一名演奏家演奏，不同的听众对它的感受可能会有很大差异。换句话说，音乐的感知质量显然取决于听众的实际素质。不幸的是，许多听众满足于沉浸在情感的漩涡中，将他们对音乐的反应局限于被声音包围的感官体验。但声音是有组织的；这些声音既有理智的吸引力，也有情感的吸引力。

The destiny of a piece of music, while basically in the hands of the composer and performer, also depends on the attitude and ability of the listener. It is the listener in the larger sense who dictates the ultimate acceptance or rejection of the composition and performer. Musicians know full well from experience that the same music with the same performers can be received with drastic differences by varying audiences. In other words, the perceived quality of music is clearly at the mercy of the actual quality of its auditors. Unfortunately for music, many listeners are content to sit in an emotional bath and limit their reaction to music to the sensuous element of being surrounded by sounds. But the sounds are organized; the sounds have intellectual as well as emotional appeal.

学习如何聆听音乐的冒险之旅是接触这门艺术的一大乐趣。聆听是一门可以传授的学科，本书梳理并阐明了聆听音乐的方法。独自阅读本书并不能让你一夜之间成为聆听大师，但它可以引领你踏上这条道路。你努力去理解正在发生的事情，最终会获得千倍的回报，你将体验到强烈的愉悦感和日益增长的兴趣。

The adventure of learning how to listen to music is one of the great joys of exposure to this art. Listening is a subject that can be taught and this book organizes and clarifies approaches to this subject. Reading the book unaided will not suddenly make you a virtuoso listener, but it can set you on the path. Your efforts to understand more of what is taking place will be rewarded a thousand-fold in the intense pleasure and increased interest you will find.

当然，很多音乐无需特别关注即可欣赏。音乐能满足各种各样的胃口，将其与精心策划的菜单进行比较便可说明这一点。毕竟，开胃菜是为了挑逗，主菜是为了滋养，而甜点则是令人愉悦的餐后小食，让人心旷神怡。如果你研究一下交响乐团的节目单，就会发现这条原则普遍存在，也就是说，序曲、交响曲，以及与之形成对比的轻松结尾。有时，音乐盛宴完全是主菜。有时，比如在特别的“流行”音乐会上，它主要是开胃菜和甜点。但需要指出的是，每首音乐作品的性质决定了它的目的，而隐含目的的实现表明了作曲家、演奏者和听众的成败。

There is much music of course that requires no special attention for enjoyment. Music serves a wide gamut of appetites, and comparisons to a well-planned menu illustrate the point. An appetizer, after all, is meant to titillate, a principal course is meant to nourish, and a dessert is meant as a pleasant afterthought to send people on their way. If you examine the programs of symphony orchestras you will find that in general this principle abounds, that is to say, the overture, the symphony, and the contrasting lighter ending. Sometimes the musical meal is all of the main-course variety. Sometimes, as in special “pops” concerts, it is mostly appetizers and desserts. But the point to be made is that the nature of each piece of music defines its purpose, and the realization of the implied purpose indicates the success or failure of the composition, performer, and listener.

我们的音乐开胃菜和甜点，并不需要聆听沉重而复杂的音乐所需的特殊理解。这绝不会贬低“轻”音乐的价值。毕竟，音乐本身并不存在不可接受的类型——只是每种音乐内部存在着优劣不一的品质差异。在当今时代，人们如此热衷于讨论各种音乐的同等价值，强调这些区别尤为重要。

Our musical appetizers and desserts do not require the special understanding necessary for listening to music of great weight and complication. This in no way diminishes the worth of “light” music. There is after all no such thing as an unacceptable kind of music—only varying qualitative examples from good to bad within each kind. These distinctions are especially important to emphasize at a time in history when there is so much talk about the equal worth of all kinds of music.

流行音乐有着特殊的目的：娱乐大众，同时又要求听众付出最少的努力。试图将流行音乐的价值与所谓的严肃音乐进行比较，毫无意义。回到食物的类比，我们营养的主要来源并不否定其周围的浮华。尊重各种音乐，不进行不合逻辑的比较，就是享受音乐，因为我们的天性决定了不同音乐作品的不同魅力。我们从阅读小说、诗歌和最深刻的哲学著作中获得乐趣和灵感，同时，我们也从阅读一本引人入胜的杂志中获得放松的乐趣。

Popular music has a special purpose: to entertain while demanding the least amount of effort on the part of those exposed. To attempt to compare the worth of popular music with that of so-called serious music is a non-issue. Getting back to our food analogy, the prime sources of our nourishment do not invalidate the frills that surround them. To honor all kinds of music without false claims of illogical comparisons is to enjoy as our natures dictate the varying appeals of diverse efforts. We take pleasure and inspiration in reading novels, poetry, and philosophy of the most profound nature, while at the same time derive pleasure in relaxing with an attractive magazine.

以上并非暗示音乐与垃圾食品的对应物有害健康，而是暗示局限于一种艺术的饮食方式会限制你的健康。这本书应该能帮助那些对更复杂音乐形式感兴趣的听众。毋庸置疑：伟大的音乐源于伟大而专注的头脑和极其虔诚的听众的辛勤付出。聆听这类音乐的人，相对于那些清醒时被如同我们呼吸的空气般无处不在的声音所充斥的人们来说，只是微不足道的比例。

The above is not to imply that the musical counterpart of junk food is bad for your health, but rather that a diet restricted to one kind of art is limiting. This book should help listeners who have a curiosity about more complicated forms of music. And make no mistake about it: great music is born of great effort by great and dedicated minds and by greatly devoted listeners. The number of people who listen to music of this character are but an insignificant percentage of those whose waking hours are saturated with sounds as omnipresent as the air we breathe.

科普兰的书归根结底是一本宣传之书。这本书的作者是一位致力于传播福音的人，在如今我们不那么刻意的时代，我们称之为“好音乐”。这本书是一份邀请，你最好接受。

Copland’s book in the final analysis is a book of propaganda. It is a book written by a man deeply committed to spreading the Gospel of what in less self-conscious days we could refer to as “good music.” The book is an invitation, and one that you would do well to accept.

 

 

——威廉·舒曼，

纽约市

，1988年

—William Schuman

New York City

1988

1957 年版作者注

Authorʹs Note for the 1957 Edition

自1939年本书第一版发行以来，已过去近二十年。我很高兴得知，自那时起，它一直受到美国国内外音乐听众的喜爱。1

Almost twenty years have passed since the first edition of this book was issued in 1939. It is naturally gratifying to me to know that it has continued to be found useful by music listeners since that time, both in America and abroad.1

过去二十年，我们见证了世界各地对各种音乐形式的兴趣空前高涨。音乐聆听的数量和质量都发生了变化，但幸运的是，作者认为“听什么”这个基本问题基本保持不变。因此，正文只需要进行一些细微的修改。

During the past two decades we have witnessed an unprecedented spread of interest in all forms of music throughout the world. Both the quantity and quality of music listening have changed, but fortunately for the author, the basic problems of “what to listen for” have remained about the same. For that reason, only minor corrections were needed in the body of the text.

增加了两个新章节——一个是关于如何聆听当今音乐作品这个棘手的问题，另一个则考虑了电影配乐这个相对较新的领域及其与电影观众的关系。鉴于我在第一版前言中最初的说法，当代音乐作品本身并不存在特殊的聆听问题，因此增加的第一个章节需要解释一下。在我看来，这仍然是事实。然而，同样真实的是，在所谓的现代音乐诞生 50 年后，仍然有成千上万的好心音乐爱好者认为它听起来很奇怪。似乎值得再试一次，看看我是否能阐明其他章节未涉及的一些新音乐聆听方面的问题。这两个新章节都基于最初为《纽约时报杂志》撰写的文章。我非常感谢编辑允许我改写该杂志最初刊登的一些材料。

Two new chapters have been added—one on the thorny question of how present-day composition should be listened to, the other considering the comparatively new province of film scoring and its relation to the movie-goer. The first of these added sections needs a word of explanation in view of my original claim, in the Preface to the first edition, that contemporary composition posed no special listening problems of its own. This still seems to me to be true. Nevertheless, it is equally true that after fifty years of so-called modern music there are still thousands of well-intentioned music lovers who think it sounds peculiar. It seemed worth an extra try to see if I could elucidate some few facets of new music listening that do not come within the scope of other chapters. Both new sections are based on articles originally prepared for The New York Times Magazine. My thanks are due the editors for permission to recast some of the material originally printed there.

本书的最后列出了文中提到的作品的录音（并有少量补充）。对于有兴趣进一步阅读的读者，本书还添加了简短的参考书目，其中包括作曲家兼作家的书籍特别列表。列出这些书目是希望听众能够亲耳聆听作曲家的独到见解。

At the back of the book a list of recordings of works mentioned in the text (with a few additions) will be found. For those interested in further reading, a short bibliography has been added, including a special listing of books by composer-authors. These were set down in the hope that listeners would want to hear composers speak for themselves.

 

 

—亚伦·科普兰

克罗顿维尔，纽约

—Aaron Copland

Crotonville, New York

前言

Preface

本书旨在尽可能清晰地阐述理性聆听音乐的基本原则。“解释”音乐并非易事，我不敢自夸自己比其他人做得更好。但大多数音乐欣赏作家都是从教育者或音乐评论家的角度来探讨这个问题。这是一本作曲家的书。

To put down as clearly as possible the fundamentals of intelligent music listening is the object of this book. The job of “explaining” music is no easy one, and I cannot flatter myself that I have succeeded better than others. But most writers on music appreciation approach the problem from the standpoint of the educator or the music critic. This is a composerʹs book.

对作曲家来说，聆听音乐是一个极其自然而简单的过程。对其他人来说也应该如此。如果需要解释的话，作曲家自然会认为，既然他知道音乐作品的构成，那么没有人比他更有资格评判听众应该从中获得什么。

To a composer, listening to music is a perfectly natural and simple process. That’s what it should be for others. If there is any explaining to be done, the composer naturally thinks that, since he knows what goes into a musical composition, none has a better right to say what the listener ought to get from it.

作曲家或许错了。或许，富有创造力的艺术家在对待音乐方面无法像更客观的教育家那样客观。但在我看来，这种风险值得冒。因为作曲家面临着至关重要的利害关系。在帮助他人更明智地聆听音乐的过程中，他致力于传播一种音乐文化，而这最终将影响人们对他自己作品的理解。

Perhaps the composer is wrong about that. Perhaps the creative artist cannot be so objective in his approach to music as the more detached educator. But it seems to me that the risk is worth taking. For the composer has something vital at stake. In helping others to hear music more intelligently, he is working toward the spread of a musical culture, which in the end will affect the understanding of his own creations.

问题依然存在：该如何着手？专业作曲家如何打破自身与普通听众之间的隔阂？作曲家该如何表达，才能让音乐更完整地成为听众自己的音乐？本书旨在解答这些问题。

Still the question remains, how to go about it? How can the professional composer break down the barrier between himself and the lay listener? What can the composer say to make music more completely the listener’s own? This book is an attempt to answer these questions.

如果有机会，每个作曲家都想知道关于任何一个认真对待音乐爱好者的人的两件非常重要的事情。他想知道这两件事：

Given the chance, every composer would like to know two very important things about anyone who takes himself seriously as a music lover. He would like to know these two things:

1. 你听到正在发生的一切吗？

1. Are you hearing everything that is going on?

2. 你真的对此很敏感吗？

2. Are you really being sensitive to it?

或者，换句话说：

Or, to put it differently:

1. 就笔记本身而言，您是否遗漏了什么？

1. Are you missing anything as far as the notes themselves are concerned?

2. 您的反应是困惑的吗？还是您对自己的情绪反应相当清楚？

2. Is your reaction a confused one, or are you quite clarified as to your emotional response?

无论是什么音乐，这些问题都切中要害。它们同样适用于帕莱斯特里纳弥撒曲、巴厘岛甘美兰、查韦斯奏鸣曲或第五交响曲。事实上，每当作曲家面对陌生的音乐，无论新旧，他都会或多或少有意识地自问这些问题。毕竟，作曲家的音乐直觉并非一成不变。他与普通听众的主要区别在于，作曲家更善于聆听。

Those are very pertinent questions, no matter what the music may be. They apply equally well to a Palestrina Mass, a Balinese gamelan, a Chávez sonatina, or the Fifth Symphony. In fact, they are the very same questions that the composer puts to himself, more or less consciously, whenever he is confronted with unfamiliar music, old or new. For, after all, there is nothing infallible about a composerʹs musical instincts. The main difference between him and the lay listener is that he is better prepared to listen.

那么，这本书就是为听力做准备的。

This book, then, is a preparation for listening.

任何一位名副其实的作曲家都不会满足于让你只听过去的音乐。正因如此，我努力将我提到的每一个观点不仅应用于已成名的杰作，也应用于当代人的音乐。我经常观察到，真正的音乐爱好者的标志是渴望熟悉这门艺术的每一种表现形式，无论古今。真正的音乐爱好者不愿将他们的音乐享受局限于过度雕琢的“三个B”时期。另一方面，读者或许会认为，只要他对公认的经典作品有了更深入的理解，就已经足够了。但我相信，聆听亨德尔赋格曲的“问题”与聆听欣德米特的类似作品本质上并无二致。撇开相对优劣的问题不谈，两者在演奏过程中确实存在着某种相似之处，忽视这一点将是愚蠢的。鉴于我必然会在这类书中讨论赋格曲，读者既可以在新作品中看到赋格曲形式的例子，也可以在旧作品中看到赋格曲形式的例子。

No composer worthy of the name would be content to prepare you to listen only to music of the past. That is why I have tried to apply every point made not only to established master works but also to the music of living men. I have often observed that the mark of a real music lover was an imperious desire to become familiar with every manifestation of the art, ancient and modern. Real lovers of music are unwilling to have their musical enjoyment confined to the overworked period of the three B’s. The reader, on the other hand, may think that he has accomplished enough if he has been led to a richer understanding of the accepted classics. But it is my belief that the “problem” of listening to a fugue by Handel is essentially no different from that of listening to a similar work by Hindemith. There is a definite similarity of procedure which it would be foolish to ignore, quite aside from the question of relative merit. Inasmuch as I am bound to discuss fugues in a book of this kind, the reader might just as well see the fugue form exemplified in a new work as in an old one.

遗憾的是，无论音乐是古老还是新潮，总有一些技术细节需要解释。否则，读者就无法理解更高级的音乐形式的解释。在每一个例子中，我都尽力将技术细节保持在最低限度。在我看来，听众对音调的敏感度始终比了解产生音调的振动次数更重要。即使对作曲家本人来说，这类信息的价值也有限。他最希望的是鼓励你尽可能地成为一个完全自觉、完全清醒的听众。理解音乐问题的核心就在于此。它并不比这更难。

Unfortunately, whether the music is old or new, a certain number of technicalities have to be explained. Otherwise the reader cannot hope to grasp explanations of the higher musical forms. In every instance I have made an effort to keep technicalities to a minimum. It has always seemed to me more important for the listener to be sensitive to the musical tone than to know the number of vibrations that produce the tone. Information of that kind is of limited value even to the composer himself. What he desires above all is to encourage you to become as completely conscious and wide awake a listener as can possibly be developed. There lies the kernel of the problem of understanding music. It is no more difficult than that.

虽然这本书主要面向普通读者，但我希望音乐学生也能从中受益。典型的音乐学院学生专注于完善自己正在学习的特定曲目，往往会忽略音乐艺术的整体性。这本书或许可以起到一定的作用，尤其是在后面关于基本形式的章节中，将学生经常习得的那些松散的泛泛而谈的知识进行梳理。

Though the book was written primarily with the layman in mind, it is my hope that music students may also profit by reading it. In their concentration on perfecting themselves in the particular piece they happen to be studying, typical conservatory students tend to lose sight of the art of music as a whole. This book may serve, perhaps, especially in the later chapters on fundamental forms, to crystallize the loose general knowledge the student often acquires.

提供令人满意的音乐范例这一长期难题至今仍未找到解决方案。文中提到的每首乐曲均已录制，因此读者可以聆听。为了方便阅读乐谱的读者快速参考，文中附有适量的音乐插图。或许有一天，我们能找到完美的方法来阐释书中关于音乐的论述。在此之前，那些不幸的门外汉将不得不接受我关于简单信仰的一些观察。

No solution has been found for the perennial problem of supplying satisfactory musical examples. Every piece of music mentioned in the text has been recorded and therefore may be heard by the reader. For the benefit of quick reference by those who read notes, a moderate number of musical illustrations have been printed in the text. Some day the perfect method for illustrating a book’s statement about music may be discovered. Until then, the unfortunate layman will have to accept a number of my observations on simple faith.

致谢

Acknowledgments

《在音乐中聆听什么》是作者在 1936 年和 1937 年冬天在纽约社会研究新学院举办的十五场讲座的课程名称。我要感谢新学院院长阿尔文·约翰逊博士，他提供了公共论坛，激发了本书的写作。

What to listen for in music was the title of a course of fifteen lectures given by the author at the New School for Social Research in New York City during the winters of 1936 and 1937. Dr. Alvin Johnson, director of the New School, deserves my thanks for providing the public forum which stimulated the writing of this book.

这些讲座是为普通听众和音乐学生设计的，并非面向专业音乐家。因此，本书的讨论范围也相应有限。我的目的并非包罗万象地讨论一个很容易泛泛而谈的话题，而是将讨论限制在我认为至关重要的听力问题上。

The talks were designed for the layman and music student, not for the professional musician. The present volume, therefore, is correspondingly limited in scope. My purpose was not to be all-inclusive on a subject that might very easily spread itself but to confine the discussion to what seemed to me to be essential listening problems.

艾略特·卡特先生阅读了手稿，我非常感谢他提出的宝贵建议和友好的批评。

The manuscript was read by Mr. Elliott Carter, to whom I am indebted for valuable suggestions and friendly criticisms.

1

1

准备工作

Preliminaries

所有关于理解音乐的书籍都同意一点：你不可能只通过阅读相关书籍来更好地欣赏这门艺术。如果你想更好地理解音乐，没有什么比聆听音乐更重要。没有什么可以取代聆听音乐。我在本书中所说的一切都是你只能在本书之外获得的体验。因此，除非你下定决心比过去听更多的音乐，否则你阅读这本书可能会浪费时间。我们所有人，无论专业与否，都在永远努力加深对艺术的理解。读书有时可能会对我们有所帮助。但没有什么可以取代首要考虑——聆听音乐本身。

All books on understanding music are agreed about one point: You can’t develop a better appreciation of the art merely by reading a book about it. If you want to understand music better, you can do nothing more important than listen to it. Nothing can possibly take the place of listening to music. Everything that I have to say in this book is said about an experience that you can only get outside this book. Therefore, you will probably be wasting your time in reading it unless you make a firm resolve to hear a great deal more music than you have in the past. All of us, professionals and nonprofessionals, are forever trying to deepen our understanding of the art. Reading a book may sometimes help us. But nothing can replace the prime consideration—listening to music itself.

幸运的是，如今聆听音乐的机会比以往任何时候都多得多。随着广播、留声机，更不用说电视和电影中越来越多地播放着好音乐，几乎每个人都有机会聆听音乐。事实上，正如我一位朋友最近所说，如今每个人都有机会听不懂音乐。

Luckily, opportunities for hearing music are much greater than they ever were before. With the increasing availability of good music on radio and phonograph, not to mention television and the movies, almost anybody has the chance to listen to music. In fact, as a friend of mine recently said, nowadays everybody has the chance not to understand music.

我常常觉得，人们倾向于夸大正确理解音乐的难度。我们音乐家经常会遇到一些诚实的人，他们总是以这样或那样的方式说：“我非常喜欢音乐，但我对音乐一窍不通。” 我的剧作家和小说家朋友很少听到有人说：“我对戏剧或小说一窍不通。” 然而，我强烈怀疑，那些对音乐如此谦虚的人，同样有理由对其他艺术保持谦虚。或者，更委婉地说，他们同样没有理由对自己对音乐的理解保持谦虚。如果你对自己的音乐反应有任何自卑感，请试着摆脱它们。它们往往是没有道理的。

It has often seemed to me that there is a tendency to exaggerate the difficulty of properly understanding music. We musicians are constantly meeting some honest soul who invariably says, in one form or another: “I love music very much, but I don’t understand anything about it.” My playwright and novelist friends rarely hear anyone say, “I don’t understand anything about the theater or the novel.” Yet I strongly suspect that those very same people, so modest about music, have just as much reason to be modest about the other arts. Or, to put it more graciously, have just as little reason to be modest about their understanding of music. If you have any feelings of inferiority about your musical reactions, try to rid yourself of them. They are often not justified.

无论如何，在你真正理解“拥有音乐天赋”的含义之前，你没有理由对自己的音乐才能感到沮丧。关于“拥有音乐天赋”的含义，有很多奇怪的流行观念。人们总是被告知，他或她可以“去看一场演出，然后回家就能用钢琴弹奏出所有曲子”，以此作为拥有音乐天赋的无可辩驳的证据。仅凭这一点就能说明一个人具有一定的音乐天赋，但并不能表明他对音乐的敏感度，而这正是本文要考察的。模仿能力强的艺人还不能算作演员，而音乐模仿者也不一定具有深厚的音乐天赋。每当人们谈到拥有音乐天赋时，另一个被提及的特质就是拥有绝对音感。能够识别出A音有时可能会有所帮助，但这本身并不能证明你是一个拥有音乐天赋的人。它不应该被理解为表示一种油嘴滑舌的音乐性，而对于我们这里所关注的真正音乐理解来说，它的意义是有限的。

At any rate, you have no reason to be downcast about your musical capacities until you have some idea of what it means to be musical. There are many strange popular notions as to what “being musical” consists of. One is always being told, as the unarguable proof of a musical person, that he or she can “go to a show and then come home and play all the tunes on the piano.” That fact alone bespeaks a certain musicality in the person in question, but it does not indicate the kind of sensitivity to music that is under examination here. The entertainer who mimics well is not yet an actor, and the musical mimic is not necessarily a profoundly musical individual. Another attribute which is trotted forth whenever the question of being musical arises is that of having absolute pitch. To be able to recognize the note A when you hear it may, at times, be helpful, but it certainly does not prove, taken by itself, that you are a musical person. It should not be taken to indicate anything more than a glib musicality which has only a limited significance in relationship to the real understanding of music which concerns us here.

然而，对于有潜在智慧的听众来说，有一个最低要求。他必须能够在听到旋律时识别它。如果真有五音不全这种说法，那就意味着无法识别曲调。我很同情这样的人，但他无能为力；就像色盲对画家来说毫无用处一样。2但如果你自信能够识别出某个特定的旋律——不是唱出旋律，而是在演奏时识别它，即使间隔几分钟，即使其他不同的旋律也已经响起——那么更深层次欣赏音乐的钥匙就掌握在你手中了。

There is, however, one minimum requirement for the potentially intelligent listener. He must be able to recognize a melody when he hears it. If there is such a thing as being tone-deaf, then it suggests the inability to recognize a tune. Such a person has my sympathy, but he cannot be helped; just as the color-blind are a useless lot to the painter.2 But if you feel confident that you can recognize a given melody—not sing a melody, but recognize it when played, even after an interval of a few minutes and after other and different melodies have been sounded—the key to a deeper appreciation of music is in your hands.

仅仅从音乐发生的不同时刻来聆听是不够的。你必须能够将你在任何特定时刻听到的内容与之前刚刚发生的事情以及之后即将发生的事情联系起来。换句话说，音乐是一种存在于时间点的艺术。从这个意义上说，它就像一本小说，只不过小说中的情节更容易记住，部分原因是真实事件被叙述出来，部分原因是人们可以回溯并刷新记忆。音乐“事件”本质上更抽象，因此在想象中将它们串联起来并不像阅读小说那么容易。这就是为什么你必须能够识别曲调。因为在音乐中，取代故事的通常是旋律。旋律通常是引导听众的。如果你无法在旋律初现时就识别它，也无法追随它的轨迹直到它最终出现，我不明白你聆听音乐还有什么意义。你只是模糊地意识到了音乐的存在。但识别出一个曲调意味着你知道自己在音乐中处于什么位置，并且很有可能知道自己接下来要做什么。这是更智能地理解音乐的唯一必要条件。

It is insufficient merely to hear music in terms of the separate moments at which it exists. You must be able to relate what you hear at any given moment to what has just happened before and what is about to come afterward. In other words, music is an art that exists in point of time. In that sense it is like a novel, except that the events of a novel are easier to keep in mind, partly because real happenings are narrated and partly because one can turn back and refresh one’s memory of them. Musical “events” are more abstract by nature, so that the act of pulling them all together in the imagination is not so easy as in reading a novel. That is why it is necessary for you to be able to recognize a tune. For the thing that takes the place of a story in music is, as a rule, the melody. The melody is generally what guides the listener. If you can’t recognize a melody on its first appearance and can’t follow its peregrinations straight through to its final appearance, I fail to see what you have to go on in listening. You are just vaguely being aware of the music. But recognizing a tune means you know where you are in the music and have a good chance of knowing where you’re going. It is the only sine qua non of a more intelligent approach to understanding music.

某些学派倾向于强调听众拥有一些实际的音乐体验的价值。他们实际上声称，用一根手指弹奏老黑乔的钢琴曲，比阅读十几卷书更能让你更接近音乐的奥秘。当然，弹一会儿钢琴，甚至弹得还不错，也无妨。但作为音乐入门，我对此持怀疑态度，仅仅因为许多钢琴家毕生致力于演奏伟大的作品，但他们对音乐的理解总体上却相当薄弱。至于那些普及音乐的人，他们一开始会附上华丽的故事和描述性的标题来让音乐更容易理解，最后却在名曲的主题上加上打油诗——他们为听众的问题提供的“解决方案”实在令人不齿。

Certain schools of thought are inclined to stress the value for the listener of some practical experience of music. They say, in effect, play Old Black Joe on the piano with one finger and it will get you closer to the mysteries of music than reading a dozen volumes. No harm can come, certainly, from pecking the piano a bit or even from playing it moderately well. But as an introduction to music I am suspicious of it, if only because of the many pianists who spend their lives playing great works, yet whose understanding of music is, on the whole, rather weak. As for the popularizers, who first began by attaching flowery stories and descriptive titles to make music easier and ended by adding doggerel to themes from famous compositions—their “solution” for the listenerʹs problems is beneath contempt.

没有作曲家相信欣赏音乐有什么捷径。作曲家唯一能为听众做的，就是指出音乐本身究竟存在什么，并合理地解释其缘由。剩下的事，就交给听众自己去做吧。

No composer believes that there are any short cuts to the better appreciation of music. The only thing that one can do for the listener is to point out what actually exists in the music itself and reasonably to explain the wherefore and the why of the matter. The listener must do the rest.

2

2

我们如何聆听

How We Listen

我们每个人聆听音乐的能力各不相同。但为了分析起见，如果我们将整个聆听过程分解成各个组成部分，或许会更加清晰。从某种意义上说，我们都是在三个独立的层面上聆听音乐。由于缺乏更好的术语，我们不妨将其命名为：(1) 感官层面，(2) 表达层面，(3) 纯粹的音乐层面。将聆听过程机械地分解成这些假设层面，唯一的好处是能够更清晰地了解我们的聆听方式。

We all listen to music according to our separate capacities. But, for the sake of analysis, the whole listening process may become clearer if we break it up into its component parts, so to speak. In a certain sense we all listen to music on three separate planes. For lack of a better terminology, one might name these: (1) the sensuous plane, (2) the expressive plane, (3) the sheerly musical plane. The only advantage to be gained from mechanically splitting up the listening process into these hypothetical planes is the clearer view to be had of the way in which we listen.

聆听音乐最简单的方式，就是纯粹地享受音乐本身带来的愉悦。这就是感官层面。在这个层面上，我们聆听音乐时无需思考，无需任何考量。我们一边做着其他事情，一边打开收音机，心不在焉地沉浸在音乐之中。纯粹的音乐魅力，便能带来一种无需思考却又令人心旷神怡的境界。

The simplest way of listening to music is to listen for the sheer pleasure of the musical sound itself. That is the sensuous plane. It is the plane on which we hear music without thinking, without considering it in any way. One turns on the radio while doing something else and absentmindedly bathes in the sound. A kind of brainless but attractive state of mind is engendered by the mere sound appeal of the music.

你可能正坐在房间里读这本书。想象一下，钢琴上突然响起一个音符。这一个音符足以瞬间改变房间的氛围——这证明了音乐中的声音元素是一种强大而神秘的媒介，嘲笑或轻视它是愚蠢的。

You may be sitting in a room reading this book. Imagine one note struck on the piano. Immediately that one note is enough to change the atmosphere of the room—proving that the sound element in music is a powerful and mysterious agent, which it would be foolish to deride or belittle.

令人惊讶的是，许多自认为合格音乐爱好者的人，却在聆听音乐时滥用了这一层面。他们去听音乐会是为了忘却自我。他们把音乐当作一种慰藉或逃避。他们进入了一个理想世界，在那里，人们无需思考日常生活的现实。当然，他们也不会思考音乐本身。音乐让他们抛开现实，去往一个梦想之地，梦想因音乐而起，与音乐相关，却从未真正聆听过音乐。

The surprising thing is that many people who consider themselves qualified music lovers abuse that plane in listening. They go to concerts in order to lose themselves. They use music as a consolation or an escape. They enter an ideal world where one doesn’t have to think of the realities of everyday life. Of course they aren’t thinking about the music either. Music allows them to leave it, and they go off to a place to dream, dreaming because of and apropos of the music yet never quite listening to it.

是的，音乐的声音感染力是一种强大而原始的力量，但你绝不能让它过度地夺走你的兴趣。感官层面在音乐中很重要，非常重要，但它并非音乐的全部。

Yes, the sound appeal of music is a potent and primitive force, but you must not allow it to usurp a disproportionate share of your interest. The sensuous plane is an important one in music, a very important one, but it does not constitute the whole story.

无需再就感官层面进行更离题的讨论。它对每个正常人的吸引力是不言而喻的。然而，对不同作曲家所使用的不同类型的声音素材变得更加敏感是有可能的。因为所有作曲家使用声音素材的方式并不相同。不要以为音乐的价值与其感官吸引力成正比，也不要以为最优美的音乐出自最伟大的作曲家之手。如果真是这样，拉威尔将比贝多芬更伟大。关键在于，每个作曲家的声音元素各不相同，他对声音的运用构成了其风格不可或缺的一部分，在聆听时必须加以考虑。因此，读者可以看到，即使在音乐聆听的这个主要层面上，更有意识的方法也是有价值的。

There is no need to digress further on the sensuous plane. Its appeal to every normal human being is self-evident. There is, however, such a thing as becoming more sensitive to the different kinds of sound stuff as used by various composers. For all composers do not use that sound stuff in the same way. Don’t get the idea that the value of music is commensurate with its sensuous appeal or that the loveliest-sounding music is made by the greatest composer. If that were so, Ravel would be a greater creator than Beethoven. The point is that the sound element varies with each composer, that his usage of sound forms an integral part of his style and must be taken into account when listening. The reader can see, therefore, that a more conscious approach is valuable even on this primary plane of music listening.

音乐存在的第二个层面是我所说的表现层面。在这里，我们立即触及了争议的领域。作曲家们总是回避任何关于音乐表现力方面的讨论。斯特拉文斯基本人不是宣称他的音乐是一个“物体”，一个“事物”，它有自己的生命，除了其纯粹的音乐存在之外没有其他意义吗？斯特拉文斯基这种固执的态度或许源于许多人试图从众多作品中解读出不同的含义。天知道，要准确地说出一段音乐的意义，要明确地说出来，要最终说出来让每个人都满意，这已经够难的了。但这不应该导致人们走向另一个极端，否认音乐“表现力”的权利。

The second plane on which music exists is what I have called the expressive one. Here, immediately, we tread on controversial ground. Composers have a way of shying away from any discussion of music’s expressive side. Did not Stravinsky himself proclaim that his music was an “object,” a “thing,” with a life of its own, and with no other meaning than its own purely musical existence? This intransigent attitude of Stravinsky’s may be due to the fact that so many people have tried to read different meanings into so many pieces. Heaven knows it is difficult enough to say precisely what it is that a piece of music means, to say it definitely, to say it finally so that everyone is satisfied with your explanation. But that should not lead one to the other extreme of denying to music the right to be “expressive.”

我个人认为，所有音乐都具有表现力，只是程度不同，但所有音乐的音符背后都蕴含着某种意义，而这些意义最终构成了乐曲所要表达的内容，以及乐曲所要探讨的内容。这个问题可以简单地概括为：“音乐有意义吗？”我的答案是：“是的。”而“你能用这么多词语来表达它的意义吗？”我的答案是：“不能。”难点就在这里。

My own belief is that all music has an expressive power, some more and some less, but that all music has a certain meaning behind the notes and that the meaning behind the notes constitutes, after all, what the piece is saying, what the piece is about. This whole problem can be stated quite simply by asking, “Is there a meaning to music?” My answer to that would be, “Yes.” And “Can you state in so many words what the meaning is?” My answer to that would be, “No.” Therein lies the difficulty.

头脑简单的人永远不会满足于第二个问题的答案。他们总是希望音乐有意义，而且越具体，他们就越喜欢。音乐越让他们联想到火车、暴风雨、葬礼，或者任何其他熟悉的概念，就越能让他们觉得它富有表现力。这种关于音乐意义的流行观念——受到常见的音乐评论家的煽动和鼓吹——无论何时何地都应该予以制止。一位胆怯的女士曾向我坦白，她怀疑自己在音乐欣赏方面存在严重缺陷，因为她无法将音乐与任何明确的东西联系起来。当然，这完全是本末倒置。

Simple-minded souls will never be satisfied with the answer to the second of these questions. They always want music to have a meaning, and the more concrete it is the better they like it. The more the music reminds them of a train, a storm, a funeral, or any other familiar conception the more expressive it appears to be to them. This popular idea of music’s meaning—stimulated and abetted by the usual run of musical commentator—should be discouraged wherever and whenever it is met. One timid lady once confessed to me that she suspected something seriously lacking in her appreciation of music because of her inability to connect it with anything definite. That is getting the whole thing backward, of course.

然而，问题依然存在：一个聪明的音乐爱好者应该在多大程度上能够为任何一部特定的作品赋予一个明确的含义呢？我想说，它不比一个笼统的概念更接近。音乐在不同的时刻表达着宁静或兴奋、遗憾或胜利、愤怒或喜悦。它以无数种微妙的差别和差异表达了这些以及其他许多情绪。它甚至可能表达一种任何语言中都没有合适词汇来表达的意义状态。在这种情况下，音乐家们常常喜欢说它只有纯粹的音乐意义。有时他们走得更远，说所有的音乐都只有纯粹的音乐意义。他们真正的意思是，找不到合适的词来表达音乐的意义，而且即使可以，他们也不觉得有必要去寻找。

Still, the question remains, How close should the intelligent music lover wish to come to pinning a definite meaning to any particular work? No closer than a general concept, I should say. Music expresses, at different moments, serenity or exuberance, regret or triumph, fury or delight. It expresses each of these moods, and many others, in a numberless variety of subtle shadings and differences. It may even express a state of meaning for which there exists no adequate word in any language. In that case, musicians often like to say that it has only a purely musical meaning. They sometimes go farther and say that all music has only a purely musical meaning. What they really mean is that no appropriate word can be found to express the music’s meaning and that, even if it could, they do not feel the need of finding it.

但无论专业音乐家持有何种观点，大多数音乐新手仍在寻找特定的词语来表达他们对音乐的反应。这就是为什么他们总是觉得柴可夫斯基比贝多芬更容易“理解”。首先，在柴可夫斯基的作品上找到一个有意义的词比在贝多芬的作品上更容易。容易得多。此外，对于这位俄罗斯作曲家来说，每次你回顾他的一部作品，它几乎总是在告诉你同样的东西，而对于贝多芬来说，你往往很难准确地说出他在说什么。任何音乐家都会告诉你，这就是为什么贝多芬是更伟大的作曲家。因为总是对你讲述同样东西的音乐必然会很快变得沉闷的音乐，而每次聆听意义都略有不同的音乐更有可能保持活力。

But whatever the professional musician may hold, most musical novices still search for specific words with which to pin down their musical reactions. That is why they always find Tschaikovsky easier to “understand” than Beethoven. In the first place, it is easier to pin a meaning-word on a Tschaikovsky piece than on a Beethoven one. Much easier. Moreover, with the Russian composer, every time you come back to a piece of his it almost always says the same thing to you, whereas with Beethoven it is often quite difficult to put your finger right on what he is saying. And any musician will tell you that that is why Beethoven is the greater composer. Because music which always says the same thing to you will necessarily soon become dull music, but music whose meaning is slightly different with each hearing has a greater chance of remaining alive.

如果可以的话，请听一听巴赫《平均律古钢琴》中的四十八个赋格主题。逐一聆听每个主题。你很快就会意识到每个主题都反映了一个不同的情感世界。你也很快会意识到，一个主题在你看来越美丽，就越难找到一个词来完全满意地描述它。是的，你当然会知道它是一个欢快的主题还是一个悲伤的主题。换句话说，你将能够在自己的脑海中围绕你的主题画出一个情感框架。现在更仔细地研究一下悲伤的主题。试着确定它的悲伤的确切性质。它是悲观的悲伤还是无奈的悲伤？它是宿命的悲伤还是微笑着的悲伤？

Listen, if you can, to the forty-eight fugue themes of Bach’s Well Tempered Clavichord. Listen to each theme, one after another. You will soon realize that each theme mirrors a different world of feeling. You will also soon realize that the more beautiful a theme seems to you the harder it is to find any word that will describe it to your complete satisfaction. Yes, you will certainly know whether it is a gay theme or a sad one. You will be able, in other words, in your own mind, to draw a frame of emotional feeling around your theme. Now study the sad one a little closer. Try to pin down the exact quality of its sadness. Is it pessimistically sad or resignedly sad; is it fatefully sad or smilingly sad?

假设你很幸运，能够用如此多的词语，准确描述你所选主题的含义，并让自己感到满意。但这仍然无法保证其他人也会感到满意，也无需如此。重要的是，每个人都要亲身感受一个主题，或者类似地，一整部音乐作品所蕴含的具体表现力。如果这是一部伟大的艺术作品，不要指望每次重温它，你都能获得完全相同的感受。

Let us suppose that you are fortunate and can describe to your own satisfaction in so many words the exact meaning of your chosen theme. There is still no guarantee that anyone else will be satisfied. Nor need they be. The important thing is that each one feel for himself the specific expressive quality of a theme or, similarly, an entire piece of music. And if it is a great work of art, don’t expect it to mean exactly the same thing to you each time you return to it.

当然，主题或乐曲不必只表达一种情感。以第九交响曲的第一个主要主题为例。它显然是由不同的元素构成的。它所表达的并不是单一的东西。然而，任何听到它的人都会立刻感受到力量，一种威力。这种力量并非仅仅因为主题演奏得响亮而产生。它是主题本身所固有的力量。主题非凡的力量和活力让听众觉得它做出了强有力的陈述。但千万不要试图把它归结为“生命的命运之锤”之类的话。问题就在这里。音乐家在恼怒中说，它除了音符本身之外什么也没有，而非专业人士却过于急于抓住任何能让他产生更接近音乐含义的错觉的解释不放。

Themes or pieces need not express only one emotion, of course. Take such a theme as the first main one of the Ninth Symphony, for example. It is clearly made up of different elements. It does not say only one thing. Yet anyone hearing it immediately gets a feeling of strength, a feeling of power. It isn’t a power that comes simply because the theme is played loudly. It is a power inherent in the theme itself. The extraordinary strength and vigor of the theme results in the listener’s receiving an impression that a forceful statement has been made. But one should never try to boil it down to “the fateful hammer of life,” etc. That is where the trouble begins. The musician, in his exasperation, says it means nothing but the notes themselves, whereas the nonprofessional is only too anxious to hang on to any explanation that gives him the illusion of getting closer to the music’s meaning.

现在，也许读者会更好地理解我所说的音乐确实具有表达意义，但我们无法用太多语言来表达这种意义的意思。

Now, perhaps, the reader will know better what I mean when I say that music does have an expressive meaning but that we cannot say in so many words what that meaning is.

音乐存在的第三个层面是纯粹的音乐层面。除了悦耳的音乐声响及其所赋予的富有表现力的感受之外，音乐还存在于音符本身及其操控之中。大多数听众对这第三个层面的认识不足。本书的主要任务就是帮助他们更好地理解这一层面上的音乐。

The third plane on which music exists is the sheerly musical plane.
