His type of harmony is generally referred to as “atonality,” to distinguish it from music of tonality.6 What was left was the series of twelve “equal” semitones of the chromatic scale. Schoenberg himself found this remainder somewhat anarchical in later years and began the construction of a new system for handling these twelve equal semitones which he named the twelve-tone system. I shall do no more than mention it, for an adequate explanation would take us too far afield.

德彪西虽然在和声方面不如勋伯格激进，但他先于勋伯格开启了旧体系的瓦解。德彪西是有史以来最有直觉的音乐家之一，也是我们这个时代第一位敢于让耳朵成为判断和声优劣的唯一评判者的作曲家。在德彪西的作品中，分析家发现了一些无法再用旧和声来解释的和弦。如果有人问德彪西为什么使用这样的和弦，我相信他会给出唯一可能的答案：“我喜欢这样！”就好像一位作曲家终于对自己的耳朵有了信心。我有点夸张了，因为毕竟作曲家从来不需要等着理论家告诉他们该做什么或不该做什么。恰恰相反，情况总是相反——理论家在作曲家本能地写下他的思维逻辑之后，才对其进行解释。

Debussy, though less radical harmonically than Schoenberg, preceded him in starting the breakdown of the old system. Debussy, one of the most instinctive musicians who ever lived, was the first composer of our time who dared to make his ear the sole judge of what was good harmonically. With Debussy, analysts found chords that could no longer be explained according to the old harmony. If one had asked Debussy why he used such chords, I am sure he would have given the only possible answer: “I like it that way!” It is as if one composer finally had confidence in his ear. I exaggerate a little, for, after all, composers have never had to wait for theoreticians to tell them what or what not to do. On the contrary, it has always been the other way about—theoreticians have explained the logic of the composer’s thought after he has instinctively put it down.

无论如何，德彪西的成就在于彻底扫除了所有先前的和声科学理论。他的作品开创了一个完全的和声自由时代，而这自此之后一直是无数听众的绊脚石。他们抱怨这种新音乐充满了“不和谐音”，而所有过去的音乐史都证明，和谐音与不和谐音之间必然存在着合理的融合。

At any rate, what Debussy accomplished was the sweeping aside of all previously held theories of harmonic science. His work inaugurated a period of complete harmonic freedom, which has been a stumbling block for innumerable listeners ever since. They complain that this new music is full of “dissonances” and that all past musical history proves that there must always be a sensible mixture of consonance and dissonance.

如果我们要消除这个绊脚石，那么关于协和音与不协和音的问题就值得用一段话来阐述。正如人们多次指出的那样，整个问题纯粹是一个相对问题。说协和音是悦耳的和弦，而不协和音是令人不悦耳的和弦，未免过于简单化了。因为，一个和弦对你来说，其不协和音的强弱取决于你所处的时代，取决于你的聆听经验，也取决于它是用铜管乐器演奏的极强音，还是用弦乐器演奏的极弱音。因此，不协和音只是相对的——相对于你、你的时代以及它在整部作品中所处的位置而言。这并不像某些评论家那样否认不协和音的存在，而只是说，协和音与不协和音的恰当融合，应该由作曲家自行判断。如果所有新音乐在你听来都是持续不断的不和谐音，那么可以肯定地说，你的聆听体验对于你这个时代的音乐来说是不够的——当我们意识到普通听众听到的新音乐与他听到的以前时代的音乐相比所占比例很小时，在大多数情况下这并不奇怪。

This question of consonance and dissonance deserves a paragraph to itself, if we are to remove the stumbling block. The whole problem, as has been pointed out many times, is a purely relative one. To say that a consonance is a pleasant-sounding chord, and a dissonance unpleasant, is making the case much too simple. For a chord is more or less dissonant to you according to the period in which you live, according to your listening experience, and according to whether the chord is played fortissimo in the brass instruments or caressed pianissimo in the strings. So that a dissonance is only relative—relative to you, your epoch, and the place that it holds in the piece as a whole. This does not deny the existence of dissonance, as some commentators seem to do, but merely that the proper mixture of consonance and dissonance is a matter to be left to the composer’s discretion. If all new music sounds continually and unrelievedly dissonant to you, then it is a safe guess that your listening experience is insufficient as regards music of your own time—which is not so strange in the majority of cases, when we realize the small proportion of new music heard by the average listener compared with what he hears of the music of former times.

第一次世界大战前引入了另一项重要的和声创新。起初，由于其同样具有革命性的声音，它被与无调性相混淆。但实际上，它与无调性完全相反，因为它重申了调性原则，并且是双重的。也就是说，它不满足于一种调性，它引入了同时发出两个或多个独立调性的想法。达律斯·米约有时最有效地运用这一方法，这种方法被称为“多调性”。一个明显的例子是米约关于巴西主题的作品之一《科尔科瓦多》，其中右手演奏 D 大调，左手演奏 G 大调。同样，如果你倾向于被新音乐的多调性所干扰，我们只能建议你聆听，直到它们像舒曼或肖邦的音乐一样熟悉为止。如果你这样做，你可能不会再喜欢这种音乐（因为不用说，并不是所有的复调音乐都是好音乐），但你将不再受到和声冲突产生的“不和谐音”的困扰。

One other important harmonic innovation was introduced before World War I. At first, it was confused with atonality because of its similarly revolutionary sound. But actually, it was the exact opposite of atonality, in that it reaffirmed the principle of tonality and reaffirmed it doubly. That is to say, not content with one tonality, it introduced the idea of sounding two or more separate tonalities simultaneously. This process, which Darius Milhaud has used most effectively at times, became known as “polytonality.” A clear example of it is to be found in Corcovado, one of Milhaud’s pieces on Brazilian themes, Saudades do Brazil, in which the right hand plays in the key of D major while the left hand essays G major. Here, again, if you are inclined to be disturbed by the polytonalities of new music, one can only advise you to listen until they become as familiar to you as the music of Schumann or Chopin. If you do that, you may not find the music any the more to your liking (for, needless to add, not all polytonal music is good music), but it will no longer be the “dissonances” produced by the clash of harmonies that disturb you.

二十世纪上半叶的和声革命如今已彻底终结。多调性和无调性都已成为当今音乐创作的常态。值得关注的一个意外发展是：二战结束后，人们对阿诺德·勋伯格十二音体系的兴趣再度高涨，尤其是在意大利、法国和瑞士等此前几乎未受其影响的国家。意大利作曲家路易吉·达拉皮科拉和瑞士作曲家弗兰克·马丁等作曲家毫不犹豫地从十二音体系中提取调性内涵，从而消除了其部分全色的刺耳之处。年轻作曲家，作为勋伯格更为激进的学生安东·韦伯恩的追随者，坚持创作比这位维也纳大师本人的音乐更严谨、更无调性的音乐。

The harmonic revolution of the first half of the twentieth century is now definitely at an end. Polytonality and atonality have both become a normal part of current musical usage. One unexpected development should be noted: the recrudescence of interest, at the end of World War II, in the twelve-tone method of Arnold Schoenberg, especially in countries like Italy, France, and Switzerland, where there had previously been little or no sign of influence. Composers like the Italian Luigi Dallapiccola or the Swiss Frank Martin have not hesitated to extract tonal implications from the dodecaphonic (twelve-tone) method, thereby removing some of its panchromatic sting. Younger composers, adherents of Schoenberg’s more radical pupil Anton Webern, have persisted in writing a music more rigorously athematic and atonal than that of the Viennese master himself.

尽管和声技术不断创新，当代音乐很大一部分仍然保持着基本的自然音阶和调性。但它已不再是世纪之交之前的自然音阶和调性和声。如同大多数革命一样，这场革命在我们的和声语言中留下了印记。因此，如今的音乐常常被认为是以调性为中心的，即使它可能不再具有旧意义上可分析的调性。这种和声保守主义的倾向无疑有助于弥合当代作曲家与其听众之间的隔阂。随着唱片、广播和电影音轨的普及，前天大胆的和声正逐渐且毫不费力地融入我们时代的音乐语言中。

Despite harmonic innovations, a large part of contemporary music remains basically diatonic and tonal. But it is no longer the diatonic, tonal harmony of the period before the turn of the century. Like most revolutions, this one has left its mark on our harmonic language. As a result, music written nowadays may often be said to be tonally centered even though it may have no tonality analyzable in the old sense. This tendency toward harmonic conservatism is certain to help bridge the gap between the contemporary composer and his audience. With the familiarity bred of phonograph disk, radio, and film track the daring harmonies of the day before yesterday are gradually and painlessly being assimilated into the musical language of our time.

 

 

蒙特威尔第——“Hor che'l ciel e la terra”

Monteverdi—“Hor che’l ciel e la terra”

约翰·艾略特·加德纳（飞利浦）

John Eliot Gardiner (Philips)

勋伯格——五首管弦乐曲

Schoenberg—Five Pieces for Orchestra

皮埃尔·布列兹，BBC 交响乐团（索尼）

Pierre Boulez, BBC Symphony (Sony)

7

7

音乐的四要素

The Four Elements of Music

四、音色

IV. TONE COLOR

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

节奏、旋律与和声之后，便是音色，或称声调色彩。正如听不到特定音色就无法听到言语一样，音乐也只能存在于特定音调的色彩之中。音乐中的音色类似于绘画中的色彩。它是一个令人着迷的元素，不仅因为人们已经探索了丰富的资源，也因为未来蕴藏着无限的可能性。

After rhythm, melody, and harmony, comes timbre, or tone color. Just as it is impossible to hear speech without hearing some specific timbre, so music can exist only in terms of some specific color in tone. Timbre in music is analogous to color in painting. It is a fascinating element, not only because of vast resources already explored but also because of illimitable future possibilities.

音乐中的音色是指由特定的音乐发声媒介产生的声音品质。这是对每个人都非常熟悉的事物的正式定义。正如大多数人知道白色和绿色的区别一样，识别音色差异也是我们大多数人与生俱来的先天感知能力。很难想象有人会“音盲”到无法区分男低音和女高音，或者用乐器的术语来说，无法区分大号和大提琴。问题不在于是否知道声音或乐器的名称，而在于能否识别出两者在屏风后面发出的声音在音质上的差异。

Tone color in music is that quality of sound produced by a particular medium of musical tone production. That is a formal definition of something which is perfectly familiar to everyone. Just as most mortals know the difference between white and green, so the recognition of differences in tone color is an innate sense with which most of us are born. It is difficult to imagine a person so “tone-blind” that he cannot tell a bass voice from a soprano or, to put it instrumentally, a tuba from a cello. It is not a question of knowing the names of the voices or instruments but simply of recognizing the difference in their tone quality, if both were heard from behind a screen.

因此，每个人都能本能地开始更全面地了解音色的各个方面。不要让这种与生俱来的欣赏能力限制你对某些特定音色的品味，而排斥所有其他音色。我想到的是一位热爱小提琴音色却极度厌恶其他乐器的人。经验丰富的听众应该希望拓宽自己的欣赏范围，涵盖所有已知的音色。此外，虽然我说过每个人都能大致区分音色，但也存在一些只有通过聆听才能发现的细微差别。即使是音乐学生，一开始也很难区分单簧管和它的“兄弟”低音单簧管的音色。

Instinctively, therefore, everyone has a good start toward getting a fuller understanding of the various aspects of tone color. Don’t allow this natural appreciation to limit your taste for certain favorite tone colors to the exclusion of all others. I am thinking of the man who adores the sound of a violin but feels an extreme distaste for any other instrument. The experienced listener should wish rather to broaden his appreciation to include every known species of tone color. Moreover, although I have said that every person can make broad distinctions in tone colors, there are also subtle differences that only experience in listening can clear up. Even a music student, in the beginning, has difficulty in distinguishing the tone of a clarinet from that of its blood brother the bass clarinet.

聪明的听众在音色方面应该有两个主要目标：（a）提高对不同乐器及其各自音调特征的认识；（b）更好地欣赏作曲家在使用任何乐器或乐器组合时的表达目的。

The intelligent listener should have two main objectives in relation to tone color : (a) to sharpen his awareness of different instruments and their separate tonal characteristics and (b) to gain a better appreciation of the composer’s expressive purpose in using any instrument or combination of instruments.

在探讨不同乐器各自的音质之前，作曲家对其乐器可能性的态度应该更全面地解释一下。毕竟，并非每个音乐主题都生来就被赋予了调性。作曲家常常会发现自己的主题可以用小提琴、长笛、单簧管、小号或其他五六种乐器同样出色地演奏。那么，是什么促使他决定选择其中一种乐器而不是另一种呢？原因只有一个：他选择的乐器音色最能表达他作品背后的含义。换句话说，他的选择取决于任何特定乐器的表现力。这不仅适用于单个乐器，也适用于乐器组合。在某些情况下选择巴松管而不是双簧管的作曲家，可能还需要决定他的音乐理念是最适合弦乐合奏还是完整的管弦乐队。而在任何情况下，让他做出决定的因素都是他想要传达的表达力。

Before exploring the separate instruments for their individual tone qualities, the attitude of the composer toward his instrumental possibilities should be more fully explained. After all, not every musical theme is born fully swaddled in a tonal dress. Very often the composer finds himself with a theme that can be equally well played on the violin, flute, clarinet, trumpet, or half a dozen other instruments. What, then, makes him decide to choose one rather than another? Only one thing: He chooses the instrument with the tone color that best expresses the meaning behind his idea. In other words, his choice is determined by the expressive value of any specific instrument. That is true in the case not only of single instruments but also of combinations of instruments. The composer who chooses a bassoon rather than an oboe in certain instances may also have to decide whether his musical idea best belongs in a string ensemble or a full orchestra. And the thing that makes him decide in every case will be the expressive meaning that he wishes to convey.

当然，有时作曲家会瞬间构思出一个主题及其调性。音乐中有很多杰出的例子。其中经常被引用的是《牧神的午后》 （L'après midi d'un faune）开头的长笛独奏。同样的主题，如果用长笛以外的任何乐器演奏，都会引发截然不同的情感感受。我们无法想象德彪西会先构思出这个主题，然后再决定将其改编成长笛。两者必然是同时构思的。但这并不能解决问题。

At times, of course, a composer conceives a theme and its tonal investiture instantaneously. There are outstanding examples of that in music. One that is often quoted is the flute solo at the beginning of L’après midi d’un faune (Afternoon of a Faun). That same theme, played by any other instrument than the flute, would induce a very different emotional feeling. It is impossible to imagine Debussy’s conceiving the theme first and then later deciding to orchestrate it for a flute. The two must have been conceived simultaneously. But that does not settle the matter.

即使主题在作曲家脑海中浮现，其完整的管弦乐版本，在特定作品的后期音乐发展也可能需要对同一主题进行不同的管弦乐处理。在这种情况下，作曲家就像一位剧作家，为某一场景中的女演员选择服装。舞台上一位女演员坐在公园的长椅上。剧作家可能希望她穿着合适的衣服，以便观众在帷幕拉开时就能知道她当时的心情。这不仅仅是一件漂亮的衣服；而是一件特别设计的服装，让你对这一特定场景中的这一特定角色产生一种特定的感觉。这同样适用于“装扮”音乐主题的作曲家。他所能运用的音色是如此丰富，以至于只有清楚地了解他想要传达的情感，他才能决定在哪件乐器或哪组乐器之间做出选择。

For even in the case of themes that come to the composer in their full orchestral panoply, later musical developments in the course of a particular piece may bring on the need for varied orchestral treatments of the same theme. In such a case, the composer is like a playwright deciding on a dress for an actress in a particular scene. The stage shows us an actress seated on a bench in a park. The playwright may wish to have her clothed in such a way that the spectator knows as soon as the curtain rises what mood she is in. It is not just a pretty dress; it’s an especially designed dress to give you a particular feeling about this particular character in this particular scene. The same holds true for the composer who “dresses” a musical theme. The entire gamut of tonal color at his disposal is so rich that nothing but a clear conception of the emotional feeling that he wishes to convey can make him decide as between one instrument and another or one group of instruments and another.

特定色彩与特定音乐必然联系的想法相对较新。亨德尔之前的作曲家似乎对乐器色彩缺乏强烈的感觉。至少，他们中的大多数人甚至懒得明确写下特定声部需要哪种乐器。对他们来说，四声部乐谱是用四件木管乐器还是四件弦乐器演奏似乎无关紧要。如今，作曲家们坚持用特定的乐器来演绎特定的想法，他们为此创作的方式也变得如此独特，以至于即使小提琴声部和双簧管的音域被限制在同一音域，它们也可能无法演奏。

The idea of the inevitable connection of a specific color for a specific music is a comparatively modern one. It seems likely that composers before Handel’s time did not have a strong feeling for instrumental color. At any rate, most of them did not even trouble to write down explicitly what instrument was desired for a particular part. Apparently it was a matter of indifference to them whether a four-part score was executed by four woodwind instruments or four strings. Nowadays composers insist on certain instruments for certain ideas, and they have come to write for them in a way so characteristic that a violin part may be unplayable on an oboe even when they are confined to the same register.

作曲家能够运用的每一种音色，都是逐渐融入音乐的。这通常涉及三个步骤。首先，乐器必须被发明出来。由于乐器与其他发明一样，通常始于某种原始形式，因此第二步是乐器的完善。第三，演奏者必须逐渐掌握新乐器的技巧。钢琴、小提琴以及大多数其他乐器的发展历程都是如此。

Each of the separate tone colors that the composer is enabled to use only gradually found its way into music. Three steps were generally involved. First, the instrument had to be invented. Since instruments, like any other invention, usually begin in some primitive form, the second step was the perfecting of the instrument. Thirdly, players had gradually to achieve technical mastery of the new instrument. That is the story of the piano, the violin, and most other instruments.

当然，每种乐器，无论多么完美，都有其局限性。音域、力度和演奏都有局限性。每种乐器都能演奏出低音，但不能再低，高音，但不能再高。作曲家有时可能希望双簧管能比它低半个音。但这没有办法；这些限制是注定的。力度限制也是如此。小号虽然比小提琴演奏得响亮，但也不能演奏得比它能演奏的更响亮。作曲家有时会痛苦地意识到这个事实，但却无法回避它。

Of course, every instrument, no matter how perfected, has its limitations. There are limitations of range, of dynamics, of execution. Each instrument can play so low and no lower, so high and no higher. A composer may wish at times that the oboe could play just half a tone lower than it does. But there is no help for it; these limits are prescribed. So are dynamic limitations. A trumpet, though it plays loudly by comparison with a violin, cannot play more loudly than it can. Composers are sometimes painfully aware of that fact, but there is no getting around it.

作曲家也必须时刻牢记演奏的难度。一个看似注定要用单簧管演奏的旋律，却会因为单簧管的某些结构特性而运用到一组特定的音符，而这些音符给单簧管演奏者带来了难以克服的困难。同样的音符，用双簧管或巴松管演奏可能很容易，但用单簧管演奏却非常困难。因此，作曲家在选择音色时并非完全自由。

Difficulties of execution must also be continually borne in mind by the composer. A melodic idea that seems predestined to be sung by a clarinet will be found to make use of a particular group of notes that present insuperable difficulties to the clarinetist because of certain constructional peculiarities of his instrument. These same notes may be quite easy to perform on oboe or bassoon, but it so happens that on a clarinet they are very difficult. So composers are not completely free agents in making their choice of tone colors.

尽管如此，他们的地位远胜于前辈。正因为乐器是机器，像其他任何机器一样，都会不断改进，所以任何当代作曲家在单纯的音色方面都享有贝多芬所不具备的优势。当代作曲家拥有更新、更完善的素材可供创作，此外，他们还能从前辈的经验中受益。尤其是在管弦乐队的运用上，这一点尤为突出。难怪那些以对当代音乐的严谨态度而自豪的评论家，会欣然承认现代作曲家在管弦乐队运用上的才华和智慧。

Nevertheless they are in a much better position than were their predecessors. Just because instruments are machines, subject to improvement like any other machine, any contemporary composer enjoys advantages that Beethoven did not have as far as mere tone color is concerned. The present-day composer has new and improved materials to work with, besides which he benefits from the experience of his forebears. This is especially true of his use of the orchestra. No wonder that critics who pride themselves on their severity toward contemporary music willingly allow the brilliance and cleverness of the modern composer’s handling of the orchestra.

如今，作曲家必须了解每种乐器的本质——如何才能最好地运用它们，充分发挥其最独特的特质。我想以我们熟知的钢琴为例，来解释一下我所说的“运用乐器的特质”是什么意思。一篇关于管弦乐编曲的论文，也会对每种乐器进行同样的阐述。

It is important nowadays for a composer to have a feeling for the essential nature of each instrument—how it may best be used to exploit its most personal characteristics. I should like to take, for example, a perfectly familiar instrument—the piano—and show what I mean by using an instrument characteristically. A treatise on orchestration would do the same for each of the instruments.

钢琴是一种随身携带的乐器——有人曾称它为“万物之母”。它可以替代各种不同的乐器，包括管弦乐队本身。但它本身也是一个独立的存在——它也是一架钢琴——因此它拥有独属于自己的属性和特性。作曲家若能充分利用钢琴的本质，就能最大限度地发挥它的优势。让我们来看看钢琴的本质是什么。

The piano is a handy instrument to have around—“maid of all work,” someone once called it. It can substitute for a large variety of different instruments including the orchestra itself. But it is also a being in its own right—it is also a piano—and as such it has properties and characteristics that belong to itself alone. The composer who exploits the piano for its essential nature will be using it to best advantage. Let us see what that essential nature is.

钢琴的使用方式有两种：振动式或非振动式。这是由钢琴的结构决定的：多根琴弦绷在钢架上，每根琴弦上都有一个制音器。制音器对钢琴的演奏至关重要，它由钢琴踏板控制。不踩踏板时，钢琴音色仅在钢琴家手指按下音符时持续。但如果移除制音器（即踩下踏板），钢琴音色就会持续。无论哪种情况，钢琴音色的强度都会在敲击的瞬间减弱。踏板在一定程度上弥补了这一弱点，因此是优秀钢琴作曲的关键。

A piano may be used in one of two ways: either as a vibrating or as a nonvibrating instrument. That is true because of its construction, which consists of series of strings stretched across a steel frame, with a damper on each string. This damper is vital to the nature of the instrument. It is controlled by the piano pedal. When the pedal is untouched, piano tone lasts only as long as the note is pressed by the pianist’s finger. But if the damper is removed (by pushing the pedal down), the tone is sustained. In either case, piano tone declines in intensity from the instant it is struck. The pedal minimizes this weakness somewhat and therefore holds the key to good piano writing.

尽管钢琴是由克里斯托福里于1711年左右发明的，但直到19世纪中叶，作曲家们才懂得如何以真正独特的方式利用踏板。肖邦、舒曼和李斯特之所以成为钢琴创作的大师，是因为他们充分考虑到了钢琴作为一种振动乐器的特性。法国的德彪西和拉威尔，以及俄罗斯的斯克里亚宾，在钢琴创作方面继承了肖邦和李斯特的传统。他们都充分认识到，钢琴的本质一方面在于它是由共振的琴弦组成的，它能产生感性而柔和的音调，另一方面又能产生明亮而脆性的音调组合，而这些音调一旦松开制音踏板就会立即消失。

Although the piano was invented around 1711 by one Cristofori, it was not until the middle nineteenth century that composers understood how to take advantage of the pedal in a truly characteristic way. Chopin, Schumann, and Liszt were masters of piano writing because they took fully into account its peculiarities as a vibrating instrument. Debussy and Ravel in France, Scriabin in Russia carried on the tradition of Chopin and Liszt, as far as their piano writing is concerned. All of them took full cognizance of the fact that the piano is, on one side of its nature, a collection of sympathetically vibrating strings, producing a sensuous and velvety or brilliant and brittle conglomeration of tones, which are capable of immediate extinction through release of the damper pedal.

近代作曲家们已经利用了钢琴本质的另一面——非振动音调。

More recent composers have exploited the other side of the piano’s essential nature—the nonvibrating tone.

非振动钢琴是指很少或根本不使用踏板的钢琴。这样演奏时，钢琴音色干硬，且独具特色。现代作曲家对粗犷、冲击力强的音色效果的追求，在这种钢琴的新用途中得到了宝贵的释放，将钢琴变成了一种大型木琴。贝拉·巴托克、卡洛斯·查韦斯和阿图尔·奥涅格等现代作曲家的钢琴作品中便可找到这类钢琴的优秀范例。阿图尔·奥涅格在其为钢琴与管弦乐队创作的小协奏曲中，有一个引人入胜的最后乐章，其钢琴音色干脆利落，颇具噼啪声。

The nonvibrating piano is the piano in which little or no use is made of the pedal. Played thus, a hard, dry piano tone is produced which has its own particular virtue. The feeling of the modern composer for harsh, percussive tonal effects found valuable outlet in this new use of the piano, turning it into a kind of large xylophone. Excellent examples of this may be found in the piano works of such moderns as Béla Bartók, Carlos Chávez or Arthur Honegger. This last composer has an attractive last movement in his Concertino for piano and orchestra which fairly crackles with a dry, brittle piano sonority.

我之前关于钢琴的观点也适用于其他所有乐器。每一种乐器都有其独特的创作方式。乐器所能发出的、独一无二的音色正是作曲家所追求的。

The point I have been making in relation to the piano is valid for every other instrument also. There is definitely a characteristic way of writing for each one of them. The tonal colors that an instrument can produce that are uniquely its own are the ones sought after by the composer.

单色

SINGLE TONE COLORS

现在，我们可以更好地考察单音色，例如在常见的交响乐团中常见的音色。管弦乐器通常被视为常态，因为它们在作曲家的乐谱中最为常见。稍后，我们将探讨这些单音色是如何混合形成各种乐器组合的音色的。

Now we are in a better position to examine single tone colors, such as are found in the usual symphony orchestra. Orchestral instruments are generally taken as a norm, for it is those that we are most apt to find in a composer’s score. Later we shall want to know how these single tone colors are mixed to form timbres of various instrumental combinations.

管弦乐器主要分为四类，或称四部分。第一部分当然是弦乐器；第二部分是木管乐器；第三部分是铜管乐器；第四部分是打击乐器。每个部分都由一组类型相似的相关乐器组成。每位作曲家在创作时，都会将这四个部分牢记在心。

Orchestral instruments are divided into four principal types, or sections. The first section, of course, is that of the strings; the second, of the woodwind; the third is the brass; and the fourth is the percussion. Each of these sections is made up of a related group of instruments of similar type. Every composer, when working, keeps these four divisions very much to the front of his mind.

弦乐组是所有乐器中最常用的，它本身由四种不同类型的弦乐器组成，分别是小提琴、中提琴、大提琴（或简称大提琴）和低音提琴。

The string section, which is the most used of all, is itself made up of four different types of stringed instruments. These are the violin, the viola, the violon-cello (or cello, for short), and the double bass.

你最熟悉的乐器当然是小提琴。在管弦乐谱中，小提琴被分为两个部分——所谓的第一小提琴和第二小提琴——但实际上只有一种乐器。当然，无需赘述小提琴那抒情、歌唱般的音质；它对我们所有人来说都太熟悉了。但你可能不太熟悉某些特殊的效果，这些效果有助于赋予小提琴更丰富的音色。

The instrument with which you are most familiar is, of course, the violin. In orchestral writing, violins are divided into two sections—so-called first and second violins—but only one type of instrument is involved. There is certainly no need to describe the lyric, singing quality of the violin; it is much too familiar to all of us. But you may be less familiar with certain special effects which help to give the instrument a greater variety of tone color.

其中最重要的是拨弦，用手指拨动琴弦而不是用弓演奏，从而产生类似吉他的效果。这种效果对我们大多数人来说也相当熟悉。不太为人所知的是泛音效果。泛音的产生方式不是用手指按压琴弦，而是轻轻触碰琴弦，从而产生一种类似笛子、具有特殊魅力的音色。双停是指同时弹奏两根或多根琴弦，从而产生和弦效果。最后，还有一种隐晦而敏感的音色，可以通过使用弱音器获得。弱音器是一种放置在乐器琴桥上的小型附加装置，可以立即减弱乐器的响度。

Most important of these is the pizzicato, in which the string is plucked by the finger instead of being played with the bow, thus producing a somewhat guitar-like effect. That, too, is familiar enough to most of us. Less well known is the effect of harmonics, as they are called. These are produced by not pressing the finger on the string in the usual way but lightly touching it instead, thereby creating a flutelike tone of special charm. Double stopping means playing on two or more strings simultaneously, so that a chordal effect is obtained. Finally, there is the veiled and sensitive tone obtainable through use of the mute, a small extra contraption placed on the bridge of the instrument, immediately deadening the sonority.

所有这些不同的效果不仅可以在小提琴上实现，而且在所有其他弦乐器上也可以实现。

All of these varied effects are obtainable not only on the violin but also on all the other stringed instruments.

中提琴是一种经常与小提琴混淆的乐器，因为它们不仅外观相似，而且握法和演奏方式也相似。仔细观察就会发现，中提琴体型更大、重量更重，音色也更厚重、低沉。它无法像小提琴那样发出高音，但可以通过低音来弥补这一点。它扮演着小提琴女高音的女低音角色。虽然它缺乏高音乐器那种轻盈抒情的音质，但另一方面，它拥有一种低沉而富有表现力的音色——仿佛充满了情感。

The viola is an instrument that is often confused with the violin, because it not only resembles it in outward appearance but is held and played in the same fashion. Closer examination would show that it is a slightly larger and weightier instrument, producing a heavier and graver tone. It cannot sing notes as high as the violin’s but compensates for that by being able to sing lower. It plays a contralto role to the violin’s soprano. If it lacks the light lyric quality of the higher instrument, it possesses, on the other hand, a gravely expressive sonority—seemingly full of emotion.

大提琴是一种更容易辨认的乐器，演奏者坐着演奏，将其牢牢地支撑在双膝之间。它演奏男中音和低音，而中提琴演奏女低音。它的音域比中提琴低一个八度，但是由于音高较低，大提琴的音质众所周知。然而，作曲家们知道大提琴有三个不同的音区。在高音区，大提琴可以演奏出非常凄美动人的乐器。在其音域的另一端，其音响效果是严肃而深沉的。最常用的中音区产生我们更熟悉的大提琴音色——一种严肃、流畅、类似男中音的音质，几乎总是能表达出某种程度的情感。

The cello is a more easily recognized instrument played, as it is, by a seated performer holding it firmly propped between both knees. It plays baritone and bass to the viola’s contralto. Its range is one full octave lower than the viola, but it pays for this by not being able to go so high. The quality of cello tone is well known. Composers, however, are conscious of three different registers. In its upper register, the cello can be a very poignant and touching instrument. At the other extreme of its range, the sonority is one of sober profundity. The middle register, most frequently used, produces the more familiar cello tone—a serious, smooth, baritone-like quality of sound, almost always expressive of some degree of feeling.

弦乐家族的最后一支乐器——低音提琴，是所有乐器中体型最大的，而且必须站立演奏。由于它经常出现在爵士乐队中，近年来它的重要性与其体型更加相称。低音提琴最初用于管弦乐队时，扮演着非常卑微的角色，所做的工作不过是大提琴低八度的演奏（也就是所谓的低音提琴的二重奏）。但它在这方面做得很好。后来，作曲家们赋予它自己的演奏空间，让它在管弦乐队的深处演奏。它几乎从不作为独奏乐器；如果你听过低音提琴尝试演奏旋律，你就会明白为什么。低音提琴的真正作用是为其上方的整个结构提供坚实的基础。

The last of the string family, the double bass, is the largest of all and must be played standing. Because it is seen in jazz bands, it has recently taken on an importance more nearly commensurate with its size. When it was first used in orchestras, it played a very menial role, doing little more than what the cello did (doubling the bass, as it is called) an octave lower. This it does very well. Later composers gave it a part of its own to play, down in the depths of the orchestra. It almost never functions as a solo instrument; and if you have ever heard a double bass try to sing a melody, you will understand why. The proper function of the double bass is to supply a firm foundation for the entire structure above it.

第二部分管弦乐器包括木管乐器。它们同样分为四种类型，但每种类型都有一种与其密切相关的乐器，与其所属的直接类别密切相关，可以说是主要类型的近亲。四种主要的木管乐器是长笛、双簧管、单簧管和巴松管。长笛的“近亲”是短笛和G调长笛；双簧管与英国管有亲缘关系，正如一本管弦乐谱书籍所述，英国管既不是英国管也不是管子，但却被称为英国管。单簧管与单簧管、短笛和低音单簧管有亲缘关系；巴松管与低音巴松管有亲缘关系。

The second section of orchestral instruments comprises those that come under the heading of woodwinds. Once again they are of four different types, though in this case each type has a closely related instrument which belongs in its immediate group, a kind of first cousin to the main type. The four principal woodwinds are the flute, oboe, clarinet, and bassoon. The flute’s “first cousins” are the piccolo and the flute in G; the oboe is related to the English horn, which, as one orchestration book has it, is neither English nor a horn but called that nevertheless. The clarinet is related to the clarinet piccolo and bass clarinet; and the bassoon, to the double bassoon.

最近，一种新的乐器被加入，它的一部分是木管乐器，叫做萨克斯管。你可能听说过它！起初，它在普通的交响乐团中很少使用。后来，爵士乐队突然开始使用它，现在它又在交响乐领域得到了更广泛的应用。

Recently a new instrument has been added, which is partly a woodwind, called the saxophone. You’ve probably heard of it! At first, it was only very sparingly used in the usual symphonic orchestra. Then suddenly the jazz band began exploiting it, and now it is finding its way back to more extended use in the symphonic field.

即使管弦乐队所有乐器都演奏到最大音量，你通常也能听到短笛的歌声。在极强音下，它拥有纤细却尖锐而明亮的音色，能够盖过任何在听音范围内的乐器。作曲家们对它的运用非常谨慎。通常，它只是将长笛的音色高出一个八度，使其音色翻倍。但近年来，作曲家们已经证明，如果用更温和的音域轻柔地演奏，它就能呈现出一种纤细而迷人的歌唱之声。

Even if all the instruments of the orchestra are playing their loudest, you can generally hear the piccolo above all of them. In fortissimo, it possesses a thin but shrill and brilliant sonority and can outpipe anyone within listening distance. Composers are careful how they use it. Often it merely doubles, an octave higher, what the flute is doing. But recent composers have shown that, played quietly in its more moderate register, it has a thin singing voice of no little charm.

长笛的音色广为人知。它拥有柔和、清凉、流畅或轻柔的音色。由于其鲜明的个性，它是管弦乐队中最具魅力的乐器之一。它极其灵活；它演奏速度更快，音准更精确，比任何其他木管乐器都高。大多数听众都熟悉它的高音区。近年来，它的低音区被广泛使用，它以极具个性的方式，富有深沉的表现力。

The tone color of the flute is fairly well known. It possesses a soft, cool, fluid or feathery timbre. Because of its very defined personality, it is one of the most attractive instruments in the orchestra. It is extremely agile; it can play faster and more notes to the second than any other member of the woodwinds. Most listeners are familiar with its upper register. Much use has been made in recent years of its lowest register which is darkly expressive, in a most individual way.

双簧管是一种鼻音乐器，音质与长笛截然不同。（双簧管演奏者垂直握持乐器，而长笛演奏者水平握持乐器。）双簧管是木管乐器中最具表现力的，其表现方式非常主观。相比之下，长笛则显得缺乏个人色彩。双簧管具有一定的田园风情，作曲家常常将其巧妙地运用。与其他木管乐器相比，双簧管必须演奏得足够好，才能使其有限的音域充分变化。

The oboe is a nasal-sounding instrument, quite different in tone quality from the flute. (The oboe player holds his instrument perpendicularly, whereas the flutist holds his horizontally.) The oboe is the most expressive of the woodwinds, expressive in a very subjective way. By comparison, the flute seems impersonal. The oboe has a certain pastoral quality which is often put to good use by composers. More than any other woodwind the oboe must be well played if its limited tonal scope is to be sufficiently varied.

英国管是一种男中音双簧管，缺乏经验的听众常常会将其音色与双簧管混淆。然而，它拥有独特的哀婉音质，瓦格纳在《特里斯坦与伊索尔德》第三幕的引子中充分发挥了这种特点。

The English horn is a kind of baritone oboe, which is often, by inexperienced listeners, confused in tone color with the oboe. It possesses a plaintive quality all its own, however, which was fully exploited by Wagner in the introduction to the third act of Tristan and Isolde.

单簧管音色流畅、开阔，近乎空洞。它比双簧管音色更清凉、更均匀，也更明亮。它的音质更接近长笛而非双簧管，但其灵动性几乎与长笛不相上下，能够以同样优雅的音色演绎各种旋律。在最低八度，它拥有独特的音色，令人难以忘怀。它的动态范围比任何其他木管乐器都更出色，从轻柔的耳语到最辉煌的极强音，无所不包。

The clarinet has a smooth, open, almost hollow sound. It is a cooler, more even-sounding instrument than the oboe, being also more brilliant. Much closer to the flute than to the oboe in quality, it has almost as great an agility as the former, singing with an equal grace melodies of all kinds. In its lowest octave it possesses a unique tone color of a deeply haunting effect. Its dynamic range is more remarkable than that of any other woodwind, extending from a mere whisper to the most brilliant fortissimo.

低音单簧管与单簧管本身几乎没有区别，只是音域低了一个八度。在低音区，它有着一种幽灵般的音质，令人难以忘怀。

The bass clarinet hardly differs from the clarinet itself, except that its range is one octave lower. In its bottom register, it has a ghostlike quality which is not easily forgotten.

巴松管是最多功能的乐器之一，它能演奏许多不同的乐曲。它的高音区有一种非常独特的哀婉音色。斯特拉文斯基在《春之祭》的开篇就巧妙地运用了这种音色。另一方面，巴松管在低音区能发出干涩、幽默的断奏，几乎带有一种顽皮的效果。它总是被用来凭借其浑厚的音色，使沉闷的低音部分更加富有共鸣。它的确是一种非常实用的乐器。

The bassoon is one of the most versatile of instruments. It is able to do a number of different things. In its upper register, it has a plaintive sound which is very special. Stravinsky made excellent use of that timbre at the very beginning of Le Sacre du Printemps (Rite of Spring). On the other hand, the bassoon produces a dry, humorous staccato in the lower register, of an almost puckish effect. And it is always being called upon to make dullish bass parts more resonant by the sheer weight of its tone. A handy instrument it certainly is.

低音巴松管与它的关系，就如同低音提琴与大提琴的关系。拉威尔在《鹅妈妈组曲》中用它来描绘野兽。它主要为乐队提供低音部分，在乐队最需要的地方，在最深处。

The double bassoon bears the same relationship to it as the double bass does to the cello. Ravel used it to characterize the beast in his Beauty and the Beast from the Mother Goose Suite. Mainly it helps to supply a bass voice to the orchestra where it is badly needed, down in its very depths.

铜管乐器组与其他乐器组一样，主要有四种乐器。它们是圆号（确切地说是法国号）、小号、长号和大号。（短号与小号太相似了，因此无需特别提及。）

The brass section, like the others, boasts four principal types of instruments. These are the horn (or French horn, to be exact), the trumpet, the trombone, and the tuba. (The cornet is too much like the trumpet to need special mention.)

法国号是一种音色圆润优美的乐器——音色柔和、悦耳，近乎流畅。大声吹奏时，它会呈现出一种庄严的铜管音质，与其柔和的音色截然相反。如果说还有比八支圆号齐奏出极强旋律更雄伟的声音，那我从未听过。圆号还有另一种最有效的音色，那就是用弱音器或将手放在喇叭口处来止音。强音时，会产生一种哽咽刺耳的声音。而同样的方法，如果不用强音，则会发出一种超凡脱俗的音色，仿佛来自遥远的地方，散发着神奇的魔力。

The French horn is an instrument with a lovely round tone—a soft, satisfying, almost liquid tone. Played loud, it takes on a majestic, brassy quality which is the complete opposite of its softer tone. If there exists a more noble sound than eight horns singing a melody fortissimo in unison, I have never heard it. There is one other most effective sonority to be obtained from the horn by stopping the tone either with a mute or with the hand placed in the bell of the instrument. A choked, rasping sound is produced when the tone is forced. The same procedure, when unforced, gives an unearthly tone which seems to emanate with magical effect from distant places.

小号是那种辉煌、尖锐、气势磅礴的乐器，人人皆知。它是所有作曲家在高潮时刻的支柱。但它在轻柔演奏时也能发出优美的音色。与圆号一样，小号也有其特殊的弱音器，可以产生在戏剧性时刻必不可少的咆哮、刺耳的音响效果；而当用钢琴演奏时，则可以产生柔和、悦耳、类似笛子的声音。近年来，爵士乐队的小号手们使用了各种各样的弱音器，每种弱音器都能产生截然不同的音响效果。最终，其中一些几乎肯定会被引入交响乐团。

The trumpet is that brilliant, sharp, commanding instrument with which everyone is familiar. It is the mainstay of all composers at climactic moments. But it also possesses a beautiful tone when played softly. Like the horn it has its special mutes, which produce a snarling, strident sonority which is indispensable in dramatic moments and a soft, dulcet, flutelike voice when played piano. Recently, jazz-band trumpetists have made use of a large assortment of mutes, each producing a quite different sonority. Eventually some of these are almost certain to be introduced into the symphony orchestra.

长号的音质与法国号相似。它同样拥有高贵而雄伟的音色，比圆号的音色更宏大圆润。但它也与小号相似，因为它在极强音时音色绚丽夺目。管弦乐队中，长号声部的巧妙运用常常能营造出庄严宏伟的氛围。

The tone of the trombone is allied in quality to that of the French horn. It also possesses a noble and majestic sound, one that is even larger and rounder than the horn’s tone. But it also partly belongs with the trumpet, because of its brilliance of timbre in fortissimo. Moments of grandeur and solemnity are often due to a judicious use of the trombone section of the orchestra.

大号是管弦乐队中外观最华丽的乐器之一，因为它占据了演奏者的手臂。但它并不容易驾驭。要演奏它，必须拥有良好的牙齿和充足的余音。它比长号更重，更庄重，也更难驾驭。它很少用于旋律演奏，尽管近年来，作曲家们偶尔会将一些主题交给它，效果也各不相同。（拉威尔在穆索尔斯基《图画展览会》管弦乐版中的大号独奏就是一个特别好的例子。）然而，在大多数情况下，它的功能是强调低音，因此，它发挥了宝贵的作用。

The tuba is one of the orchestra’s more spectacular-looking instruments, since it fills the arms of the player holding it. It isn’t easily manageable. To play it at all one must possess good teeth and plenty of reserve wind. It is a heavier, more dignified, harder-to-move kind of trombone. It is seldom used melodically, though in recent years composers have entrusted occasional themes to its bearlike mercies, with varying results. (Ravel’s tuba solo in his orchestral version of Moussorgsky’s Pictures at an Exhibition is a particularly happy example.) For the most part, however, its function is to emphasize the bass, and, as such, it does valuable service.

管弦乐队的第四乐段由各种打击乐器组成。每个参加音乐会的人都会注意到这个乐段，或许过于频繁了。除了少数例外，这些乐器没有固定的音高。它们通常用于以下三种情况之一：增强节奏效果、动态提升高潮感，或为其他乐器增添色彩。它们的效力与它们的使用量成反比。换句话说，它们越是被保留在关键时刻，就越能发挥其作用。

The fourth section of the orchestra is made up of various kinds of percussion instruments. Everyone who attends a concert notices this section, perhaps too much. With a few exceptions, these instruments have no definite pitch. They are generally used in one of three ways: to sharpen rhythmic effects, dynamically to heighten the sense of climax, or to add color to the other instruments. Their effectiveness is in inverse ratio to the use that is made of them. In other words, the more they are saved for essential moments the more effective they will be.

在打击乐组中，最令人瞩目的是鼓家族。它们大小不一，种类繁多，既能制造节奏，又能发出噪音，从小型的通通鼓到大型的低音鼓，应有尽有。唯一具有明确音高的鼓是众所周知的定音鼓，通常两三个一组。用两根鼓槌演奏，其音域宽广，从朦胧遥远的隆隆声到震耳欲聋的连续轰鸣。其他一些并非鼓类的噪音制造器还包括钹、锣（或称铜锣）、木块、三角铁、响板等等。

In the percussion group, it is the drum family that is most imposing. These are all rhythm- and noise-makers of various sizes and assortments, from the little tom-tom to the big bass drum. The only drum with a definite pitch is the well-known kettledrum, usually found in groups of two or three. Played with two sticks, its dynamic range goes all the way from a shadowy, far-off rumble to an overpowering succession of thudlike beats. Other noisemakers, though not of the drum variety, are the cymbals; the gong, or tam-tam; the wood block; the triangle; the slapstick; and many more.

其他打击乐器组提供的是色彩，而不是噪音或节奏。这些乐器通常具有一定的音高，例如钢片琴、钟琴、木琴、颤音琴、管钟等等。前两种乐器发出细小的钟声，这对于音乐的色彩营造者来说非常重要。木琴可能是这类乐器中最为人熟知的，而颤音琴则是最近才加入的。竖琴、吉他和曼陀林等著名乐器有时也因其拨弦音色而被归类为打击乐器。近年来，钢琴已成为管弦乐队不可或缺的一部分。

Other percussion-group instruments provide color rather than noise or rhythm. These are likely to be of definite pitch, such as the celesta and glockenspiel, the xylophone, the vibraphone, the tubular bells, and others. The first two produce tiny, bell-like tones which are a great asset to the colorist in music. The xylophone is possibly the most familiar of this group, and the vibraphone the most recent addition. Well-known instruments like the harp, guitar, and mandolin are also sometimes grouped with the percussion instruments because of their plucked-string timbre. In recent years, the piano has been used as an integral part of the orchestra.

当然，还有很多非管弦乐器，例如管风琴、簧风琴、手风琴，更不用说人声了，我们只能列举这些乐器。毋庸置疑，所有这些乐器有时都会与管弦乐队一起使用。

There are, of course, a number of nonorchestral instruments, such as the organ, the harmonium, the accordion—not to mention the human voice—which we can do little more than list. Needless to add, all these are sometimes used with orchestra.

混合色调

MIXED TONE COLORS

将这些不同的乐器以不同的组合方式混合在一起是作曲家最乐于做的事情之一。尽管理论上可能的组合方式非常多，但作曲家通常只选择那些已经熟悉的乐器组合。这些乐器可能是同一家族的乐器组合，例如弦乐四重奏，也可能是不同家族的乐器组合，例如长笛、大提琴和竖琴。这里只能列举一些常见的组合：三重奏，由小提琴、大提琴和钢琴组成；木管五重奏，由长笛、双簧管、单簧管、巴松管和圆号组成；单簧管五重奏（带弦乐）；长笛、单簧管和巴松管三重奏。近年来，作曲家们对一些不太常见的组合进行了大量的实验，并取得了不同的成果。其中最具创意和成功的作品之一是斯特拉文斯基芭蕾舞剧《婚礼》的伴奏乐队，由四架钢琴和十三件打击乐器组成。

Mixing these separate instruments in different combinations is one of the composer’s more pleasant occupations. Though there are theoretically a very large number of possible combinations, composers usually confine themselves to groups of instruments that usage has made familiar. These may be groupings of instruments belonging to the same family, such as the string quartet, or those of different families, like flute, cello, and harp. It isn’t possible to do more than mention a few customary combinations: trio, made up of violin, cello, and piano; the woodwind quintet, a combination of flute, oboe, clarinet, bassoon, and horn; the clarinet quintet (with strings); the flute, clarinet, and bassoon trio. In recent years, composers have done a considerable amount of experimenting in less usual combinations with varied results. One of the most original and successful is the accompanying orchestra of Stravinsky’s ballet Les Noces, comprised of four pianos and thirteen percussion instruments.

所有室内乐组合中最常见的是弦乐四重奏，由两把小提琴、一把中提琴和一把大提琴组成。如果作曲家有主观倾向，那么弦乐四重奏对他来说没有比它更好的媒介了。它的音色本身就营造出一种亲密感和个人情感，这种情感在与乐器的音响效果紧密接触的房间中得到了最佳体现。这种媒介的局限性绝不能忽视；作曲家常常试图让弦乐四重奏听起来像一个小型管弦乐队。在其自身的框架内，它是一种令人钦佩的复音媒介，我的意思是，它存在于四种乐器各自独立的声部中。聆听弦乐四重奏时，你必须准备好进行对位聆听。在后面讲到音乐织体时，这一点的含义将会更加清晰。

The most usual of all chamber-music combinations is that of the string quartet, composed of two violins, viola, and cello. If a composer is subjectively inclined, there is no better medium for him than the string quartet. Its very timbre creates a sense of intimacy and personal feeling which finds its best frame in a room where contact with the sonority of the instruments is a close one. The limits of the medium must never be lost sight of; composers are often guilty of trying to make the string quartet sound like a small orchestra. Within its own frame it is an admirably polyphonic medium, by which I mean that it exists in terms of the separate voices of the four instruments. In listening to the string quartet, you must be prepared to listen contrapuntally. What that means will become clearer later on when the chapter on musical texture is reached.

毫无疑问，交响乐团是作曲家们迄今为止发展出的最引人入胜的乐器组合。从听众的角度来看，它同样引人入胜，因为它本身就包含了所有乐器的组合，种类繁多，无穷无尽。

The symphony orchestra is, without doubt, the most interesting combination of instruments composers have yet evolved. It is equally fascinating from the listener’s standpoint, for it contains within itself all instrumental combinations, of an endless variety.

聆听管弦乐队时，务必牢记四个主要声部及其相对重要性。无论定音鼓演奏者多么引人入胜，都不要被他们的滑稽动作所迷惑。不要仅仅因为弦乐声部坐在你最前面，就只关注他们。努力戒掉聆听管弦乐队的不良习惯。聆听管弦乐队时，除了享受声音本身的纯粹美感之外，你所能做的最重要的事情就是将主要的旋律素材从其周围和辅助元素中分离出来。旋律线通常从一个声部过渡到另一个声部，或从一种乐器过渡到另一种乐器，如果你想要跟上它的旋律线，就必须时刻保持警惕。作曲家通过精心平衡乐器的音响效果来提供帮助；指挥家则通过实现这些平衡，根据作曲家的意图调整各个环境来提供帮助。但是，如果你不准备将旋律素材从其伴奏的音网中分离出来，那么任何方法都无济于事。

In listening to the orchestra, it is wise to keep well in mind the four principal sections and their relative importance. Don’t become hypnotized by the antics of the kettledrum player, no matter how absorbing they may be. Don’t concentrate on the string section alone, just because they are seated up front nearest you. Try to free yourself of bad orchestral listening habits. The main thing you can do in listening to the orchestra, aside from enjoying the sheer beauty of the sound itself, is to extricate the principal melodic material from its surrounding and supporting elements. The melodic line generally passes from one section to another or from one instrument to another, and you must always be mentally alert if you expect to be able to follow its peregrinations. The composer helps by careful balancing of his instrumental sonorities; the conductor helps by realizing those balances, adjusting individual conditions to the composer’s intention. But none can be of any help if you are not prepared to disengage the melodic material from its accompanying web of sound.

如果正确看待指挥，或许能在这方面有所帮助。他通常会把注意力主要放在演奏主旋律的乐器上。如果你观察他的演奏，即使不了解乐曲本身，也能知道你的注意力应该集中在哪里。毋庸置疑，一位优秀的指挥会将自己限制在必要的手势上；否则，他可能会让人分心。

The conductor, if rightly looked at, may be of some help in this. He generally will be found giving his primary attention to the instruments who have the main melody. If you watch what he is doing, you will be able to tell, without previous knowledge of a piece, where the center of your interest should be. It goes without saying that a good conductor will confine himself to necessary gestures; otherwise he can be most distracting.

一篇关于音色、由美国撰写的章节，如果不提及爵士乐队，那将是不完整的。爵士乐队是我们自己对新管弦乐音色的独创性贡献。无论你喜不喜欢，爵士乐队在新颖的音效方面都是一个真正的创造。正是由于没有弦乐，而依赖于铜管和管乐作为旋律乐器，才使得现代舞乐队听起来与维也纳华尔兹管弦乐队截然不同。如果你仔细聆听爵士乐队，你会发现某些乐器提供节奏背景（钢琴、班卓琴、贝司和打击乐器），其他乐器提供和声织体，通常情况下，一个独奏乐器演奏旋律。小号、单簧管、萨克斯管和长号可以互换使用，作为和声乐器或旋律乐器。真正的乐趣始于当旋律与一个或多个辅助旋律形成对位时，旋律和节奏元素错综复杂，只有仔细聆听才能解开。你完全可以把爵士乐队作为一种练习，在精神层面上如何将不同的音乐元素区分开来。当乐队发挥到极致时，它会给你带来很多挑战。

A chapter on tone color, written in America, would be incomplete without some mention of the jazz band, our own original contribution to new orchestral timbres. The jazz band is a real creation in novel tonal effects, whether you like them or not. It is the absence of strings and the resultant dependence on brass and wind as melody instruments that makes the modern dance band sound so different from a Viennese waltz orchestra. If you listen to a jazz band closely, you will discover that certain instruments provide the rhythmic background (piano, banjo, bass, and percussion), others the harmonic texture, with, as a rule, one solo instrument playing the melody. Trumpet, clarinet, saxophone, and trombone are used interchangeably as harmonic or melodic instruments. The real fun begins when the melody is counterpointed by one or more subsidiary ones, making for an intricacy of melodic and rhythmic elements that only the closest listening can unravel. There is no reason why you should not use the jazz band as a way of practicing how mentally to disconnect separate musical elements. When the band is at its best, it will set you problems aplenty.

 

 

布里顿——青少年管弦乐队指南

Britten—A Young Person’s Guide to the Orchestra

伦纳德·伯恩斯坦，纽约爱乐乐团（索尼）

Leonard Bernstein, New York Philharmonic (Sony)

莫扎特——《独奏管乐与管弦乐队交响协奏曲》；《小提琴、中提琴与管弦乐队交响协奏曲》

Mozart—Sinfonia Concertante for Solo Winds and Orchestra; Sinfonia Concertante for Violin, Viola and Orchestra

奥菲斯室内乐团（德意志留声机）

Orpheus Chamber Orchestra (Deutsche Grammophon)

拉威尔—— 《波莱罗舞曲》

Ravel—Bolero

乔治·索尔蒂爵士，芝加哥交响乐团（伦敦）

Sir Georg Solti, Chicago Symphony (London)

8

8

音乐织体

Musical Texture

为了更好地理解音乐的聆听要点，门外汉应该大致区分三种不同的音乐织体：单音织体、主音织体和复音织体。

In order better to understand what to listen for in music, the layman should, in a general way, be able to distinguish three different kinds of musical texture. There are three species of texture: monophonic, homophonic, and polyphonic.

单音音乐当然是所有音乐中最简单的。它是由单一、无伴奏的旋律线组成的音乐。中国音乐和印度音乐的织体都是单音的。他们的旋律线没有我们理解的和声伴奏。除了复杂的节奏打击乐伴奏外，旋律线本身极其精妙细腻，运用了四分之一音和其他我们体系中不曾有过的更小音程。不仅所有东方民族，就连希腊人的音乐也具有单音织体。

Monophonic music is, of course, the simplest of all. It is music of a single, unaccompanied melodic line. Chinese or Hindu music is monophonic in texture. No harmony, in our sense, accompanies their melodic line. The line itself, aside from a complex rhythmic percussion accompaniment, is of an extraordinary finesse and subtlety, making use of quarter tones and other smaller intervals unknown in our system. Not only all Oriental peoples but also the Greeks had a music that was monophonic in texture.

我们自身音乐中单音发展最精妙之处，莫过于格里高利圣咏。它起源于早期教堂音乐，最初并不明确，但随着一代又一代教堂作曲家对类似素材的不断演绎和改良，其表现力得到了极大的提升。格里高利圣咏是西方音乐中无伴奏旋律线的最佳范例。

The finest development of monophony in our own music is Gregorian chant. From uncertain beginnings in very early church music, its expressive power became greatly enhanced by generations of church composers’ working and reworking a similar material. It is the best example we have in Western music of an unaccompanied melodic line.

在后来的时代，单音的使用通常是偶然的。音乐仿佛停顿片刻，将注意力集中在一行上，从而产生一种类似于风景中一片开阔空间的效果。当然，十八世纪和二十世纪作曲家为长笛或大提琴等独奏乐器创作的奏鸣曲中也有一些单音写作的例子。由于数百年来伴奏和声的沿袭，这些单音作品常常暗示着一种隐含的和声，即使实际上并没有发出任何声音。一般来说，单音是所有织体中最清晰的，不会造成聆听上的问题。

In later times, the use of monophony has usually been incidental. The music seems to pause for a moment, concentrating attention on a single line, thereby producing an effect similar to an open space in a landscape. There are, of course, examples of monophonic writing in sonatas for solo instruments, such as flute or cello, by eighteenth- and twentieth-century composers. Because of hundreds of years of accompanying harmonies, these single-lined works often suggest an implied harmony, even though none is actually sounded. In general, monophony is the clearest of all textures and presents no listening problems.

第二种类型——同音织体——比单音织体更容易被立即听出，但难度略高。由于它在音乐中经常使用，它对我们听众也更为重要。它由一条主旋律线和一段和弦伴奏组成。只要音乐还以声乐和对位的方式构思——也就是说，直到16世纪末——我们意义上的同音织体就不为人知。同音织体是早期意大利歌剧作曲家的“发明”，他们寻求一种比对位方法更直接的方式来传达戏剧情感，并更清晰地呈现文本。

The second species—homophonic texture—is only slightly more difficult to hear immediately than monophony. It is also more important for us as listeners, because of its constant use in music. It consists of a principal melodic line and a chordal accompaniment. As long as music was vocally and contrapuntally conceived—that is, until the end of the sixteenth century—homophonic texture in our sense was unknown. Homophony was the “invention” of the early Italian opera composers who sought a more direct way of imparting dramatic emotion and a clearer setting of the text than was possible through contrapuntal methods.

发生的事情很容易解释。有两种方法可以理解简单的和弦连续。一种是，我们可以用对位法来理解，也就是说，一个和弦的每个独立声部都移动到下一个和弦的下一个音符；另一种是，我们可以用和声法来理解，在这种情况下，我们不再考虑各个独立声部。关键在于，17 世纪意大利创新者的前辈们从未像第一种方式那样，将他们的和声视为由各个旋律声部组合而成。当所有重音都集中在一条线上，而所有其他元素都沦为伴奏和弦时，革命性的一步就迈出了。

What happened is fairly easy to explain. There are two ways of considering a simple succession of chords. Either we may consider it contrapuntally, that is, each separate voice of one chord moving to its next note in the following chord; or we may think of it harmonically, in which case no thought of the separate voices is retained. The point is that the predecessors of the Italian innovators of the seventeenth century never thought of their harmonies except in the first way, as resulting from the combination of separate melodic voices. The revolutionary step was taken when all emphasis was placed upon a single line, and all other elements reduced to the status of mere accompanying chords.

这是卡契尼早期同音音乐的一个例子，展现了“较新”、较朴素的和弦伴奏。需要具备相当的历史视角才能体会到这首作品在最初的听众看来有多么独特。

Here is an early example of homophonic music from Caccini, showing the “newer,” plainer kind of chordal accompaniment. It is necessary to have a fair amount of historical perspective to realize how original this seemed to its first listeners.

不久之后，这些简单的和弦就被分解，或者说，被称之为“塑形”。将这些和弦塑形或变成流畅的琶音，本质上并没有改变什么。这种技法一经发现，很快就得到了进一步的完善，并从此对作曲家们产生了非同寻常的吸引力。上述和弦塑形的例子如下：

It wasn’t very long before these simple chords were broken up, or figurated, as it is called. Nothing is essentially changed by figurating or turning these chords into flowing arpeggios. Once discovered, this device was soon elaborated and has exerted an unusual fascination on composers ever since. The foregoing example in chordal figuration would appear thus:

音乐中唯一真正带来聆听挑战的织体是第三种——复调织体。复调音乐对听众的注意力要求更高，因为它由独立且相互独立的旋律线构成，这些旋律线共同构成和声。困难在于，我们的聆听习惯是由和声构想的音乐所塑造的，而复调音乐要求我们以更线性的方式聆听，在某种意义上，忽略由此产生的和声。

The only texture in music that poses real listening problems is the third kind—polyphonic texture. Music that is polyphonically written makes greater demands on the attention of the listener, because it moves by reason of separate and independent melodic strands, which together form harmonies. The difficulty arises from the fact that our listening habits are formed by music that is harmonically conceived, and polyphonic music demands that we listen in a more linear fashion, disregarding, in a sense, those resultant harmonies.

任何听众都不能忽视这一点，因为它是更明智地聆听音乐的基石。我们必须始终牢记，1600年之前创作的所有音乐以及之后创作的许多音乐都是复调织体的音乐，因此，当你聆听帕莱斯特里纳或奥兰多·迪·拉索的音乐时，你的聆听方式与聆听舒伯特或肖邦的音乐截然不同。这不仅体现在情感层面，也体现在音乐的构思方式上，从技术层面来说，也体现在音乐本身的完全不同。复调织体意味着听众能够听到由不同声部演唱的独立旋律，而不是仅仅听到所有声部时时刻刻、垂直排列的声音。

No listener can afford to ignore this point, for it is fundamental to a more intelligent approach toward listening. We must always remember that all music written before the year 1600 and much that was written later was music of polyphonic texture, so that when you listen to music of Palestrina or Orlando di Lasso, you must listen differently from the way you listen to Schubert or Chopin. That is true not only from the standpoint of its emotional meaning but also, technically, because the music was conceived in an entirely different way. Polyphonic texture implies a listener who can hear separate strands of melody sung by separate voices, instead of hearing only the sound of all the voices as they happen from moment to moment, vertical fashion.

本书中没有哪个部分比这一点更需要直接的音乐阐释。读者若不反复聆听同一首乐曲，费尽心思去理清那些交织的声部，就无法彻底理解。这里我们只能举一个例子：巴赫著名的众赞歌前奏曲《我呼唤我的上帝，耶稣·基督》。

No point in this book needs direct musical illustration more than this one. The reader cannot expect to grasp it thoroughly without listening to the same piece of music over and over, making a mental effort to disentangle the interweaving voices. Here we must confine ourselves to a single illustration: Bach’s well-known chorale prelude Ich ruf zu Dir, Herr Jesu Crist.

这是三声部复音的一个例子。作为一项实验工作，你应该把这首短曲听四遍，先听最容易听清的部分——高音，或称女高音声部。现在再听一遍，这次听低音声部，它运用了重复的音符，节奏平稳。接下来应该听中音，或称中间声部。这个声部是一种有型旋律，但由于其十六分音符（更快）的节奏，可以与其他声部区分开来。现在，一起听这三个声部，在脑海中将它们区分开来：女高音的旋律持续，中音的旋律更流畅，低音的旋律平稳。一个补充实验可以包括一次听两个声部：女高音和低音，中音和女高音，低音和中音，然后再一起听这三个声部。 （为了本次调查的目的，建议使用 RCA Victor 的斯托科夫斯基编曲。7）

This is an example of three-voiced polyphony. As a bit of laboratory work, you should listen to this short piece four times, hearing first the part that is always easiest to hear—the top, or soprano, part. Now listen again, this time for the bass part which moves in a well-poised manner, making use of repeated notes. The alto, or middle voice, should be listened for next. This voice is a kind of figurated melody, but it is distinguishable from the others because of its sixteenth-note (faster) motion. Now hear all three voices together, keeping them well apart in your mind: the soprano with its sustained melody, the alto with the more flowing inner melody, and the bass with its poised line. A supplementary experiment might consist of hearing two voices at a time: soprano and bass, alto and soprano, bass and alto, before hearing all three voices together. (For the purposes of this investigation, RCA Victor’s Stokowski arrangement is recommended.7)

进行这个小实验，你将为自己做一件非常有意义的事情。除非你能以这种方式——声部对声部、线对线——聆听所有复音音乐，否则你的聆听体验就不算真正到位。

In carrying out this little experiment, you will be doing a very valuable thing for yourself. Until you can hear all polyphonic music in this way—in terms of voice against voice, line against line—you will not be listening properly.

复音织体带来了一个问题：人耳能同时掌握多少个独立声部？对此，人们众说纷纭。就连作曲家也偶尔会攻击复音，认为它是强加于我们的理性观念，而非天成。尽管如此，我认为可以肯定地说，只要有相当多的聆听经验，聆听二声部或三声部音乐无需过多精神负担。真正的麻烦在于，复音音乐由四、五、六或八个独立声部组成。但一般来说，作曲家会辅助进行复音聆听，因为他很少让所有声部同时进行。即使在四声部复音中，作曲家也会设法让一个声部保持静默，而其他三个声部活跃。这大大减轻了负担。

Polyphonic texture brings with it the question of how many independent voices the human ear can grasp simultaneously. Opinions differ as to that. Even composers have occasionally attacked polyphony, holding it to be an intellectual idea that has been forced upon us—not a natural one. Nevertheless, I think it can safely be maintained that with a fair amount of listening experience, two- or three-voiced music can be heard without too much mental strain. Real trouble begins when the polyphony consists of four, five, six, or eight separate and independent voices. But, as a rule, listening polyphonically is aided by the composer because he seldom keeps all the voices going at the same time. Even in four-voiced polyphony, composers so manage that one voice is usually silent while the other three are active. This lightens the burden considerably.

对于复调音乐，还有一点值得一提：反复聆听比单音音乐更能保持你的兴趣。即使你无法将所有声部都听得一样好，当你再次聆听时，很有可能会听到一些不同的声音。你总是可以从不同的角度去聆听。

There is also this to be said for polyphonic music: that repeated hearings keep up your interest better than music of homophonic texture. Even supposing that you do not hear all the separate voices equally well, there is every likelihood that when you return to it again, there will be something different for you to listen to. You can always hear it from a different angle.

但人们是否能同时听到多个声音现在仅仅是一个学术问题，因为世界上许多伟大的音乐都是按照复音聆听的原理创作的。

But whether one can hear several voices at a time or not is now merely an academic question, since so much of the world’s great music has been written on the principle of polyphonic listening.

此外，当代作曲家明显倾向于重新燃起对复调写作的兴趣。这源于人们对十九世纪音乐的普遍反感，因为十九世纪音乐的织体基本是主音。由于新一代作曲家对十八世纪的审美理念更加认同，他们也继承了那个时期的对位织体——但有一点不同：他们独立声部的创作产生了不再传统的和声。这种较新的对位写作有时被称为线性对位，或“不协和”对位。从听众的角度来看，在现代对位中，由于没有了可以依靠的悦耳的和声网，他们不太可能失去每个声部的独立感。在近代的对位写作中，声部仿佛“突出”了出来；因为人们强调的是它们的独立性，而不是它们的统一性。

Moreover, contemporary composers have shown a marked leaning toward a renewal of interest in polyphonic writing. This was brought on as part of the general reaction against nineteenth-century music, which is basically homophonic in texture. Because the newer composers feel more sympathy with the esthetic ideals of the eighteenth century, they also have taken over the contrapuntal texture of that period—but with this difference: that their independent part writing results in harmonies that are no longer conventional. This newer kind of contrapuntal writing has sometimes been called linear, or “dissonant,” counterpoint. From the listener’s standpoint, there is less chance of losing the sense of the separateness of each voice in modern counterpoint, since there is no mellifluous harmonic web to fall back upon. In recent contrapuntal writing, the voices “stick” out, as it were; for it is their separateness rather than their togetherness which is stressed.

以下是欣德米特较新的对位法的一个例子，他是现代复调织体的最佳实践者之一：8

Here is an example of the newer counterpoint from Hindemith, who is one of the best practitioners of modern polyphonic texture:8

那么请记住，复音结构的音乐，无论是巴赫还是欣德米特的作品，聆听的方式都是完全相同的。

Remember, then, that music of polyphonic texture, whether it is by Bach or by Hindemith, is listened to in exactly the same way.

当然，并非所有音乐都能划分为这三种织体。在任何一首乐曲中，作曲家都可以不经过渡地从一种织体过渡到另一种织体。作为听众，你必须准备好跟随作曲家在任何特定时刻选择的织体类型。他的选择本身就具有情感意义。显然，一条单一的无伴奏旋律线比复杂的音网更能产生更自由的感觉和更直接的个人表达。主音音乐的效果在很大程度上依赖于和声背景，通常比复音音乐更能直接吸引听众。但复音音乐也带来了更大的智力投入。你必须更积极地聆听才能听出其中发生的事情，这一事​​实本身就需要更大的智力投入。通常，作曲家在创作复音音乐时也会投入更多的脑力。通过在一首乐曲中运用所有三种织体，可以获得更丰富的表现力。

Not all music, of course, is divided into one of these three different kinds of texture. In any piece of music, the composer may go from one kind to another without transition. You, as listener, must be prepared to follow the species of texture that the composer chooses for any given moment. His choice is, in itself, not without emotional significance. Obviously, a single unaccompanied melodic line produces a greater sense of freedom and direct personal expression than a complicated web of sound. Homophonic music, which depends so much on harmonic background for its effect, generally has more immediate appeal for the listener than polyphonic music. But polyphonic music brings with it a greater intellectual participation. The mere fact that you must listen more actively in order to hear what goes on in itself induces a greater intellectual effort. Composers, as a rule, also put more mental effort into writing polyphonic music. By utilizing all three kinds of texture in a single piece, a greater variety of expressive feeling is obtained.

贝多芬《第七交响曲》中的快板乐章，堪称音乐杰作中丰富织体的典范。（推荐托斯卡尼尼的RCA Victor唱片。）乐章开头几乎完全是和弦，只有高音部分略带旋律。无论如何，它的织体绝对是主音的。随后，中提琴和一半的大提琴加入了一段新的饱满旋律。这种效果只是部分对位，因为伴奏的高音和低音部分仅仅是对开头和弦结构的暗示。但之后（唱片第一面快结束时），出现了一个纯粹的对位部分。第一和第二小提琴开始围绕一个取自第一个颇为平淡的主题的片段编织出复音织体。如果您能理解这首对位乐章中十六分音符的旋律是如何逐渐叠加在开头和弦的极强音之上的，您就能更接近贝多芬构思乐章高潮的真实方式。在这里，一如既往，更深入的聆听将换来与作曲家思想更紧密的接触——这不仅仅是在技术层面，因为对音乐织体的更敏锐感知必定能使音乐的表达意义更加完整。

The Allegretto movement from Beethoven’s Seventh Symphony provides as good an example as any of a varied texture in one of the masterworks of music. (Toscanini’s RCA Victor recording is recommended.) The beginning is almost entirely chordal, with only a suggestion of a melodic phrase in the upper voice. In any case, it is definitely homophonic in texture. Then a new and full-sung melody is added in the violas and half the cellos. The effect is only partly contrapuntal, because the accompanying upper and lower voices are little more than a suggestive reminder of the opening chordal structure. But much later on (toward the end of the first side of the record), a purely contrapuntal section is arrived at. The first and second violins begin to weave a polyphonic texture about a fragment taken from the first rather inexpressive theme. If you are able to follow the way in which, gradually, the sixteenth-note motion engendered in this contrapuntal part is superimposed above a fortissimo sounding of the opening chords, you will be coming closer to the actual way in which Beethoven conceived the climax of the movement. Here, as always, a greater awareness in listening will be repaid by closer contact with the composer’s thought—and not only in the technical sense, for a greater sensitivity to musical texture is certain to make the expressive meaning of music more completely felt.

毫无疑问，当读者有机会思考关于基本形式的章节时，就能更全面地理解对位织体及其与主音的关系。尤其是对赋格形式的讨论，应该能让读者更容易理解复音织体。

A fuller understanding of contrapuntal texture and its relation to homophony will come, no doubt, when the reader has had the opportunity to consider the chapters on fundamental forms. Particularly the discussion of fugal forms should make the hearing of polyphonic texture easier.

 

 

格里高利圣咏——“萨鲁姆”礼拜仪式

Gregorian Chant—The “Sarum” Liturgy

塔利斯学者（吉梅尔）

Tallis Scholars (Gimell)

中世纪复调音乐——约翰内斯·西科尼亚的音乐

Medieval Polyphony—Music of Johannes Ciconia

PAN乐团（新阿尔比恩）

Ensemble P.A.N. (New Albion)

巴赫——B小调弥撒曲

Bach—Mass in B Minor

Philippe Herreweghe，Collegium Vocale（维珍经典）

Philippe Herreweghe, Collegium Vocale (Virgin Classics)

贝多芬——第七交响曲（参见第二章列表）

Beethoven—Symphony No. 7 (see listing under Chapter Two)

9

9

音乐结构

Musical Structure

几乎任何人都能更容易地辨别旋律、节奏，甚至和声，而不是一首长篇乐曲的结构背景。正因如此，从现在开始，我们必须将重点放在音乐的结构上；因为读者应该意识到，在更有意识地聆听时，最需要注意的一点是将整首乐曲串联起来的精心设计。

Almost anyone can more readily distinguish melodies and rhythms, or even harmonies, than the structural background of a lengthy piece of music. That is why our main emphasis, from here on, must be put upon structure in music; for the reader should realize that one of the principal things to listen for, when listening more consciously, is the planned design that binds an entire composition together.

音乐的结构与其他艺术形式并无二致；它只是艺术家素材的连贯组织。但音乐素材具有流动性，甚至相当抽象的特性；因此，作曲家的结构任务因音乐本身的性质而倍感艰巨。

Structure in music is no different from structure in any other art; it is simply the coherent organization of the artist’s material. But the material in music is of a fluid and rather abstract character; therefore the composer’s structural task is doubly difficult because of the very nature of music itself.

在解释音乐形式时，普遍的倾向是将其过于简化。通常的方法是抓住某些众所周知的形式模式，并或多或少地展示作曲家如何在这些模式中创作作品。然而，仔细研究大多数杰作就会发现，它们很少能像教科书所设想的那样完美地契合其外在形式。结论是不可避免的：仅仅认为音乐结构只是选择一个形式模式，然后用灵感迸发的音调填充它是不够的。正确理解，形式只能是一个生命体从作曲家所基于的前提逐渐生长的过程。由此可见，“每一首真正的音乐作品的形式都是独一无二的”。音乐内容决定了形式。

The general tendency, in explaining form in music, has been to oversimplify. The usual method is to seize upon certain well-known formal molds and demonstrate how composers write works within these molds, to a greater or lesser extent. Close examination of most masterworks, however, will show that they seldom fit so neatly as they are supposed to into the exteriorized forms of the textbooks. The conclusion is inescapable that it is insufficient to assume that structure in music is simply a matter of choosing a formal mold and then filling it with inspired tones. Rightly understood, form can only be the gradual growth of a living organism from whatever premise the composer starts. It follows, then, that “the form of every genuine piece of music is unique.” It is musical content that determines form.

然而，作曲家绝非完全独立于外在的形式模式。因此，听众有必要理解既定或选定的音乐形式与作曲家对该形式的独立性之间的关系。这其中涉及两点：作曲家对历史音乐形式的依赖性和独立性。首先，读者可能会问：“这些形式是什么？作曲家为什么要费心去关注它们？”

Nevertheless, composers are not by any means entirely independent of outer formal molds. It therefore becomes necessary for the listener to understand this relationship between the given, or chosen, form and the composer’s independence of that form. Two things, then, are involved: the dependence and independence of the composer in relation to historical musical forms. In the first place, the reader may ask: “What are these forms, and why should the composer bother about them in any way?”

问题前半部分的答案很简单：奏鸣曲-快板、变奏、帕萨卡利亚、赋格，这些都是一些最为人熟知的音乐形式。这些形式模式都是通过几代作曲家在不同国家创作的经验积累，慢慢演变而来的。对于当今的作曲家来说，抛弃所有经验，在创作每部新作品时都从头开始，这似乎是愚蠢的。这很自然，尤其是在音乐素材的组织本身就非常困难的情况下，作曲家们每次开始创作时，都会倾向于依赖这些久经考验的形式。在开始创作之前，他们的脑海中就会浮现出所有这些熟悉的音乐模式，它们支撑着他们的想象力，有时甚至激发他们的想象力。

The answer to the first part of the question is easy: The sonata-allegro, the variation, the passacaglia, the fugue are the names of some of the best-known forms. Each one of these formal molds was only slowly evolved through the combined experience of generations of composers working in many different lands. It would seem foolish for present-day composers to discard all that experience and to begin to work from scratch with each new composition. It is only natural, particularly since the organization of musical material is by its very nature so difficult, that composers tend to lean on these well-tried forms each time that they begin to write. In the back of their minds, before beginning to compose, are all these used and known musical molds which act as a support and, sometimes, a stimulus for their imaginations.

同样，如今的剧作家，尽管手头上的故事素材种类繁多，通常也会将自己的喜剧改编成三幕剧的形式。这已成为惯例——而非五幕剧。他或许更喜欢由多个短场景组成的戏剧形式，这种形式最近颇受欢迎；又或许是没有中场休息的长篇单幕剧。但无论他选择哪种形式，我们都假定他从一种通用的戏剧形式开始。同样，作曲家每次也都从一种通用且广为人知的音乐形式开始创作。

In the same way, a playwright working today, despite the variety of story material at his disposal, generally fits his comedy into the form of a three-act play. That has become the custom—not the five-act play. Or he may prefer the form of the play in a number of short scenes, which has found favor recently; or the long one-acter without intermission. But whatever he chooses, we presume that he begins from a generalized play form. In the same way, the composer each time begins from a generalized and well-known musical form.

布索尼认为这是一种弱点。他写了一本小册子，证明音乐的未来需要作曲家摆脱对既定形式的过度依赖。然而，作曲家们仍然像过去一样依赖这些形式，新形式模式的出现也依然罕见。

Busoni felt that this was a weakness. He wrote a pamphlet to prove that the future of music demanded the freeing of composers from their overdependence on predetermined forms. Nevertheless, composers continue to depend on them as in the past, and the emergence of a new formal mold is just as rare an occurrence as ever.

但无论选择何种外在模式，都必须遵循一些基本的结构原则。换句话说，无论你的建筑方案如何，它都必须始终通过材料本身的性质在心理上得到证实。正是这一事实迫使作曲家跳出形式化的既定模式。

But whatever outer mold is chosen, there are certain basic structural principles which must be fulfilled. In other words, no matter what your architectural scheme may be, it must always be psychologically justified by the nature of the material itself. It is that fact which forces the composer out of the formal, given mold.

例如，假设一位作曲家正在创作一种通常以尾声（coda）或结束部分为前提的音乐形式。有一天，在创作素材时，他偶然发现了一个他知道注定要成为尾声的部分。碰巧的是，这个尾声特别安静，基调令人回味。然而，就在这之前，必须构建一个漫长的高潮。现在，他开始创作高潮。但当他完成那个漫长的高潮部分时，他可能会发现，这使得安静的结尾变得多余。在这种情况下，由于素材发展的需求，形式模式将被推翻。同样，贝多芬在其第七交响曲的第一乐章中，尽管所有教科书都提到第一乐章形式中的“对比主题”，但实际上并没有对比主题——至少不是通常意义上的对比主题，这是由于他开头所用主题材料的特殊性。

For example, let us take the case of a composer who is working on a form that generally presupposes a coda, or closing section, at the end of his composition. One day, while working with his material, he happens on a section that he knows was destined to be that coda. It so happens that this particular coda is especially quiet and reminiscent in mood. Just before it, however, a long climax must be built. Now he sets about composing his climax. But by the time he has that long climactic section finished, he may discover that it renders the quiet close superfluous. In such a case, the formal mold will be overthrown, because of the exigencies of the evolving material. Similarly Beethoven, in the first movement of his Seventh Symphony, despite what all the textbooks say about “contrasting themes” of the first-movement form, does not have contrasting themes—not in the usual sense, at any rate, owing to the specific character of the thematic material with which he began.

那么，请记住两点。记住形式模型的大致轮廓，并记住作曲家思想的内容迫使他以一种独特而个性化的方式运用这种形式模型——以一种只属于他正在创作的那部特定作品的方式。这主要适用于艺术音乐。简单的民歌在其小框架内往往具有完全相同的结构。但没有两部交响曲是完全相同的。

Keep two things in mind, then. Remember the general outlines of the formal mold, and remember that the content of the composer’s thought forces him to use that formal mold in a particular and personal way—in a way that belongs only to that particular piece that he is writing. That applies chiefly to art music. Simple folk songs are often of an exactly similar structure within their small frame. But no two symphonies were ever exactly alike.

所有形式的首要考虑，都是营造一种前文提到的长线感。这长线必须赋予我们方向感，并且必须让我们感受到这个方向是必然的。无论采用何种手段，最终结果都必须在听众心中产生一种令人满意的连贯感，这种连贯感源于作曲家最初音乐理念的心理必然性。

The prime consideration in all form is the creation of a sense of the long line which was mentioned in an earlier chapter. That long line must give us a sense of direction, and we must be made to feel that that direction is the inevitable one. Whatever the means employed, the net result must produce in the listener a satisfying feeling of coherence born out of the psychological necessity of the musical ideas with which the composer began.

结构区别

STRUCTURAL DISTINCTIONS

音乐结构有两种理解方式：(1) 形式与整部作品的关系；(2) 形式与作品中各个独立、较短的部分的关系。较大的形式区别通常与交响曲、奏鸣曲或组曲的整个乐章有关。较小的形式单元则共同构成一个完整的乐章。

There are two ways in which structure in music may be considered: (1) form in relation to a piece as a whole and (2) form in relation to the separate, shorter parts of a piece. The larger formal distinctions would have to do with entire movements of a symphony, a sonata, or a suite. The smaller formal units would together make up one entire movement.

如果将这些形式上的区别与小说的构造进行类比，门外汉可能会更清楚地理解这些区别。一部长篇小说可以分为四卷——第一卷、第二卷、第三卷和第四卷。这就好比一套组曲或交响曲的四个乐章。第一卷又可以分为五章。同样，第一乐章由五节组成。一章包含许多段落。在音乐中，每个节也可以细分为更小的部分（遗憾的是，没有专门的术语来表示这些更小的单位）。段落由句子组成。在音乐中，句子类似于音乐理念。当然，单词类似于单个音调。毋庸置疑，这种比较只是广义的。

These formal distinctions may be clearer to the layman if an analogy is made with the construction of a novel. A full-length novel might be divided into four books—I, II, III, and IV. That would be analogous to the four movements of a suite or symphony. Book I might be, in turn, divided into five chapters. Similarly, movement I would be made up of five sections. One chapter would contain so many paragraphs. In music, each section would also be subdivided into lesser sections (unfortunately, no special term denotes these smaller units). Paragraphs are composed of sentences. In music, the sentence would be analogous to the musical idea. And, of course, the word is analogous to the single musical tone. Needless to say, this comparison is meant to be taken only in a general sense.

在概述单个乐章时，习惯上用字母A、B、C等来表示较大的部分。较小的部分通常用a、b、c等来表示。

In the outlining of a single movement, it has become the custom to represent the larger sections by letters A, B, C, etc. Smaller divisions are usually represented by a, b, c, etc.

结构原理

STRUCTURAL PRINCIPLES

音乐中运用一个至关重要的原则来营造形式平衡感。这个原则对音乐艺术如此重要，以至于只要音乐还在创作，它就可能以某种方式被运用。这个原则就是非常简单的重复。音乐的大部分在结构上都基于对这个原则的广义解读。在音乐中使用重复似乎比在任何其他艺术形式中都更合理，这可能是因为它本身就比较不规则。唯一需要提及的另一个形式原则是重复的反面——非重复。

One all-important principle is used in music to create the feeling of formal balance. It is so fundamental to the art that it is likely to be used in one way or another as long as music is written. That principle is the very simple one of repetition. The largest part of music bases itself structurally on a broad interpretation of that principle. It seems more justified to use repetition in music than in any of the other arts, probably because of its rather amorphous nature. The only other formal principle that need be mentioned is the opposite of repetition—that is, nonrepetition.

一般来说，以重复为脊柱结构的音乐可以分为五种不同的类别。第一类是精确重复；第二类是分段重复或对称重复；第三类是变奏重复；第四类是赋格处理重复；第五类是发展重复。除第一类外，后面的每一类都将在单独的章节中讨论。每个类别都有不同的类型形式，这些类型形式都属于特定类型的重复。精确重复（第一类）非常简单，不需要任何特殊演示。其他类别根据以下类型形式划分：

Speaking generally, music that is based on repetition for its spinal structure may be divided into five different categories. The first one is exact repetition; the second, sectional, or symmetrical, repetition; the third, repetition by variation; the fourth, repetition by fugal treatment; the fifth, repetition through development. Each one of these categories (with the exception of the first) will receive separate treatment in single chapters later. Each category will be found to have different type forms which come under the heading of a specific kind of repetition. Exact repetition (the first category) is too simple to need any special demonstration. The other categories are split up according to the following type forms:

仅有的其他基本形式类别是基于非重复的类别，以及所谓的“自由”形式。

The only other basic formal categories are those based on nonrepetition, and the so-called “free” forms.

在开始讨论这些大型重复形式之前，最好先研究一下在较小规模上应用的重复原则。这很容易做到，因为这些重复原则既适用于构成整个乐章的大乐段，也适用于每个乐段内的小单元。因此，音乐形式就像一连串的轮子，其中最小轮子的构造与最大轮子的构造非常相似。民歌通常以类似于这些较小单元之一的乐句为基础，并尽可能地用来阐释最简单的重复原则。

Before launching into discussion of these large type forms of repetition, it would be wise to examine the principle of repetition applied on a smaller scale. This is easily done because these repetitional principles apply both to the large sections which comprise an entire movement and also to the small units within each section. Musical form, therefore, resembles a series of wheels within wheels, in which the formation of the smallest wheel is remarkably similar to that of the largest one. A folk song is often constructed on lines similar to one of these smaller units and whenever possible will be used to illustrate the simplest repetition principles.

最基本的重复是精确重复，可以用“aaaa ”等表示。这种简单的重复在很多歌曲中都能找到，歌曲中相同的音乐在连续的诗节中重复。第一种变奏形式发生在类似的歌曲中，为了使歌词更加贴近歌词，对重复部分进行细微的改动。这种重复可以用“a-aʹ -aʺ-aʹʹʹ”等表示。

The most elementary of all is that of exact repetition, which may be represented by a-a-a-a, etc. Such simple repetitions are to be found in many songs, where the same music is repeated for consecutive stanzas. The first form of variation occurs when, in similar songs, minor alterations are made in the repetition to allow for a closer setting of the text. This kind of repetition may be represented as a-aʹ-aʺ-aʹʹʹ, etc.

下一种重复形式不仅对许多民歌至关重要，而且对艺术音乐中最小和最大乐段而言也至关重要。它是离题后的重复。这种重复可以是精确的，在这种情况下用aba表示；也可以是变化的，因此用ab-aʹ表示。在音乐中，第一个a经常会立即重复。在离题之前，似乎存在着某种基本需求，需要将第一个乐句或乐段印在听众的脑海中。然而，大多数理论家都认为，第一个a的重复并不会改变aba 的本质形式。（在音乐中，可以用符号 : 来表示重复，形成公式：a : -ba。）以下是两首民歌《月光》和《奥古斯丁的爱人啊！ 》中这种重复的形式：

The next form of repetition is fundamental not only to many folk songs but also to art music in its smallest and largest sections. It is repetition after a digression. This repetition may be exact, in which case it is represented by a-b-a; or it may be varied and therefore represented by a-b-aʹ. Very often in music the first a is immediately repeated. There would appear to be some fundamental need to impress a first phrase or section on the listener’s mind before the digression comes. Most theorists agree, however, that the essential a-b-a form is unchanged by the repetition of the first a. (In music, it is possible to indicate the repetition by the sign: , making the formula : a :-b-a.) Here is this species of repetition in two folk songs, Au clair de la lune and Ach! du lieber Augustin:

同样的公式在艺术音乐中也能找到。舒曼的《童年场景》中的第一首钢琴曲就是一个很好的例子，它是由aba组成的短曲，第一个a重复出现。以下是没有伴奏的旋律线：

The very same formula may be found in art music. The first of Schumann’s piano pieces in Scenes from Childhood is a good example of a short piece made up of a-b-a, with the first a repeated. Here is the melodic line without the accompaniment:

同样的套路，略有变化，可以在贝多芬《钢琴奏鸣曲》（作品27，第二号）谐谑曲的第一页中找到。这里，即使是第一个a，在立即重复时，也会因节奏上的某种错位而略有​​变化；而最后一次重复则有所不同，结尾处有更强烈的终止式感觉。（音乐中的“终止式”指的是结束乐句。）旋律轮廓如下：

The same formula, with slight changes, may be found as part of a longer piece in the first page of the Scherzo from Beethoven’s Piano Sonata, Op. 27, No. 2. Here, even the first a, when immediately repeated, is slightly changed by a certain dislocation in the rhythm; and the final repetition is different by a stronger cadential feeling at the end. (A “cadence” in music means a closing phrase.) Here is the melodic outline:

快板

Allegretto

列举出更多带有细微变化的“阿巴”公式的例子很容易，但我的目的并非包罗万象。关于这些较小的单元，需要记住的一点是：每当一个主题出现时，它很可能会立即重复；重复之后，需要进行离题；离题之后，可以预料到会回到第一个主题，无论是原样还是变化。同样的“阿巴”公式如何应用于整部作品，包括奏鸣曲式，将在后面的章节中进行说明。

It would be easy to multiply examples of the a-b-a formula, with tiny variations, but my purpose is not to be all-inclusive. The point to remember about these smaller units is that every time a theme is exposed, there is strong likelihood that it will be repeated immediately; that once repeated, a digression is in order; and that after the digression, a return to the first theme, either exact or varied, is to be expected. How this same a-b-a formula applies to a piece as a whole, including the sonata form, will be demonstrated in later chapters.

唯一的其他基本形式原则，即非重复原则，可以用公式abcd等来表示。它可以通过以下英国民歌《爱的种子》以小的方式得到说明，所有四个乐句都是不同的：

The only other basic formal principle, that of nonrepetition, may be represented by the formula a-b-c-d, etc. It may be illustrated in a small way by the following English folk song The Seeds of Love, all four phrases of which are different:

同样的原则在巴赫及其同时代人创作的许多前奏曲中都能找到。一个简短的例子是《平均律古钢琴谱》第一卷中的降B大调前奏曲。统一性是通过采用特定的模式来实现的，在该模式中自由书写，但避免任何音符或乐句的重复。我们将在“自由形式”一章中再次讨论这一点。

This same principle may be found in many of the preludes composed by Bach and other of his contemporaries. A short example is the B flat major Prelude from Book I of the Well Tempered Clavichord. Unity is achieved by adopting a specific pattern, writing freely within that pattern, but avoiding any repetition of notes or phrases. We shall be returning to it in the chapter on Free Forms.

要在一首二十分钟的乐曲中，不使用任何形式的主题重复，达到类似的统一性绝非易事。这或许解释了非重复原则主要应用于短篇作品的原因。听众会发现，它的使用频率远低于任何一种重复形式，而这些重复形式现在必须详细探讨。

To obtain a similar unity in a piece lasting twenty minutes without using any form of thematic repetition is no easy achievement. That probably accounts for the fact that the principle of nonrepetition is applied for the most part to short compositions. The listener will find it used much less frequently than any of the repetition forms, which now must be considered in detail.

 

 

舒曼——童年场景

Schumann—Scenes from Childhood

Rado Lupu（伦敦）

Rado Lupu (London)

贝多芬——升C小调奏鸣曲，作品27，第2号

Beethoven—Sonata in C-sharp Minor, Opus 27, No. 2

阿尔弗雷德·布伦德尔（飞利浦）

Alfred Brendel (Philips)

10

10

基本形式

Fundamental Forms

一、剖面图

I. SECTIONAL FORM

两部曲；三部曲；回旋曲；自由分段编排

Two Part; Three Part; Rondo; Free Sectional Arrangement

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

听众最容易理解的形式是分段构建的。相关部分之间或多或少清晰的划分很容易被理解。从某种角度来看，几乎所有音乐都可以被认为是分段构建的——即使是理查·施特劳斯的长调诗也是如此。但在本章中，我们将仅限于讨论那些明显由不同部分以某种方式组合而成的典型形式。

The easiest form for the listener to grasp is that built sectionally. The more or less clearly defined separation of related parts is readily assimilated. From a certain perspective, practically all music might be considered to be sectionally constructed—even the long tone poems of a Richard Strauss. But in this chapter we shall confine ourselves to those type forms which are obviously made up of a combination in some arrangement of separate sections.

两部分表格

TWO-PART FORM

其中最简单的是二部或二元形式，用AB表示。二部形式如今很少使用，但它在 1650 年至 1750 年的音乐中扮演着主要角色。在印刷页面上可以清楚地看到A和B的划分，因为A部分的结尾几乎总是用带有重复符号的双小节表示。有时重复符号也跟在B部分的结尾后面，在这种情况下，公式更准确地说是AABB。但是，正如我已经指出的，在分析形式时，我们不会考虑这些精确的重复，因为它们并不真正影响整个音乐的总体轮廓。此外，诠释者在实际演奏所指示的重复时会自行判断。

The simplest of these is two-part, or binary, form, represented by A-B. Two-part form is very little used nowadays, but it played a preponderant role in the music written from 1650 to 1750. The division into A and B may be clearly seen on the printed page, for the end of the A section is almost always indicated by a double bar with a repetition sign. Sometimes a repetition sign follows the end of the B section also, in which case the formula would more truly be A-A-B-B. But, as I have already pointed out, in analyzing forms we do not take into account these exact repetitions, because they do not really affect the general outlines of the music as a whole. Moreover, interpreters use their own discretion in the matter of actually playing the repetitions indicated.

在所有其他形式中，B部分表示一个独立的部分，其音乐素材与A部分不同。然而在二部曲式中，第一部分和第二部分之间存在一般对应关系。A和B似乎互相平衡；B通常只不过是A的重新编排版本。具体如何“重新编排”在每首曲子中有所不同，这在很大程度上解释了二部结构的巨大多样性。B部分通常一部分由A的重复组成，一部分由A中某些乐句的发展组成。因此，可以说，后来变得如此重要的发展原则就起源于此。如果门外汉能留意每个部分结尾处强烈的终止感，他就能清楚地听出这种形式的两个部分。
