In all other forms, a B section would indicate an independent section, different in musical material from the A section. In two-part form, however, there is a general correspondence between the first and second parts. The A and B seem to balance one another; B often is little more than a rearranged version of A. Exactly how the “rearrangement” is carried out differs with each piece and largely accounts for the great variety within the two-part structure. The B section is often made up partly of a repetition of A, and partly of a kind of development of certain phrases to be found in A. It might be said, therefore, that the principle of development which became so important in later times had its origin here. The two parts of the form will be clearly heard by the layman if he listens for the strong cadential feeling at the end of each part.

十七、十八世纪创作的数千首短小的克拉维钦琴乐曲都采用了这种两声部结构。十七世纪的组曲通常由四五首或更多首这样的乐曲组成，这些乐曲带有某种舞曲形式。组曲中最常见的舞曲是阿勒曼德舞曲、库朗特舞曲、萨拉班德舞曲和吉格舞曲。较少使用的舞曲包括加沃特舞曲、布列舞曲、帕斯皮舞曲和洛雷舞曲。（这种早期组曲类型不应与现代组曲混淆，现代组曲只不过是一些比奏鸣曲或交响曲乐章更轻快的乐曲的集合。）

The two-part form was utilized in thousands of short pieces for clavecin, written during the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries. The seventeenth-century type of suite was comprised of four or five or more of such pieces, which were in some species of dance form. The dances most usually included in the suite are the allemande, the courante, the saraband, and the gigue. Not so often used are the gavotte, bourrée, passepied, and louré. (This early type of suite is not to be confused with the modern suite which is nothing more than a collection of pieces lighter in character than the movements of a sonata or symphony.)

作为两部曲式的例子，建议读者听听弗朗索瓦·库普兰或多梅尼科·斯卡拉蒂的作品。 （推荐听万达·兰多夫斯卡录制的这两位作曲家的作品。）库普兰（1668 年至 1733 年）出版了四本大键琴小品集，其中包含一些法国人创作的最优秀的音乐。这些小品的标题常常很奇特，例如《神秘的街垒》或《双胞胎》或《小苍蝇》。这最后一篇作品（Le Moucheron）是两部曲式的一个特别好的例子。《小伙子》也是如此，它还是 18 世纪智慧和精神的光辉典范。在《温柔的语言》中可以发现一些当今法国音乐的感性。库普兰在这种微型形式的界限内创造了一个微妙的感觉世界。

As examples of two-part form, the reader is urged to hear pieces by François Couperin or Domenico Scarlatti. (Recordings by Wanda Landowska of both composers are recommended.) Couperin, who lived from 1668 to 1733, published four books of clavecin pieces, containing some of the finest music ever written by a Frenchman. They often are titled fancifully, for example, The Mysterious Barricades or Twins or The Little Fly. This last piece (Le Moucheron) is a particularly fine example of two-part form. So is La Commère, which is, besides, a brilliant example of eighteenth-century wit and esprit. Something of the sensuosity of present-day French music will be found in Les langeurs tendres. Couperin created a world of subtle feeling within the limits of this miniature form.

多梅尼科·斯卡拉蒂（1685-1757）是意大利的库普兰。他创作了数百首两部曲，均归类为奏鸣曲，但这些作品无论在形式还是情感上都与后期奏鸣曲毫无共同之处。斯卡拉蒂的个性鲜明地体现在他创作的每一部作品中。他偏爱华丽华丽的键板琴作品，跳跃和交叉双手的演奏具有真正的器乐风格。他大胆运用和声，这在当时的作曲家中被认为是大胆的。（许多和声被19世纪的学院派编辑“淡化”了。）如此丰富的作品中，很难选出合适的例子。在隆戈版本中，奏鸣曲 第413号（D小调）、第104号（C大调）和第338号（G小调）均位列其最杰出的作品之列。

Domenico Scarlatti (1685-1757) is the Italian counterpart of Couperin. He composed hundreds of pieces in two-part form, all under the generic name of sonata, though they have nothing in common with the later sonata either in form or in feeling. Scarlatti’s personality is strongly evident in everything he wrote. He had a penchant for brilliant, showy clavecin writing, with large skips and crossing of hands in true instrumental style. Nor was he afraid of using harmonies that must have struck his contemporaries as daring. (Many of these harmonies were “toned down” by academic editors of the nineteenth century.) It is difficult to choose examples from so great a profusion of riches. In the Longo edition, Sonatas No. 413 (D minor), No. 104 (C major), and No. 338 (G minor) are among his finest works.

第二种分段式是三段式，用公式ABA表示。我们已经了解了如何根据aba构建乐曲的小单元。现在，我们有必要结合乐曲的整体结构来演示它。

The second type of sectional form is three-part form, represented by the formula A-B-A. We have already seen how the small unit of a piece may be built according to a-b-a. Now it is necessary to demonstrate it in relation to a piece as a whole.

三部分表格

THREE-PART FORM

就三部曲式而言，我们讨论的是一种至今仍被作曲家沿用的结构类型。其中最清晰的早期例子是海顿或莫扎特的小步舞曲。其中的B部分（有时被称为“三重奏”）与A部分形成鲜明对比。它有时几乎像一首独立的小曲，两边都被第一部分所包围：小步舞曲-三重奏-小步舞曲。当回到第一部分是精确重复时，作曲家不会费心将其重新写出来，而只是注明“da capo”（从头开始）。但当回到第一部分时，如果出现变化，则必须写出第三部分。

In the case of three-part form, we are dealing with a type of construction that is in continual use by composers today. Among the clearest early examples are the minuets of Haydn or Mozart. Here the B section—sometimes labeled “trio”—is in distinct contrast to the A section. It is sometimes almost like an independent little piece, bounded on both sides by the first part: minuet-trio-minuet. When the return to the first section was exact repetition, composers did not trouble to write it out again but merely indicated “da capo” (from the beginning). But when the return is varied, the third section must be written out.

小步舞曲及其三部曲式逐渐改变了其特征，即使在所谓的古典作曲家中也是如此。海顿本人开启了小步舞曲的转型，从一种简单的舞蹈形式最终演变为贝多芬的谐谑曲。事实上，很少有比小步舞曲向谐谑曲的转变更能体现形式模式的逐渐扩展的例子了。ABA（三部曲）的轮廓保持不变，但其特征却发生了彻底的转变。在贝多芬的手中，优雅庄重的小步舞曲变成了唐突而异想天开的谐谑曲-快板，与缓慢的前奏乐章形成了鲜明的对比。

The minuet, and with it the three-part form, gradually changed its character, even among so-called classical composers. Haydn himself began the transformation of the minuet from a simple dance form to what finally became the Beethoven scherzo. In fact, there are few better examples of the gradual expansion of a formal pattern than this metamorphosis of minuet to scherzo. The outline A-B-A remained the same, but the character became transformed completely. In Beethoven’s hands, the graceful and dignified minuet turned into the brusque and whimsical scherzo-allegro which contrasts so well with the slow preceding movement.

贝多芬本人对这种形式做出了一项重要改变，后来的作曲家也采用了这一改变。在早期的小步舞曲和谐谑曲中，第一部分和第二部分的结尾通常有一种完整的结束感。然而，后期这种形式的例子用桥段将A部分连接到B部分；同样，在返回时，将B 部分连接到A 部分，从而产生更强的连续感。这种趋势在大多数音乐形式中都会发现；在需要更强的连续流畅感之前，不同部分的分界点往往会消失。从听众的角度来看，明显的分界线更容易跟随，但形式的更高发展带来了对不间断的更长线条的需求。

One important alteration was made in the form by Beethoven himself and adopted by composers who followed him. It was usual to have, in the earlier minuets and scherzos, a complete sense of close at the end of both first and second parts. Later examples of the form, however, connect the A section by a bridge passage to the B section; and likewise, on the return, B to A, thereby creating a greater impression of continuity. This tendency will be found in most forms in music; the demarcation points of separate sections tend to melt away before the need for a greater impression of continuous flow. Definitely marked divisions are easier to follow from the listener’s vantage point, but the higher development of form brings with it the need for the manipulation of an uninterrupted and longer line.

这是海顿弦乐四重奏作品17号第5首小步舞曲的典型插图。其划分清晰：

Here is a typical illustration of the Haydn Minuet from the String Quartet, Op. 17, No. 5. The divisions are clearly marked:

想要欣赏现代小步舞曲的典范，我推荐《库普兰之墓》中的拉威尔小步舞曲。这首曲子由六首钢琴小品组成，后来由作曲家改编成管弦乐。它保留了典型的ABA调式，但有以下区别：回到A部分时，巧妙地同时使用了A和B调；最后添加了一个相当精妙的尾声。但小步舞曲的曲式基本保持不变。

For a modern example of minuet form, I can recommend the Ravel Minuet from Le tombeau de Couperin, a set of six piano pieces, which were later orchestrated by the composer. The typical A-B-A form is present, with these differences: The return to the A section is made up of an ingenious combination of both A and B at the same time; and a fairly elaborate coda is added at the end. But nothing essential to the form of the minuet has been changed.

现在让我们看看贝多芬如何处理小步舞曲。让我们以钢琴奏鸣曲（作品 27 号，第 2 号）中的同一谐谑曲为例，其第一页已在上一章进行分析。在分析整个谐谑曲时，发现第一页本身是: a : -ba，因此算作更大的ABA公式中的A部分。为了形成对比， B部分（三重奏）的质量更为持久。谐谑曲的任何中间部分几乎都是如此，并且使各个部分易于区分。返回A是精确的重复。

Now let us see what Beethoven did with the minuet form. Let us take as illustration the same Scherzo from the Piano Sonata, Op. 27, No. 2, the first page of which was analyzed in the preceding chapter. In analyzing the Scherzo as a whole, that first page, which itself was found to be : a :-b-a, counts as A of the larger A-B-A formula. The B section—the Trio—is more sustained in quality, for the sake of contrast. This is almost always true of any middle part of a scherzo and makes the divisions easily distinguishable. The return to the A is an exact repetition.

如果演奏得慢一些，这首谐谑曲可能会被认为是一首小步舞曲，但奏鸣曲作品 27 号第 1 号中的谐谑曲却并非如此。它具有贝多芬式的暴风雨般的特质，完全脱离了最初构成这种形式的庄严小步舞曲的风格。如果写一个通常持续对比类型的B部分， A部分的氛围就会被破坏。有趣的是，贝多芬是如何做到既写出对比部分，又保持第一部分那种忙乱、沸腾的特质的。回到A部分时，节奏中出现了轻微的切分音，这有助于强调暴风雨般的氛围。

Played slowly, this particular Scherzo might conceivably be a minuet, but that is not true of the Scherzo of the Sonata, Op. 27, No. 1. The Beethoven-like, stormy character completely removes it from the stately minuet that originated the form. To have written a B section of the usual sustained and contrasted type would have dissipated the mood of the A section. It is interesting to see how Beethoven manages both to write a contrasting section and yet to keep up the hectic, seething character of the first part. The return to the A is varied by a slight syncopation in the rhythm, which serves to emphasize the stormy mood.

三部曲式，略加改编，是无数作品的通用类型，其名称各异。其中一些最为人熟知的有：夜曲、摇篮曲、叙事曲、挽歌、圆舞曲、练习曲、随想曲、即兴曲、间奏曲、玛祖卡舞曲、波兰舞曲等等。当然，这些作品不一定是三部曲式，但它们很可能是。务必留意对比鲜明的中间部分以及某种形式的回归开头。这些是三部曲式的显著特征。

Three-part form, with slight adaptations, is the generic type form for innumerable pieces, variously named. Some of the most familiar are: nocturne, berceuse, ballade, elegy, waltz, étude, capriccio, impromptu, intermezzo, mazurka, polonaise, etc. These are not, of course, necessarily three-part in form, but they certainly are likely to be. Always watch for the contrasted middle part and some kind of return to the beginning. Those are the unmistakable earmarks of the three-part form.

篇幅所限，仅举一例：肖邦第十五号前奏曲，降D大调。这是ABA曲式“改编”的绝佳范例。在平静而持续的情绪第一部分之后，是B部分，相比之下，它更具戏剧性，也更具“威胁性”。它展现出一种趋势，这种趋势后来变得越来越频繁，即利用两者共同的元素，例如节奏或旋律音型（在本例中是一个重复音符），将B部分与A部分连接起来。如此处理后， B部分似乎从第一部分衍生而出，而不仅仅是一个独立的、形成对比的部分，后者或许同样适合其他作品。这首前奏曲中回到A部分的段落被大大缩短了。肖邦仿佛在对听众说：“你还记得第一部分的情绪。带你回溯几小节，就足以让你感受到整体，而不必费心演奏完整个乐段。”这是本文很好的心理推理，增加了形式处理的原创性和简洁性。

Limitation of space forbids the pointing out of more than one illustration: the Chopin Prelude No. 15, in D flat. This is an excellent example of “adaptation” of the A-B-A form. After a first part of quiet and sustained mood comes the B part, which is more dramatic and “threatening,” by way of contrast. It demonstrates a tendency, which later became more and more frequent, to find a way of connecting the B to the A by utilizing some element common to both, such as a rhythmic or melodic figure (in this case, a repeated note). Treated thus, the B section seems to grow out of the first part instead of being merely an independent and contrasted section, which might conceivably belong to some other piece equally well. The return to the A in this Prelude is very much shortened. It is as if Chopin said to the listener: “You remember the mood of this first part. Taking you back for a few measures will suffice to give you a feeling of the whole without bothering to play it all the way through.” That is good psychological reasoning in this particular piece and adds to both the originality and the conciseness of the formal treatment.

回旋曲

THE RONDO

第三种重要的基于分段原理的曲式是回旋曲。它可以很容易地简化为“ABACADA ”等形式。因此，任何回旋曲的典型特征都是在每次离题之后回到主旋律。主旋律至关重要；离题的次数和长度并不重要。离题提供对比和平衡；这是它们的主要功能。回旋曲有不同类型，有快有慢。但最常见的类型是奏鸣曲的最终乐章——轻快、欢快、富有歌唱性。

The third important type form which bases itself on the sectional principle is that of the rondo. It is easily reduced to the formula A-B-A-C-A-D-A, etc. The typical feature of any rondo, therefore, is the return to the principal theme after every digression. The main theme is the important thing; the number or length of the digressions is immaterial. The digressions provide contrast and balance; that is their principal function. There are different types of rondo form, both slow and fast. But the most usual type is that found as final movement of a sonata—light, cheerful, and songlike.

回旋曲是一种非常古老的音乐形式，但它远未失去其实用价值。在库普兰的音乐以及美国作曲家沃尔特·皮斯顿的最新作品中都能找到例子。在早期的例子中——甚至包括海顿和莫扎特的时代——各个部分之间的划分都非常清晰。但在这里，再次强调，这种曲式运用的后期发展倾向于打破界限，因此我们可以坦诚地说，回旋曲的本质特质在于创造一种不间断的流畅感。无论音乐是新是旧，这种流畅的风格都是回旋曲特质的根本。

The rondo is a very old musical form, but it has far from outlived its usefulness. Examples may be found in the music of Couperin as well as in the latest work of the American Walter Piston. In early examples—even up to and including the time of Haydn and Mozart—the divisions between sections were clearly marked. But here, again, later developments in the use of the form tend to break down demarcation points, so that one may truthfully say that the essential quality of the rondo is the creation of an uninterrupted sense of flow. That smoothly flowing style is fundamental to the rondo character, whether the music is old or new.

早期回旋曲的一个绝佳例证是海顿《 D大调第九钢琴奏鸣曲》的最后一个乐章的轮廓（参见117-118页）。请注意一个非常重要的特征：A音每次回归时都会有所变化，即使重复多次，也依然能带来新的趣味。后期回旋曲每次回归时，A音都会呈现出不同的版本。

A fine illustration of the early rondo is the outline of the last movement of the Haydn Piano Sonata, No. 9, in D major (see pages 117-118). Notice a very important feature, the fact that each time the A returns, it is varied, which makes for new interest despite the numerous repetitions. Later rondos invariably show different versions of A each time that it returns.

现代回旋曲的例子可以在鲁塞尔、米约、兴德米特、斯特拉文斯基、勋伯格等人的作品中找到。施特劳斯的著名例子是蒂尔·欧伦施皮格尔的《快乐的恶作剧》，它过于复杂，如果不进行专门的分析就无法掌握。

Numerous examples of modern rondos will be found in the works of Roussel, Milhaud, Hindemith, Stravinsky, Schoenberg, etc. The famous example from Strauss, Till Eulenspiegel’s Merry Pranks, is too complex to be grasped without special analysis.

免费剖面图

FREE SECTIONAL FORM

第四种，也是最后一种，乐段构建类型不能简化为任何一种公式，因为它允许任意的乐段自由编排，使其组合成一个连贯的整体。任何符合音乐意义的编排方式都是可行的，例如ABB或ABCA或ABACABA 。第一种是肖邦《C 小调前奏曲》第 20 号的公式；最后一种是舒曼《童年场景》中名为《惊恐》的乐段的公式。舒曼的这首乐曲尤其容易理解，因为每个乐段都很短，而且各有特色。

The fourth, and final, type of sectional build-up cannot be reduced to any one formula, because it allows for any free arrangement of sections which together make a coherent whole. Any arrangement that makes musical sense is possible, for instance A-B-B or A-B-C-A or A-B-A-C-A-B-A. The first is the formula of the Chopin Prelude in C minor, No. 20; the last is that of the piece called Frightening from Schumann’s Scenes from Childhood . It is particularly easy to follow in the Schumann piece, because each section is so short and so different in character.

贝拉·巴托克的《组曲》 Op. 14 的第一和第二乐章是现代作曲家采用的非传统方式编排各个部分的一个典型例子。

A good example of an unconventional arrangement of various sections, as used by a modern composer, is Béla Bartók’s Suite, Op. 14, in the first and second movements.

 

 

D. 斯卡拉蒂——奏鸣曲选段

D. Scarlatti—Selections from his Sonatas

伊戈尔·基普尼斯 (大键琴) (索尼)

Igor Kipnis (harpsichord) (Sony)

海顿——四重奏，作品17

Haydn—Quartets, Opus 17

塔特莱四重奏（匈牙利）

Tatrai Quartet (Hungaroton)

贝多芬——E大调奏鸣曲，作品27，第1号

Beethoven—Sonata in E flat, Opus 27, No. 1

阿尔弗雷德·布伦德尔（飞利浦）

Alfred Brendel (Philips)

肖邦—前奏曲

Chopin—Preludes

阿瑟·鲁宾斯坦（RCA）

Arthur Rubinstein (RCA)

巴托克——钢琴组曲

Bartók—Suite for Piano

贝拉·巴托克（Angel-EMI）

Béla Bartók (Angel-EMI)

11

11

基本形式

Fundamental Forms

二、变更形式

II. VARIATION FORM

固定低音；帕萨卡利亚；恰空；

主题与变奏

Basso Ostinato; Passacaglia; Chaconne;

Theme and Variations

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

变奏曲式很好地体现了听众在音乐形式方面预期​​听到的内容和预期听不到的内容。也就是说，如果认为听众第一次听到变奏曲式时，能够准确地听到每个变奏，那就太愚蠢了。然而，即使听众无法详细理解每个变奏的运作方式，了解其大致轮廓对他来说也具有相当大的价值。只要稍加准备，就能相对轻松地听出任何变奏曲式的大致轮廓，无论作品是古典作品还是现代作曲家的作品。

The variation forms well exemplify what the listener is expected to hear and what he is not expected to hear, as regards form in music. That is to say, it would be foolish to imagine that any listener, when hearing a variation form for the first time, hears it with any degree of exactitude as regards each separate variation. Nevertheless, it is of considerable value to him to know the general outlines, even though he is unable to follow the working out of each individual variation in detail. With a little preparation, it is comparatively easy to hear the general outlines of any variation form, whether the work is that of a classic or that of a modern composer.

在进一步探讨之前，读者需要注意，音乐中的变奏有两个不同的方面，切勿混淆。第一个方面是变奏作为一种音乐手法，纯粹是偶然运用的。也就是说，音乐中的任何元素都可以变奏——任何和声、任何旋律、任何节奏。同样，变奏作为一种手法，可以暂时应用于任何曲式——组曲、奏鸣曲、赋格曲等等。事实上，它是一种如此基本的手法，以至于作曲家们不断地依赖它，几乎不假思索地运用它。但第二个方面也不容忽视——变奏在不同变奏形式中的运用，它是唯一且独一无二的形式原则。我打算在这里探讨的正是这第二个方面。

Before going further, the reader should be warned that the variation in music has two different aspects and that they must not be confused. The first aspect is that of the variation used as a device in music, in a purely incidental way. That is, any of the elements in music may be varied—any harmony, any melody, any rhythm. Likewise, the variation as a device may be applied momentarily to any form—sectional, sonata, fugal, etc. It is a device so fundamental, in fact, that composers fall back on it continuously and apply it almost without thinking. But the second aspect must not be lost sight of—the variation as used in the different variation forms proper, where it is the sole and exclusive formal principle. It is this second aspect that I propose to treat here.

音乐中的变奏原理由来已久。它如此自然地融入这门艺术，以至于很难想象它曾经被摒弃的时代。即使在帕莱斯特里纳时代以及更早，在声乐盛行的时代，旋律变奏的原理在音乐实践中也已根深蒂固。16世纪大师的弥撒曲通常完全基于单一旋律，并在弥撒的各个部分以变奏形式运用。虽然变奏原理最初应用于旋律，但英国维金纳琴作曲家很快就将其改编为器乐风格，通过改变和声框架，其方式与如今大致相同。事实上，这些早期英国大师对这种新技巧的运用过于频繁，以至于它变得相当乏味；它与其说是一种正式的原则，不如说是一种纯粹的公式。任何人都可以选一个主题，写出十个变奏，其中充满了奔跑、颤音和大量的音型，而这些音型本身并无多大趣味。当然，对于那个时期的最佳范例来说情况并非如此，比如伯德对《卡门的汽笛》的变奏。

The principle of variation in music is a very old one. It belongs to the art so naturally that it would be hard to imagine a time when it was not being used. Even in Palestrina’s day, and before, when vocal music was paramount, the principle of varying a melody was well established in musical practice. A Mass by a sixteenth-century master was often based entirely on a single melody which was used in a varied form in each of the separate parts of the Mass. Though the variation principle was first applied melodically, the English virginal composers soon adapted it to instrumental style by varying the harmonic framework in much the same way that it is done nowadays. In fact, these early English masters used this new device to such an extent that it became rather tiresome; it became not so much a formal principle as a mere formula. Anybody could take a theme and write ten variations on it full of runs and trills and a profusion of figurations, which were not in themselves overly interesting. Naturally, that isn’t true of the best examples of the period, such as Byrd’s variations on The Carman’s Whistle.

从那时起，几乎没有哪段时期作曲家不采用变奏曲式创作。作为一种基本模式，它被古典音乐大师海顿和莫扎特、早期浪漫主义大师贝多芬和舒伯特以及后期浪漫主义大师舒曼和勃拉姆斯反复使用。如今，变奏曲式依然盛行，施特劳斯的名作《堂吉诃德》、埃尔加的《谜语变奏曲》、丹第的《伊斯塔尔变奏曲》，以及更近代的斯特拉文斯基的八重奏、兴德米特的《天鹅之恋》、罗伊·哈里斯的弦乐四重奏（《一个主题的三个变奏曲》）都证明了这一点。如果需要证明的话，这应该可以证明变奏曲式在音乐史上的地位；作曲家不太可能完全放弃它们。

Since that time there has hardly been a period during which composers have not written in the variation form. As a basic mold it was repeatedly used by the classical Haydn and Mozart, the early romantics Beethoven and Schubert, and the later romanticists Schumann and Brahms. It flourishes today, as ever, as witness the famous Don Quixote of Strauss, the Enigma Variations of Elgar, the Istar Variations of D’Indy, or to come to more recent times, the Octet of Stravinsky, the Schwanendreher of Hindemith, the string quartet (Three Variations on a Theme) of Roy Harris. This should be proof, if proof were needed, that the variation forms are fundamental in musical history; and it is unlikely that composers will ever completely abandon them.

低音固定音型

BASSO OSTINATO

在四种变奏形式中，低音固定音型（basso ostinato）或称基础低音（ground bass）是最容易辨认的。与其说它是一种音乐形式，不如说它是一种音乐技巧。字面意思是“顽固的低音”，这或多或少准确地描述了它的本质。低音部分会反复重复一个简短的乐句——可以是伴奏音型，也可以是一段真实的旋律，而高音部分则正常进行。它为创作1920年代的“现代音乐”提供了一种简便的方法，左手始终以相同的方式演奏，右手则任其发展。或许正因为如此，低音固定音型一度对新一代作曲家产生了过于强烈的吸引力。

Of the four types of variation forms, the basso ostinato, or ground bass, is the easiest to recognize. It might more properly be termed a musical device than a musical form. Literally translated, it means an “obstinate bass,” which is more or less an exact description of what it is. A short phrase—either an accompanimental figure or an actual melody—is repeated over and over again in the bass part, while the upper parts proceed normally. It provides an easy method for writing “modern music” of the 1920 vintage, the left hand continuing always in the same way, and the right hand left to its own devices. Perhaps because of that, for a time the basso ostinato exerted too strong a charm on the newer composers.

现在让我们来看看不同时期低音固定音型的练习示例。最简单的版本是那些低音部分仅仅是伴奏音型的版本。西贝柳斯的钢琴田园曲就呈现了这样的音型：9

Now let us examine illustrations of the basso ostinato as it was practiced at different periods. The simplest versions are those in which the ground bass is little more than an accompanimental figure. The Pastorale for piano of Sibelius presents such a figure:9

另一个更近的例子是阿图尔·奥涅格 (Arthur Honegger) 著名清唱剧《大卫王》中的《送葬曲》。10在这里，固定低音也只是一个音型，非常适合上部辛辣的音调变化：

Another, and more recent, example is the Cortège from Arthur Honegger ’s well-known oratorio King David.10 Here, too, the ostinato bass is a mere figure, which lends itself well to the piquant tonal changes of the upper part:

请注意，一旦低音在您的意识中牢固确立，它在某种程度上可能会被视为理所当然，从而允许更加专注于剩余的材料。

Note that once the ground bass is firmly established in your consciousness, it may, to a certain extent, be taken for granted, thereby permitting a greater concentration on the remaining material.

十七世纪的音乐中有很多优美的例证。这是蒙特威尔第最后的作品之一，创作于1642年，名为《波佩亚的加冕》。在这首作品中，低音部分不再仅仅是一个音型，而是一个真正意义上的旋律。

Many beautiful illustrations may be culled from music of the seventeenth century. Here is one from Monteverdi’s last works, written in 1642, The Coronation of Poppea. In this case, the ground bass is no longer a mere figure; it is a real melody in its own right.

亨利·珀塞尔是英国历史上最伟大的作曲家之一，他生活在十七世纪末，尤其钟爱低音固定音型。他的作品中大量展现了这种手法的丰富运用。以下是他著名歌剧《狄多与埃涅阿斯》中一首名为《狄多的哀歌》的独唱曲。低音部分出人意料地具有半音阶，因此易于记忆，而其上方的和弦则散发着一种浪漫的光芒，这远超珀塞尔的时代。

Henry Purcell, one of the greatest composers England has ever produced, lived toward the end of the seventeenth century and was especially fond of the basso ostinato. His works show numerous illustrations of the most varied use of this device. Here is an example taken from his famous opera Dido and Aeneas, a solo song called “Dido’s Lament.” The ground bass is surprisingly chromatic and therefore easy to remember, and the chords above it have a romantic glow about them far in advance of Purcell’s period.

现代最佳范例之一是斯特拉文斯基哑剧《士兵的故事》中的第二首名为《士兵的小提琴》的乐曲。作曲家借助低音提琴的四个音符拨奏，描绘出一幅半悲怆半讽刺的画面，堪称现代音乐中最早、最精彩的幽默例证之一。[费利克斯·佩特雷克在他的《十一首儿童小品》（暂无录音）中，巧妙地运用了低音固定音型来营造幽默效果。]

One of the best of modern examples is the second number called the “Soldier’s Violin” from Stravinsky’s pantomime The Story of a Soldier. With the aid of four notes pizzicato in the double bass, the composer pens a half-pitiful, half-sarcastic picture which provides one of the earliest and best illustrations of humor in modern music. [Felix Petyrek makes effective use of the basso ostinato for humorous purposes in his Eleven Small Children’s Pieces (no recording available).]

帕萨卡利亚舞曲

THE PASSACAGLIA

帕萨卡利亚是第二种变奏形式。它与低音固定音型一样，整首乐曲都建立在重复的低音部分之上。但这一次，低音部分始终是一个旋律乐句，而非一个单纯的音型。正如我们即将看到的，与低音固定音型的逐字重复相比，它也可以有更多变化的处理方式。

The passacaglia is the second type of variation form. Here, again, as in the basso ostinato, an entire composition is founded upon a repeated bass part. But this time, the ground bass is invariably a melodic phrase, never a mere figure. It is also open to more varied treatment, as we shall soon see, than the literal repetitions of the basso ostinato.

帕萨卡利亚舞的起源鲜为人知。据说它是一种源自西班牙的四分之三拍的慢舞。无论如何，如今的帕萨卡利亚舞以及过去的帕萨卡利亚舞始终缓慢而庄重，保留了最初的四分之三拍子，尽管并非一成不变。但与这种舞蹈的所有联系都已消失。

The origin of the passacaglia is not too well known. It is said to have been a slow dance, in three-quarter time, of Spanish origin. At any rate, the present-day passacaglia, and those of the past, are always slow and dignified in character, retaining the original three-quarter time signature, although not invariably so. But all connection with the dance has been lost.

帕萨卡利亚舞曲总是以低音部无伴奏的主题陈述开始。由于这个主题构成了所有后续变奏的基础，因此至关重要的是，主题本身必须牢牢地印刻在听众的脑海中。因此，通常来说，在前几个变奏中，主题会在低音部重复出现，而高音部则开始轻柔地向前推进。

A passacaglia invariably begins with a statement of the theme unaccompanied, in the bass. Since it is this theme that is to form the foundation for all further variation, it is of paramount importance that the theme itself be well established in the mind of the listener. Therefore, as a rule, for the first few variations the theme is literally repeated in the bass, while the upper part begins a gentle forward movement.

一般来说，作曲家在处理帕萨卡利亚曲式时有两个目标。首先，随着每个新变奏的加入，主题必须以新的视角来看待。换句话说，作曲家的创造性想象力必须激发、维持并丰富人们对反复出现的低音部分的兴趣。其次，除了任何一个变奏本身的美感之外，所有变奏都必须合在一起，形成累积的动感，使整个曲式在心理上令人满意。这第二个目标自巴赫时代以来尤为重要。

Speaking generally, the composer has two objectives in treating the passacaglia form. First, with the addition of each new variation the theme must be seen in a new light. In other words, interest in the oft repeated ground bass must be aroused and sustained and added to by the composer’s creative imagination. Secondly, aside from the beauty of any one variation, taken alone, they must all together gather cumulative momentum, so that the form as a whole may be psychologically satisfying. This second objective has been particularly true since Bach’s time.

在最初的几个变奏之后，低音部分主题的逐字重复无需保留。最简单的技巧是将主题本身移至上部或中部，并反转其自然位置。其他技巧会暂时隐藏主题，尽管它肯定会以某些音型的低音音符或看似单纯和弦伴奏的低音音符的形式出现。将主题演奏得慢一倍或快一倍，或以对位法结合新的主题素材，在每种情况下都是为变奏创造可能性的合理技巧。

The literal repetitions of the theme in the bass need not be retained after the first few variations. The simplest device is to move the theme itself to an upper or middle part, inverting its natural position. Other devices momentarily conceal the theme, though it is surely present either as the bottom note of some figuration or as the bottom note of what may appear to be a mere chordal accompaniment. The theme played twice as slowly or twice as fast or contrapuntally combined with new thematic material is in each case a legitimate device for variation possibilities.

将不同的变奏组合成一个连贯的整体时，通常将几个类似模式的变奏组合在一起。这样可以使变奏之间的过渡更加流畅。自巴赫以来，人们通常通过简单地增加小节中的音符数量来实现累积效果，从而通过越来越快的节奏营造出高潮感。事实上，巴赫与前辈们对这种曲式的主要区别之一就在于他采用了越来越快的节奏来营造高潮，这种技巧后来被反复使用，而不仅仅是在帕萨卡利亚舞曲中。

In binding the different variations into a coherent whole, it is customary to group several variations of a similar pattern together. This affords smoother transitions from one type of variation to the next. Cumulative effect has often been achieved, from Bach’s time onward, by the simple process of increasing the number of notes in a measure, thereby creating a sense of climax through faster and faster motion. As a matter of fact, one of the main differences between Bach’s use of the form and that of his predecessors was this adoption of a faster and faster motion to build climaxes, a device that has since been used over and over again and not only in the passacaglia form.

在所有音乐文献中，最杰出的代表作之一，也是讨论音乐形式时总是被引用的，是巴赫的C小调帕萨卡利亚管风琴曲。它基于以下典型主题：

One of the finest examples in all musical literature, and one which is invariably quoted when the form is under discussion, is Bach’s great organ Passacaglia in C minor. It is based on the following characteristic theme:

强烈建议普通听众反复研读音符或录音，或两者兼而有之，因为很少有作品比认真聆听更值得。首先，必须牢记主题。其次，要记住，每次主题演奏一遍后，都会开始一个新的变奏。这起初可能会造成混淆，因为就像前两个变奏一样，除了第二个富有表现力的和声增强外，模式几乎完全相同。请注意，在第四个变奏中，乐章是如何开始加快的，从八分音符变为十六分音符。前四个变奏的主题保持不变；在第五变奏中，主题以一种伪装的形式，可以作为每个上行琶音的低音音符。在第八个变奏中，在和弦上方添加了一条新的对位线，其低音音符是主位音。在下一个变奏中，主题被移调到女高音声部，对位线位于其下方。尤其要注意结尾处，即赋格开始之前，主题逐渐增强的势头。 （赋格曲经常被写为帕萨卡利亚舞曲的结尾，但它们不会以任何方式影响形式本身。）

The lay listener is urged to study the notes or the recording or both many times, as few compositions will better repay careful listening. First, it is necessary to have the theme well in mind. Then to remember that a new variation begins each time the theme has been played through once. This may cause confusion at first, when, as in the first two variations, the pattern is almost identical, except for a heightening of the expressive harmonies in the second. Note how the movement begins to get faster in the fourth variation, changing from eighth notes to sixteenths. For the first four variations the theme remains exactly the same; in the fifth variation the theme, in a disguised version, may be found as the bottom note of each upward arpeggio. In the eighth variation, a new contrapuntal line is added above chords, the bottom note of which is thematic. In the next variation, the theme is transposed to the soprano part, with the contrapuntal line below it. Note particularly the gathering momentum at the end, just before the fugue begins. (Fugues are often written as the conclusion of a passacaglia, but they do not affect the form itself in any way.)

帕萨卡利亚舞曲在十九世纪曾一度被忽视。当时的作曲家在处理变奏曲式时似乎更倾向于创作主题和变奏。但现代作曲家也创作了帕萨卡利亚舞曲。拉威尔 为小提琴、大提琴和钢琴而作的三重奏的中间乐章就是一个很好的例子。阿尔班·贝尔格的歌剧《沃采克》和安东·韦伯恩的管弦乐帕萨卡利亚舞曲（作品1）都展现了这种舞曲的现代演绎。

The passacaglia was somewhat neglected during the nineteenth century. Composers during that period seemed to prefer writing the theme and variations when treating variation forms. But modern composers have written passacaglias. A good example is that of the middle movement of the Ravel Trio for violin, cello, and piano. Both Alban Berg in his opera Wozzeck and Anton Webern (Passacaglia for orchestra, Op. 1) show modern treatments of the form.

恰空舞曲

THE CHACONNE

恰空舞曲是第三种变奏曲式，与帕萨卡利亚舞曲关系密切。事实上，两者之间的区别非常细微，以至于理论家们有时会就某首乐曲应该被归类为帕萨卡利亚舞曲还是恰空舞曲（如果作曲家本人没有明确标注的话）展开激烈争论。一个典型的例子就是勃拉姆斯《第四交响曲》的最后一个乐章。一些评论家称之为帕萨卡利亚舞曲，另一些评论家则称之为恰空舞曲。由于勃拉姆斯只称其为第四乐章，因此这场争论可能还会持续很长时间。

The chaconne is the third type of variation form. It is very closely related to the passacaglia. In fact, the differences are so slight, that at times there has been considerable argument among theorists as to whether to label a piece a passacaglia or a chaconne, if the composer himself neglected to do so. The classic example of that is the last movement of Brahms’ Fourth Symphony. Some commentators refer to it as a passacaglia, and others as a chaconne. Since Brahms called it only the fourth movement, the argument will probably continue for a long time to come.

无论如何，恰空舞曲和帕萨卡利亚舞曲一样，最初很可能是一种四分之三拍的慢舞曲。它仍然保留着其庄重、庄重的特质。但与帕萨卡利亚舞曲不同的是，恰空舞曲并非以无伴奏的低音主题开场。相反，低音主题从一开始就伴随着和声的伴奏。这意味着低音主题并非像在帕萨卡利亚舞曲中那样占据着独一无二的重要地位；因为伴奏和声有时也会在恰空舞曲中发生变化。因此，恰空舞曲是帕萨卡利亚舞曲与主题和变奏之间的过渡，这一点我们稍后会谈到。

In any case, the chaconne, like the passacaglia, was in all likelihood originally a slow dance form in three-quarter time. It still retains its stately, sober character. But unlike the passacaglia, it does not begin with an unaccompanied bass theme. Instead, the bass theme is heard from the start with accompanying harmonies. This means that the bass theme is not given the exclusively important role to play that it occupies in the passacaglia; for the accompanying harmonies are also sometimes varied in the chaconne. So that the chaconne is a kind of stepping stone between the passacaglia and the theme and variations, as will appear presently.

以下是巴赫伟大先驱迪特里希·布克斯特胡德 (Dietrich Buxtehude) 创作的恰空主题：

Here is a chaconne theme from the great forerunner of Bach’s, Dietrich Buxtehude:

在这种情况下，正如你所见，低音部分的主题已经有了伴奏和声，所以这第一个句子听起来就像是帕萨卡利亚舞曲的第一个变奏。这就是混乱的开始。

In this case, as you see, the theme in the bass already has its accompanying harmonies, so that this first statement sounds as if it were the first variation of a passacaglia. That is where the confusion begins.

恰空曲式的现代典范是上文提到的勃拉姆斯交响曲的乐章，因为我自己也应该把它归入这一类别。可惜篇幅所限，无法进行任何详细的分析。简而言之，构成低音的主题最初听起来像是开头和弦的高音部分，而这些和弦本身在很多情况下也与主题一起保留下来。换句话说，恰空与帕萨卡利亚不同，它除了低音之外，还带有某种和声倾向。

The great modern example of the chaconne form is the movement of the Brahms symphony mentioned above, for it is in that category that I myself should list it. Unfortunately, space limitations prevent any detailed analysis. Suffice it to say that the theme which later constitutes the ground bass is first heard as the top part of the opening chords, which are themselves retained along with the theme in many instances. In other words, the chaconne, unlike the passacaglia, has something of a harmonic bias along with its ground bass.

主题与变奏

THEME AND VARIATIONS

主题变奏是变奏曲式中最后一种，也是最重要的一种。它的名声已经超越了纯音乐的范畴，类似于赋格曲式，并被用来为诗歌和小说命名。

The theme and variations is the last, and most important, of the variation forms. Its fame has spread beyond the realm of absolute music, something in the manner of the fugue form, and has been used to title poems and novels.

变奏所采用的主题要么是作曲家原创的，要么是从其他地方借用的。通常，主题本身的特点是简单直接的。最好是这样，以便听众在变奏开始之前就能听到最简单的版本。读者必须记住，主题和变奏，像许多其他形式一样，随着时间的推移变得越来越复杂。在前面的例子中，主题通常是清晰界定的两部分或三部分的小形式，其轮廓在随后的每个变奏中都保留下来。另一方面，各个变奏本身则松散地串联在一起，似乎只具有一般的平衡感和对比感作为形式原则。

The theme that is adopted for variation is either original with the composer or borrowed from some other source. As a rule, the theme itself is simple and direct in character. It is best to have it so in order that the listener may hear it in its simplest version before the varying process begins. The reader must keep in mind the fact that the theme and variations, like many other forms, became increasingly complex as time went on. In the earlier examples, the theme was usually in a clearly defined small two- or three-part form, the outlines of which were retained in each variation that followed. The separate variations themselves, on the other hand, were loosely strung together, seeming to possess as formal principle only a general sense of balance and contrast.

现代作曲家的做法则相反。作曲家在创作每个单独的变奏时，往往忽略了主题的轮廓，而是试图将所有主题组合成某种结构统一的整体。关于帕萨卡利亚曲式的论述——考虑到各个部分累积的效果而将其连接起来——对于主题和变奏来说更是如此。

Modern practice reverses this. The outlines of the theme with which the composer begins are often lost sight of in each separate variation, but a definite attempt is made to build all of them together into some semblance of structural unity. What was stated in this connection in relation to passacaglia form—the joining of the separate parts in view of their cumulative effect—is even more true of the theme and variations.

变奏有多种类型，几乎可以应用于任何主题。五种常见的变奏类型很容易区分：(1) 和声，(2) 旋律，(3) 节奏，(4) 对位，(5) 前四种类型的组合。没有任何教科书公式能够预见一位富有创造力的作曲家可能想到的所有变奏方案。甚至很难阐明我从任何一首曲子中选择的五个主要部分。为了便于说明，最好写出一些著名曲调的典型变奏方案的开头，例如《啊！你的爱人奥古斯丁》（见附录一）。

There are different types of variation which may be applied to practically any theme. Five general types may easily be distinguished: (1) harmonic, (2) melodic, (3) rhythmic, (4) contrapuntal, (5) a combination of all four previous types. No textbook formula could possibly foresee every kind of variation scheme that an inventive composer might hit upon. It is even difficult to illustrate the five main divisions I have chosen from any one piece. For purposes of illustration it seemed better to write out the beginnings of typical variation schemes for some well-known tune, such as Ach! du lieber Augustin (see Appendix I).

正如前文所述，这绝非穷尽任何单一主题几乎无限的变奏可能性。大多数作曲家习惯于在作品开头紧贴原主题，随着乐曲的推进逐渐赋予更多自由。通常，在乐曲的最后，主题会以原有的形式再次出现。这仿佛作曲家在说：“你看，我们曾经可以走多远；好吧，我们又回到了起点。”

As has already been said, this by no means exhausts the almost limitless possibilities for the variation of any single theme. It is customary with most composers to stay rather close to the original theme at the beginning of a composition, taking more and more liberties as the piece progresses. Very often, at the very end, the theme is stated once again in its original form. It is as if the composer were saying: “You see how far away it was possible to go; well, here we are back again where we started.”

音乐文献中充斥着大量的主题和变奏，提及任何具体的例子都显得多余。尽管如此，我还是强烈建议读者听听莫扎特的 A 大调钢琴奏鸣曲的第一乐章，该乐章由一个主题和六个变奏组成。请注意，六个变奏中的每一个都保留了主题的正式轮廓。变奏 1 是华丽旋律型变奏的典范；变奏 4 则是和声的骨架化。第三个变奏体现了古典大师所钟爱的一个小技巧，其中和声从大调变为小调。从听众的角度来看，重要的是要注意每个新变奏的开头，以便您脑海中对乐曲的划分方式与作曲家在创作时在脑海中划分的方式相同。

Musical literature is so generously supplied with themes and variations that the mentioning of any particular example would seem almost superfluous. Nevertheless, I strongly advise the reader to hear the first movement of Mozart’s A major Piano Sonata, which is in the form of a theme and six variations. Note that the formal outline of the theme is retained in each of the six variations. Variation 1 is a good example of the florid-melodic type of variation; variation 4, of the skeletonizing of the harmony. One small device, dear to the classic masters, is exemplified by the third variation, where the harmony is changed from major to minor. From the listener’s standpoint, it is important to be conscious of the beginning of each new variation, so that the piece is split up in your mind in the same way that it was divided in the composer’s mind at the moment of composition.

舒曼被广泛引用的《交响练习曲》和加布里埃尔·福莱不太知名但令人钦佩的主题与变奏曲是十九世纪的优秀例子，但比莫扎特的复杂得多。

Excellent nineteenth-century examples, but of a much greater complexity than the Mozart, are Schumann’s much quoted Etudes Symphoniques and the less well-known but admirable Theme and Variations of Gabriel Fauré.

一个有趣的现代例子，包含变奏曲式本身的细微变奏，即斯特拉文斯基八重奏的中间乐章。这里，我们并没有采用通常的A-Aʹ -Aʺ-Aʹʹʹ-Aʹʹʹʹ 等结构，而是采用了这样的结构： A-Aʹ -Aʺ-Aʹʹʹ-Aʹʹʹ-Aʹʹʹʹ-Aʹ-A。这里奇特之处在于，作曲家在经过几次变奏之后，并没有像回旋曲式那样每次都回到主题本身，而是回到主题的第一个变奏。

An interesting modern example, containing a slight variation of the variation form itself, is the middle movement of Stravinsky’s Octet. Here, instead of the usual scheme: A-Aʹ-Aʺ-Aʹʹʹ-Aʹʹʹʹ, etc., we get this plan: A-Aʹ-Aʺ-Aʹ-Aʹʹʹ-Aʹʹʹʹ-Aʹ-A. The curious feature here is that the composer, after a few variations, does not return each time to the theme itself (as in the rondo form) but to the first variation of the theme.

作者本人创作的《钢琴变奏曲》（1930）基于一个相对较短的主题，它一反常态，将主题的最简版本放在了第二位，而严格来说，第一个变奏被称为“主题”。这样做的目的是先为听众呈现一个更震撼的主题版本，这似乎更符合整部作品的戏剧性特征。

The author’s own Piano Variations (1930), based on a comparatively short theme, reverses the usual procedure by putting the simplest version of the theme second, calling what is, properly speaking, a first variation a “theme.” The idea was to present the listener with a more striking version of the theme first, which seemed more in keeping with the generally dramatic character of the composition as a whole.

 

 

西贝柳斯—钢琴音乐

Sibelius—Piano Music

拉尔夫·戈托尼（Ondine）

Ralf Gothoni (Ondine)

珀塞尔—— 《狄多与埃涅阿斯》

Purcell—Dido and Aeneas

洛林·亨特，巴洛克爱乐乐团（Harmonia Mundi）

Lorraine Hunt, Philharmonia Baroque (Harmonia Mundi)

斯特拉文斯基—— 《士兵的故事》

Stravinsky—The Soldier’s Tale

杰拉德·施瓦茨，洛杉矶室内乐团（Delos）

Gerard Schwarz, Los Angeles Chamber Orchestra (Delos)

巴赫——管风琴帕萨卡利亚舞曲

Bach—Passacaglia for Organ

玛丽·克莱尔·阿兰（埃拉托）

Marie-Claire Alain (Erato)

科普兰——帕萨卡利亚钢琴曲

Copland—Passacaglia for Piano

Leo Smit（索尼）

Leo Smit (Sony)

科普兰——钢琴变奏曲

Copland—Piano Variations

大卫·尼尔·琼斯（Amphion）

David Neil Jones (Amphion)

莫扎特——A大调钢琴奏鸣曲，K.331

Mozart—Piano Sonata in A, K. 331

内田光子（飞利浦）

Mitsuko Uchida (Philips)

12

12

基本形式

Fundamental Forms

三、赋格形式

III. FUGAL FORM

赋格曲；大协奏曲；合唱前奏曲；

经文歌和牧歌

Fugue; Concerto Grosso; Chorale Prelude;

Motets and Madrigals

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

第一章开篇就提出了这样一个前提：要学会更明智地聆听，反复聆听大量的音乐至关重要；无论读多少书都无法取代这种聆听。书中的论述尤其适用于赋格曲式。如果你真心想了解这些曲式的内涵，你必须愿意反复研读。赋格曲式比任何其他曲式都更需要反复聆听，才能让门外汉充分理解。

Chapter 1 began with the premise that it was essential, in learning to listen more intelligently, to hear a great deal of music over and over again; and that no amount of reading could possibly replace that listening. What was written there is especially true in regard to fugal forms. If you really wish to hear what goes on in these forms, you must be willing to go after them again and again. More than any other formal mold, fugal forms demand repeated hearings if they are to be fully heard by the layman.

任何被归类为赋格曲式的作品，都在某种程度上带有赋格的特质。我相信你已经知道，所有赋格曲的织体都是复音的或对位的（这两个术语含义相同）。因此，所有赋格曲式的织体都是复音的或对位的。

Whatever comes under the heading of fugal form partakes in some way of the nature of a fugue. You already know, I feel sure, that in texture all fugues are polyphonic or contrapuntal (the terms are identical in meaning). Therefore, it follows that all fugal forms are polyphonic or contrapuntal in texture.

此时，读者不妨回顾一下第八章中关于复音聆听的内容。那里提到，复音聆听音乐意味着听众能够同时听到不同的旋律。各个部分不必同等重要，但必须独立聆听。这并非难事；任何智力一般的人，只要稍加练习，就能同时听到多个旋律。无论如何，这是明智聆听赋格曲式的必要条件。

At this point, the reader might do well to review what was said in Chapter 8 about listening polyphonically. It was stated there that hearing music polyphonically implies a listener who can hear separate strands of melody simultaneously. The parts need not be of equal importance, but they must be heard independently. This is no great feat; any person of average intelligence can, with a little practice, hear more than one melody at a time. At any rate, it is the sine qua non of intelligent listening to fugal forms.

赋格曲主要有四种形式：第一，赋格本身；第二，大协奏曲；第三，众赞歌前奏曲；第四，经文歌和牧歌。毋庸置疑，对位写作并不仅限于这些形式。正如变奏原理被认为适用于任何形式一样，对位织体几乎可以在任何形式中无需准备地出现。换句话说，随时准备好聆听复音乐曲。

The four principal fugal forms are: first, the fugue proper; second, the concerto grosso; third, the chorale-prelude; fourth, motets and madrigals. It goes without saying that contrapuntal writing is not confined to these forms alone. Just as the principle of variation was seen to be applicable to any form, so in the same way a contrapuntal texture may occur without preparation in almost any form. Be ready, in other words, to listen polyphonically at any moment.

复调织体中总会用到一些著名的对位技巧。它们并非总是存在，但可能会出现，因此听众必须留意。其中最简单的技巧有：模仿、卡农、倒置、增、减。更难懂的是蟹行式（cancrizan，蟹行式）和倒置的蟹行式。其中一些技巧隐藏在复杂的对位织体中，理解起来相当困难。我现在指出这些技巧，更多是为了完整性，而不是为了让你每次都能从一个例子中识别它们（参见附录二）。

A certain number of well-known contrapuntal devices are used whenever the texture is polyphonic. They are not invariably present, but they may put in an appearance, and so the listener must be on the lookout for them. The simplest of these devices are: imitation, canon, inversion, augmentation, diminution. More recondite are cancrizans (crab motion) and the inverted cancrizans. Some of these devices, enmeshed within the web of contrapuntal texture, are quite difficult to follow. I point them out now more for the sake of completeness than because you will learn from one single illustration to recognize them each time that they occur (see Appendix II).

模仿是所有技巧中最简单的。任何在学校唱过歌的人都知道模仿的含义。在玩一种“跟随领袖”的音乐游戏时，一个声音模仿另一个声音的动作。当在乐曲的过程中偶然使用时，这种技巧被称为“模仿”。这种非常自然的想法可以在很早的音乐和当代音乐中找到。最简单的模仿会营造出一种多声部音乐的假象，尽管实际上只发出一个旋律。模仿不必从原声带开始的同一个音符开始。在这种情况下，我们说模仿在“高四度”或“低二度”，表示模仿声音进入的音高。矛盾的是，你必须对位地聆听，尽管只涉及一个旋律。

Imitation is the simplest device of all. Anyone who has ever sung a round in school will know the meaning of imitation. Playing a kind of “follow-the-leader” musical game, one voice imitates what another voice does. When used incidentally during the course of a piece, this device is referred to as “imitation.” This perfectly natural idea may be found in very early music as well as in contemporary music. The simplest imitation sets up an illusion of many-voiced music, although only one melody is actually sounded. The imitation need not start on the same note with which the original voice begins. In such a case, we speak of imitation “at the fourth” above or “at the second” below, indicating the pitch at which the entrance of the imitating voice was made. Paradoxically, you have to listen contrapuntally, although only one melody is in question.

卡农只是一种更为精妙的模仿，其模仿从乐曲的开头到结尾都合乎逻辑地进行。换句话说，卡农可以说是一种形式，而模仿始终是一种技巧。十八世纪的音乐提供了无数的例子；过去一个世纪中被引用最多的例子是塞萨尔·弗兰克的小提琴奏鸣曲的最后一个乐章。最近，欣德米特以两支长笛奏鸣曲的形式创作了卡农。

Canon is merely a more elaborate species of imitation, in which the imitation is carried out logically from the beginning of a piece to the end. In other words, canon may be spoken of as a form, whereas imitation is always a device. Eighteenth-century music supplies numerous examples; the most quoted illustration of the past century is that of the last movement of César Franck’s Violin Sonata. Recently, Hindemith has written canons in the form of sonatas for two flutes.

转位不太容易识别。它就像把旋律倒过来一样。转位后的旋律总是朝着与原旋律相反的方向移动。也就是说，原旋律向上跳跃一个八度，转位后的旋律就会向下跳跃一个八度，以此类推。当然，并非所有旋律转位后都有意义。旋律转位是否符合音乐的合理性，取决于作曲家。

Inversion is not so easily recognized. It consists of turning a melody upside down, as it were. The melody inverted always moves in the opposite direction from the melody of its original version. That is, when the original leaps an octave upward, the inversion leaps an octave downward, and so forth. Of course, not all melodies make sense when inverted. It is up to the composer to decide whether or not the inversion of a melody is justified on musical grounds.

增音很容易解释。当你增一个主题时，音符的时值会加倍，从而使主题比原来慢一倍。（四分音符变成二分音符，二分音符变成全音符，等等。）减音与增音相反。它把音符的时值减半，使主题的移动速度比原来快一倍。（全音符变成二分音符，二分音符变成四分音符，等等。）

Augmentation is easily explained. When you augment a theme, you double the time value of the notes, thereby making the theme twice as slow as it originally was. (A quarter note becomes a half, a half note a whole, etc.) Diminution is the opposite of augmentation. It consists of halving the note values, so that the theme moves twice as fast as originally. (A whole note becomes a half, a half note a quarter, etc.)

坎克里赞，或称蟹行，顾名思义，是指旋律倒着读。换句话说，在坎克里赞中，ABCD变成了DCBA。同样，仅仅机械地运用这种手法并不总是能产生音乐效果。坎克里赞比其他对位手法少见得多，尽管以阿诺德·勋伯格为首的现代维也纳乐派已经大量使用了它。更复杂的是倒置坎克里赞，其主题先倒着读，然后再倒置。

Cancrizans, or crab motion, as the name implies, means the melody read backward. In other words, A-B-C-D becomes, in cancrizans, D-C-B-A. Here, again, the mere mechanical application of the device does not always produce musical results. Cancrizans is much more rarely found than the other contrapuntal devices, although the modern Viennese school, led by Arnold Schoenberg, has made liberal use of it. Still more involved is inverted cancrizans, in which the theme is first read backward and then inverted.

掌握对位聆听的能力，加上对各种技巧的理解，足以让你做好聆听赋格曲的准备。大多数赋格曲都是三声部或四声部的。五声部赋格曲较为少见，双声部赋格曲则更少见。一旦采用了一定数量的声部，就必须始终保持这种声部。然而，这些声部并非在赋格曲中连续存在，因为一首写得好的赋格曲会在每条旋律线中留有喘息的空间。因此，在四声部赋格曲中，听众很少会同时听到三个以上的声部。

The ability to listen contrapuntally, plus a comprehension of these various devices, is all that is necessary in order to prepare oneself to hear fugues intelligently. Most fugues are written in three or four voices. Five-voiced fugues are rarer, and two-voiced rarer still. Once a certain number of voices are adopted, they are held to throughout. They are not, however, continuously present in the fugue, for a well-written fugue implies breathing spaces in each melodic line. So that in a four-voiced fugue, the listener seldom hears more than three voices at a time.

但无论有多少个声部同时进行，总有一个声部占主导地位。正如玩杂耍的人在玩三个物体时，会把我们的注意力吸引到最高的那个物体上，作曲家也会以同样的方式把我们的注意力吸引到其中一个同样独立的声部上。只要赋格曲出现，主题或主题就会占据主导地位。因此，读者可以体会到牢记赋格曲主题的重要性。作曲家总是在赋格曲的开头阐明主题，而不带伴奏。赋格曲的主题通常很短——两到三小节长——并且具有明确的特征。（如果可以，请研究一下巴赫在他的《平均律古钢琴》中使用的著名的四十八个赋格曲主题。）

But no matter how many voices may be going on at the same time, there is always one voice that predominates. Just as a juggler, handling three objects, draws our attention to the object that goes highest, so, in the same way, the composer draws our attention to one of the equally independent voices. It is the theme, or subject, of the fugue that takes precedence whenever present. Therefore, the reader can appreciate how important it is to bear in mind the subject of the fugue. Composers aid by invariably stating the subject at the beginning of the fugue without accompaniment. Fugue subjects are generally rather short—two or three measures long—and of a well-defined character. (Examine, if you can, the famous forty-eight fugue themes used by Bach in his Well Tempered Clavichord.)

在尽可能详细地展示赋格曲的整体蓝图之前，需要明确的是，赋格曲式的总体轮廓远不如其他形式的赋格曲那么清晰。每首赋格曲在声部呈现、曲长和内部细节方面都各不相同。它的各个部分远不如，比如说，分段式中的部分那样容易区分。在这种非技术性的书中，不可能对每首赋格曲进行完整分析所需的逐小节解释。

Before demonstrating as much as can be blueprinted of the fugue as a whole, it should be made clear that the general outlines of the form are not nearly so definite as that of other formal molds. Every fugue differs as to presentation of voices, as to length, and as to inner detail. Its separate parts are not nearly so distinguishable as, let us say, separate parts in sectional forms. In a nontechnical book of this sort, it is not possible to make the measure-by-measure explanation that each fugue demands for complete analysis.

然而，所有赋格曲都以所谓的“呈示部”开始。在继续探讨赋格曲式的其余部分之前，我们先来看看赋格曲的呈示部由哪些部分组成。正如我所说，每首赋格曲都以朴素的赋格主题的宣告开始。如果我们以四声部赋格曲为例，那么主题将首次出现在四个声部之一中：女高音、女低音、男高音或男低音。（为方便起见，我们将它们称为 V-1、V-2、V-3 和 V-4。）这四个声部中的任何一个都可以是赋格主题的第一个陈述。无论顺序如何，主题都会在四个声部中依次出现，如下所示：

All fugues, however, begin with what is called an “exposition.” Let us see what the exposition of a fugue consists of before going on to examine the remainder of the form. Every fugue, as I have said, begins with an announcement of the unadorned fugue subject. If we take as model a four-voiced fugue, then the subject will appear for the first time in one of four voices: soprano, alto, tenor, or bass. (For convenience sake, let’s call them V-1, V-2, V-3, and V-4.) Any one of the four voices may have the first statement of the fugue subject. Whatever the order may be, the subject is heard in each one of the four voices, one after another, like this:

或者入口顺序可能是这样的：

Or the order of entrance may be thus:

（V-2 和 V-4 更准确地说是主题的“回答”。为了简单起见，我在四个语态中都保留了“主题”。）

(V-2 and V-4 are more exactly known as “answers” to the subject. I have retained “subject” in all four voices for the sake of simplicity.)

毋庸置疑，当第二声部随着主旋律进入时，第一声部不会停止。相反，它会继续为主旋律添加一个对位旋律，或者通常所说的对位主旋律（CS）。因此，基本结构实际上是：

It goes without saying that when the second voice enters with the subject, the first voice does not stop. On the contrary, it continues to add a countermelody, or countersubject as it is generally called (CS), to the principal subject. Thus, the ground plan really reads:

一旦主体和反主体在任何一个声音中展现出来，它就可以自由地继续下去，不受任何限制，这就是所谓的“自由声音”。填满这一点后，我们的阐述的总体方案就完成了：

When once the subject and countersubject are exposed in any one voice, it is free to continue without restrictions as a so-called “free voice.” With that filled in, our ground plan of the exposition is completed:

在某些赋格曲中，由于调性关系过于专业，此处不便详述，因此无法直接从一个声部的入场过渡到下一个声部。十字线就代表了这一点。当赋格曲中的每个声部都演唱完一次主题后，呈示部就被认为结束了。（某些赋格曲有一个重呈示部，其中呈示部重复，但声部入场的顺序不同。）

In some fugues, it is not feasible to go directly from one entrance of a voice to the next without a measure or two of transition, because of tonal relationships too technical to be gone into here. That is what the crosses indicate. The exposition is considered to be at an end when each of the voices of a fugue has sung the theme once. (Certain fugues have a reexposition section in which the exposition is repeated but with the voices entering in different order.)

呈示部是赋格曲式中唯一确定的部分。此后，该曲式便只能粗略地概括。其总体结构可以简化为如下公式：呈示部——（再呈示部）——片段1——主题——片段2——主题——片段3——主题——（等等）——延音（有关该术语的解释，请参阅第142页）——终止式。一般而言，一系列片段与赋格主题的陈述交替出现，每次陈述都有新的方面。片段的数量或主题的回归没有固定的规则。片段通常与赋格主题或复主题的某个片段相关。它很少完全由独立的素材构成。它的主要功能是转移对赋格主题的注意力，以便更好地为主题的重新进入做好准备。它的总体特征通常是一段过渡——比赋格主题的发展部更轻松，更少辩证性。

The exposition is the only part of the fugue form that is definitely set. From there on, the form can be summarized only loosely. The general plan might be reduced to a formula something like this: exposition—(reexposition)—episode 1—subject—episode 2—subject—episode 3—subject—(etc.)—stretto (see page 142 for explanation of this term)—cadence. Speaking generally, a series of episodes alternate with statements of the fugue subject, seen each time in new aspects. No rules govern the number of episodes or returns of the theme. An episode is often related to some fragment of the fugue subject or countersubject. It seldom is made up entirely of independent materials. Its principal function is to divert attention from the theme of the fugue, so as better to prepare the stage for its reentrance. Its general character is usually that of a bridge section—more relaxed in quality, less dialectic than the fugue subject developments.

尽管出现了上述套路，但赋格曲中除了赋格主题本身的核心以及每次出现时常伴随的复主题之外，并无真正的重复。如果不清楚地理解，每次赋格主题的出现都会对主题本身产生不同的诠释，那么赋格曲式的一半意义就被忽略了。它可以增或转位，可以与自身或与其他新主题结合，可以缩短或延长，可以轻柔地演唱，也可以大胆地演唱。每一次新的出现都考验着作曲家的创造力。在赋格曲的主体部分——即呈示部之后、强音部之前——通常采用严格的转调式，但这过于技术性，无法在此进行全面讨论。

Despite the appearance of the preceding formula, there is no actual repetition in a fugue except for the kernel of the fugue subject itself, and the countersubject which often accompanies its every appearance. Half the point of fugue form would be missed if it were not clearly understood that with each entrance of the fugue subject a different light is thrown upon the theme itself. It may be augmented or inverted, combined with itself or with other new themes, shortened or lengthened, sung quietly or boldly. Each new appearance tests the ingenuity of the composer. During the main body of the fugue—that is, after the exposition and before the stretto—a severe modulatory scheme is generally adopted, which is too technical for full discussion here.

赋格曲中的强音是可选的，但如果出现，通常出现在最后的终止式之前。强音是一种模仿，其各个声部接连进入，产生一种声部倾覆的印象。并非所有赋格曲主题都同样适合这种处理方式，这也解释了为什么强音并非在所有赋格曲中都能找到。无论赋格曲的性质如何，结尾都绝非随意。通常，结尾会伴随着对赋格主题的最后清晰陈述，并强调毫无疑问地确立主调。

A stretto in a fugue is optional, but when present it is usually found just before the final cadence. Stretto is the name given a species of imitation in which the separate parts enter so immediately one after another that an impression of toppling voices is obtained. Not all fugue subjects lend themselves equally well to this kind of treatment, which explains why strettos are not found in every fugue. Whatever the nature of the fugue, the end is never casual. It brings with it, as a rule, one final, clear statement of the fugue subject and an insistence on the establishment without question of the tonic key.

赋格曲要求专注聆听，因此篇幅不长，最多几页。赋格曲的风格仅受限于创作者的想象力。它或许忧郁，或许诙谐，但绝不会试图在一首赋格曲中兼具两者。就其总体特征而言，赋格曲诉说着一件事，其基调源于赋格曲主题本身的性质。换句话说，赋格曲的情感范围受限于创作者所采用的主题类型。

The fugue asks for concentrated listening and is therefore not very long, a few pages at most. The character of the fugue is limited only by the imagination of its creator. It may be somber or witty, but it never tries to be both in one fugue. As far as its general character goes, a fugue says one thing, and it derives its keynote from the nature of the fugue subject itself. The emotional scope, in other words, is limited to the kind of theme with which one begins.

赋格曲的学科性特征几个世纪以来一直挑战着作曲家的创造力，并且仍在继续。但普遍的看法是，赋格曲本质上是一种18世纪的音乐形式。这或许部分归因于18世纪的作曲家们倾向于忽视这种在他们心中无疑与过去时代的形式主义联系在一起的音乐形式，以及浪漫主义时期对表达自由的强调。当然还有其他原因，但这些就足够了。

The disciplinary aspect of the fugue has challenged the ingenuity of composers for centuries and continues to do so. But the consensus of opinion is that the fugue, in essence, is an eighteenth-century form. That may be partly accounted for by the fact that the composers of the following century tended to neglect a form that was undoubtedly associated in their minds with the formalism of a past era, plus the emphasis placed upon freedom of expression during the romantic period. There were other reasons also, but these will suffice.

然而，近代作曲家们对赋格曲重新燃起了兴趣。他们在这一领域的成就是否足以证明他们重新演绎这种过去已臻完美的形式，只有未来才能给出答案。无论如何，现代赋格曲并没有什么本质上的不同。就其形式或总体情感特征而言，它仍然是一个严谨时代的赋格曲。听众在两种情况下面临的问题完全相同。

Recent composers, however, have shown a renewal of interest in the fugue. Whether or not their accomplishments in this field will justify their redoing a form that the past has done so consummately well, the future alone can tell. In any case, there is nothing essentially different about a modern fugue. As far as the form goes, or the general emotional character, it is still the fugue of a disciplined age. The listener’s problem is exactly similar in both cases.

大协奏曲

CONCERTO GROSSO

第二种主要的赋格形式是大协奏曲。它本质上也是一种十九世纪前的形式，就像所有这些赋格形式一样。请不要将它与后来的协奏曲混淆，后者是为一位技艺精湛的独奏家在管弦乐队伴奏下创作的。大协奏曲的起源可以归因于这样一个事实：十七世纪下半叶的作曲家们对将少量乐器与大量乐器进行对比所产生的效果产生了浓厚的兴趣。较小的一组乐器称为协奏曲，可以由作曲家喜欢的任意乐器组合而成。无论较小的一组乐器是什么，这种形式都是围绕协奏曲与较大乐器（通常称为全奏）之间的辩证互换而建立的。

The second principal fugal form is that of the concerto grosso. It, too, is an essentially pre-nineteenth-century form, as are all these fugal forms. It should not be confused in your mind with the later concerto, which is written for a virtuoso soloist accompanied by orchestra. The origin of the concerto grosso is attributable to the fact that composers in the second half of the seventeenth century became intrigued by the effect to be obtained from contrasting a small body of instruments with a large body of instruments. The smaller group, called the concertino, might be formed of any combination of instruments pleasing to the composer. Whatever the smaller group of instruments may be, the form is built around the dialectical interchange between the concertino and the larger body of instruments, or tutti, as it is often called.

大协奏曲是一种器乐赋格体裁。它通常由三个或更多乐章组成。这种形式的经典范例是亨德尔和巴赫的作品。后者以这种形式创作的作品被称为勃兰登堡协奏曲，共有六部，每部都使用了不同的协奏曲。聆听这些作品的对位织体，常常会给人一种美妙健康、充满活力的感觉。各个声部的内部运动散发出一种运动的特质，仿佛一切都处于完美的运转状态。

The concerto grosso, then, is a kind of instrumental fugal form. It is generally made up of three or more movements. The classical examples of the form are those of Handel and Bach. The latter’s essays in the form, known as the Brandenburg Concerti, of which there are six, make use of a different concertino in each one. Very often, in listening to the contrapuntal texture of one of these works, one has an impression of wonderful health and vitality. The inner movement of the separate parts gives off an athletic quality, as if all were in excellent working order.

十九世纪，大协奏曲被弃用，取而代之的是独奏家与管弦乐队协奏曲。大协奏曲或许可以被视为早期大协奏曲的分支。与其他十八世纪的协奏曲形式一样，大协奏曲也重新引起了近代作曲家的兴趣。一个著名的现代例子是欧内斯特·布洛赫的《大协奏曲》。

During the nineteenth century, the form was abandoned in favor of the concerto for soloist and orchestra, which may rightfully be considered an offshoot of the earlier concerto grosso. Like other eighteenth-century forms, the concerto grosso has enjoyed renewed interest on the part of recent composers. A well-known modern example is the Concerto Grosso by Ernest Bloch.

合唱前奏曲

CHORALE PRELUDE

众赞歌前奏曲是赋格曲式的第三类，其轮廓不如大协奏曲清晰，因此更难准确定义。它起源于路德时代之后新教教堂吟唱的众赞歌曲调。教堂作曲家们运用他们的聪明才智，为这些简单的旋律创作了精妙的变奏。从某种意义上说，它们是赞美诗曲调的变奏，我将列举其中三种最著名的众赞歌曲调处理方式。

The chorale prelude, which is the third of the fugal forms, is less definite in outline than the concerto grosso and therefore more difficult to define with any degree of exactitude. It had its origin in the chorale tunes that were sung in Protestant churches after the time of Luther. Composers attached to the church exercised their ingenuity in making elaborate settings of these simple melodies. They are, in a sense, variations on a hymn tune, and I shall mention three of the best-known types of treatment of these choral tunes.

最简单的方法是保持原有旋律不变，同时通过增加和声的复杂性或使伴奏声部更复杂的复音，使伴奏的和声更引人入胜。第二种方法是修饰主题本身，赋予最纯粹的旋律轮廓一种意想不到的优雅和华丽。第三种也是最复杂的类型，是一种围绕众赞歌旋律编织的赋格曲。例如，可以用众赞歌旋律的某个片段作为赋格曲的主题。赋格曲的呈示部在创作时仿佛没有众赞歌；然后，在赋格曲平静地进行的同时，不知不觉中，就会听到众赞歌的悠长音符在其上方或下方。

The simplest method consists of keeping the given melody intact, while making the accompanying harmonies more interesting, either by increasing the harmonic complexity or by making the accompanying voices more intricately polyphonic. A second type embroiders upon the theme itself, lending the barest melodic outline an unsuspected grace and floridity. The third, and most involved type, is a kind of fugue woven around the tune of the chorale. For example, some fragment of the chorale tune may serve as fugue subject. An exposition of a fugue is written just as if there were to be no chorale; and then without warning, while the fugue continues along placidly, above or beneath it may be heard the long-drawn-out notes of the chorale.

巴赫的一些最杰出的作品都写于这些众赞歌前奏曲的某一形式中。他的《管风琴集》（Orgelb uchlein）收录了一系列短小的众赞歌前奏曲，蕴含着取之不尽、用之不竭的音乐宝藏，任何音乐爱好者都无法忽视。这些作品不仅从表达角度出发，令人动容，更展现了精湛的技艺——思想与情感完美融合的典范。

Some of Bach’s finest creations were written in one or another of these forms of chorale prelude. His Orgelb uchlein is a collection of short chorale preludes containing an inexhaustible wealth of musical riches, which no music lover can afford to ignore. Deeply moving from an expressive standpoint, they are nevertheless marvels of technical ingenuity—a magistral illustration of the welding of thought and emotion.

经文歌和牧歌

MOTETS AND MADRIGALS

第四种也是最后一种赋格形式是经文歌和牧歌。我得补充一点，经文歌或牧歌严格来说不是一种形式；但由于它们会被越来越频繁地聆听，并且肯定属于对位形式，所以它们在这里就显得恰如其分了。它们的形式无法一概而论，因为它们是合唱作品，无伴奏演唱，其形式轮廓取决于每个具体段落的歌词。

The fourth and last of the fugal forms is that of motets and madrigals. I hasten to add that a motet or madrigal is not a form, properly speaking; but since they will be listened to with increasing frequency and definitely belong with the contrapuntal forms, their proper place is here. One cannot generalize as to their form, because they are choral compositions, sung without accompaniment and dependent on their words in each individual instance for their formal outline.

十五、十六、十七世纪，经文歌和牧歌创作了大量作品。两者的区别在于，经文歌是用神圣的词语创作的短小声乐作品，而牧歌则是用世俗的词语创作的类似作品。牧歌的风格通常不那么严肃。两者都是巴赫及其同时代人出现之前典型的声乐赋格形式。

Motets and madrigals were written in profusion during the fifteenth, sixteenth, and seventeenth centuries. The difference between the two is that the motet is a short vocal composition on sacred words, whereas the madrigal is a similar composition on secular words. The madrigal is generally less severe in character. Both are typical vocal fugal forms of the era before the advent of Bach and his contemporaries.

从听众的角度来看，区分经文歌或牧歌的织体至关重要。同样，在这方面，没有固定的规则；经文歌和牧歌的风格可以是赋格式的，也可以是和弦式的，或者两者兼而有之。我不明白，如果不了解这些声乐形式的不同织体，如何才能清晰地聆听它们。赋格式或对位式织体的经文歌或牧歌，将独立的旋律声部与歌词连接起来，这一事实会比纯器乐形式更有助于听众更容易地听出对位。

From the listener’s standpoint, it is important to distinguish the texture of motet or madrigal. Here, again, no rule prevails; motets and madrigals may be either fugal or chordal in style or a combination of both. I fail to see how these vocal forms may be heard intelligently without an elementary idea as to their different textures. In the motet or madrigal of fugal or contrapuntal texture, the fact that the separate melodic voices are attached to words will be found especially helpful in aiding the listener to hear the counterpoint more easily than in the purely instrumental forms.

文艺复兴时期涌现出众多运用这些声乐形式的大师。意大利的帕莱斯特里纳、荷兰的奥兰多·迪·拉索、西班牙的维多利亚；英国的伯德、威尔比、莫利和吉本斯，都是音乐史上最辉煌时期之一的杰出人物。大多数音乐会观众对这个非凡时代的陌生，反映出我们这个时代音乐兴趣相对狭隘。

The Renaissance period is crowded with masters who used these vocal forms. Palestrina in Italy, Orlando di Lasso in the Netherlands, Vittoria in Spain; Byrd, Wilbye, Morley, and Gibbons in England are some of the outstanding names in one of the most remarkable eras in music. The unfamiliarity of most of our concertgoers with this extraordinary epoch is indicative of the comparatively narrow musical interests of our time.

 

 

巴赫——勃兰登堡协奏曲

Bach—Brandenburg Concertos

特雷弗·皮诺克（Trevor Pinnock），巴洛克乐团（档案）

Trevor Pinnock, Baroque Ensemble (Archiv)

巴赫—— 《平均律钢琴曲集》（参见第二章列表）

Bach—Well Tempered Clavier (see listing under Chapter Two)

弗兰克——A大调小提琴与钢琴奏鸣曲

Franck—Sonata in A for Violin and Piano

Gidon Kremer、O. Maisenberg（飞利浦）

Gidon Kremer, O. Maisenberg (Philips)

贝多芬——A大调钢琴奏鸣曲，作品110

Beethoven—Piano Sonata in A flat, Opus 110

阿尔弗雷德·布伦德尔（飞利浦）

Alfred Brendel (Philips)

勋伯格——第三弦乐四重奏

Schoenberg—String Quartet No. 3

阿尔迪蒂四重奏（蒙田唱片）

Arditti Quartet (Disques Montaigne)

十三

13

基本形式

Fundamental Forms

四、奏鸣曲式

IV. SONATA FORM

奏鸣曲整体；奏鸣曲形式；交响曲

Sonata as a Whole; Sonata Form Proper; The Symphony

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

奏鸣曲式之于当今听众的意义，与赋格曲式之于十八世纪初的听众的意义不相上下。毫不夸张地说，自那时以来，几乎每一部长篇音乐作品的基本曲式都以某种方式与奏鸣曲相关。这种曲式的生命力令人惊叹。它在今天依然充满活力，如同其发展初期一样。早期奏鸣曲式的逻辑性，加上它在后世作曲家手中的可塑性，无疑解释了它在过去150多年里持续吸引着音乐创作者的想象力。

The sonata form, for the present-day listener, has something of the same significance that the fugal forms had for listeners of the first part of the eighteenth century. For it is not too much to say that, since that time, the basic form of almost every extended piece of music has been related in some way to the sonata. The vitality of the form is astonishing. It is just as much alive today as it was during the period of its first development. The logic of the form as it was practiced in the early days, plus its malleability in the hands of later composers, accounts, no doubt, for its continuous hold on the imagination of musical creators for the past 150 years or more.

当然，我们不应忘记，当我们谈到奏鸣曲式时，我们讨论的不仅仅是被称为奏鸣曲的作品中的形式，因为该术语的含义远比这广泛得多。例如，每部交响曲都是一首为管弦乐队而作的奏鸣曲；每部弦乐四重奏都是一首为四弦乐器而作的奏鸣曲；每部协奏曲都是一首为独奏乐器和管弦乐队而作的奏鸣曲。大多数序曲也是奏鸣曲第一乐章的形式。“奏鸣曲”一词本身的使用通常仅限于为独奏乐器而作的作品，无论是否有钢琴伴奏；但很容易看出，这远远不足以涵盖事实上奏鸣曲式在不同媒介中的各种应用。

Of course, it must not be forgotten that when we speak of sonata form we are not discussing only the form to be found in pieces that are called sonatas, for the meaning of the term is much more widespread than that. Every symphony, for example, is a sonata for orchestra; every string quartet is a sonata for four strings; every concerto a sonata for a solo instrument and orchestra. Most overtures, also, are in the form of the first movement of a sonata. The usage of the term “sonata” itself is generally confined to compositions for a solo instrument, with or without piano accompaniment; but, as may easily be seen, that is not nearly broad enough to include the varied applications of what is, in fact, sonata form to different mediums.

幸运的是，对于普通听众来说，奏鸣曲式，无论其表现形式如何，总体上都比我们之前研究过的其他一些形式更容易理解。这是因为它带来的问题并非像赋格曲那样，需要聆听个别小节的细节，而是需要遵循大乐段的大致轮廓。此外，奏鸣曲的织体通常不像赋格曲那样具有对位性。就织体而言，它包罗万象——几乎所有内容都包含在奏鸣曲式的宽广范围内。

Fortunately for the lay listener, the sonata form, in any of its many manifestations, is, on the whole, more immediately accessible than some of the other forms we have been studying. That is because the problem it presents is not one of listening for detail in separate measures, as in the fugue, but of following the broad outlines of large sections. Also, the texture of the sonata, as a rule, is not nearly so contrapuntal as that of the fugue. As texture, it is much more all-inclusive—almost anything goes within the broad confines of the sonata form.

在进一步探讨之前，读者应该注意“奏鸣曲式”一词的另一个可能混淆之处。事实上，它指两种不同的东西。首先，当我们指的是由三个或四个乐章组成的整部作品时，我们所说的奏鸣曲式。另一方面，当我们指音乐中一种特定的结构类型时，我们所说的奏鸣曲式也通常出现在整部奏鸣曲的第一乐章，也常常出现在最后一乐章。因此，你必须记住两点：(1) 整首奏鸣曲；(2) 真正的奏鸣曲式，有时也称为奏鸣曲快板，或第一乐章式。奏鸣曲快板指的是几乎所有奏鸣曲的第一乐章都是快板（或快速）速度。

Before venturing farther, the reader should be warned against one other possible confusion regarding the use of the term “sonata form.” It is applied, as a matter of fact, to two different things. In the first place, we speak of sonata form when we mean an entire work consisting of three or four movements. On the other hand, we also speak of sonata form when we refer to a specific type of structure in music generally found in the first, and often also the last, movement of an entire sonata. Therefore, you must keep in mind two things: (1) the sonata as a whole and (2) the sonata form proper, sometimes referred to as sonata allegro, or first-movement form, the sonata allegro referring to the fact that almost all first movements of sonatas are in allegro (or fast) tempo.

还有一点需要牢记。当你去听音乐会，发现曲目单上列出了亨德尔或巴赫的小提琴和钢琴奏鸣曲时，不要去听这里讨论的曲式。奏鸣曲（sonata）一词在当时与康塔塔（cantata）一词相对——奏鸣曲是用来演奏的，而康塔塔是用来歌唱的。除此之外，它与莫扎特和海顿时代的后期奏鸣曲几乎没有任何关联。

There is still another distinction that must be kept in mind. When you go to a concert and find listed on the program a sonata for violin and piano by Handel or Bach, do not listen for the form under discussion here. The word sonata was used at that time in contradistinction to the word cantata—sonata being something to be played, and cantata something to be sung. Otherwise it bears little or no relation to the later sonata of Mozart and Haydn’s time.

我们所熟知的奏鸣曲，据说很大程度上是由巴赫的儿子卡尔·菲利普·埃马努埃尔·巴赫创作的。他被认为是最早尝试这种新奏鸣曲形式的作曲家之一，而这种新形式的经典轮廓后来由海顿和莫扎特明确确立。贝多芬倾尽所有才华，拓展了当时奏鸣曲式的概念；舒曼和勃拉姆斯也在其后，以略微逊色的方式拓展了形式模式的意义。如今，对这种形式的处理已经非常自由，在某些情况下几乎无法辨认。然而，即使在今天，这种形式的大部分外在表现和大量的心理暗示仍然完好无损。

The sonata as we think of it is said to be largely the creation of one of Bach’s sons, Karl Philipp Emanuel Bach. He is credited with having been one of the first composers to experiment with the new form of sonata, the classic outlines of which were later definitely set by Haydn and Mozart. Beethoven put all his genius into broadening the sonata-form conceptions of his time; and he was followed by Schumann and Brahms, who also extended, in a lesser way, the significance of the formal mold. By now the treatment of the form is so free as to be almost unrecognizable in certain cases. Nevertheless, much of the outer shell and a good deal of the psychological implications of the form are intact, even today.

整首奏鸣曲

THE SONATA AS A WHOLE

整首奏鸣曲由三个或四个独立乐章组成。虽然也有一些双乐章奏鸣曲，以及近代出现的单乐章奏鸣曲，但这些都属于例外。乐章之间最明显的区别在于速度：三乐章奏鸣曲的节奏是快——慢——快；而四乐章奏鸣曲的节奏通常是快——慢——中速——非常快。

Three or four separate movements comprise the sonata as a whole. There are examples of two-movement and, more recently, one-movement sonatas, but these are exceptional. The most obvious distinction between the movements is one of tempo: in the three-movement species, it is fast—slow—fast; and in the four-movement sonata, it is usually fast—slow—moderately fast—very fast.

人们通常想知道是什么让这三四个乐章如此契合。没有人能对这个问题给出完全令人满意的答案。习惯和熟悉使它们看起来像是一体的，但我一直怀疑，即使用海顿第98交响曲中的小步舞曲代替海顿第99交响曲中的小步舞曲，也不会在两部作品中发现严重的连贯性缺失。尤其是在这首奏鸣曲的早期例子中，各个乐章之间的联系更多是出于平衡、对比和某些调性关系的需要，而非彼此之间有任何内在联系。后来，正如我们将在奏鸣曲所谓的循环形式中看到的那样，作曲家们确实尝试通过主题的统一性来连接各个乐章，同时保留各个乐章的一般特征。

People generally want to know what it is that makes these three or four movements belong together. No one has come forward with a completely satisfactory answer to that question. Custom and familiarity make them seem to belong together, but I have always suspected that one could substitute the Minuet of Haydn’s 98th symphony for the Minuet in Haydn’s 99th symphony without sensing a serious lack of coherence in either work. Particularly in these early examples of the sonata, the movements are linked together more from the need of balance and contrast and certain tonality relationships than from any intrinsic connection with each other. Later on, as we shall see in the so-called cyclic form of the sonata, composers did try to link their movements through thematic unity while retaining the general characteristics of the separate movements.

现在，让我们暂时思考一下整首奏鸣曲各个乐章的整体形式。我们的描述应被视为普遍适用，因为几乎所有关于奏鸣曲形式的论述都会与某些特定的例外情况相矛盾。正如前文所述，任何奏鸣曲（我泛指交响曲、弦乐四重奏等）的第一乐章都是奏鸣曲快板式。我们将在后面几页深入探讨这种形式。

Now let us consider, for a moment, the form of each of the separate movements of the sonata as a whole. Our descriptions are to be taken as generally true, for there is almost no statement that can be made about sonata form that some specific exceptional instance does not contradict. As has already been said, the first movement of any sonata—and I use that word generically to denote symphonies and string quartets and the like—is always in sonata-allegro form. We shall be investigating that form thoroughly a few pages farther on.

第二乐章通常是慢乐章，但并不存在所谓的慢乐章式。它的写法可能多种多样。例如，它可能是一个主题加变奏，就像我们之前学习过的那样。也可能是回旋曲式的慢板——可以是短回旋曲，也可以是延长回旋曲。它甚至可能比这更简单，与普通的三部段落式相似。更罕见的是，它与第一乐章的奏鸣曲式非常相似。聆听者在聆听慢乐章时，必须对以上任何一种形式做好准备。

The second movement is usually the slow movement, but there is no such thing as a slow-movement form. It may be written in one of several different molds. For example, it may be a theme and variation such as we have already studied. Or it may be a slow version of a rondo form—either a short or an extended rondo. It might be even more simple than that, relating itself to the ordinary three-part sectional form. More rarely, it bears close resemblance to the first-movement sonata form. The listener must be prepared for any one of these various forms when hearing the slow movement.

第三乐章通常是小步舞曲或谐谑曲。在海顿和莫扎特的早期作品中，第三乐章是小步舞曲；在后期，则是谐谑曲。无论哪种情况，第三乐章都是ABA（三部曲式），在“乐章段落”中讨论过。有时，第二乐章和第三乐章可以互换——不是慢乐章是第二乐章，谐谑曲是第三乐章，而是谐谑曲是第二乐章，慢乐章是第三乐章。

The third movement is usually a minuet or scherzo. In the earlier works of Haydn and Mozart, it is the minuet; in later times, the scherzo. In either case, it is the A-B-A, three-part form which was discussed under Sectional Forms. Sometimes the second and third movements are interchangeable—instead of finding the slow movement second and the scherzo third, the scherzo may be second and the slow movement third.

第四乐章，通常被称为终曲，几乎总是采用延长回旋曲式或奏鸣曲-快板式。因此，只有奏鸣曲的第一乐章才为我们呈现出一种全新的面貌。

The fourth movement, or finale, as it is often called, is almost always either in extended rondo form or in sonata-allegro form. Thus it is only the first movement of the sonata that presents an entirely new physiognomy for us.

单乐章奏鸣曲通常有两种类型：一种是局限于第一乐章的延伸处理；另一种是试图在一个乐章内涵盖所有四个乐章。双乐章奏鸣曲的曲风过于难以预测，难以被归类。

One-movement sonatas are generally of two types: Either they confine themselves to an extended treatment of first-movement form; or they attempt to include all four movements within the limits of a single movement. Two-movement sonatas are too unpredictable to be catalogued.

奏鸣曲-快板，或第一乐章形式

SONATA-ALLEGRO, OR FIRST-MOVEMENT, FORM

奏鸣曲-快板式最显著的特征之一在于，它可以很容易地简化为常见的三部式：ABA。就其最广泛的轮廓而言，它与“音乐结构”一章中分析的微小乐段，或“乐段式”中讨论的各种三部式并无二致。但必须记住，ABA 的每个乐段都代表着音乐的大段落，每个乐段的长度可达五到十分钟。

It is one of the more remarkable features of the sonata-allegro form that it may so easily be reduced to the ordinary tripartite formula: A-B-A. As far as its broadest outlines are concerned, it does not differ from the tiny section analyzed in the chapter on Musical Structure or from the various kinds of three-part form considered under Sectional Forms. But it must be remembered in this case that each of the sections of the A-B-A represent large divisions of music, each of them lasting as much as five or ten minutes in length.

对奏鸣曲-快板曲式的传统解释很容易论证。它主要解释了早期和不太复杂的快板奏鸣曲式。一张简单的图表可以展示该曲式的大致轮廓：

The conventional explanation of sonata-allegro form is easily demonstrated. It explains, for the most part, the earlier and less complex forms of the sonata allegro. A simple diagram will show the general outlines of the form:

由此可见，本例中该公式的ABA结构被命名为呈示部-展开部-再现部。在呈示部中，主题素材得以展现；在展开部中，主题素材以全新的、出乎意料的方式处理；在再现部中，主题素材在其原始背景中再次被呈现。

呈示部包含第一主题、第二主题和结束主题。11第一主题的特点是戏剧性，或者说“男性化”，并且始终为主调；第二主题的特点是抒情性，或者说“女性化”，并且始终为属调；结束主题比这两个主题都重要，也是属调。发展部是“自由的”；也就是说，它自由地组合呈示部中引入的材料，有时也添加自己的新材料。在这一部分，音乐进入新的和外来的调性。再现部或多或少地重申了呈示部中的内容，只是现在所有主题都变成了主调。

The exposition section contains a first theme, a second theme, and a closing theme.11 The character of the first theme is dramatic, or “masculine,” and it is always in the tonic key; the character of the second theme is lyrical, or “feminine,” and it is always in the dominant key; the closing theme is less important than either of these and is also in the dominant key. The development section is “free”; that is, it freely combines the material introduced in the exposition and sometimes adds new material of its own. In this section, the music moves into new and foreign keys. The recapitulation restates more or less literally what was found in the exposition, except that all the themes are now in the tonic key.

关于这种形式的粗略描述就到此为止。现在，让我们更仔细地考察一下，看看能否对这种形式进行概括，使其更适用于各个时期的实际例子。

So much for the bare outlines of the form. Now let us examine it more closely and see if we cannot generalize regarding the form in such a way as to make it more applicable to actual examples of all periods.

所有奏鸣曲快板，无论哪个时期，都保留了呈示部-发展部-再现部的三部分形式。呈示部包含各种音乐元素。这是它的本质，因为如果不是这样，就很少或根本没有发展可言。这些不同的元素通常分为小a、小b和小c，分别代表过去所说的第一主题、第二主题和结束主题。我说“过去常常这样称呼”，是因为近代分析家对这种命名法与实际作品本身所呈现的证据之间的明显差异感到不满。很难以任何程度的最终性概括呈示部到底包含哪些内容。尽管如此，我们可以肯定地说，主题是暴露的，这些主题在特征上形成对比，并且它们在部分的结尾带来了某种结束感。为方便起见，将小a称为第一主题并无不妥，只要我们清楚地理解，它实际上可能由多个主题或主题片段组成，通常具有强烈的戏剧性和肯定性。b 即所谓的第二主题也是如此，它实际上也可能是由一个或多个主题组成的系列，但更具抒情性和表现力。一组表示力量和侵略性的主题与另一组舒缓且更具歌曲性的主题并置，是呈示部的核心，并决定了整个奏鸣曲-快板式的特征。在该形式的许多早期例子中，素材按第一主题和第二主题的顺序排列得更为严格，而后来我们只能确定呈示部中会出现两个对立的元素，但无法确切地说出它们将以何种顺序出现。

All sonata allegros, of whatever period, retain the tripartite form of exposition-development-recapitulation. The exposition contains a variety of musical elements. That is its essential nature, for there would be little or nothing to develop if that were not so. These varied elements are usually divided into a small a, a small b, and a small c, representing what used to be called the first, second, and closing themes. I say “used to be called” because recent analysts have become dissatisfied with the obvious disparity between this nomenclature and the evidence presented by the actual works themselves. It is difficult to generalize with any degree of finality as to exactly what goes into an exposition section. Still, one can safely say that themes are exposed, that these themes are contrasted in character and that they bring some sense of close at the end of the section. For the sake of convenience, there would be no objection to calling the small a the first theme, provided it were clearly understood that actually it may consist of a conglomeration of several themes or fragments of themes, usually of a strongly dramatic and affirmative quality. The same is true of the b, so-called second, theme, which again may actually be a series of one or more themes, but of a more lyrical and expressive nature. This juxtaposition of one group of themes denoting power and aggressiveness with another group which is relaxed and more songlike in quality is the essence of the exposition section and determines the character of the entire sonata-allegro form. In many of the early examples of the form, the ordering of the material into first and second themes is more strictly adhered to, whereas later on we can be sure only that two opposing elements will be present in the exposition, without being able to say in exactly what sequence they will appear.

小写c标题下的最后一个主题或主题组构成一个或多个结束句。因此，它可以是任何能引出结论的性质。这一点很重要，因为如果希望听众明智地跟上发展部，他们应该清楚地知道呈示部的结尾在哪里。如果你读谱，你总是可以通过寻找带有重复符号的双小节来机械地找到任何古典奏鸣曲或交响曲中呈示部的结尾，这表示整个乐段的正式重复。如今，诠释者在重复呈示部方面会运用他们的判断力。因此，聆听第一乐章形式的问题之一就是要注意这种重复的可能性。更现代的奏鸣曲和交响曲不表示任何重复，所以即使你读谱，也不容易找到乐段的结尾。

The last theme, or themes, under the heading of small c, constitutes a closing sentence or sentences. Therefore it may be of any nature that leads to a sense of conclusion. This is important, because an audience should have a clear idea of where the end of the exposition occurs, if it is expected to follow the development intelligently. If you read notes, you can always mechanically find the end of the exposition in any of the classic sonatas or symphonies by looking for the double bar with repeat sign, indicating the formal repetition of the entire section. Interpreters nowadays use their discretion in the matter of repeating the exposition. So that part of the problem of listening to the first-movement form is to watch out for this possibility of repetition. More modern sonatas and symphonies do not indicate any repetition, so that even if you read notes the end of the section is not so easily found.

呈示部中还有一个重要元素。如果没有过渡，你就无法很好地从一种极具戏剧性的情绪转换到另一种抒情的情绪。这种过渡，或常说的过渡部分，可以很短，也可以相当复杂。但它在主题上绝不能与元素a或b具有同等重要性，因为那样只会导致混淆。在这种时候，作曲家会求助于某种音乐形象或乐段，它们之所以重要，是因为它的功能意义，而不是它内在的音乐趣味。因此，要注意a和b之间的桥梁，以及b和c之间可能存在的第二座桥梁。

One other element is important in the exposition. You cannot very well go from one mood that is powerfully dramatic to another that is lyrically expressive without some sort of transition. This transition, or bridge section, as it is often called, may be short or fairly elaborate. But it must never be of equal significance thematically with elements a or b, for that could lead only to confusion. Composers, at such moments, fall back upon a kind of musical figuration, or passage work, which is important because of its functional significance rather than for its intrinsic musical interest. Watch out, then, for the bridge between a and b and the possibility of a second bridge between b and c.

正是发展部赋予了快板奏鸣曲其独特的个性。其他任何曲式都没有专门的段落来延伸和发展上一节已介绍过的音乐素材。正是奏鸣曲快板式的这一特点——它能够自由地运用已介绍过的音乐素材——让所有作曲家都为之着迷。因此，正确理解奏鸣曲式，它本质上是一种心理性和戏剧性的音乐形式。你无法很好地融合呈示部的两个或多个元素，而不产生一种挣扎或戏剧感。发展部挑战着每位作曲家的想象力。甚至可以说，它是区分作曲家和普通人的主要因素之一。因为任何人都可以用口哨吹奏旋律。但你必须是一位作曲家，拥有作曲家的技艺和技巧，才能写出真正优秀的旋律发展部。

It is the development section that gives the sonata allegro its special character. In no other form is there a special division reserved for the extension and development of musical material already introduced in a previous section. It is that feature of the sonata-allegro form that has so fascinated all composers—that opportunity for working freely with materials already announced. So you see that the sonata form, properly understood, is essentially a psychological and dramatic form. You cannot very well mix the two or more elements of the exposition without creating a sense of struggle or drama. It is the development section that challenges the imagination of every composer. One might go so far as to say that it is one of the main things that separates the composer from the layman. For anyone can whistle tunes.
