But you really have to be a composer, with a composer’s craft and technique, in order to be able to write a really fine development of those tunes.

发展部不受任何规则的约束。作曲家可以完全自由地选择发展部的类型、选择用于发展部的主题素材、引入新素材（如有）以及整个部分的长度。我们只能概括出两个因素：(1) 发展部通常以部分重述第一主题开始，以提醒听众起点；(2) 在发展部的过程中，音乐通过一系列遥远的调性进行转调，当在再现部开头最终达到原始调性时，这些调性有助于营造一种回归的感觉。当然，这些因素会根据你考察的是奏鸣曲-快板式的早期还是晚期而有很大差异。例如，早在贝多芬时代，发展部就比他之前更加复杂。即使在近代，当第一、第二和结束主题的经典主音-属音-属音关系已完全瓦解时，转调式结构依然被沿用。正如我之前指出的，发展部越来越受到重视，以至于它成为了奏鸣曲-快板式的关键部分，作曲家将他所有的想象力和创造力倾注于此。

No rules govern the development section. The composer is entirely free as to types of development; as to the thematic material chosen for development; as to the introduction of new materials, if any; and as to the length of the section as a whole. One can only generalize about two factors: (1) that the development usually begins with a partial restatement of the first theme in order to remind the listener of the starting point; and (2) that during the course of the development the music modulates through a series of far-off keys which serve to prepare a sense of homecoming when the original tonality is finally reached at the beginning of the recapitulation. These things vary considerably, of course, in accordance with whether you examine an early or late example of sonata-allegro form. For instance, the development section became much more elaborate, even as early as Beethoven’s day, than it had been before his time. The modulatory scheme has been adhered to, even in recent times, when the classic tonic-dominant-dominant relationship of the first, second, and closing themes, respectively, has completely broken down. More and more the trend has been to attach added importance to the development section, as I have already pointed out, so that it has become the pivotal section of the sonata-allegro form, into which the composer pours every ounce of imagination and invention that he possesses.

再现部，顾名思义，是对呈示部的重复。在古典快板奏鸣曲中，重复通常非常精确；即使如此，也倾向于省略非关键部分，省略那些已经充分听过的内容。在后来的时代，重复变得越来越自由，有时甚至变得如同幽灵般飘忽不定。其原因并不难理解。快板奏鸣曲起源于作曲家们“古典”思维的时期；也就是说，他们从一个轮廓清晰的结构入手，并在其中融入控制良好、情感客观的音乐。ABA的正式轮廓与音乐内容的本质之间并不矛盾。但随着浪漫主义时代的到来，音乐变得更加戏剧化和心理化。新的浪漫主义内容不可避免地难以在本质上是古典主义的形式框架内得到体现。因为，如果作曲家在呈示部中陈述他的素材，然后以极具戏剧性和心理张力的方式展开，那么他最终应该会得出不同的结论，这才是合乎逻辑的。如果展开部中所有的混乱和挣扎只是为了回到我们最初的结论，那还有什么意义呢？这就是为什么现代作曲家倾向于缩短再现部或用新的结尾来代替，这似乎是合理的。

The recapitulation is, as its name indicates, a repetition of the exposition. In the classical sonata allegro, the repetition is generally exact; though even here the inclination is to omit nonessentials, leaving out material already sufficiently heard. In later times, the repetition became more and more free until it sometimes is a mere wraith of its former self. It is not very difficult to understand why this is so. The sonata allegro had its origin in a period when composers were “classically” minded; that is, they began with a structure whose outlines were perfectly clear, and into it they put a music well controlled and of an objective emotional quality. There was no contradiction between the formal A-B-A outline and the nature of the musical content. But with the advent of the romantic era, music became much more dramatic and psychological. It was inevitable that the new romantic content should be difficult to contain within the framework of an essentially classical formal scheme. For it is only logical to say that if the composer states his material in the exposition, and if he then develops it in a highly dramatic and psychological fashion, he really should come to a different conclusion about it in the end. What sense does it make to go through all the turmoil and struggle of the development section if it is only to lead back to the same conclusions from which we started? That is why the tendency on the part of modern composers to shorten the recapitulation or to substitute a new conclusion seems justified.

音乐中最非同寻常的错误之一，莫过于斯克里亚宾的例子。这位才华横溢的俄罗斯作曲家，于1915年去世。他创作的主题素材独具匠心，充满灵感。然而，创作了十首钢琴奏鸣曲的斯克里亚宾，却有着一个绝妙的想法，试图将这种全新的情感融入到古典奏鸣曲式的束缚之中，包括再现部等等。如今，很少有作曲家会再犯这样的错误。事实上，他们有时会走向另一个极端，对“奏鸣曲”一词进行过于宽泛的解读，以至于使其几乎毫无意义。因此，如今的听众必须对这个词的几乎所有用法做好准备。

One of the most extraordinary mistakes in music is the example supplied us by Scriabin, the Russian composer of amazing gifts, who died in 1915. The quality of his thematic material was truly individual, truly inspired. But Scriabin, who wrote ten piano sonatas, had the fantastic idea of attempting to put this really new body of feeling into the strait-jacket of the old classical sonata form, recapitulation and all. Few modern composers make that error any longer. In fact, they sometimes go to the other extreme, giving so liberal an interpretation to the word sonata as to make it practically meaningless. So that nowadays, the listener must be prepared for almost any application of the term.

在该曲式发展初期，便添加了两项重要的扩展。在“快板”之前，先有一段引子，并在结尾处附加一段尾声。引子的速度几乎总是很慢，这明确表明A部分尚未开始。它可能包含与随后的快板完全无关的音乐素材；也可能为了进一步增强整体感，演奏了A部分主旋律的慢速版本。尾声的描述并非如此明确。自贝多芬以来，它在拓展曲式的界限方面发挥了主导作用。其目的是营造一种神化感——素材被最后一次以全新的视角呈现。在这里，同样，没有任何规则来约束整个过程。有时，处理方式会延伸到尾声，使其成为一种第二展开部分，但始终指向一种尾声和结论的感觉。

Two important extensions were added to the form while it was still in the early stages of development. An introductory section preceded the “allegro,” and a coda was tacked on at the end. The introduction is almost always slow in tempo, a sure indication that the A section has not yet begun. It may consist of musical materials which are entirely independent of the allegro to follow; or it may be that a slow version of the main theme in A is given out to further the feeling of unity. The coda cannot be so definitely described. From Beethoven on, it has played a preponderant role in stretching the boundaries of the form. Its purpose is to create a sense of apotheosis—the material is seen for the last time and in a new light. Here, again, no rules govern the procedure. At times, the treatment is so extended as to make the coda a kind of second development section though always leading toward a sense of epilogue and conclusion.

这篇奏鸣曲-快板曲式的总结，只有运用在聆听具体作品时，才能对读者有所裨益。我从众多作品中选取了贝多芬的《华尔斯坦钢琴奏鸣曲》（作品53）作为范例，其分析详见附录三。要从此类分析中获益，就必须反复聆听作品。我的经验告诉我，只有当我能够在心里默唱，在脑海中重现作品时，我才能彻底理解它。没有比这更好的方式来真正体会到单纯的形态轮廓与体验生命体千变万化之间的区别了。这就像阅读人体相貌描述与了解一个活生生的男人或女人之间的区别一样。

This summary of sonata-allegro form can be of value to the reader only if it is applied in listening to definite works. I have chosen as one example, out of many, Beethoven’s Waldstein Sonata for piano, Op. 53, an analysis of which will be found in Appendix III. To profit from an analysis of this kind, it is necessary to hear a work over and over again. My own experience has taught me that I know a work thoroughly only when I am able mentally to sing it over to myself, to recreate it in my own mind, as it were. There is no better way of truly appreciating the differences between a mere diagrammatic outline of a form and a contact with the kaleidoscopic changes of a living organism. It is like the difference between reading a description of the physiognomy of a human being and knowing a living man or woman.

交响曲

THE SYMPHONY

交响曲如今的地位如此之高，以至于我们不可能不加讨论地略过它，即使它并非一个独立于奏鸣曲的曲式。在音乐厅或广播中聆听管弦乐曲目，几乎不可能不与常规曲目中的某部交响曲相遇。然而，应该记住的是，除了上述问题之外，这些交响曲并不会引发其他具体问题。

The present-day status of the symphony is such that it is impossible to pass it by without further discussion, even though it does not constitute an independent form, different from the sonata. It is practically impossible to hear an orchestral program in the concert hall or on the air without being confronted with one or another of the symphonies of the regular repertoire. It should be remembered, however, that these present no specific problems other than those outlined above.

交响曲的起源并非人们所预料的像大协奏曲那样的器乐形式，而是源于早期意大利歌剧的序曲。序曲，或称交响曲，由亚历山德罗·斯卡拉蒂完善，由三个部分组成：快-慢-快，从而预示了古典交响曲的三个乐章。大约在1750年，交响曲脱离了孕育它的歌剧，在音乐厅中独立存在。卡尔·内夫在其《音乐史纲要》中描述了这一过程。剧院交响乐移师音乐厅后，音乐界掀起了一股演奏交响乐的狂热。作曲家们每次发表的作品从未少于六部。许多人创作了上百部甚至更多；总数多达数千部。在这种情况下，试图寻找新风格的创始人是徒劳的。众多作曲家参与了这场新运动，最早的参与者包括意大利人、法国人和德国人。12

The symphony had its origin not in instrumental forms like the concerto grosso, as one might have expected, but in the overture of early Italian opera. The overture, or sinfonia, as it was called, as perfected by Alessandro Scarlatti consisted of three parts: fast-slow-fast, thus presaging the three movements of the classical symphony. The sinfonia, around 1750, became detached from the opera which gave it birth and led an independent life in the concert hall. Karl Nef, in his Outline of the History of Music, describes what happened. “After the theatre symphony had been transferred to the concert hall, the musical world was seized by a veritable mania to play symphonies. The composers never published less than half a dozen at a time. Many of them wrote a hundred and more; the sum total mounted to many thousands. Under these circumstances it would be idle to attempt to discover the man who founded the new style. Numerous composers collaborated in the new movement, in the earliest period Italians, Frenchmen, and Germans.”12

当时最好的管弦乐团在曼海姆从1743年到1777年一直保持着。海顿和莫扎特的前辈们在这里开创了后期交响曲的许多特色，例如管弦乐的渐强和渐弱，以及管弦乐结构中更大的灵活性。整体织体更具主音性，借鉴了歌剧风格中较为轻快的歌唱性，而非大协奏曲中较为厚重的对位手法。

The best orchestra of the day was maintained from 1743 to 1777 in Mannheim. Here the precursors of Haydn and Mozart originated many of the features of the later symphony, such as the orchestral crescendo and diminuendo and a greater flexibility in the orchestral fabric. The general texture was more homophonic, borrowing from the lighter, singing quality of operatic style, rather than the heavier contrapuntal manner of the concerto grosso.

正是在此基础上，海顿逐渐完善了交响乐风格。我们不应忘记，他在交响乐领域取得的一些最伟大成就，是在莫扎特去世后，经过了漫长的酝酿和成熟期后创作的。他留下了交响乐这一圆满的艺术形式，虽然在其自身风格的框架内，交响乐仍有进一步发展的空间，但无法达到更臻完美的境界。

It was on this foundation that Haydn gradually perfected symphonic style. We must not forget that some of his greatest achievements in this medium were created after the death of Mozart and after a long period of gestation and maturity. He left the symphony a rounded art form, capable of further development but not of greater perfection within the limits of his own style.

贝多芬著名的《九交响曲》由此铺就。这部交响曲与其歌剧起源完全脱节。它的形式更加宏大，情感范围更加开阔，管弦乐队以一种全新且前所未闻的方式演奏着，气势磅礴。贝多芬一手打造出一部似乎只有他才能掌控的巨作。

The way was paved for Beethoven’s famous Nine. The symphony lost all connection with its operatic origins. The form was enlarged, the emotional scope broadened, the orchestra stamped and thundered in a completely new and unheard-of fashion. Beethoven singlehandedly created a colossus which he alone seemed able to control.

在他之后的十九世纪作曲家——舒曼和门德尔松——创作的交响曲远不如他宏大。到了十九世纪中叶，交响曲在管弦乐领域濒临失去霸主地位的危险。“现代主义者”李斯特、柏辽兹和瓦格纳显然认为，除非交响曲能与某种纲领性理念相结合，或将其精髓融入音乐剧的主体，否则它就“过时了”。正是勃拉姆斯、布鲁克纳和柴可夫斯基等“保守派”捍卫了这项看似注定失败的事业。

For the nineteenth-century composers who followed him—Schumann and Mendelssohn—wrote a less titanic symphony. By the middle of the century, the symphony was in danger of losing its hegemony in the orchestral field. The “modernists” Liszt, Berlioz, and Wagner apparently considered the symphony “old hat” unless it was combined with some programmatic idea or incorporated in essence into the body of a music drama. It was “conservatives” like Brahms, Bruckner, and Tschaikovsky who defended what began to look very much like a lost cause.

这一时期，交响曲式出现了一项重要创新，即所谓的交响曲循环式。塞萨尔·弗兰克尤其钟爱这种手法。它试图通过统一主题素材，将整部作品的不同部分串联起来。有时，一个“座右铭”主题会在交响曲不同乐章的意外时刻出现，给人一种单一统一思想的印象。有时——这才是更真实的循环式——整部交响曲的所有主题素材可能仅源自几个原始主题，这些主题会随着作品的进展而完全变形，最初作为朴素的引子主题，最终转变为谐谑曲的主旋律，慢乐章和终曲也是如此。

One important innovation was introduced during this period as regards symphonic form, namely, the so-called cyclic form of the symphony. César Franck was especially fond of this device. It was an attempt to bind the different parts of the entire work by unifying the thematic materials. Sometimes a “motto” theme is heard at unexpected moments in different movements of the symphony, giving an impression of a single unifying thought. At other times—and this is more truly cyclic form—all thematic material in an entire symphony may be derived from only a few primal themes, which are completely metamorphosed as the work progresses, so that what was first given out as a sober introductory theme is transformed into the principal melody of the scherzo, and similarly in slow movement and finale.

如果循环乐段未能得到更广泛的采用，可能是因为它未能解决每个独立乐章中音乐逻辑的需要。也就是说，所有主题素材的统一不过是一种技巧，其趣味性或多或少取决于作曲家运用的巧妙程度，但交响曲本身仍然需要创作！同样需要解决的是形式和内容的问题，相比之下，从单一来源获取所有素材只是小事一桩。继弗兰克之后，他的学生兼弟子文森特·丹第也运用了循环乐段，而最近，埃内斯特·布洛赫也在多部作品中运用了它。

If the cyclic form has not been adopted more widely, it is probably because it does not solve the need for musical logic within each separate movement. That is, the unification of all the thematic material is no more than a device, more or less interesting depending upon the ingenuity with which it is carried out by the composer, but the symphony itself must still be written! The same problems of form and substance must be grappled with, compared to which the derivation of all the material from a single source is only a detail. After Franck, his pupil and disciple Vincent d’Indy made use of cyclic form, and more recently Ernest Bloch has utilized it in more than one work.

不久前，人们普遍认为现代作曲家已经放弃了交响曲这种形式。毫无疑问，在本世纪头二十年，一些杰出作曲家对交响曲的兴趣有所减退。德彪西、拉威尔、勋伯格和贝拉·巴托克在他们成熟的时期都没有创作交响曲。但近年来，情况有所改变。如果我们从法国作曲家米约和奥涅格的作品，俄罗斯作曲家米亚斯科夫斯基（共创作了27部作品）、普罗科菲耶夫和肖斯塔科维奇的作品，英国作曲家巴克斯、沃恩·威廉姆斯和沃尔顿，以及美国作曲家哈里斯、塞申斯和皮斯顿的作品来判断，交响曲又重新被创作出来。我们不应忘记，即使在所谓的交响曲衰落时期，马勒和西贝柳斯等中坚力量也仍在实践交响曲。或许，这表明人们对这种形式重新产生了兴趣，直到今天，他们的作品才开始在交响乐团的常规曲目中占有一席之地。

Not so very long ago, the impression was current that modern composers had abandoned the form of the symphony. No doubt there was a lull in interest on the part of leading men of the first twenty years of the present century. Debussy, Ravel, Schoenberg, and Béla Bartók in their mature years did not write symphonies. But more recently that has changed. Symphonies have been written again, if we can judge by the works of Frenchmen like Milhaud and Honegger; Russians like Miaskovsky (with twenty-seven to his credit), Prokofieff and Shostakovitch; Englishmen like Bax, Vaughan Williams, and Walton; Americans like Harris, Sessions, and Piston. We should not forget the further fact that even during the period of its supposed decline, the symphonic form was being practiced by stalwarts such as Mahler and Sibelius. Perhaps it is indicative of a renewed interest in the form that only in the present day have their works begun to find a place in the regular repertoire of symphonic organizations.

与后世的一些音乐家相比，马勒和西贝柳斯在形式处理上更加大胆。马勒一心想让这部交响曲更加宏大。他把管弦乐队的规模扩大到庞大的规模，增加了乐章的数量，在第二和第八乐章中引入了合唱团，总的来说，他承担起了继承贝多芬交响曲传统的责任。马勒被猛烈抨击为装腔作势的人，认为他的自命不凡是被误导了。但如果人们可以从他的九部交响曲的各个乐章中挑选，我确信他最终的地位将与柏辽兹相当。无论如何，我们可以在他的作品中找到新的对位织体和新的管弦乐色彩的衍生，没有这些，现代交响曲是不可想象的。

Mahler and Sibelius have been more adventurous in their treatment of the form than some of the later men. Mahler wanted desperately to make the symphony bigger than it was. He enlarged the size of the orchestra to gargantuan proportions, increased the number of movements, introduced the choral body in the Second and Eighth, and in general took it upon himself to carry on the traditions of the Beethoven symphony. Mahler has been bitterly attacked as a poseur, as having been hopelessly misled in his pretensions. But if one can pick and choose among the separate movements of his nine symphonies, I for one am certain that his eventual position will be equivalent to that of Berlioz. At any rate, we can find the derivation of new contrapuntal textures and new orchestral colors in his work, without which the modern symphony would be inconceivable.

西贝柳斯对这种曲式的运用非常自由，尤其是在他的第四和第七交响曲中。后者属于相当罕见的单乐章交响曲类型。关于西贝柳斯对交响曲式的精湛演绎，已有大量论述。但问题是，他是否偏离了通常的常规，以至于几乎与十九世纪的模式脱节。我个人猜测，尽管第七交响曲名为“交响诗”，但它的形式更接近交响诗，而非交响曲。无论如何，从普通听众的角度来看，必须记住西贝柳斯的乐章并非循规蹈矩地构建，而是更多地依赖于一个主题逐渐有机地发展为另一个主题，而不是一个主题与另一个主题之间的对比。在最佳状态下，音乐似乎会从看似毫无希望的开端逐渐绽放。

Sibelius has handled the form freely, especially in his Fourth and Seventh symphonies. The latter belongs with the rather rare species of one-movement symphonies. Much has been written of Sibelius’ masterly development of symphonic form. But it is a question whether his departures from the usual norm have not been so great as to be almost disconnected from the nineteenth-century model. My own guess is that the Seventh is closer in form, despite its name, to the symphonic poem than it is to the symphony. At any rate, from the lay listener’s point of view, it must be remembered that Sibelius’ movements are not conventionally constructed and depend more on the gradual organic growth of one theme evolving into another rather than the contrast of one theme with another. At its best, the music seems to flower, often from unpromising beginnings.

如果要概括近代作曲家对这种形式的处理，我们可以肯定地说，交响曲作为三个或更多独立乐章的集合，其地位依然如昔。这种形式依然没有丝毫的微不足道或漫不经心。它仍然是作曲家试图把握强烈情感的形式。如果说有任何根本性的变化，那很可能是单个乐章内部结构设置的变化。从这种有限的意义上讲，这种形式更加自由——素材的引入方式更加轻松——第一、第二和结束部分的划分即使存在，也远没有那么清晰；没有人能够预测发展部分的性质或再现部分的程度（如果有的话）。这就是为什么现代交响曲比那些对我们来说已经更加完整消化的古老交响曲更难聆听的原因。

If any generalizations may be made as to the handling of the form by more recent composers, one can safely say that the symphony as a collection of three or more separate movements is still as firmly established as ever. There is still nothing puny or casual about the form. It is still the form in which the composer tries to come to grips with big emotions. If any fundamental changes may be discerned, they are likely to be changes of the inner structural setup of an individual movement. In that restricted sense, the form is freer—the materials are introduced in a more relaxed way—the divisions into first, second, and closing groups are much less clear if they are present at all; no one can predict the nature of the development section or the extent of the recapitulation, if any. That’s why the modern symphony is more difficult to listen to than the older, to us more fully digested, examples of the form.

显然，这部交响曲以及随之而来的奏鸣曲-快板式尚未完成。除非所有迹象都存在误导，否则它们都将迎来一个健康的后代。

Clearly, the symphony, and with it the sonata-allegro form, is not finished yet. Unless all signs are misleading, they both will have a healthy progeny.

 

 

贝多芬——“华尔斯坦”奏鸣曲（见第三章列表）

Beethoven—“Waldstein” Sonata (see listing under Chapter Three)

马勒——C小调第二交响曲

Mahler—Symphony No. 2 in C minor

伦纳德·伯恩斯坦，纽约爱乐乐团（索尼）

Leonard Bernstein, New York Philharmonic (Sony)

勃拉姆斯——E小调第四交响曲

Brahms—Symphony No. 4 in E minor

卡洛斯·克莱伯，维也纳爱乐乐团（德意志留声机）

Carlos Kleiber, Vienna Philharmonic (Deutsche Grammophon)

舒曼——D小调第四交响曲

Schumann—Symphony No. 4 in D minor

约翰·艾略特·加德纳（德意志留声机）

John Eliot Gardiner (Deutsche Grammophon)

西贝柳斯——A小调第四交响曲

Sibelius—Symphony No. 4 in A minor

詹姆斯·莱文，柏林爱乐乐团（德意志留声机）

James Levine, Berlin Philharmonic (Deutsche Grammophon)

14

14

基本形式

Fundamental Forms

V. 自由形式

V. FREE FORMS

序曲；交响诗

The Prelude; The Symphonic Poem

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

为了理解“自由”形式的构成，我们必须了解什么是严格形式。前四章总结了严格形式的基本形式。我们发现，仅仅描述一部作品的外部结构框架并不能涵盖其真正的内在形式；作曲家可以自由运用所有形式模式，因此可以说他既依赖于这些模式，又独立于这些模式。

In order to have some conception of what a “free” form consists of, we have to know what a strict form is. In the previous four chapters, fundamental forms of the strict variety were summarized. We discovered that the mere description of the outer structural frame of a piece does not encompass the true inner form of that piece; that all formal molds are freely used by the composer, so that he may be said to be both dependent and independent of them at the same time.

所有不以任何一种常见形式模板为参考点的形式，严格来说都是“自由”形式。我们之所以给“自由”一词加上引号，是因为严格来说，并不存在绝对自由的音乐形式。无论作品多么自由，它作为形式都必须有意义。这一点显而易见；任何艺术形式都是如此，尤其对于很容易失去连贯性的音乐而言。因此，即使在所谓的自由形式中，也必然会存在一些基本的形式规划，尽管它可能与我们迄今为止讨论过的任何正常形式模板都无关。

All forms that do not have as point of reference one of the usual formal molds are technically “free” forms. We also put the word “free” in quotation marks because, properly speaking, there is no such thing as an absolutely free musical form. No matter how free a piece may be, it must always make sense as form. That much is obvious; it is true of any art, and especially true of music where it is so easy to lose the feeling of coherence. Therefore, even in so-called free forms, some basic formal plan will certainly be present, though it may be unrelated to any of the normal formal molds that we have considered up to now.

某些类型的作品似乎比其他类型的作品更自然地归于“自由”的形式。例如，声乐作品由于需要遵循歌词，通常就属于这一类别。例如，教堂弥撒，尽管其各个部分的大致轮廓是预先确定的，但其变化的可能性却几乎是无限的。一位作曲家可能会写一个非常简短的开场曲《Kyrie》，而另一位作曲家则会将其延长至十五分钟。一般来说，声乐作品在形式上比器乐作品“更自由”。

Certain types of composition seem to fall more naturally than others into forms that are “free.” Vocal works, for example, because of the necessity for following the words, often fall into that category. The church Mass, for instance, despite the fact that the general outlines of its separate parts are predetermined, has almost limitless possibilities for variety. One composer may write a very short opening Kyrie, whereas another will stretch it out to last for fifteen minutes. In general, vocal compositions are “freer” in form than instrumental works.

在器乐作品中，钢琴和管弦乐作品比室内乐更有可能采用“自由”形式。这可能是因为“自由”形式在音乐中经常与音乐之外的理念联系在一起，而室内乐几乎总是被归入所谓的“绝对音乐”范畴。如果作曲家从音乐之外的理念入手，他很可能会发现常规形式的刻板模式过于局限，无法达到他的目的，这很自然。许多近期“自由”形式的例子或许可以归因于此。

Among instrumental pieces, piano and orchestral works are more likely to be in “free” forms than chamber music. This may have come about because “free” forms are so often used in music in connection with extramusical ideas, and chamber music almost always fits into the category of so-called “absolute music.” It is only natural that if a composer starts with an extramusical idea, he will probably find the stereotyped patterns of the usual forms too constricting for his purposes. Many recent examples of “free” form may be credited to that source.

显然，我们无法对“自由”形式进行概括。然而，可以肯定地说，我们很可能在两种类型的作品中遇到它们：前奏曲和交响诗（或音调诗）。

It is obviously impossible to make generalizations about “free” forms. Nevertheless, it is safe to say that we are likely to meet them in one of two types of composition: the prelude and the symphonic, or tone, poem.

前奏曲是一个非常宽泛的术语，涵盖了各种类型的乐曲，通常是为钢琴而写的。作为标题，它可以指任何类型，从宁静忧郁的乐曲到冗长华丽的技艺精湛的乐曲。但就形式而言，它通常属于“自由”类别。前奏曲是任何形式结构不太明确的乐曲的统称。许多其他名称不同的乐曲都属于同一类别，例如幻想曲、挽歌、即兴曲、随想曲、咏叹调、练习曲等等。这类乐曲可能是严格的ABA形式，也可能是“自由”处理的。因此，听众如果希望跟上作曲家的结构思路，就必须提高警惕。

The prelude is a very loose term for a large variety of pieces, generally written for piano. As a title, it may mean almost anything from a quiet, melancholy piece to a long and showy, virtuoso piece. But as form it will generally be found to belong in the “free” category. Prelude is a generic name for any piece of not too specific formal structure. Many other pieces with different names belong in the same category—pieces that are called fantasy, elegy, impromptu, capriccio, aria, étude, and so forth. Pieces such as these may be in strict A-B-A form, or they may be “freely” treated. The listener, therefore, must be on the alert if he expects to follow the composer’s structural idea.

巴赫创作了大量前奏曲（通常后接一段平衡赋格），其中许多都是“自由”形式。布索尼正是以此作为他认为音乐应走之路的典范。巴赫在这些“自由”前奏曲中实现了设计的统一，他要么采用特征明确的模式，要么采用清晰的和声推进，将乐曲从开头引向结尾，而无需重复主题素材。通常，两种方法相结合。通过这些方式，巴赫营造出一种自由幻想的感觉和大胆的设计自由，这是在严格的形式中无法实现的。听到这些作品，人们会越来越相信布索尼说得非常正确，未来音乐形式的处理问题与这种巴赫式的形式自由息息相关。

Bach wrote a good many preludes (very often followed by a balancing fugue) many of which are in “free” form. It was these that Busoni pointed to as an example of the path that he thought music should take. Bach achieved a unity of design in these “free” preludes either by adopting a pattern of well-defined character or by a clear progression of chordal harmonies which lead one from the beginning of a piece to the end without utilizing any repetition of thematic materials. Often, both methods are combined. By these means Bach engenders a feeling of free fantasy and a bold freedom of design that would be impossible to achieve within a strict form. When one hears them, the conviction grows that Busoni was quite right in saying that the future problems of handling form in music are bound up with this Bach-like freedom in form.

巴赫《平均律古钢琴曲》第一卷中的降B大调前奏曲就是一个很好的例子。这首曲子完全没有主题，也没有任何主题由乐段构成。音乐就是以这种模式开始的（见下文）。

An excellent illustration is the B flat major Prelude from Bach’s Well Tempered Clavichord, Book I. Here there can be no question of themes and their being built up by sections. The music begins with this pattern (see below).

到达乐段中途时，巴赫放弃了他的模式，转而采用一系列饱满的和弦，其间穿插着回旋和音阶段落。只有在倒数第二小节，才提到了开头的模式，而且即使那样，也没有真正重复音符，而仅仅是重复一个音符。此类作品中统一原则的唯一外在标志是骨架式的和弦框架。在巴赫的幻想曲中可以找到其他更宏伟的例子，例如在半音阶幻想与赋格或著名的 G 小调管风琴幻想与赋格中。尤其是在他的大型管风琴作品中，巴赫通过运用这种更自由的结构类型创造了一种非凡的壮丽感。

By the time the halfway mark has been reached, Bach abandons his pattern for a series of full-sounding chords, interspersed with roulades and scale passages. Only in the penultimate measure is there a reference to the pattern of the beginning, and even then there is no actual repetition of notes but merely one of pattern. The only outward sign of a unifying principle in a piece of this kind is the skeletal chordal frame. Other illustrations of a much grander kind are to be found in Bach’s Fantasies, for instance in the Chromatic Fantasy and Fugue or the famous G minor organ Fantasy and Fugue. Particularly in his big organ works, Bach creates an extraordinary sense of magnificence through utilization of this freer type of structure.

在十九世纪的大部分时间里，作曲家们创作的音乐形式都很容易辨认。这无疑是因为在三部曲或奏鸣曲-快板曲式的框架内，音乐形式可以呈现出相当程度的多样性。但即使在十九世纪后期，随着理查·施特劳斯的出现——他无疑专注于其大型管弦乐作品中“自由”形式的问题——音乐的重点仍然放在主题的陈述及其充分发展上。

For the larger part of the nineteenth century, composers wrote in forms that are easily identified. This was due, no doubt, to the considerable degree of variety that could be achieved within the limits of three-part, or sonata-allegro, form. But even later in the century, with the advent of Richard Strauss, who certainly was preoccupied with the problems of “free” forms in his large orchestral works, the emphasis is still on the statement of themes and their full development.

我认为，本世纪人们对真正“自由”曲式兴趣的复苏，很大程度上要归功于德彪西的影响。他以极具个人特色的方式创作短曲式，在当时的音乐界鲜有先例。他没有参考任何已知的范本，而是创作了二十四首钢琴前奏曲，每首都各具特色。每创作一首新的前奏曲都意味着发明一种新的曲式，因为创作一首前奏曲并不能促进下一首前奏曲的创作。难怪他的作品相对较少。

Much of the revival of interest in true “free” forms during the present century is attributable, I believe, to Debussy’s influence. He had very little precedent in the music of his time for the highly individual fashion in which he worked in short forms. Without depending upon any known models, he composed twenty-four Preludes for piano, each one of which has its own formal character. Each new Prelude meant inventing a new form, for the writing of one did not help in the creation of the next. No wonder his output was comparatively small.

如同巴赫的图案设计一样，德彪西有时会运用微小的图案或主题，来辅助衔接作品。例如，钢琴前奏曲《雪中脚步》 （Des pas sur la neige）。这首小主题始终作为背景贯穿始终。它由单一节奏构成，每次旋律都向上移动一级，例如：13

Just as in the case of the pattern design of Bach, Debussy sometimes makes use of a tiny figure, or motif, as an aid in binding a piece together. Take, for example, the piano prelude called Footsteps in the Snow (Des pas sur la neige). Here the tiny motif is consistently retained as background throughout the piece. It is a combination of a single rhythm which melodically moves a step upward each time, thus:13

在那神秘而令人回味的音型之上，一段典型的德彪西式旋律，如幽灵般飘渺，片段式地展开。请注意，这段旋律从未重复；相反，它似乎在一系列犹豫和隐秘的冲动中逐渐自发地涌现，最终微妙而坚定地获得一种圆满的感悟。这首曲子无疑是统一的，但其统一的方式与德彪西的前辈们截然不同。

Above that mysteriously evocative figure, a typically Debussian melody, wraithlike and fragmentary, is heard. Note that the melody is never repeated; instead it seems gradually to come to life of its own accord, through a series of hesitations and secret impulsions until, delicately but surely, a sense of completion is obtained. The piece certainly is unified, but the means for unification are quite different from those used by Debussy’s forerunners.

自德彪西时代以来，音乐形式越来越倾向于自由，但如今它却给普通听众带来了严重的障碍。有两个因素使音乐易于聆听：简单的旋律和大量的重复。新音乐往往包含相当深奥的旋律，并避免重复。一种相反的趋势已经出现——追求浓缩。人们可以在阿诺德·勋伯格的钢琴曲集（作品 19）中最清楚地看到这种趋势（没有录音）。在每一首钢琴小曲中，情感的强度都如此之大，以至于重复是不可想象的。有时甚至没有主题可言——在一首曲子中一个小小的节奏，在另一首曲子中一个和弦就足以吸引听众。当出现旋律时，它既不容易掌握，也不会停下来重复已经讲过的内容。因此，观众觉得勋伯格难以接受也就不足为奇了。总的来说，我认为音乐爱好者在理解所谓的现代音乐时遇到的困难有一半是源于对音乐组合方式的缺乏理解。

Since Debussy’s time, form has tended toward greater and greater freedom, until it now presents serious obstacles for the lay listener. Two things make music easy to listen to: a melody that is straightforward and plenty of repetition. New music often contains rather recondite melodies and avoids repetition. An opposite tendency has asserted itself—the urge toward condensation. One can see that tendency most clearly in the Piano Pieces, Op. 19, of Arnold Schoenberg, a work of his middle period (no recording available). In each of these little piano pieces, the intensity of emotion is so great that repetition would be unthinkable. Sometimes there is no theme to speak of—in one piece a tiny rhythm, in another a single chord is enough to hold the listener. When a melody is present, neither is it easy to grasp, nor does it ever stop to go over ground already covered. It isn’t surprising therefore, that audiences find Schoenberg hard to take. In general, I should say that half the difficulty music lovers find in understanding so-called modern music comes from a lack of comprehension of the way in which the music is put together.

交响诗

SYMPHONIC POEM

我们如今拥有形式自由的原因之一，很可能是交响诗的创作。交响诗，或称音调诗，提出了标题音乐的问题，这个问题必须首先阐明。

One of the reasons for our present freedom of form may very well be the creation of the symphonic poem. The symphonic, or tone, poem brings up the question of program music which must be elucidated first.

读者应该在心中清楚地区分标题音乐（以某种方式与故事或诗歌理念相联系的音乐）和所谓的“绝对”音乐（没有音乐以外的内涵）。用音乐作为描述自身之外事物的手段是非常自然的，几乎像孩子一样的想法。事实上，这是一个相当古老的想法，因为即使是 17 世纪的作曲家也倾向于用音乐来描述事物。战争是人们喜爱的主题；而且，在器乐繁荣之前，模仿动物就已经很受欢迎。库瑙是巴赫和亨德尔的前辈，他以《圣经奏鸣曲》而闻名，其中的圣经故事，如大卫杀死歌利亚，在音乐中被“现实地”描绘出来。雅内昆的杰作《鸟鸣》（Chant des oiseaux）完美展现了十六世纪作曲家如何通过人声合唱模仿鸟鸣。女人的咯咯声也是他尝试的主题。可见，这个想法并非新想法。

The reader should clearly distinguish in his own mind the difference between program music, which is music connected in some way with a story or poetic idea, and so-called “absolute” music, which has no extramusical connotations. To use music as a means of describing something outside itself is a perfectly natural, almost childlike idea. It is a rather old idea, as a matter of fact, for even composers of the seventeenth century had a penchant for describing things musically. Battles were favorite themes; also the imitation of animals was in high favor even before the flowering of instrumental music. Kuhnau, a predecessor of Bach and Handel, has made himself justly famous with his Bible Sonatas, in which biblical stories, such as the slaying of Goliath by David, are “realistically” portrayed in the music. Jannequin’s remarkable Chant des oiseaux will give an excellent illustration of what a composer of the sixteenth century could do in the way of imitating the sounds of birds by means of a chorus of human beings. Women’s Cackle was another subject he essayed. So you see the idea is not a new one.

但直到十九世纪，作曲家才真正能够很好地描述事物。音乐变得越来越不天真。如今，如果你想用音乐重现一场战斗，在现代管弦乐队的伴奏下，你很可能会创作出一幅相当不愉快的现实主义画面。换句话说，十九世纪发展了用音乐更精确地描述音乐之外事件的方法。也许歌剧的发展也让作曲家对音乐的描述能力产生了兴趣。我们也不能忘记浪漫主义运动的影响。浪漫主义作曲家仅仅写一首悲伤的作品是不够的；他想让你知道是谁感到悲伤，以及他悲伤的具体情况。这就是为什么柴可夫斯基不满足于写一首带有优美第二主题的无题序曲，而是将其命名为《罗密欧与朱丽叶》，从而将主题标记为“罗密欧对朱丽叶的爱”动机。

But it wasn’t until the nineteenth century that composers were really able to describe things well. Music became less and less naive. Nowadays if you wish to reenact a battle musically, given a modern orchestra, the chances are that you can probably create a pretty unpleasantly realistic picture. The nineteenth century, in other words, developed the means for a more exact depiction in musical terms of extramusical events. Perhaps the development of opera also was responsible for interesting composers in the descriptive powers of music. Nor must we forget the influence of the romantic movement. It wasn’t enough for a romantic composer to write a sad piece; he wanted you to know who it was that felt sad and the particular circumstances of his sadness. That is why Tschaikovsky was not satisfied to write an untitled overture with a beautiful second theme but called it Romeo and Juliet, thereby labeling the theme as the “Romeo’s-love-for-Juliet” motif.

贝多芬本人，正如《田园交响曲》所见证的，被用音乐语言描述外部事件的想法所吸引。他的音乐作品是描述性管弦乐的先驱之一。贝多芬在《第六交响曲》中开创了这一先河，这部杰出的作品为柏辽兹的整个职业生涯奠定了基础。《梦幻交响曲》是十九世纪作曲家在生动描绘田园或战争场景方面取得的进步的一个惊人例证，他们不仅能够生动地描绘田园或战争场景，还能描绘他们想要描绘的任何事件或想法。

Beethoven himself, as witness the Pastoral Symphony, was attracted by the idea of describing outward events in musical terms. His was one of the first examples of descriptive orchestral music. What Beethoven began in his Sixth Symphony, as an exceptional work, Berlioz made the basis for an entire career. The Fantastic Symphony is an amazing example of the progress composers had made in the nineteenth century in the ability to describe graphically not only pastoral or warlike scenes but any event or idea that they chose to depict.

一般来说，描述性音乐有两种。第一种属于文字描述。作曲家希望重现夜晚的钟声。因此，他为管弦乐队、钢琴或他使用的任何媒介创作特定的和弦，使其听起来像夜晚的钟声。真实的东西被现实地模仿。这种音乐描述的一个著名例子是施特劳斯一首交响诗中模仿羊咩咩叫的段落。在这一点上，音乐的存在理由仅仅是模仿。

Speaking generally, there are two kinds of descriptive music. The first comes under the heading of literal description. A composer wishes to recreate the sound of bells in the night. He therefore writes certain chords, for orchestra or piano or whatever medium he is using, which actually sound like bells in the night. Something real is being imitated realistically. A famous example of that kind of description in music is the passage in one of Strauss’s tone poems where he imitates the bleating of sheep. The music has no other raison d’être than mere imitation at that point.

另一种描述性音乐则不那么刻板，更具诗意。它并不刻意描绘特定的场景或事件；然而，某些外在环境会激起作曲家的某些情感，他希望将这些情感传达给听众。这些情感可能是云朵、大海、集市或飞机。但关键在于，它并非字面意义上的模仿，而是对作曲家心中所反映的现象进行音乐诗意化的转录。这构成了标题音乐的更高级形式。羊咩咩叫声听起来永远是羊咩咩叫声，但音乐中描绘的云朵却赋予了想象力更大的自由。

The other type of descriptive music is less literal and more poetic. No attempt is made to describe a particular scene or event; nevertheless some outward circumstance arouses certain emotions in the composer which he wishes to communicate to the listener. It may be clouds or the sea or a country fair or an airplane. But the point is that instead of literal imitation, one gets a musicopoetic transcription of the phenomenon as reflected in the composer’s mind. That constitutes a higher form of program music. The bleating of sheep will always sound like the bleating of sheep, but a cloud portrayed in music allows the imagination more freedom.

必须牢记一个原则：无论音乐多么具有纲领性或描述性，它都必须仅以音乐的形式存在。永远不要让作曲家根据故事内容来向你证明他的作品的合理性。仅仅因为女主人公的死期不合时宜而缓慢地结束一部作品是不够的。缓慢的结局也必须通过音乐内容来证明。简而言之，故事趣味永远不能取代音乐趣味，也不能成为音乐程序的借口。音乐必须能够独立存在，这样即使对故事一无所知的人听到它也不会以任何方式影响他的享受。换句话说，故事绝不能仅仅是一个额外的吸引力。即使你不知道标题，《罗密欧与朱丽叶》也是柴可夫斯基最好的作品之一。第一个主题充满戏剧性、扣人心弦且结构严谨。如果你知道它象征着蒙太古家族和凯普莱特家族之间的争斗，那么这个主题可能对你来说更有意义；但与此同时，它无疑限制了其想象力的吸引力。这是所有标题音乐都面临的风险。或许正因如此，如今的作曲家创作的标题音乐远不如上世纪末那么多。

One principle must be kept firmly in mind: No matter how programmatic or descriptive music may be, it must always exist in terms of music alone. Never allow a composer to justify his piece to you because of the story content. It is not sufficient to close a piece slowly because the heroine meets an untimely end. That slow end must also be justified by the musical content. In short, story interest can never take the place of musical interest; nor can it be made an excuse for musical procedure. The music must be able to stand on its own feet, so that a person hearing it with no knowledge of the story would not have his enjoyment curtailed in any way. In other words, the story must never be more than an added attraction. Romeo and Juliet is one of Tschaikovsky’s best pieces even if you don’t know the title. The first theme is dramatic and exciting and well knit. If you happen to be aware that it symbolizes the fight between the rival houses of Montague and Capulet, the theme may seem more pertinent to you; but at the same time it undoubtedly limits its imaginative appeal. That is the danger that all programmatic music runs. Possibly because of it, composers nowadays do not write nearly so much program music as was customary at the end of the past century.

令人惊讶的是，相当一部分标题音乐是用某种基本形式写成的。人们本以为，既然作曲家在描述某种事物，形式就必然是自由的。但事实往往并非如此。尤其是在初期，绝对音乐及其形式模式的影响力过于强大，令人难以忽视。因此，贝多芬的《田园交响曲》首先是一部交响曲，其次才是田园交响曲。同样，《罗密欧与朱丽叶》充满激情的戏剧性，也出人意料地轻松地融入了常规的奏鸣曲-快板式，包括引子、第一和第二主题、展开部和再现部。直到施特劳斯和德彪西，作曲家才有勇气为了更忠实于他们的标题意图而放弃更严格的形式。这种更大自由的开端当然是交响诗的创造，它是十九世纪为数不多的新形式之一。

Surprisingly enough, a considerable amount of program music is written in one or another of the fundamental forms. One would have expected that since the composer was describing something, the form would necessarily be free. That is often not the case. In the beginning, especially, the hold of absolute music and its formal molds was too strong to be ignored. Thus Beethoven’s Pastoral Symphony is a symphony first and a pastoral symphony only in a secondary sense. Likewise, the passionate drama of Romeo fits with surprising ease into the regular sonata-allegro form with an introduction, first and second theme, development, and recapitulation. It wasn’t until Strauss and Debussy that composers had the courage to abandon stricter forms for the sake of greater fidelity to their programmatic intentions. The beginning of that greater freedom was, of course, the creation of the symphonic poem, one of the few new forms in the nineteenth century.

李斯特普遍被认为是交响诗的创始人。他一人创作了十三首交响诗，其中一些至今仍在演奏。李斯特意识到，如果要恰当地表达诗歌理念，就不能局限于更严格的形式，即使柏辽兹在其标题交响曲中也运用了这种形式。他提出了单乐章交响诗的解决方法，并在出版的乐谱中附有引言。其他作曲家纷纷效仿李斯特，例如圣桑、塞萨尔·弗兰克、保罗·杜卡斯、柴可夫斯基、斯美塔那、巴拉基列夫以及许多与其相比不那么杰出的作曲家。他们的交响诗并非都采用“自由”形式，但其原则已确立。

Liszt is generally credited with having originated the symphonic poem. He wrote thirteen of them himself, some of which are still performed. Liszt realized that a poetic idea, if it was to be properly expressed, could not be confined to the limits of the stricter forms, even as applied by Berlioz in his programmatic symphonies. The one-movement symphonic poem, with an introductory explanation printed in the published score, was his solution. Liszt’s example was followed by other composers, notably Saint-Saëns, César Franck, Paul Dukas, Tschaikovsky, Smetana, Balakireff, and a host of lesser men. Not all their tone poems are in “free” forms. But the principle had been established.

理查·施特劳斯在 1890 年至 1900 年间创作了一系列交响诗，其自由和大胆震惊了音乐界。这些交响诗在逻辑上继承了李斯特的思想，但更加宏大和自命不凡。早期的交响诗类似于交响曲的一个乐章，而施特劳斯的音诗更像是一部完整的交响曲。尽管存在明显的弱点，最终可能会影响它们在交响乐曲目中看似稳固的地位，但它们仍然是非凡的成就。作为图像表现形式，它们几乎没有对手，作为自由形式的处理，它们是同类中的首创。即使它们依赖于回旋曲（蒂尔·欧伦斯皮格尔）或变奏曲（堂吉诃德）等更严格的形式，对素材的处理也非常不落俗套，以至于构成了实际上的“自由”形式。在《英雄生涯》（Ein Heldenleben）或《查拉图斯特拉如是说》（Also sprach Zarathustra ）中，其形式可以说是分段构建的，但其规模之大，却使其整体结构呈现出危险的头重脚轻。人类的思维是否真的能够将一段持续四十多分钟、不间断的自由形式中的各个时刻联系起来，这仍是一个问题。无论如何，这正是施特劳斯要求我们做的。要充分理解施特劳斯交响诗的形式轮廓，需要的解释比本书所能提供的更多。

Richard Strauss, between 1890 and 1900, wrote a series of symphonic poems which astonished the musical world by their freedom and daring. They were the logical heirs of Liszt’s idea but on a much grander and more pretentious plane. The earlier symphonic poem was analogous with a single movement of a symphony, but the Straussian tone poem is more the equivalent of the full-sized symphony. Despite obvious weaknesses, which may eventually affect their present seemingly solid position in the symphonic repertoire, they are remarkable achievements. As pictorial representation they have few rivals, and as treatment of forms that were free they were the first of their kind. Even when they lean on one of the stricter forms such as the rondo (Till Eulenspiegel) or the variation (Don Quixote), the handling of the material is so unconventional as to constitute what is practically a “free” form. In Ein Heldenleben (A Hero’s Life) or Also sprach Zarathustra , where the form may be said to be sectionally built, the mere size is so big as to make the composition dangerously top-heavy. It is a question whether the human mind can really relate the separate moments of a free form that lasts more than forty minutes without pause. That, at any rate, is what Strauss asks us to do. To grasp adequately the formal contours of a Strauss tone poem would take more explaining than is possible within the limits of this book.

使纲领性思想与时俱进是非常简单的事情。所需要的只是用音乐术语描述一些典型的现代现象，例如工业厂房或流线型快艇。这样做很容易给旧思想披上一层似是而非的现代气息。正如我已经说过的，近代作曲家并没有写太多的纲领性音乐。然而，也有例外。阿图尔·奥涅格因其名为《太平洋 2-3-1》的短管弦乐而声名鹊起。这个标题指的是欧洲一种以该名字命名的特定类型的火车头。奥涅格利用了这样一个事实，即火车的缓慢启动、逐渐加速、在空间中飞驰、减速直至完全停止与音乐之间存在一定的相似性。他巧妙地让听众感受到蒸汽的嘶嘶声和机械装置的突突声，同时又创作出一部结构严谨、旋律与和声和谐的作品，如同其他作品一样。《太平洋2-3-1》是现代标题音乐的典范；如果它算不上一部伟大的作品，那是因为部分旋律素材质量不佳，而非标题音乐本身的处理不当。

To bring the programmatic idea up to date is a very simple matter. All that is necessary is to describe in musical terms some typically modern phenomenon such as an industrial plant or a streamlined speedboat. By so doing it is easy enough to give the old idea a specious air of modernity. As I have already said, recent composers have not written much program music. Nevertheless, there have been exceptions. Arthur Honegger came in for a considerable amount of notoriety because of his short orchestral piece called Pacific 2-3-1. The title refers to a specific type of locomotive which is known by that name in Europe. Honegger took advantage of the fact that there is a certain analogy between the slow starting of a train, its gradual pickup of speed, its rush through space, and the slowing down to a full stop—and music. He manages very well to give the listener an impression of the hissing of steam and the chug-chug of the mechanism and, at the same time, to write a piece solidly constructed of melodies and harmonies like any other piece. Pacific 2-3-1 is an excellent example of modern program music; if it is not a great piece of music, it is because of the poor quality of some of the melodic material rather than the treatment of the programmatic idea itself.

从字面意义上来说，标题音乐显然正在衰落。奥涅格创作了第二部标题音乐作品《橄榄球》；莫索洛夫创作了《铸铁厂》；其他作曲家则以职业拳击比赛、溜冰场、广播电台、福特工厂、五分钱和一角钱商店作为音乐描述的素材。但是，一方面是脱离印象派音乐的潮流，另一方面是新古典主义的冲动，使得标题音乐的追随者相对较少。如今的作曲家，或者说大多数作曲家，不喜欢混合他们的音乐类型；他们要么创作纯粹的戏剧作品，要么创作纯音乐。但没有人能够预言标题音乐何时会重新引起人们的兴趣。新的电子乐器，一旦足够完善，无疑将为音乐的模仿能力开辟全新的可能性。

Program music, in this literal sense, is apparently on the wane. Honegger wrote a second programmatic piece called Rugby; Mossolov wrote his Iron Foundry; other composers have used prize fights, skating rinks, radio stations, Ford factories, five and ten cent stores as material for musical description. But the trend away from impressionist music on the one hand and the urge toward neoclassicism on the other has left program music with comparatively few adherents. Composers nowadays, or most of them, prefer not to mix their categories; either they write straight theatrical works or they write absolute music. But no one can prophesy when program music may develop a recrudescence of interest. New electrical instruments, when they are sufficiently perfected, will undoubtedly open up brand-new possibilities for the imitative powers of music.

 

 

巴赫—— 《平均律钢琴曲集》（参见第二章列表）

Bach—Well-Tempered Clavier (see listing under Chapter Two)

德彪西——钢琴前奏曲

Debussy—Preludes for Piano

沃尔特·吉泽金 (Angel-EMI)

Walter Gieseking (Angel-EMI)

R·施特劳斯—— 《堂吉诃德》

R. Strauss—Don Quixote

史蒂文·伊瑟利斯（大提琴）、埃多·德·瓦特（指挥）（维珍经典）

Steven Isserlis (cello), Edo de Waart (conductor) (Virgin Classics)

柴可夫斯基—— 《罗密欧与朱丽叶》幻想序曲

Tschaikovsky—Romeo and Juliet, Fantasy Overture

夏尔·杜图瓦，伦敦交响乐团（伦敦）

Charles Dutoit, London Symphony (London)

15

15

歌剧和音乐剧

Opera and Music Drama

迄今为止，人们仅仅将更智慧地聆听视为与音乐会音乐相关的问题。尽管这听起来可能有些奇怪，但以音乐本身为目的，与任何音乐之外的理念毫无关联，这并非表面上的自然现象。音乐并非始于音乐会音乐，这一点毋庸置疑。只是在经历了长达一个世纪的历史发展之后，那些为了自身而聆听的音乐，才得以看似自给自足。

Up to now, the question of listening more intelligently has been considered solely in relation to music that comes under the heading of concert music. Strange as it may seem, music that is an end in itself, having no connection with any extramusical idea, is not the natural phenomenon that it seems to be. Music did not begin as concert music, certainly. It was only after century-long historical developments that music, listened to for its own sake, was able to seem self-sufficient.

相比之下，戏剧音乐则显得格外自然。它的起源可以追溯到原始部落的原始仪式音乐，或是中世纪宗教剧的圣咏。即使在今天，为戏剧、电影或芭蕾舞创作的音乐似乎也自成一派。唯一一种颇具争议、因此需要解释的戏剧音乐形式，是歌剧。

Theatrical music, on the other hand, is, by comparison, a perfectly natural thing. Its origins go as far back as the primitive ritual music of a savage tribe or the religious chant of a sacred play in the Middle Ages. Even today, music written to accompany a play, film, or ballet seems self-explanatory. The only form of theatrical music that is at all controversial, and therefore in need of some explaining, is the operatic form.

在我们这个时代，歌剧是一种名声稍逊的艺术形式。我当然指的是音乐“精英”的观点。这并非总是如此。曾经有一段时间，歌剧被认为比其他任何形式都更先进。但直到最近，精英阶层还习惯于以某种居高临下的姿态谈论歌剧。

Opera in our own day is an art form with a somewhat tarnished reputation. I speak, naturally, of the opinion of the musical “elite.” That wasn’t always true. There was a time when opera was thought of as a more advanced form than any other. But until quite recently, it was customary among the elite to speak of the operatic form with a certain amount of condescension.

歌剧声名狼藉的原因有很多。其中最重要的一点就是歌剧带有瓦格纳的“污点”。在他去世后的至少三十年里，整个音乐界都在竭尽全力摆脱瓦格纳的巨大影响。但这并非因为他的音乐，而只是意味着每一代新人都必须创作自己的音乐；而这是一件非常困难的事情，尤其是在瓦格纳去世后的歌剧院里。

There were several reasons for the disrepute into which opera fell. Among the first of these was the fact that opera bore the “taint” of Wagner about it. For at least thirty years after his death, the entire musical world made heroic efforts to throw off the terrific impact of Wagner. That is no reflection on his music. It simply means that each new generation must create its own music; and it was a very difficult thing to do, particularly in the opera house, immediately after Wagner had lived.

此外，撇开瓦格纳式的音乐剧不谈，可以坦诚地说，蜂拥而至聆听歌剧的观众并没有给歌剧增添多少光彩。一方面，它与有时被称为“理发师观众”的群体联系在一起——这些人是一群音乐爱好者，认为真正的音乐艺术是一本不可触及的书。另一方面，还有“社会公众”，他们把歌剧变成了一个时尚的游乐场，只关注其马戏表演的一面。

Moreover, quite aside from Wagnerian music drama, it might truthfully be said that the public that flocked to hear opera did the form little credit. On the one hand, it became associated with what was sometimes called a “barber public”—musical groundlings for whom the real art of music was assumed to be a closed book. On the other hand, there was the “society public,” turning the opera into a fashionable playground, with an eye only for its circus aspect.

此外，目前上演的剧目大多是些老掉牙的“老掉牙”的陈词滥调，过时的摆设，只适合让电影大亨们叹为观止。在这种情况下，怎么可能再塞入一部以20世纪20年代更现代的风格创作的新歌剧呢？尽管这种新的、革命性的音乐早已席卷音乐厅。在音乐精英们看来，所有故作严肃的音乐似乎都会被歌剧院拒之门外。即使一部新作品幸运地登上了歌剧舞台，如果它之前没有被传统歌剧制作的矫揉造作所扼杀，观众很可能会觉得它太过深奥。

Moreover, the repertoire currently performed was made up for the most part of old “chestnuts,” outmoded show pieces that were fit only to strike awe in the mind of a movie magnate. How could one possibly think of injecting into this situation a new opera written in the more up-to-date manner of the 1920’s, despite the fact that this new, revolutionary music was already invading the concert halls? To the musical elite, all music of serious pretensions seemed to be automatically ruled out of the opera house. If by lucky chance a new work did reach the operatic stage, it was more than likely to be found too esoteric for the audience, if it hadn’t previously been annihilated by the artificialities of the conventional opera production.

这些是那些认真对待音乐的人低估歌剧这一艺术形式的原因之一。然而，大约在1924年，人们对歌剧的兴趣又重新燃起，这股热潮起源于德国。当时，德国的每个小镇都有一座歌剧院。据说，当时至少有10个一流歌剧院和20个二流歌剧院，几乎全年都在演出。我们不应忘记，在德国，歌剧的地位已经超过了我们的音乐喜剧、电影和戏剧的总和。每个善良的公民都每周订阅一次歌剧，因此，歌剧作为一种艺术形式进行革新几乎成了一项社会义务。此外，音乐出版商也大力鼓励新歌剧作品的创作。一部真正成功的歌剧能为作者和出版商带来丰厚的经济回报。当时，作曲家创作歌剧，出版商出版歌剧，都有足够的动力，此外，战后观众也对体验非传统意义上的全新歌剧形式感兴趣。不久之后，人们的兴趣也蔓延到了其他国家，甚至我们自己的大都会歌剧院也偶尔演出一部具有代表性的现代歌剧，以表达对新歌剧的敬意。

Those are some of the reasons for the low estimate of the opera as a form in the opinion of the people who look upon music seriously. But around 1924 a renewal of interest in opera began, which had its origin in Germany. Every small town in Germany has an opera house. There were said to be, around that time, at least ten first-class and twenty secondclass operatic stages that functioned most of the year round. We must not forget that in Germany the opera takes the place of our musical comedy, movie, and theater combined. Every good citizen owns his weekly subscription to the opera, so that there was almost a social obligation for opera to renew itself as a form. Moreover, publishers of music did much to encourage the writing of new operatic works. A really successful opera brought a large financial return to both authors and publishers. There was then plenty of incentive for composers to write operas and publishers to print them, plus the added advantage of a postwar audience interested in experiencing new operatic ventures off the conventional path. Before long, interest spread to other countries, and even our own Metropolitan half-heartedly paid its respects to new opera by an occasional performance of a representative modern work.

如果读者要相信歌剧中新注入的生命力有其合理性，他必须对歌剧这种形式有所了解。我确信我的许多读者都认为歌剧是一种枯燥乏味的形式，如果可以避免，他们根本不想去看歌剧演出。让我们看看有什么方法可以打破这种偏见。

If the reader is to be convinced that the life newly imbued in opera has some justification, he must have some understanding of opera as a form. I feel sure that many of my readers are convinced that opera is a dull form and do not ever want to go to an operatic performance if they can possibly avoid it. Let us see what can be said to break down that prejudice.

首先要强调的一点，也是再怎么强调也不为过的一点，就是歌剧从头到脚都受着惯例的束缚。当然，歌剧并非唯一受此束缚的艺术形式。例如，剧院假装房间里有一面墙，而我们则以某种神奇的方式，在真实生活上演时旁观。初次参观剧院的孩子会想象那里发生的一切都是真实发生的；但我们成年人却毫不费力地接受了舞台的惯例，认为它们是真实的，尽管我们很清楚演员们只是在装腔作势。关键在于，歌剧也有其惯例——而且比剧院的惯例更为重要。如果你想更坦然地接受歌剧院更伟大的惯例，那么你必须意识到自己在多大程度上接受了剧院的惯例。

The first point to be made, and one that cannot be too strongly emphasized, is that opera is bound from head to foot by convention. Of course, opera is not the only form of art that is so bound. The theater, for example, pretends that the fourth wall of a room is there and that we, in some miraculous way, look on while real life is being enacted. Children who visit the theater for the first time imagine that everything that occurs there is really happening; but we grownups have no trouble in accepting the convention of the stage as real, though we very well know that the actors are only making believe. The point is that opera has its conventions, too—and still greater ones than the theater. It is important for you to realize to what an extent you accept convention in the theater if you are to be less reluctant to accept the still greater one of the opera house.

从某种意义上说，歌剧只是唱出来的戏剧，而非说出来的戏剧。这是惯例中最重要的一个，而且与现实完全不符。即便如此，歌剧也并非连续演唱（至少在瓦格纳时代之前是如此），而是被分解成规律对比的固定乐段——这使得它与其所描绘的现实更加脱节。此外，所讲述的故事往往充满了难以言喻的愚蠢。歌剧舞台上似乎从未发生过任何有意义的事情。歌剧演员的表演也丝毫没有减轻歌剧剧本（歌剧剧本的称呼）的愚蠢。

In a sense, an opera is simply a drama sung instead of a drama spoken. That is the first of the conventions and completely at variance with reality. Even so, the drama is not sung continuously (until Wagner’s time, at any rate) but, instead, is broken up into regularly contrasted, set musical pieces—which removes it one step farther from any connection with the reality that it is supposedly depicting. Moreover, the story that is being told is often of a fatuity that can hardly be exaggerated. Nothing sensible ever seems to take place on an operatic stage. Nor does the acting of opera singers conspire to aid in making the libretto—as the book of an opera is called—any the less fatuous.

最后，还有宣叙调的问题——歌剧中既非说也非唱，而是半唱半唱的部分——它只讲述故事（尤其是在古老的歌剧中），却丝毫没有试图激发听众的音乐兴趣。当歌剧用听众不熟悉的语言演唱时，就像大多数英语国家的歌剧一样，这些宣叙调部分可能会令人感到无比无聊。这些事实证明，歌剧并非现实主义的艺术形式；我们也不能要求它必须现实主义。事实上，没有人比只理解艺术中的现实主义的人更令人厌倦。除非眼前的事物看似真实，否则绝不相信，这体现了一种相当低劣的艺术心态。我们必须承认，象征性的东西也能反映现实，有时甚至比单纯的现实主义更能带来审美愉悦。歌剧院是寻找这些更具象征意义的愉悦的好地方。简而言之，我一直试图传达的是，为了享受歌剧院的表演，你必须首先接受它的惯例。

Finally, there is the matter of the recitative—that part of an opera which is neither spoken nor sung but rather is half sung—telling the story part (especially in old operas), without any attempt at stimulating musical interest. When an opera is sung in a language unfamiliar to the listener, as most operas are in English-speaking countries, these recitative sections can be of surpassing boredom. These facts go to prove that the opera is not a realistic form of art; and one must not demand that it be realistic. As a matter of fact, no one is more tiresome than the person who can understand only realism in art. It shows a rather low artistic mentality never to believe anything you see unless it appears to be real. One must be willing to allow that symbolic things also mirror realities and sometimes provide greater esthetic pleasure than the merely realistic. The opera house is a good place in which to find these more symbolic pleasures. In short, what I have been trying to convey is that in order to enjoy what goes on in the opera house you must begin by accepting its conventions.

令人惊讶的是，有些人仍然认为歌剧是一种已死的形式。它与其他任何音乐形式都截然不同，其独特之处在于其包罗万象。它几乎囊括了所有音乐媒介：交响乐团、独唱、声乐合唱、合唱。音乐的风格可庄重也可轻松——两者并存于同一部作品中。歌剧可以包含交响乐或“纯粹”音乐，也可以是纯粹的描述性和纲领性音乐。歌剧还包含芭蕾舞、哑剧和戏剧。它们之间可以无缝衔接。换句话说，几乎无法想象任何一种音乐或戏剧艺术形式会在歌剧院中得到充分的展现。

It is surprising that some people still consider opera a dead form. What makes it so different from any of the other forms of music is its all-inclusiveness. It contains within itself almost every musical medium: the symphony orchestra, the solo voice, the vocal ensemble, the chorus. The character of the music may be either serious or light—and both in the same work. Opera may contain music of a symphonic, or “absolute,” nature, or it may be purely descriptive and programmatic. An opera also contains ballet, pantomime, and drama. It passes easily from one to the other. In other words, it is almost impossible to imagine any type of musical or theatrical art that would not be at home in an opera house.

但除此之外，歌剧以其独特的方式展现出其壮观的场面。它是一场宏大的戏剧——舞台上挤满了人；灯光、服装和布景都美轮美奂。一个对这种媒介不感兴趣的作曲家，其灵魂中几乎没有戏剧性。大多数创作者显然都有这样的经历，因为歌剧已经让一些世界上最优秀的作曲家着迷。

But added to that is the spectacular display which only the opera can give in its own way. It is theater on a grand scale—crowds of people on the stage; magnificence of lights, costumes, and scenery. A composer who isn’t attracted by such a medium has very little theatricalism in his soul. Most creators apparently have their share, for opera has fascinated some of the world’s finest composers.

创作歌剧的难题在于将所有这些互不相关的元素组合成一个艺术整体。这绝非易事。事实上，几乎不可能随便选一部歌剧，然后说：“这是一部完美的歌剧！它就是每个人都必须遵循的形式解决方案。” 从某种意义上说，这个问题是无法解决的，因为几乎不可能平衡一部歌剧中的各种元素，从而达到一个完全令人满意的整体。实际上，结果就是作曲家们倾向于强调一个元素而忽略另一个元素。

The problem of writing an opera is the combination of all these disparate elements to form an artistic whole. It is anything but an easy problem. As a matter of fact, it is practically impossible to choose any one opera and say: “That’s the perfect opera! There is the solution of the form that everyone must follow.” In a sense, the problem is insoluble, for it is almost impossible to equalize and balance the different elements in an opera in such a way as to achieve a completely satisfying whole. The result has been, practically speaking, that composers have tended to emphasize one element at the expense of another.

这尤其适用于歌剧的歌词，因为它是作曲家创作的首要元素。歌剧作曲家在实践中往往做了以下两种选择：要么赋予歌词以主导地位，让音乐仅仅服务于戏剧；要么坦率地牺牲歌词，将其仅仅用作悬挂音乐的支架。如此一来，歌剧的整个问题便可以归结为歌词与音乐之间截然相反的拉扯。从这个角度审视歌剧史，并观察作曲家们各自如何解决这个问题，将大有裨益。

That particularly applies to the words of an opera, as the first of the elements with which the composer works. Operatic composers have in practice done one of two things: Either they have given the words a preponderant role, using the music only to serve the drama; or they have frankly sacrificed the words, using them merely as a peg on which to hang their music. So that the entire problem of opera may be reduced to the diametrical pull of words on the one hand and music on the other. It is instructive to look at the history of opera from this standpoint and note the way in which composers solved this problem, each one for himself.

1600年提供了一个便捷的起点，因为歌剧的历史大约始于那时。它源于——至少历史学家是这么告诉我们的——一些作曲家和诗人在佛罗伦萨巴尔迪伯爵的宫殿里会面。要知道，在此之前，严肃的艺术音乐几乎完全是合唱，并且高度对位，内容复杂。事实上，音乐变得如此对位，如此复杂，以至于几乎不可能听懂歌手们在说什么。“新音乐”将改变这一切。立即注意到歌剧在其诞生之初的两个基本特征。首先，强调歌词的重音，让音乐讲述一个故事。其次，歌剧从一开始就具有“上流社会”的特质。（这比第一家公共歌剧院在威尼斯开业还要早四十年。）

The year 1600 provides a convenient starting point, for it was thereabouts that operatic history began. It was the result—or so the historian tells us—of the meetings of certain composers and poets at the palace of one Count Bardi in Florence. Remember that serious art music up to that time had been almost entirely choral and of a highly contrapuntal and involved nature. In fact, music had become so contrapuntal, so complex, that it was well-nigh impossible to understand a word of what the singers were saying. The “new music” was going to change all that. Note immediately two fundamental qualities of opera at its very inception. First, the emphasis on stressing the words, making the music tell a story. Second, the “high-society” aspect of opera from the very start. (It was forty years before the first public opera house was opened in Venice.)

在巴迪伯爵家聚会的人们表面上的目的是复兴希腊戏剧。他们希望尝试重现他们认为在希腊剧院里上演的戏剧。当然，他们最终的成果却截然不同——他们创造了一种新的形式，注定会激发后世艺术家和观众的想象力。

The ostensible purpose of the men who met at Count Bardi’s was the revival of Greek drama. They wished to attempt the recreation of what they thought went on in the Greek theater. Of course, what they accomplished was a completely different thing—the creation of a new form, which was destined to fire the imagination of artists and audiences for generations to come.

意大利的克劳迪奥·蒙特威尔第是第一位伟大的歌剧作曲家。可惜的是，他的作品如今鲜有流传，即便上演，对如今的歌剧爱好者来说，也不过是博物馆里的藏品。从我们的角度来看，蒙特威尔第的风格资源有限——大部分内容都属于我们所谓的宣叙调。如今，我们认为宣叙调在歌剧中几乎无足轻重，总是等待着紧随其后的咏叹调来唤醒我们。在我们看来，蒙特威尔第的歌剧中没有咏叹调，它们看起来不过是一首长长的宣叙调，偶尔穿插着管弦乐的间奏。但蒙特威尔第的宣叙调最非凡之处在于它的品质。它听起来绝对真实；令人叹为观止。尽管他几乎是这种新形式的开端，但在蒙特威尔第之后，没有人能够如此简洁、动人、令人信服地将歌词谱成曲。聆听蒙特威尔第的作品时，理解歌词的含义至关重要，因为他非常重视歌词。在歌剧史上，当一些作曲家回归蒙特威尔第的歌剧理想时，理解歌词的含义也同样重要。

The first of the great opera composers was the Italian Claudio Monteverdi. Unfortunately, his works are rarely given nowadays and would strike our present-day opera lovers as little more than museum pieces if they were performed. From our vantage point, Monteverdi’s style is limited in resource—it consists for the most part of what we should call recitative. Nowadays we think of the recitative as of very minor interest in an opera, and we wait always for the aria which follows it to arouse us. In our sense, Monteverdi’s operas are innocent of arias, so that they seem to be nothing but one long recitative, with an occasional orchestral interlude. But what is so very extraordinary about the recitative in Monteverdi is its quality. It rings absolutely true; it is amazingly felt. Despite the fact that he comes at almost the very beginning of the new form, no one after Monteverdi was able to put words to music so simply, so movingly, so convincingly. In listening to Monteverdi, it is necessary to understand the meaning of the words, since he puts so much emphasis upon them. That is also true much later in operatic history when certain composers returned to the Monteverdian ideal of opera.

这种新兴艺术形式开局良好，逐渐传播到意大利以外的其他国家。它首先从威尼斯传到维也纳，再从维也纳传到巴黎、伦敦和汉堡。这些是十八世纪的大型歌剧中心。到那时，歌剧已经偏离了蒙特威尔第的原型。歌词变得越来越不重要，而所有的重点都放在了歌剧的音乐方面。新形式将剧情所激发的情感浓缩成我们现在所称的咏叹调；这些咏叹调由宣叙调段落连接起来。但这些段落不应与蒙特威尔第式的宣叙调混淆；它们是普通的、日常的宣叙调，其设计目的仅仅是为了尽快讲述故事，以便能够进入下一个咏叹调。结果就形成了一种由一系列咏叹调和宣叙调交织而成的歌剧形式。歌剧没有试图通过音乐来描绘舞台上发生的事件。那是后来才有的。

The new art form, which had begun so auspiciously, spread gradually to other countries outside Italy. It went first from Venice to Vienna and from Vienna to Paris, London, and Hamburg. Those were the big operatic centers in the 1700’s. By that time, the opera had veered away from the Monteverdi prototype. The words became less and less important, while all emphasis was placed upon the musical side of the opera. The newer form condensed the emotion aroused by the action into what we now think of as arias; and these arias were connected by recitative passages. But these sections are not to be confused with the Monteverdi species of recitative; they were ordinary, workaday recitatives designed merely for the purpose of telling the story as quickly as possible so that the next aria might be reached. The result was a form of opera that consisted of a collection of arias interspersed with recitative. There was no attempt at picturizing in the music events that happened on the stage. That was to come later.

十七世纪伟大的歌剧作曲家是亚历山德罗·斯卡拉蒂，他是长笛作曲家多梅尼科的父亲，后者的作品在两部结构的讨论中被评论过。老斯卡拉蒂所发展的歌剧模式，我们现在将其与亨德尔后期的歌剧联系起来。在这种类型的歌剧中，故事情节并不重要；戏剧性是静态的，动作可忽略不计。所有的焦点都集中在歌手和声部上，歌剧的合理性仅仅体现在其音乐感染力上。事实证明，这是一种危险的发展，因为不久之后，歌手们自然而然地渴望占据舞台的中心，导致了严重的弊端，而这些弊端至今仍未完全根除。歌手之间的竞争导致在旋律线上添加了各种各样的回旋音和额外的装饰，其唯一目的就是展示特定演绎者的实力。

The great opera composer of the seventeenth century was Alessandro Scarlatti, the father of the clavecin composer Domenico, whose works were commented upon in the discussion of two-part form. The model of opera that the elder Scarlatti developed we now connect with the later operas of Handel. In this type of opera, the story is of little import; the drama is static, and the action negligible. All interest is centered on the singer and the vocal part, and opera justifies itself only in terms of its musical appeal. It proved to be a dangerous development, for it wasn’t long before the natural desire of singers to hold the center of the stage led to serious abuses which are still by no means entirely eradicated. The rivalry of singers led to the addition of all kinds of roulades and extra furbishings to the melodic line for the sole purpose of demonstrating the prowess of the particular interpreter in question.

随之而来的是不可避免的。既然歌剧已经变成了一种高度形式化、非自然的艺术形式，必然会有人挺身而出，成为改革者。歌剧史上不乏改革者。总有人试图让歌剧比之前的时代更加真实。而这位力图纠正亨德尔歌剧弊端的改革倡导者，当然是克里斯托弗·威利巴尔德·冯·格鲁克。

What followed was inevitable. Since opera had become so highly formalized and unnatural an art form, someone was bound to come forward as a reformer. The history of opera is sprinkled with reformers. Someone is always trying to make opera more real than it was in the period just before him. The champion of reform who wished to correct the abuses of the Handelian opera was, of course, Christoph Willibald von Gluck.

格鲁克本人在担任改革者之前，曾创作了大量符合当时传统意大利风格的歌剧，因此，当他说歌剧需要净化时，他深知自己在说什么。格鲁克首先试图使歌剧合理化——使其更有意义。在旧歌剧中，歌唱者至上，音乐服务于歌唱者；格鲁克则将戏剧理念置于首位，创作的音乐服务于文本的目的。每一幕都应自成一体，而非一堆或多或少有效咏叹调的平庸集合。每一幕都应保持平衡与对比，并具有流畅性和连续性，使其作为一种艺术形式具有连贯性。例如，芭蕾舞不应仅仅是为了自身利益而引入的娱乐节目，而应成为作品戏剧理念不可或缺的一部分。

Gluck himself had written a great many operas in the conventional Italian style of his day before he assumed the role of reformer, so that he knew whereof he spoke when he said that opera was in need of purification. Gluck tried above all to rationalize opera—to have it make more sense. In the older opera, the singer was supreme, and the music served the singer; Gluck made the dramatic idea supreme and wrote music that served the purposes of the text. Each act was to be an entity in itself, not a nondescript collection of more or less effective arias. It was to be balanced and contrasted, with a flow and continuity that would give it coherence as an art form. The ballet, for example, was not to be a mere divertissement introduced for its own sake but an integral part of the dramatic idea of the work.

格鲁克关于歌剧改革的想法是正确的，而且他能够将这些想法融入到实际的作品中。《奥菲欧与欧律狄刻》 、《阿米德》、《阿尔赛斯特》是他最成功的作品之一。在这些歌剧中，他创造了一种宏大而沉稳的音乐风格，与他许多作品的宏大主题非常契合。与这种宏伟的印象相伴的是非凡的平静，一种在音乐中独一无二的平静之美，完全摆脱了当时歌剧媒介的轻浮。格鲁克的作品不应被归类为博物馆藏品；它们是第一批可以说没有被时间侵蚀其影响力的歌剧。

Gluck’s ideas as to operatic reform were sound. Moreover, he was able to incorporate them into actual works. Orpheus and Eurydice, Armide, Alceste are the names of some of his most successful achievements. In these operas, he created a massive, stolid kind of music which fitted very well the grandiose subject matter of many of his works. And concomitant with the monumental impression is one of extraordinary calm, a species of calm beauty which is unique in music and utterly removed from the frivolities of the operatic medium of his day. Gluck’s works are not to be classed as museum pieces; they are the first operas of which it may be said that time has not impaired their effectiveness.

这并不是说格鲁克的改革完全成功。他的歌剧无疑比之前的歌剧更加理性，但许多改革仍需后人去完成。他的改革只是相对的；在很多情况下，他只是用自己的惯例取代了之前的惯例。但无论如何，他是一位一流的天才，他确实成功地树立了一种歌剧理想，为未来的改革者指明了方向。

That is not to say that Gluck was entirely successful in his reform. His operas are undoubtedly more rational than those which preceded him, but much was left to be accomplished by later men. His reform was only a relative one; in many instances, he merely substituted his own conventions for those that were current before him. But he was, nevertheless, a genius of the first rank, and he did succeed in setting up an ideal of opera that showed the way to future reformers.

莫扎特，歌剧史上的下一个伟大人物，并非天生的改革者。我们期望莫扎特的作品完美无瑕，无论他选择何种创作媒介。莫扎特的歌剧也不例外，因为它们比同时代的其他任何歌剧都更具才智。《魔笛》有时被称为有史以来最完美的歌剧。由于其非现实主义的特质，它的主题非常适合歌剧化。它既严肃又喜剧，将丰富的音乐想象力与通俗易懂的风格融为一体。

Mozart, the next great name in operatic history, was not by nature a reformer. What we expect to find in Mozart is perfection in whatever medium he chose to work. Mozart’s operas are no exception, for they embody more resourcefulness than can be found in any other opera up to his time. The Magic Flute is sometimes spoken of as the most perfect opera ever written. Its subject matter lends itself very well to operatic treatment because of its nonrealistic nature. It is both serious and comic, combining a wealth of musical imagination with a popular style accessible to all.

莫扎特对这一形式的贡献之一是歌剧式的终曲。这是一种只有在歌剧中才能出现的效果——在一幕的最终场景中，所有主角同时演唱，每个人都在唱着不同的主题，最后以响亮的极强音收尾，令所有相关人员都感到愉悦。莫扎特以如此明确和完美的方式完成了这一典型的音乐技巧，以至于所有在他之后使用它的人——谁又没有呢？——都受益于他。它似乎是歌剧创作中的一个基本效果，因为它在今天和莫扎特时代一样活跃。

One contribution that Mozart did make to the form was the operatic finale. This is an effect possible only in opera—that final scene of an act when all the principals sing at the same time, each one singing about something else, only to conclude with a resounding fortissimo to the delight of everyone concerned. Mozart accomplished this typically musical trick in so definitive and perfect a way that all who used it after him—as who has not?—were indebted to him. It appears to be a fundamental effect in operatic writing, since it is just as much alive today as it was in Mozart’s time.

莫扎特在另一个方面也超越了他的时代。他是第一位以德语创作喜剧的伟大作曲家。 1782年上演的《后宫诱逃》是通往未来德国歌剧之路的第一座里程碑。这部作品为众多追随者奠定了风格，其中甚至包括创作《名歌手》的瓦格纳。

Mozart was also in advance of his time in one other respect. He was the first great composer to write a comedy set in the German language. The Abduction from the Seraglio, produced in 1782, is the first milestone in the path that leads directly to the future German opera. It set the style for a long list of followers, among whom may be counted the Wagner of the Meistersinger.

理查德·瓦格纳是歌剧界的下一位伟大改革者。他与格鲁克一样，致力于使歌剧形式合理化。他将歌剧形式视为所有艺术的结合——包括诗歌、戏剧、音乐和舞台艺术——所有与本章开篇概述的壮观歌剧相关的艺术。他希望将歌剧形式命名为音乐剧，赋予其新的尊严。音乐剧与歌剧在两个重要方面有所不同：首先，将取消固定的乐曲编号，代之以连续的音乐流程，即从一幕开始到结束，始终保持不间断的连续性。为了在戏剧形式中提升真实感，歌剧中由宣叙调连接独立咏叹调的风格被摒弃。其次，引入了著名的主导动机概念。通过将特定的乐句或主题与音乐剧中的每个角色或思想联系起来，可以确保音乐元素更加紧密地联系在一起。

Richard Wagner was the next great reformer in opera. It was his purpose, as it had been Gluck’s, to rationalize operatic form. He visualized the form as a union of all the arts—to include poetry, the drama, music, and the arts of the stage—everything connected with the spectacular opera outlined in the beginning of this chapter. He wished to give a new dignity to the operatic form by naming it music drama. Music drama was to be different from opera in two important respects: In the first place, the set musical number was to be done away with in favor of a continuous musical flow which followed an uninterrupted course from the beginning of an act to its conclusion. The opera of the separate aria connected by recitative was abandoned for the sake of greater realism in the dramatic form. Secondly, the famous conception of the leitmotif was introduced. Through associating a particular musical phrase, or motif, with each character or idea in the music drama, a greater cohesion of musical elements was to be assured.

但在瓦格纳音乐剧中，最重要的是管弦乐队所扮演的角色。一个冬天，我在大都会歌剧院听了马斯奈的《曼侬》，第二天又听了瓦格纳的《女武神》，对此印象尤为深刻。在听这位法国人的作品时，人们从来不会特别关注管弦乐队。它扮演的角色就像一群在乐池里的剧院音乐家；但瓦格纳的管弦乐队一响起，人们就会觉得整个爱乐交响乐团都搬进了大都会歌剧院。瓦格纳把交响乐团带到了歌剧院，因此主要的关注点往往不在舞台上，而在乐池里。歌手的演唱往往只能作为次要的，而主要的注意力则放在管弦乐队所“讲述”的内容上。瓦格纳天生是一位交响乐家，他将自己的交响乐天赋运用到了歌剧的形式中。

But most significant in the Wagnerian music drama is the role assigned the orchestra. I had a most pronounced impression of that fact at the Metropolitan one winter on hearing Massenet’s Manon one night and Wagner’s Die Walküre the next. With the Frenchman’s work one never gave the orchestra any special attention. It played a part not unlike that of a group of theater musicians in a pit; but as soon as Wagner’s orchestra sounded, one had the impression that the entire Philharmonic Symphony had moved into the Metropolitan. Wagner brought the symphony orchestra to the opera house, so that the principal interest is often not on the stage but in the orchestra pit. The singers often must be listened to only in a secondary way, while the primary attention is placed on what the orchestra is “saying.” Wagner was by nature a symphonist who applied his symphonic gifts to the form of the opera.

问题依然存在：“瓦格纳在歌剧院里实现了现实吗？”答案一定是“没有”。他做到的并不比格鲁克更多。瓦格纳时代流行的惯例又一次被不同的惯例所取代。此外，我们也可以公正地问：“他是否实现了他孜孜不倦宣称的所有艺术的平等？”答案同样是“没有”。一位诚实的听众在观看瓦格纳的演出后，必然会留下一种主要属于音乐而非戏剧的印象。想象一下，如果瓦格纳的剧本配上不同的音乐——没有人会对它表现出丝毫的兴趣。瓦格纳之所以能牢牢抓住观众的心，正是因为他的音乐如此非凡。音乐才是至高无上的；与之相比，音乐剧的所有其他元素都显得苍白无力。剑桥大学的爱德华·登特教授恰如其分地表达了我对瓦格纳戏剧中音乐之外因素的看法。他曾说过：“关于他的歌剧的哲学和道德意义，人们写了很多胡言乱语，有些甚至出自瓦格纳本人之口。” 音乐剧，如同歌剧一样，最终的考验必然是歌剧院本身。只有瓦格纳作品所代表的对音乐资源的强大掌控力，才能让歌剧院的演出得以忍受。

The question remains: “Did Wagner achieve reality in the opera house?” The answer must be “No.” He achieved it no more than Gluck had. Once again, different conventions were substituted for those current in Wagner’s time. Also, we may ask with justice: “Did he achieve the equality of all the arts which he never tired of proclaiming?” There, again, the answer is “No.” The honest listener who witnesses a Wagnerian performance is bound to come away with an impression that is primarily a musical, not a dramatic, one. Imagine a Wagner libretto set to different music—none would evince the slightest interest in it. It is only because the music is so extraordinary that Wagner maintains his hold on the public. It is the music that is supreme; by comparison with it, all the other elements of the music drama are weak. Professor Edward Dent of Cambridge has exactly expressed my sentiments in relation to the extramusical considerations of Wagnerian drama. He has said: “A great deal of nonsense has been written, some indeed by Wagner himself, about the philosophical and moral significance of his operas.” The final test of music drama, as of opera, must be the opera house itself. It is only the overpowering command of musical resources represented by Wagner’s work that makes it bearable in the opera house.

在瓦格纳的领域中，只有两三位同时代歌剧大师能与他匹敌，其中威尔第是其中的佼佼者。和格鲁克一样，威尔第创作了大量传统的意大利歌剧，这些歌剧受到了公众的广泛好评，但却不受十九世纪音乐剧爱好者的青睐。但近年来，歌剧鉴赏家们倾向于重新评价威尔第的贡献。他们虽然对静态和“哲学化”的音乐剧舞台感到有些厌倦（更不用说感到厌倦了），但现在他们能够更好地欣赏威尔第这样的人高超的戏剧天赋。他的歌剧无疑过于传统、过于肤浅，有时甚至过于粗俗，但它们却感人至深。威尔第是天生的戏剧家—— 《阿依达》、《弄臣》、《茶花女》等作品的巨大成功使它们在歌剧剧目中占有一席之地。

Only two or three contemporaries were able to compete with Wagner on his own ground. Verdi was the principal of these. Like Gluck, he wrote a large number of conventional Italian operas, which were wildly acclaimed by the public but found little favor with the nineteenth-century admirers of music drama. But there has been a tendency in recent years on the part of the cognoscenti to reestimate the contribution made by Verdi. Somewhat chastened, not to say bored, by the static and “philosophical” music-drama stage, they are now in a position better to appreciate the virtuoso theatrical gifts of a man like Verdi. His operas were no doubt too traditional, too facile, and at times even too vulgar; but they moved. Verdi was a born man of the theater—the sheer effectiveness of works like Aïda, Rigoletto, Traviata assure them a permanent place in the operatic repertoire.

威尔第本人在其最后两部作品《奥赛罗》和《法尔斯塔夫》的创作中，多少受到了瓦格纳的影响。这两部作品均创作于他年逾古稀之时。他摒弃了单独的歌剧咏叹调，以更成熟的方式运用管弦乐队，更直接地着眼于剧情的戏剧性含义。但他并未放弃对舞台的本能感受。正因如此，这两部作品——一位老人力量的惊人体现——总体而言，比起瓦格纳更偏重理论性的音乐剧，更能成为年轻歌剧作曲家的启迪典范。

Verdi himself was somewhat influenced by the example of Wagner in the composition of his last two works, Otello and Falstaff, both written when the composer was past seventy. He put aside the separate operatic aria, used the orchestra in a more sophisticated manner, concentrated more directly on the dramatic implications of the plot. But he did not relinquish his instinctive feeling for the stage. That is why these two works—amazing examples of the powers of an old man—are on the whole better models for the edification of the young opera composer than the more theoretical music drama of Wagner.

穆索尔斯基和比才都能够创作出堪与威尔第或瓦格纳最佳作品相媲美的歌剧。在这两者中，俄罗斯歌剧的成果更为丰硕。他的《鲍里斯·戈杜诺夫》是第一部在德国以外创作的民族主义歌剧，它为走出瓦格纳式的僵局指明了方向。《鲍里斯》是一部真正意义上的歌剧。它的主角是合唱团而不是个人；它的色彩源于俄罗斯的场景；它的音乐背景因使用典型的俄罗斯民歌素材而焕然一新。第二幕的场景描绘了以沙皇寝宫为背景的克里姆林宫宫廷，加冕游行队伍穿过舞台，这是歌剧媒介有史以来最壮观的场景之一。

Moussorgsky and Bizet were both able to create operas that are worthy of comparison with the best of Verdi or Wagner. Of the two, the Russian’s operas have had the more fruitful progeny. His Boris Godounoff was the first of the nationalist operas, written outside Germany, which showed a way out of the Wagnerian impasse. Boris is operatic in the best sense of the word. Its main protagonist is the chorus rather than the individual; it derives its color from Russian locale; its musical background is freshened by the use of typically Russian folk-song material. The scene of the second tableau, which pictures the court of the Kremlin backed by the Czar’s apartments, with the coronation procession crossing the stage, is one of the most spectacular ever conceived in the operatic medium.

《鲍里斯》的影响只是慢慢地感受到的，因为直到本世纪它才在西欧上演。但德彪西在早年访问俄罗斯时一定知道它的存在。无论如何，穆索尔斯基的影响在德彪西唯一的歌剧《佩利亚斯与梅丽桑德》中显而易见，这部歌剧是歌剧史上的下一个伟大里程碑。在《佩利亚斯》中，德彪西回归了蒙特威尔第的歌剧理想；梅特林克诗剧的歌词得到了充分的体现。音乐的目的仅仅是作为歌词的框架，以增强其诗意。

The influence of Boris was only slowly felt, for it was not performed in Western Europe until the present century. But Debussy must have known of its existence during the visits that he made to Russia in early manhood. In any case, the influence of Moussorgsky is patent in Debussy’s only opera, Pelléas et Mélisande, which is the next great landmark in operatic history. In Pelléas, Debussy returned to the Monteverdian ideal of opera; the words of Maeterlinck’s poetic drama were given their full rights. The music was intended only to serve as a frame about the words, so as to heighten their poetic meaning.

德彪西的歌剧在方法和感觉上与瓦格纳音乐剧截然相反。如果我们将《特里斯坦》中的大场景与《佩利亚斯》中的类似场景进行比较，便可立即看出这一点。在瓦格纳的歌剧中，当恋人第一次表白时，音乐中流露出美妙的情感；但当佩利亚斯和梅丽桑德第一次互相表白爱意时，现场一片寂静。每个人——歌手、管弦乐队和作曲家——都感动不已。这个场景是整部歌剧的典型特征——它是轻描淡写的胜利。《佩利亚斯》中很少有强音段落；整部作品都笼罩在神秘而凄美的氛围中。德彪西的音乐为梅特林克的小剧增添了新的维度。离开音乐，我们再也无法想象这部剧了。

In method and feeling, Debussy’s opera was the antithesis of Wagnerian music drama. This is immediately seen if we compare the big scene in Tristan with the analogous one in Pelléas. In Wagner’s opera, when the lovers declare themselves for the first time, there is a wonderful outpouring of the emotions in music; but when Pelléas and Mélisande first declare their love for each other, there is complete silence. Everyone—singers, orchestra, and composer—is overcome with emotion. That scene is typical of the whole opera—it is a triumph of understatement. There are very few forte passages in Pelléas; the entire work is bathed in an atmosphere of mystery and poignancy. Debussy’s music added a new dimension to Maeterlinck’s little play. It is impossible any longer to imagine the play apart from the music.

或许正是因为戏剧与音乐的这种完全契合，《佩利亚斯与梅丽桑德》才始终是一个特例。它并没有为延续同一传统的后续歌剧创作提供新的方案。（很少有其他剧作能如此出色地为音乐背景进行设计。）此外，《佩利亚斯》的吸引力主要局限于那些懂法语的观众，因为这部作品的质量很大程度上取决于对歌词的理解。由于佩利亚斯几乎没有后代，音乐界的领袖们对歌剧形式彻底失去了兴趣，转而将交响乐或芭蕾舞作为主要的音乐形式。

Perhaps it is just because of this complete identity of play and music that Pelléas et Mélisande has remained something of a special case. It provided no new program for the production of further operas in the same tradition. (Few other plays are so well designed for musical setting.) Moreover, the appeal of Pelléas was largely confined to those who understand French, since so much of the quality of the work is dependent on an understanding of the words. Because Pelléas had almost no offspring, the leaders of musical opinion lost interest in the operatic form altogether and turned instead to the symphony or the ballet as the principal musical form.

1924年前后，人们对歌剧重新燃起兴趣的原因已有所说明。自那时起创作的所有歌剧都与瓦格纳的理想截然相反。如今的歌剧作曲家至少在一点上达成了共识：他们愿意坦然接受歌剧舞台的惯例。由于不可能让歌剧变得“真实”，他们心甘情愿地放弃了一切改革尝试。他们勇敢地从歌剧是一种非现实主义形式的前提出发，他们非但没有谴责这一事实，反而决心加以利用。他们坚信，歌剧首先是戏剧，因此，它需要一位能够创作舞台音乐的作曲家。

Reasons have already been given for the revival of interest in opera around 1924. All the operas written since then are in full reaction against Wagnerian ideals. Opera composers of today are agreed on at least one point: They are ready to accept frankly the conventions of the operatic stage. Since there is no possible hope of making opera “real,” they have willingly renounced all attempt at reform. They bravely start from the premise that opera is a nonrealistic form, and, instead of deploring that fact, they are determined to make use of it. They are convinced that opera is, first of all, theater and that, as such, it demands a composer who is capable of writing stage music.

大多数评论家认为，自《佩利亚斯》以来最重要的现代歌剧是阿尔班·贝尔格的《沃采克》。贝尔格的歌剧在几个方面都很引人注目。他和德彪西一样，都是从舞台剧开始创作的。《沃采克》是十九世纪早熟的剧作家乔治·毕希纳的作品。他用 26 个短幕讲述了一个可怜的士兵的故事，他处于社会底层，无辜地生活在悲惨之中，身后只留下一连串的不幸。这是一个现实主义的主题，带有社会含义；但在贝尔格的处理下，它变成了一种与众不同的现实主义。我们得到的印象是一种强化的现实主义，有时被称为表现主义的现实主义。歌剧中的一切都极其浓缩。一个快速的场景接着另一个，每个场景都与一些重要的戏剧时刻有关，所有这些都通过贝尔格极具表现力的音乐联系在一起并聚焦起来。

The most significant modern opera since Pelléas is, in the opinion of most critics, Alban Berg’s Wozzeck. Berg’s opera is striking on several counts. He, like Debussy, began with a stage play. Wozzeck was the work of a precocious nineteenth-century playwright, George Büchner. He tells the story, in 26 short scenes, of a poor devil of a soldier, at the bottom of the social scale, who through no fault of his own lives in misery and leaves nothing but a trail of misery behind him. This is a realistic theme, with social implications; but as Berg treated it, it became realism with a difference. The impression that we get is one of a heightened, what is sometimes called an expressionistic, realism. Everything in the opera is extremely condensed. One swift scene follows another, each relating some essential dramatic moment, and all connected and focused through Berg’s intensely expressive music.

这部原创作品在音乐界迟迟未能被接受的原因之一，在于其音乐语言本身。贝尔格是阿诺德·勋伯格的忠实学生，他运用了老师的无调性和声结构。《沃采克》是第一部登上舞台的无调性歌剧。尽管《沃采克》演奏难度高，理解难度也几乎相同，但它却在欧洲和美国都广受欢迎，这充分表明了这部音乐的戏剧力量。值得一提的是，《沃采克》和贝尔格去世前完成的最后一部作品，他的第二部歌剧《露露》都体现了这一点。贝尔格有一个颇为奇特的想法，将帕萨卡利亚舞曲或回旋曲等严格的音乐厅舞曲形式引入到他的歌剧作品中。这种歌剧形式的创新仅仅出于技术层面的考虑，因为观众在聆听作品时并不知道这些基本形式的存在，而据作曲家本人承认，这正是他的本意。与其他歌剧一样，贝尔格的作品凭借其戏剧力量占据了舞台。

One of the reasons for the slow acceptance in musical circles of this original work is the language of the music itself. Berg, as a devoted pupil of Arnold Schoenberg, made use of the atonal harmonic scheme of his teacher. Wozzeck was the first atonal opera to reach the stage. It is indicative of the dramatic power of the music that despite the fact of its being difficult to perform and almost as difficult to understand, it has made its way in both Europe and America. One other curious feature should be mentioned, which is found in Wozzeck and in the last work that Berg finished before his death, his second opera, Lulu. Berg had the somewhat strange notion of introducing strict concert-hall forms, such as the passacaglia or rondo, into the body of his operas. This innovation in operatic form has no more than a technical interest, since the public hears the work with no idea of the presence of these underlying forms, this, according to the composer’s own admission, being exactly his intention. Like every other opera, Berg’s work holds the stage by virtue of its dramatic power.

一些现代歌剧因其对当代题材的处理而俘获了公众的想象力。其中第一部是克热内克的《强尼在演奏》，这部歌剧一度风靡一时。在德国的外省民众看来，一部歌剧的主人公竟然是一位黑人爵士乐队的领队，而且作曲家竟然敢于在乐谱中加入几首爵士乐，这似乎颇具讽刺意味。

A few modern operas have taken hold of the public imagination because of their treatment of some contemporary subject.
