Pierre Boulez, Welsh National Opera (Deutsche Grammophon)

伯格—沃采克

Berg—Wozzeck

克劳迪奥·阿巴多，维也纳国家歌剧院（德意志留声机）

Claudio Abbado, Vienna State Opera (Deutsche Grammophon)

16

16

当代音乐

Contemporary Music

人们反复思考，为什么这么多音乐爱好者在聆听当代音乐时会感到迷失。他们似乎泰然处之，认为当代作曲家的作品并不适合自己。为什么？因为他们“根本听不懂”。正如一位非专业人士最近所说：“太多听众在被告知某首音乐是‘现代’时仍会退缩。” 以前——直到二十世纪二十年代中期左右——所有具有进步倾向的新音乐都被归类为“超现代”。即使在今天，仍然有人认为“古典”和“现代”代表着两种不可调和的音乐风格，一种提出可以理解的问题，另一种则充满了难以解决的问题。

Over and over again the question arises as to why it is that so many music lovers feel disoriented when they listen to contemporary music. They seem to accept with equanimity the notion that the work of the present-day composer is not for them. Why? Because they “just don’t understand it.” As a nonprofessional phrased it recently, “Far too many listeners still flinch when they are told that a piece of music is ‘modern.’ ʺ Formerly—up to the middle twenties or thereabouts—all new music of progressive tendency was bunched together under the heading “ultramodern.” Even today there still persists the idea that “classic” and “modern” represent two irreconcilable musical styles, the one posing graspable problems and the other fairly bristling with insoluble ones.

首先要记住的是，创意艺术家大体上都是严肃的——他们的目的不是愚弄你。这反过来又要求你心胸开阔、意愿良好，并且对他们所做的事情有一定的先验信心。作曲家的音域、范围、气质和表达方式各不相同。正因为如此，当代音乐赋予的音乐体验不只一种，而是很多种。记住这一点也很重要。一些当代作曲家的作品很容易理解，而另一些则可能很难理解。或者同一位作曲家的不同作品可能属于这一类或另一类。在这两者之间，有许多当代作家，他们的作品有的很容易理解，有的则很难理解。

The first thing to remember is that creative artists, by and large, are a serious lot—their purpose is not to fool you. This, in turn, presupposes on your part an open mind, good will, and a certain a priori confidence in what they are up to. Composers vary greatly in range and scope, in temperament and in expression. Because of that, contemporary music imparts not one kind, but many different kinds of musical experience. That too is important to remember. Some present-day composers are very easy to understand, others may be very tough. Or different pieces by the same composer may fit into one or the other category. In between are a great many contemporary writers who range from being quite approachable to being fairly difficult.

把所有这些音乐都归为“现代”显然不公平，只会导致混乱。因此，或许可以尝试将当代作曲的一些主要代表人物，按照其各自语言的理解难度进行划分，从而理清混乱的当代作曲格局，使其更加清晰：

To label all this music under the one heading “modern” is patently unfair, and can lead only to confusion. It might be helpful, therefore, to bring some order into the apparent chaos of contemporary composition by dividing some of its leading exponents according to the relative degree of difficulty in the understanding of their respective idioms:

非常简单：肖斯塔科维奇和哈恰图良、弗朗西斯·普朗克和埃里克·萨蒂、早期斯特拉文斯基和勋伯格、维吉尔·汤姆森。

Very easy: Shostakovitch and Khachaturian, Francis Poulenc and Erik Satie, early Stravinsky and Schoenberg, Virgil Thomson.

相当平易近人：普罗科菲耶夫、维拉·罗伯斯、欧内斯特·布洛赫、罗伊·哈里斯、威廉·沃尔顿、马利皮耶罗、布里顿。

Quite approachable: Prokofieff, Villa-Lobos, Ernest Bloch, Roy Harris, William Walton, Malipiero, Britten.

相当困难：已故斯特拉文斯基、贝拉·巴托克、米尔约、查韦斯、威廉·舒曼、奥内格、欣德米特、沃尔特·皮斯顿。

Fairly difficult: Late Stravinsky, Béla Bartók, Milhaud, Chávez, William Schuman, Honegger, Hindemith, Walter Piston.

非常强硬：中后期勋伯格、阿尔班·伯格、安东·韦伯恩、瓦雷兹、达拉皮科拉、克热内克、罗杰·塞申斯，有时还有查尔斯·艾夫斯。

Very tough: Middle and late Schoenberg, Alban Berg, Anton Webern, Varèse, Dallapiccola, Křenek, Roger Sessions, sometimes Charles Ives.

你完全不必同意我的比较评价。这些评价仅仅是为了表明，并非所有新音乐都应被视为同样难以理解。即使对音乐家来说，勋伯格的十二音学派也是最难攻克的。要理解斯特拉文斯基的后期作品，你需要热爱风格、精准和个性；要理解米约或查韦斯的作品，你需要对尖锐饱满的音响效果的品味。欣德米特和皮斯顿需要对位法的耳朵；普朗克和汤姆森需要机智的智慧；而维拉-罗伯斯则需要对华丽色彩的感受。

It is not at all essential that you agree with my comparative estimates. These are meant merely to indicate that not all new music ought to be thought of as equally inaccessible. The dodecaphonic school of Schoenberg is the hardest nut to crack, even for musicians. For the later Stravinsky you need a love of style, precision, personality; for Milhaud or Chávez a taste for sharply seasoned sonorities. Hindemith and Piston demand a contrapuntal ear; Poulenc and Thomson a witty intelligence; and Villa-Lobos a feeling for the lushly colorful.

因此，首要之务是区分作曲家，尝试分别聆听他们想要传达的内容。作曲家是不可替代的！每个人都有自己的目标，明智的听众最好将这个目标牢记在心。

The first essential, then, is to differentiate composers, trying to hear each separately in terms of what he wishes to communicate. Composers are not interchangeable! Each has his own objective and the wise listener would do well to keep that objective in the front of his mind.

当我们区分新旧音乐所带来的音乐乐趣时，也应牢记这一目标的明确性。只要未入门的音乐爱好者执着于聆听过去大师的伟大作品中那种声音或获得那种音乐享受，他就会继续觉得当代音乐奇特。这一点至关重要。我对肖邦和莫扎特音乐的热爱与其他人一样强烈，但当我坐下来创作自己的作品时，这种热爱却于事无补，因为他们的世界与我不同，他们的音乐语言也与我不同。他们音乐的基本原则在今天和在他们那个时代一样具有说服力，但运用这些原则，人们可能，也确实，创作出截然不同的作品。在接触一部严肃的当代音乐作品时，人们必须首先了解作曲家的目标是什么，然后才能预料到会听到一种与过去习以为常的不同的处理方式。

This clarification of objective should also be borne in mind when we distinguish between the musical pleasures to be derived from old and new music. The uninitiated music lover will continue to find contemporary music peculiar so long as he persists in trying to hear the same kinds of sounds or derive the same species of musical enjoyment that he gets from the great works of past masters. This point is crucial. My love of the music of Chopin and Mozart is as strong as that of the next fellow, but it does me little good when I sit down to write my own, because their world is not mine and their musical language not mine. The underlying principles of their music are just as cogent today as they were in their own period, but with these same principles one may and one does produce a quite different result. When approaching a present-day musical work of serious pretensions, one must first realize what the objective of the composer is and then expect to hear a different sort of treatment than was customary in the past.

在探讨音乐的元素和形式时，我们引用了各种例子，以展示近代作曲家如何为了自身的表达目的而调整和扩展我们的技术资源。这些对传统程序的扩展必然意味着听众能够凭借本能或训练适应不熟悉的语言风格。例如，如果你发现自己因为音乐过于不和谐而拒绝它，这可能表明你的耳朵还不够适应我们当今的音乐词汇，需要更多的练习——也就是聆听方面的训练。（作曲家本人也有可能因为创作缺乏灵感或故意制造不和谐音而犯错。）

In dealing with the elements and forms of music, various instances were cited to show how recent composers have adapted and extended our technical resources for their own expressive purposes. These extensions of conventional procedures necessarily imply the ability, on the listener’s part, to lend himself by instinct or training to the unfamiliar idiom. If, for example, you find yourself rejecting music because it is too dissonant, it probably indicates that your ear is insufficiently accustomed to our present-day musical vocabulary, and needs more practice—that is, training in listening. (There is always the possibility that the composer himself may be at fault through the writing of uninspired or willful dissonances.)

在听一部新作品时，旋律内容——或者看似缺乏旋律——可能会让人困惑。你很可能会听不到可以哼唱的简单曲调。如今的旋律可能会“无法唱出”，尤其是在器乐创作中，仅仅是因为它们远远超出了人声的限制。也可能是因为它们太过曲折、不连贯或支离破碎，没有任何即时的吸引力。这些表现力特征可能会暂时让听众感到困惑。但考虑到当代旋律创作范围的扩大，作曲家不可能回到过去那种平淡无奇、有时一目了然的旋律创作方式。假设一位天才的作曲家，反复聆听应该会让他更复杂的作品具有长久的吸引力。

In following a new work, the melodic content—or seeming lack of it—may be a source of confusion. You may very well miss hearing the straightforward tune that can be hummed. Melodies nowadays can be “unsingable,” especially in instrumental writing, if only because they go far beyond the limitations of the human voice. Or it may be that they are too tortuous, or jagged, or fragmentary to have any immediacy of appeal. These are expressive attributes that may, temporarily, perplex the listener. But the composer, given the expanded scope of contemporary melodic invention, cannot return to the plain and sometimes obvious melody writing of an earlier day. Assuming a gifted composer, repeated hearings should make clear the long-range appeal of his more intricate line.

最后，还有一种比其他任何批评都更常被提及的指责，那就是当今的音乐似乎回避了情感和感觉，它仅仅体现在理智和小聪明上，而非情感上的意义。短短一段文字难以充分阐明这种根深蒂固的误解。如果一位当代作曲家的作品给你的印象是冷漠而充满理智，那就扪心自问，你是否使用了不切实际的比较标准。大多数音乐爱好者并没有意识到自己在多大程度上被浪漫主义的音乐方式所迷惑。我们的听众已经将十九世纪的音乐浪漫主义与音乐艺术本身联系起来。由于浪漫主义过去是、现在仍然是一种如此强大的表达方式，他们往往会忘记，在浪漫主义盛行之前，伟大的音乐已经创作了数百年。

Finally there is the reproach that is repeated more often than any other, namely, that today’s music appears to avoid sentiment and feeling, that it is merely cerebral and clever rather than emotionally meaningful. A brief paragraph can hardly hope to deal adequately with this persistent misconception. If a contemporary composer’s work strikes you as cold and intellectual, ask yourself if you are not using standards of comparison that really do not apply. Most music lovers do not appreciate to what an extent they are under the spell of the romantic approach to music. Our audiences have come to identify nineteenth-century musical romanticism as analogous to the art of music itself. Because romanticism was, and still remains, so powerful an expression, they tend to forget that great music was written for hundreds of years before the romantics flourished.

巧合的是，当今相当一部分音乐与早期音乐的审美联系，远胜于与浪漫主义音乐的联系。浪漫主义大师们那种奔放不羁、个性鲜明的温暖与奔腾，并非我们所能接受。即使是当代那些明显带有浪漫主义色彩的作品，也谨慎地、毫不夸张地表达自己。这必须如此，因为不言而喻的事实是，浪漫主义运动在上世纪末已达到顶峰，从中汲取的新鲜血液已荡然无存。

It so happens that a considerable proportion of today’s music has closer aesthetic ties with that earlier music than it has with the romantics. The way of the uninhibited and personalized warmth and surge of the best of the romanticists is not our way. Even that segment of contemporary composition that clearly has romantic overtones is careful to express itself more discreetly, without exaggeration. And so it must, for the self-evident truth is that the romantic movement had reached its apogee by the end of the last century and nothing fresh was to be extracted from it.

从浪漫主义到更客观的音乐理想的转变是一个渐进的过程。由于作曲家自身难以突破，公众迟迟未能完全接受这一转变的深层含义也就不足为奇了。十九世纪是典型的浪漫主义世纪——浪漫主义在音乐艺术中找到了其最具特色的表达方式。或许正因如此，音乐爱好者们才始终不愿承认，随着新世纪的到来，一种全新的音乐必然应运而生。然而，文学界的同行们却并不指望安德烈·纪德、托马斯·曼或T·S·艾略特能像维克多·雨果或沃尔特·司各特爵士那样倾情演绎。那么，为什么巴托克或塞申斯要模仿勃拉姆斯或柴可夫斯基呢？当你觉得一部当代作品枯燥乏味、缺乏理性，缺乏情感表达时，很可能你对那个时代特有的音乐语言缺乏敏感。

The transition from romanticism to a more objective musical ideal was a gradual one. Since composers themselves found it difficult to make the break, it is not to be wondered at that the public at large has been slow to accept the full implication of what has been happening. The nineteenth century was the romantic century par excellence—a romanticism that found its most characteristic expression in the art of music. Perhaps that explains the continued reluctance of the music-loving public to admit that with the new century a different kind of music had to come into being. And yet their counterparts in the literary world do not expect André Gide or Thomas Mann or T. S. Eliot to emote with the accents of Victor Hugo or Sir Walter Scott. Why then should Bartók or Sessions be expected to sing with the voice of Brahms or Tschaikovsky? When a contemporary piece seems dry and cerebral to you, when it seems to be giving off little feeling or sentiment, there is a good chance that you are being insensitive to the characteristic musical speech of your own epoch.

音乐话语——如果它真的至关重要——必然包含实验性和争议性。这又有何不可？为什么我们这个时代的典型音乐爱好者似乎如此不愿将音乐作品视为一种可能的挑战性体验？当我听到一首我不懂的新乐曲时，我会被激发——我想一有机会就再次接触它。这是一种挑战——它让我对音乐艺术保持着浓厚的兴趣。如果反复聆听一部作品后，我却毫无感触，我并不会因此就断定现代作曲水平低下。我只是觉得这首乐曲不适合我。

That musical speech—if it is truly vital—is certain to include an experimental and controversial side. And why not? Why is it that the typical music lover of our day is seemingly so reluctant to consider a musical composition as, possibly, a challenging experience? When I hear a new piece of music that I do not understand, I am intrigued—I want to make contact with it again at the first opportunity. It’s a challenge—it keeps my interest in the art of music thoroughly alive. If, after repeated hearings, a work says nothing to me, I do not therefore conclude that modern composition is in a sorry condition. I simply conclude that that piece is not for me.

然而，我遗憾地发现，我自己的反应并不典型。大多数人似乎都讨厌音乐中的争议；他们不想自己的听歌习惯被打乱。他们把音乐当作沙发；他们想枕在上面，放松身心，抚慰日常生活的压力。但严肃音乐从来就不是用来催眠的。尤其是当代音乐，创作的目的是唤醒你，而不是让你沉睡。它是为了激发你、让你兴奋，让你感动——它甚至可能让你精疲力竭。但这不正是你去剧院或读书所追求的那种刺激吗？为什么音乐就不能例外呢？

I’ve sadly observed, however, that my own reaction is not typical. Most people seem to resent the controversial in music; they don’t want their listening habits disturbed. They use music as a couch; they want to be pillowed on it, relaxed and consoled for the stress of daily living. But serious music was never meant to be used as a soporific. Contemporary music, especially, is created to wake you up, not put you to sleep. It is meant to stir and excite you, to move you—it may even exhaust you. But isn’t that the kind of stimulation you go to the theater for or read a book for? Why make an exception for music?

新音乐听起来奇特，或许唯一的原因是，在日常聆听过程中，与年复一年演奏的传统音乐相比，人们听到的新音乐太少了。广播和音乐会节目、唱片制造商及其经销商的广告、通常的学校课程——所有这些都在不知不觉中强调了这样一种观念，即“正常”音乐是过去的音乐，是已经证明了其价值的音乐。据不完全估计，我们听到的音乐中只有四分之一可以被称为当代音乐——而且这种估计主要适用于大型音乐中心的音乐。在这种情况下，当代音乐很可能仍然“奇特”，除非听众愿意付出额外的努力来打破陌生的障碍。

It may be that new music sounds peculiar for the sole reason that, in the course of ordinary listening, one hears so little of it by comparison with the amount of conventional music that is performed year in and year out. Radio and concert programs, the advertisements of the record manufacturers and their dealers, the usual school curricula—all emphasize the idea, unwittingly, perhaps, that “normal” music is music of the past, music that has proved its worth. A generous estimate indicates that only one-quarter of the music we hear can be called contemporary—and that estimate applies mostly to music heard in the larger musical centers. Under such circumstances contemporary music is likely to remain “peculiar,” unless the listener is willing to make the extra effort needed to break the barrier of unfamiliarity.

觉得没有必要参与自己时代的音乐表达，就等于将自己与音乐艺术所能提供的最激动人心的体验之一隔绝开来。当代音乐以其他音乐无法比拟的方式与我们对话。对我们来说，更古老的音乐——布克斯特胡德和凯鲁比尼的音乐——才应该是遥远而陌生的，而不是米约和威廉·舒曼的音乐。但音乐不是具有普遍性吗？你或许会问，在世的作曲家所创作的哪些作品，在更早的音乐中找不到多少类似的表达？一切都取决于视角：我们所看到的会产生更广泛的紧张与释放的极端，更生动的乐观，更灰暗的悲观，放纵与歇斯底里的高潮，色彩的多样性——光与暗的微妙之处，一种轻松的乐趣有时溢出到怪诞、拥挤的纹理、开阔的远景、“痛苦的”渴望和令人眼花缭乱的光彩中。毫无疑问，这些情绪的各种层次和层次在古老的音乐中都有对应之处，但任何敏锐的听众都不会混淆这两者。我们通常将作品所属的时期视为其面貌的重要组成部分。任何真正的艺术表达都独一无二，这使得在其他时期进行哪怕是近似的复制都变得不可想象。正因如此，忽视当代音乐的音乐爱好者就错失了享受这种原本无法获得的审美体验的机会。

To feel no need of involvement in the musical expression of one’s own day is to shut oneself off from one of the most exciting experiences the art of music can provide. Contemporary music speaks to us as no other music can. It is the older music—the music of Buxtehude and Cherubini—that should seem distant and foreign to us, not that of Milhaud and William Schuman. But isn’t music universal? What, you may ask, does the living composer say that will not be found in somewhat analogous terms in an earlier music? All depends on the angle of vision: what we see produces wider extremes of tension and release, a more vivid optimism, a grayer pessimism, climaxes of abandonment and explosive hysteria, coloristic variety—subtleties of light and dark, a relaxed sense of fun sometimes spilling over into the grotesque, crowded textures, open-spaced vistas, “painful” longing, dazzling brilliance. Various shades and gradations of these moods have their counterpart in older music, no doubt, but no sensitive listener would ever confuse the two. We usually recognize the period a composition belongs in as an essential part of its physiognomy. It is the uniqueness of any authentic art expression that makes even approximate duplication in any other period inconceivable. That is why the music lover who neglects contemporary music deprives himself of the enjoyment of an otherwise unobtainable aesthetic experience.

理解新音乐的关键在于反复聆听。幸运的是，长碟的盛行让这一点完全成为可能。许多听众已经证实，只有反复聆听才能带来的熟悉感，才能逐渐取代难以理解的音乐。无论如何，没有比这更好的方法来检验当代音乐是否对你有意义了。

The key to the understanding of new music is repeated hearings. Fortunately for us, the prevalence of the long-play disk makes this entirely possible. Many listeners have attested to the fact that incomprehensibility gradually gives way before the familiarity that only repeated hearing can give. There is, in any event, no better way to test whether contemporary music is to have significance for you.

 

 

斯特拉文斯基—— 《彼得鲁什卡》

Stravinsky—Petrouchka

皮埃尔·蒙特，波士顿交响乐团 (RCA)

Pierre Monteux, Boston Symphony (RCA)

斯特拉文斯基 — Le Sa​​cre du Printemps（《春之祭》）

Stravinsky—Le Sacre du Printemps (“The Rite of Spring”)

埃萨-佩卡·萨洛宁，爱乐乐团（索尼）

Esa-Pekka Salonen, Philharmonia Orchestra (Sony)

布里顿——男高音、圆号与弦乐小夜曲

Britten—Serenade for Tenor, Horn and Strings

布里顿指挥，彼得·皮尔斯、巴里·塔克韦尔（伦敦）

Britten conducting, with Peter Pears, Barry Tuckwell (London)

巴托克—四重奏1-6

Bartók—Quartets 1-6

艾默生四重奏（德意志留声机）

Emerson Quartet (Deutsche Grammophon)

勋伯格——第四四重奏

Schoenberg—Quartet No. 4

阿尔迪蒂四重奏（蒙田唱片）

Arditti Quartet (Disques Montaigne)

艾夫斯——第二钢琴奏鸣曲（“协和”）

Ives—Piano Sonata No. 2 (“Concord”)

吉尔伯特·卡利什（Nonesuch）

Gilbert Kalish (Nonesuch)

17

17

电影音乐

Film Music

电影音乐是一种全新的音乐媒介，它本身就散发着独特的魅力。实际上，它是一种新的戏剧音乐形式——与歌剧、芭蕾舞和情景剧音乐息息相关——与交响乐或室内乐之类的音乐会音乐截然不同。作为一种新形式，它为作曲家开辟了前所未有的可能性，也为音乐电影的赞助人提出了一些有趣的问题。

Film music constitutes a new musical medium that exerts a fascination of its own. Actually, it is a new form of dramatic music—related to opera, ballet, incidental theater music—in contradistinction to concert music of the symphonic or chamber-music kind. As a new form it opens up unexplored possibilities for composers and poses some interesting questions for the musical film patron.

数百万电影观众对剧情片的音乐伴奏习以为常。影片结束五分钟后，他们甚至无法判断自己是否听到了音乐。如果问他们觉得配乐精彩纷呈、勉强过关，还是糟糕透顶，那只会让他们产生音乐上的自卑感。但转念一想，或许是出于自我保护，他们又会问：“难道不应该听音乐吗？难道音乐不应该像在音乐会上那样，在观众不经意间就对观众产生作用吗？”

Millions of moviegoers take the musical accompaniment to a dramatic film entirely too much for granted. Five minutes after the termination of a picture they couldn’t tell you whether they heard music or not. To ask whether they thought the score exciting or merely adequate or downright awful would be to give them a musical inferiority complex. But, on second thought, and possibly in self-protection, comes the query: “Isn’t it true that one isn’t supposed to be listening to the music? Isn’t it supposed to work on you unconsciously without being listened to directly as you would listen at a concert?”

任何关于电影音乐的讨论，都免不了要面对一个问题：到底该不该听电影配乐？如果你是一位音乐家，那就没问题了，因为你很可能忍不住要听。我曾经不止一次因为劣质配乐而毁掉了一部好电影。你也有过同样的经历吗？有吗？那么你可以庆幸自己：你绝对是个音乐人。

No discussion of movie music ever gets very far without having to face this problem: Should one hear a movie score? If you are a musician there is no problem because the chances are you can’t help but listen. More than once a good picture has been ruined for me by an inferior score. Have you had the same experience? Yes? Then you may congratulate yourself: you are definitely musical.

但普通观众却沉浸于戏剧情节，以至于忽略了背景音乐，他们想知道自己是否错过了什么。答案与你对音乐的整体感知能力息息相关。你的听觉感知能力决定了你能从背景音乐伴奏中汲取多少乐趣，而背景音乐是​​影片整体印象中不可或缺的一部分。

But it’s the average spectator, so absorbed in the dramatic action that he fails to take in the background music, who wants to know whether he is missing anything. The answer is bound up with the degree of your general musical perception. It is the degree to which you are aurally minded that will determine how much pleasure you may derive by absorbing the background musical accompaniment as an integral part of the combined impression made by the film.

了解电影配乐的更多细节，或许能帮助电影听众更好地理解。好在这个过程并非复杂到无法简单概括。

Knowing more of what goes into the scoring of a picture may help the movie listener to get more out of it. Fortunately, the process is not so complex that it cannot be briefly outlined.

在准备创作音乐时，作曲家首先要做的当然是看画面。几乎所有的配乐都是在电影本身完成后创作的。唯一的例外是剧本要求写实主义的音乐——即在银幕上以视觉方式演唱、演奏或跳舞的音乐。在这种情况下，音乐必须在场景拍摄前创作完成。之后，音乐会被录制下来，并在拍摄场景时播放录音。因此，当你看到一个演员唱歌、演奏或跳舞时，他只是在用声音来营造一种真实感，因为音乐之前已经录制好了。

In preparation for composing the music, the first thing the composer must do, of course, is to see the picture. Almost all musical scores are written after the film itself is completed. The only exception to this is when the script calls for realistic music—that is, music which is visually sung or played or danced to on the screen. In that case the music must be composed before the scene is photographed. It will then be recorded and the scene in question shot to a playback of the recording. Thus when you see an actor singing or playing or dancing, he is only making believe as far as the sound goes, for the music had previously been put down in recorded form.

对作曲家来说，影片的首次排演通常是一个庄严的时刻。毕竟，他必须与这部影片共度数周。与他一同观看的专属观众，更突显了这一时刻的庄严：制片人、导演、制片厂的音乐总监、影片剪辑师、音乐剪辑师、指挥、管弦乐师——事实上，所有参与影片配乐的人员。

The first run-through of the film for the composer is usually a solemn moment. After all, he must live with it for several weeks. The solemnity of the occasion is emphasized by the exclusive audience that views it with him: the producer, the director, the music head of the studio, the picture editor, the music cutter, the conductor, the orchestrater—in fact, anyone involved with the scoring of the picture.

排练的目的是确定需要多少音乐以及应该放在哪里。（用专业术语来说，这叫做“找到”画面。）由于没有哪部电影的背景音乐是​​贯穿整部影片的（否则就成了一部电影歌剧，一种几乎未被开发的电影形式），配乐通常由独立的片段组成，每个片段的时长从几秒到几分钟不等。长达七分钟的片段更是罕见。整部电影的配乐可能由三十个或更多这样的片段组成，加起来的音乐时长可能在四十到九十分钟之间。

The purpose of the run-through is to decide how much music is needed and where it should be. (In technical jargon this is called “to spot” the picture.) Since no background score is continuous throughout the full length of a film (that would constitute a motion-picture opera, an almost unexploited cinema form), the score will normally consist of separate sequences, each lasting from a few seconds to several minutes in duration. A sequence as long as seven minutes would be exceptional. The entire score, made up of perhaps thirty or more such sequences, may add up to from forty to ninety minutes of music.

在最终确定画面的“定位”之前，可能需要进行大量的讨论和反复的沟通。明智的做法是谨慎地运用音乐的力量，将其留到绝对必要的时刻。作曲家懂得如何运用静默——他们知道，有时，移除音乐比在音轨上使用它更有效。

Much discussion, much give-and-take may be necessary before final decisions are reached regarding the “spotting” of the picture. It is wise to make use of music’s power sparingly, saving it for absolutely essential points. A composer knows how to play with silences—knows that to take music out can at times be more effective than any use of it on the sound track might be.

另一方面，制片人兼导演更倾向于从音乐的直接功能性角度来思考。有时，他别有用心：任何场景中的瑕疵——糟糕的表演、糟糕的台词、令人尴尬的停顿——他都暗自希望一位聪明的作曲家能够掩盖。众所周知，制片人希望一部优秀的配乐能够拯救整部影片。但作曲家并非魔术师；他所能做的，几乎只能是通过音乐来强化影片的戏剧性和情感价值。

The producer-director, on the other hand, is more prone to think of music in terms of its immediate functional usage. Sometimes he has ulterior motives: anything wrong with a scene—a poor bit of acting, a badly read line, an embarrassing pause—he secretly hopes will be covered up by a clever composer. Producers have been known to hope that an entire picture would be saved by a good score. But the composer is not a magician; he can hardly be expected to do more than to make potent through music the film’s dramatic and emotional values.

精心设计的配乐无疑能为影片带来巨大的助力。我们可以用实验室的方式证明这一点，比如在关闭声音的情况下向观众展示一个高潮场景，然后再打开音轨。以下简要列举了音乐服务于银幕的几种方式：

When well-contrived, there is no question but that a musical score can be of enormous help to a picture. One can prove that point, laboratory-fashion, by showing an audience a climactic scene with the sound turned off and then once again with the sound track turned on. Here briefly are listed a number of ways in which music serves the screen:

1.营造更令人信服的时空氛围。并非所有好莱坞作曲家都注重这种细节。他们的配乐常常互相混淆：一部十三世纪的哥特式戏剧和一场冷酷的现代两性之战，处理方式却大同小异。十九世纪晚期音乐华丽的交响乐质感依然占据主导地位。但也有例外。近年来，更高级别的马戏开始拥有自己的音乐风格，大多是民歌的衍生作品。

1. Creating a more convincing atmosphere of time and place. Not all Hollywood composers bother about this nicety. Too often, their scores are interchangeable: a thirteenth-century Gothic drama and a hard-boiled modern battle of the sexes get similar treatment. The lush symphonic texture of late nineteenth-century music remains the dominating influence. But there are exceptions. Recently, the higher-grade horse opera has begun to have its own musical flavor, mostly a folksong derivative.

2.强调心理上的微妙之处——角色未言明的想法或情境中不可见的隐含。音乐可以触动观众的情绪，有时将所见之物与暗示其反面的听觉图像进行对比。这听起来并不那么微妙。一个恰到好处的不和谐和弦可以让观众在感伤的场景中感到冷漠，一段精心设计的木管乐段可以将看似庄严的时刻变成开怀大笑。

2. Underlining psychological refinements—the unspoken thoughts of a character or the unseen implications of a situation. Music can play upon the emotions of the spectator, sometimes counterpointing the thing seen with an aural image that implies the contrary of the thing seen. This is not as subtle as it sounds. A well-placed dissonant chord can stop an audience cold in the middle of a sentimental scene, or a calculated woodwind passage can turn what appears to be a solemn moment into a belly laugh.

3.充当某种中性的背景填充物。这类音乐其实不该被听到，它只是用来填补空白，比如对话中的停顿。这是电影作曲家最不讨喜的工作。但有时，尽管别人可能没注意到，他也会从这样的想法中获得些许满足：那些本身价值不高的音乐，经过专业的处理，让银幕上死气沉沉的阴影变得生动活泼，更具人性。任何电影作曲家都会证明，当这种中性填充音乐必须穿插在对话之下时，这才是最难做到的。

3. Serving as a kind of neutral background filler. This is really the music one isn’t supposed to hear, the sort that helps to fill the empty spots, such as pauses in a conversation. It’s the movie composer’s most ungrateful task. But at times, though no one else may notice, he will get private satisfaction from the thought that music of little intrinsic value, through professional manipulation, has enlivened and made more human the deathly pallor of a screen shadow. This is hardest to do, as any film composer will attest, when the neutral filler type of music must weave its way underneath dialogue.

4.营造连贯感。影片剪辑师比任何人都清楚，音乐在将一种本质上随时可能瓦解的视觉媒介串联起来方面有多么重要。这一点在蒙太奇场景中体现得最为明显，使用统一的音乐理念可以避免那些不连贯的场景快速闪现，避免显得杂乱无章。

4. Building a sense of continuity. The picture editor knows better than anyone how serviceable music can be in tying together a visual medium which is, by its very nature, continually in danger of falling apart. One sees this most obviously in montage scenes where the use of a unifying musical idea may save the quick flashes of disconnected scenes from seeming merely chaotic.

5.为场景的戏剧性铺垫打下基础，并以终结感为其画上句号。首先想到的就是电影结尾响起的音乐。有些制片人曾夸耀自己的影片没有配乐，但我从未见过或听说过有哪部影片的结尾是无声的。

5. Underpinning the theatrical build-up of a scene, and rounding it off with a sense of finality. The first instance that comes to mind is the music that blares out at the end of a film. Certain producers have boasted their picture’s lack of a musical score, but I never saw or heard of a picture that ended in silence.

我们只是略微提及了一点，并没有提及那些数不胜数的实用主义音乐——幕后的街头乐队、谷仓舞、旋转木马、马戏团音乐、咖啡馆音乐、邻居家女孩练钢琴等等。所有这些，以及许多其他以看似自然主义的意图引入的音乐，都微妙地改变了音轨的听觉趣味。

We have merely skimmed the surface, without mentioning the innumerable examples of utilitarian music—offstage street bands, the barn dance, merry-go-rounds, circus music, café music, the neighbor’s girl practicing her piano, and the like. All these, and many others, introduced with apparent naturalistic intent, serve to vary subtly the aural interest of the sound track.

现在让我们回到我们假设的作曲家。确定了各个音乐片段的开始和结束位置后，他将影片交给剪辑师，剪辑师会准备一份所谓的“提示表”。提示表为作曲家提供了每个片段中肢体动作的详细描述，以及该动作的精确时间（以三分之一秒为单位），从而使经验丰富的作曲家无需再次参考影片就能创作出完整的乐谱。

But now let us return to our hypothetical composer. Having determined where the separate musical sequences will begin and end, he turns the film over to the music cutter, who prepares a so-called cue sheet. The cue sheet provides the composer with a detailed description of the physical action in each sequence, plus the exact timings in thirds of seconds of that action, thereby making it possible for a practiced composer to write an entire score without ever again referring to the picture.

外行人通常以为，电影作曲最难的部分在于如何精准地将音乐与动作“契合”。这种时间上的限制难道不会束缚作曲家吗？答案是否定的，原因有二：首先，为特定动作配乐反而是利大于弊，因为动作本身就能激发作曲家的戏剧想象力，而创作纯音乐则缺乏这种视觉刺激。其次，时间上的调整通常只需要一些细微的调整，因为整体的音乐结构早已确定。

The layman usually imagines that the most difficult part of the job in composing for the films has to do with the precise “fitting” of the music to the action. Doesn’t that kind of timing strait-jacket the composer? The answer is no, for two reasons: First, having to compose music to accompany specific action is a help rather than a hindrance, since the action itself induces music in a composer of theatrical imagination, whereas he has no such visual stimulus in writing absolute music. Secondly, the timing is mostly a matter of minor adjustments, since the over-all musical fabric will have already been determined.

对于音乐会音乐作曲家来说，改用赛璐珞作为媒介确实会带来一些特殊的陷阱。例如，在音乐厅备受推崇的旋律创作，在某些电影场景中可能会分散注意力。即使是音乐会乐句的表达方式，通常会强调各个对位线的独立性，但应用于银幕伴奏时，也可能分散注意力。在管弦乐编曲中，音色的许多微妙之处——这些区别本应在礼堂中聆听，以彰显其自身的表现力——在音轨上却完全被浪费了。

For the composer of concert music, changing to the medium of celluloid does bring certain special pitfalls. For example, melodic invention, highly prized in the concert hall, may at times be distracting in certain film situations. Even phrasing in the concert manner, which would normally emphasize the independence of separate contrapuntal lines, may be distracting when applied to screen accompaniments. In orchestration there are many subtleties of timbre—distinctions meant to be listened to for their own expressive quality in an auditorium—which are completely wasted on sound track.

作为对这些损失的补偿，作曲家还有其他可能性，其中一些是卡内基音乐厅无法实现的技巧。例如，在为《女继承人》的一个部分配乐时，我能够将两个管弦乐队叠加在一起。两个乐队在不同时间录制相同的音乐，一个管弦乐队仅由弦乐组成，另一个管弦乐队由正常人组成。后来，通过同时重新录制原始音轨将它们合并在一起，从而产生了一种高度表现力的管弦乐织体。伯纳德·赫尔曼是最具独创性的银幕作曲家之一，他要求（并且确实做到了）八把钢片琴——这种组合在第 57 街是闻所未闻的——来暗示冬天的雪橇之旅。米克洛什·罗萨对“回音室”——一种给正常音调一种幽灵般光环的装置——的运用受到了广泛评论，随后被滥用。

As compensation for these losses, the composer has other possibilities, some of them tricks, which are unobtainable in Carnegie Hall. In scoring one section of The Heiress, for example, I was able to superimpose two orchestras, one upon another. Both recorded the same music at different times, one orchestra consisting of strings alone, the other constituted normally. Later these were combined by simultaneously rerecording the original tracks, thereby producing a highly expressive orchestral texture. Bernard Herrmann, one of the most ingenious of screen composers, called for (and got) eight celestas—an unheard-of combination on 57th Street—to suggest a winter’s sleigh ride. Miklos Rozsa’s use of the “echo chamber”—a device to give normal tone a ghostlike aura—was widely remarked, and subsequently done to death.

通过重叠输入和输出音轨，可以实现非凡的效果。就像两列火车并驾齐驱一样，可以同时引入和移除两种不同的音乐。《红马驹》给了我一个运用这一电影特长的机会。当一个小男孩的白日梦般的想象力将白色的小鸡变成白色的马戏团马时，视觉形象通过小鸡的音乐转化为马戏团的音乐，在听觉形象中得到映射，而这种效果只有通过重叠才能实现。

Unusual effects are obtainable through overlapping incoming and outgoing music tracks. Like two trains passing one another, it is possible to bring in and take out at the same time two different musics. The Red Pony gave me an opportunity to use this cinema specialty. When the daydreaming imagination of a little boy turns white chickens into white circus horses the visual image is mirrored in an aural image by having the chicken music transform itself into circus music, a device only obtainable by means of the overlap.

现在假设乐谱已经完成，准备录制。配乐阶段对作曲家来说是一个令人愉悦的地方。好莱坞聚集了美国最优秀的演奏家；音乐将以无与伦比的完美技术演奏和录制而成。

Let us now assume that the musical score has been completed and is ready for recording. The scoring stage is a happy-making place for the composer. Hollywood has gathered to itself some of America’s finest performers; the music will be beautifully played and recorded with a technical perfection not to be matched anywhere else.

大多数作曲家喜欢邀请朋友参加重要片段的录制。原因是，作曲家和他的朋友们以后都不太可能再听到音乐会级别的音乐了。因为当音乐与画面融合时，大部分的动态都会发生变化。否则，最终的作品听起来就像一场带有画面的音乐会。降低动态水平，精细的阴影处理，可能会丢失一些内部人声和低音部分。埃里希·科恩戈尔德（Erich Korngold）说得好：“电影作曲家的不朽，从录音阶段到配音室，都永垂不朽。”

Most composers like to invite their friends to be present at the recording session of important sequences. The reason is that neither the composer nor his friends are ever again likely to hear the music sound out in concert style. For when it is combined with the picture most of the dynamic levels will be changed. Otherwise the finished product might sound like a concert with pictures. In lowering dynamic levels niceties of shading, some inner voices and bass parts may be lost. Erich Korngold put it well when he said: “A movie composer’s immortality lasts from the recording stage to the dubbing room.”

配音室是将包括对话在内的所有涉及声音的音轨通过机器处理，最终获得一条主音轨的地方。就音乐而言，这是一个微妙的过程，因为“过响”和“过轻”之间只有一线之隔。操作音量旋钮的音响工程师，并不总是像作曲家希望的那样对音乐敏感。我们需要的是一种全新的职业，即一半是音乐家、一半是工程师的混音师；即便如此，对话、音乐以及各种现实声音的混合仍将始终是一个难题。

The dubbing room is where all the tracks involving sound of any kind, including dialogue, are put through the machines to obtain one master sound track. This is a delicate process as far as the music is concerned, for it is only a hairbreadth that separates the “too loud” from the “too soft.” Sound engineers, working the dials that control volume, are not always as musically sensitive as composers would like them to be. What is called for is a new species, a sound mixer who is half musician and half engineer; and even then, the mixing of dialogue, music, and realistic sounds of all kinds must always remain problematical.

鉴于这些不利于音乐充分展现的缺陷，作曲家常常希望从电影配乐中提炼出一部可行的音乐会组曲也就不足为奇了。目前有一种倾向认为，电影配乐并不适合创作音乐会音乐。这种观点认为，如果脱离了视觉上的合理性，音乐就会显得平淡无奇。

In view of these drawbacks to the full sounding out of his music, it is only natural that the composer often hopes to be able to extract a viable concert suite from his film score. There is a current tendency to believe that movie scores are not proper material for concert music. The argument is that, separated from its visual justification, the music falls flat.

我个人非常怀疑，能否制定出一条涵盖所有情况的硬性规定。每部乐谱都必须根据其优缺点进行评判，毫无疑问，那些需要在统一氛围中以更连贯的方式展开音乐的故事，比其他故事更适合为音乐会改编。一部电影的音乐几乎不可能不经过大量修改就能被提取出来。但我不明白，如果像格里格的《培尔·金特》这样成功的组曲可以用19世纪的舞台配乐创作出来，为什么20世纪的作曲家就不能指望在电影配乐方面取得同样的成就。

Personally, I doubt very much that any hard and fast rule can be made that will cover all cases. Each score will have to be judged on its merits, and, no doubt, stories that require a more continuous type of musical development in a unified atmosphere will lend themselves better than others to reworking for concert purposes. Rarely is it conceivable that the music of a film might be extracted without much reworking. But I fail to see why, if successful suites like Grieg’s Peer Gynt can be made from nineteenth-century incidental stage music, a twentieth-century composer can’t be expected to do as well with a film score.

至于电影配乐，只有在电影院里，作曲家才能第一次充分感受到自己成就的冲击力，检验自己最爱场景的戏剧冲击力，体会到细节的奇特重要性和不重要性，希望自己在某些地方做得更好，并惊讶于其他部分的效果比自己预想的还要好。毕竟，将电影与音乐相结合的艺术仍然是一门神秘的艺术。其中最神秘的一点是观众的反应：数百万观众会聆听，但谁也不知道有多少人真正听进去了。下次去看电影时，记得站在作曲家一边。

As for the picture score, it is only in the motion-picture theater that the composer for the first time gets the full impact of what he has accomplished, tests the dramatic punch of his favorite spot, appreciates the curious importance and unimportance of detail, wishes that he had done certain things differently, and is surprised that others came off better than he had hoped. For when all is said and done, the art of combining moving pictures with musical tones is still a mysterious art. Not the least mysterious element is the theatergoers’ reaction: Millions will be listening but one never knows how many will be really hearing. The next time you go to the movies, remember to be on the composer’s side.

 

 

科普兰——电影音乐

Copland—Music for Films

伦纳德·斯拉特金，圣路易斯交响乐团（RCA）

Leonard Slatkin, St. Louis Symphony (RCA)

赫尔曼——电影音乐

Herrmann—Music for Films

埃萨-佩卡·萨洛宁，洛杉矶爱乐乐团（索尼）

Esa-Pekka Salonen, Los Angeles Philharmonic (Sony)

18

18

从作曲家到诠释者再到听众

From Composer to Interpreter to Listener

本书迄今为止主要探讨的是抽象的音乐。但从实际角度来看，几乎每种音乐情境都包含三个不同的因素：作曲家、诠释者和听众。他们构成一个三足鼎立的体系，缺一不可。音乐始于作曲家，经由诠释者，最终汇聚于你——听众。归根结底，音乐中的一切都是为了你——听众——而展开的。因此，要想明智地聆听，你不仅必须清楚地理解自己的角色，还必须清楚地理解作曲家和诠释者的角色，以及他们各自对音乐体验的贡献。

Thus far, this book has been largely concerned with music in the abstract. But, practically considered, almost every musical situation implies three distinct factors: a composer, an interpreter, and a listener. They form a triumvirate, no part of which is complete without the other. Music begins with a composer; passes through the medium of an interpreter; and ends with you, the listener. Everything in music may be said, in the final analysis, to be directed at you—the listener. Therefore, to listen intelligently, you must clearly understand not only your own role but also that of composer and interpreter and what each one contributes to the sum total of a musical experience.

让我们从作曲家开始，因为我们文明中的音乐就是从他开始的。说到底，当我们听作曲家的作品时，我们在听什么？他不必像小说家那样给我们讲故事；他不必像雕塑家那样“临摹”自然；他的作品不必像建筑师的图纸那样具有直接的实用功能。那么，他给了我们什么呢？在我看来，只有一个答案：他给了我们他自己。当然，每个艺术家的作品都是他自己的表达，但没有哪一种能比得上富有创造力的音乐家的作品。他给我们的是他自己的精髓，与外界的“事件”无关，这一部分体现了他作为一个人以及他作为一个同胞的经历的最充分、最深刻的表达。

Let us begin with the composer, since music in our own civilization begins with him. What, after all, do we listen for when we listen to a composer? He need not tell us a story like the novelist; he need not “copy” nature like the sculptor; his work need have no immediate practical function like the architect’s drawing. What is it that he gives us, then? Only one answer seems possible to me: He gives us himself. Every artist’s work is, of course, an expression of himself, but none so direct as that of the creative musician. He gives us, without relation to exterior “events,” the quintessential part of himself—that part which embodies the fullest and deepest expression of himself as a man and of his experience as a fellow being.

永远记住，当你聆听作曲家的作品时，你聆听的是一个人，一个特定的个体，拥有他独特的个性。作曲家若要有任何价值，就必须拥有他自己的个性。这种个性的重要性或大或小，但就重要的音乐而言，它总是会反映出这种个性。没有一位作曲家能够将他作为人所不具备的价值融入到他的音乐中。他的性格或许带有人性的弱点——例如吕利或瓦格纳——但他音乐中所有的优点都源于他作为人身上所有的优点。

Always remember that when you listen to a composer’s creation you are listening to a man, to a particular individual, with his own special personality. For a composer, to be of any value, must have his own personality. It may be of greater or lesser importance, but, in the case of significant music, it will always mirror that personality. No composer can write into his music a value that he does not possess as a man. His character may be streaked with human frailties—like Lully’s or Wagner’s, for example—but whatever is fine in his music will come from whatever is fine in him as a man.

如果我们更深入地探究作曲家的个人性格，就会发现它实际上由两个截然不同的因素构成：他与生俱来的个性以及他所处时代的影响。显然，每位作曲家都生活在特定的时期，而每个时期也都有其独特的性格。作曲家的个性在其所处的时期框架内得到充分体现。正是个性与时代的相互作用，才形成了作曲家的风格。两位性格完全相同、生活在不同时代的作曲家，必然会创作出两种不同风格的音乐。因此，当我们谈论作曲家的风格时，我们指的是个人性格与特定时期的结合。

If we examine this question of the composer’s individual character more closely, we shall discover that it is really made up of two distinct elements: the personality with which he was born and the influences of the time in which he lives. For, obviously, every composer lives in a certain period, and each period has its character, too. Whatever personality a composer may have is expressed within the framework of his own period. It is the interreaction of personality and period that results in the formation of a composer’s style. Two composers with exactly similar personalities living in two different epochs would inevitably produce music of two different styles. When we speak of a composer’s style, therefore, we refer to the combined result of an individual character and a particular period.

也许，将这个重要的音乐风格问题应用到具体的案例中会更加清楚。以贝多芬为例。他的风格最明显的特征之一就是粗犷。贝多芬这个人，以粗犷而著称。然而，仅从音乐来看，我们就知道他是一位粗犷、粗犷的作曲家，与温文尔雅和悦耳动听截然相反。然而，贝多芬粗犷的性格在他生命的不同时期呈现出不同的表现形式。第一交响曲的粗犷不同于第九交响曲。这是时期的不同。早期的贝多芬在十八世纪古典风格的范围内粗犷，而成熟的贝多芬则受到了十九世纪解放倾向的影响。因此，在考察一位作曲家的风格时，我们必须考虑到他所处时代所反映的个性。有多少作曲家就有多少种风格，每位重要的作曲家都拥有几种不同的风格，与其所处时代的影响以及其个性的成熟期相呼应。

Perhaps this important question of musical style will be made clearer if applied to a specific case. Take Beethoven, for example. One of the most obvious characteristics of his style is its ruggedness. Beethoven, as a man, had the reputation of being a brusque and rugged individual. From the testimony of the music alone, however, we know him to be a composer with a bold, uncouth quality, the very antithesis of the suave and the mellifluous. Still, that rugged character of Beethoven’s took on a different expression at different periods of his life. The ruggedness of the First Symphony is different from that of the Ninth. It is a difference of periods. The early Beethoven was rugged within the limits of an eighteenth-century classical manner, whereas the mature Beethoven underwent the influence of the liberating tendencies of the nineteenth century. That is why, in considering the style of a composer, we must take into account his personality as reflected by the period in which he lived. There are as many styles as there are composers, and each important composer has several different styles corresponding to the influences of his own time and the maturing of his own personality.

如果听众必须理解作曲家作品中音乐风格的内涵，那么对于诠释者来说更是如此。因为诠释者在音乐中扮演着某种中介的角色。听众听到的与其说是作曲家本人，不如说是诠释者对作曲家的理解。作家与读者的联系是直接的；画家的作品只需挂得高高在上就能被欣赏。但音乐如同戏剧，是一门必须重新诠释才能流传的艺术。拙劣的作曲家在完成作品后，必须将其交给诠释艺术家——必须始终牢记，艺术家本身就拥有独特的音乐天性和个性。因此，普通听众只有能够区分作曲家的思想（理想情况下）和诠释者忠实再现思想的程度，才能公正地评判作品的诠释。

If it is essential for the listener to understand the question of musical style as applied to a composer’s work, it is even more so for the interpreter. For the interpreter is a kind of middleman in music. It is not so much the composer that the listener hears, as the interpreter’s conception of the composer. The writer’s contact with his reader is direct; the painter’s picture need only be hung well to be seen. But music, like the theater, is an art that must be reinterpreted in order to live. The poor composer, having finished his composition, must turn it over to the tender mercies of an interpretive artist—who, it must always be remembered, is a being with his own musical nature and his own personality. The lay listener, therefore, can judge an interpretation fairly only if he is able to distinguish between the composer’s thought, ideally speaking, and the degree to which the interpreter is faithfully reproducing that thought.

诠释者的角色毋庸置疑。所有人都一致认为，诠释者的存在是为了服务作曲家——吸收并重现作曲家的“信息”。这个道理显而易见——真正需要阐释的是它的实际应用。

The role of the interpreter leaves no room for argument. All are agreed that he exists to serve the composer—to assimilate and recreate the composer’s “message.” The theory is plain enough—it is its practical application that needs elucidation.

当今大多数一流的诠释艺术家都拥有足以满足任何要求的技术装备。因此，在大多数情况下，我们可以将技术熟练视为理所当然。第一个真正的诠释问题来自音符本身。如今的乐谱并非作曲家思想的精确转录。它不可能准确，因为它太模糊了；它为个人的品味和选择留出了太大的余地。正因如此，诠释者永远面临着一个问题：他应该如何严格遵循印刷的乐谱？作曲家也是人——众所周知，他们有时会记谱不准确，有时会忽略重要的遗漏。他们也常常会改变自己对速度或力度的指示。因此，诠释者必须在印刷的乐谱之前运用他们的音乐智慧。当然，在两个方面都可能出现夸张——过于严格地遵循乐谱，或者偏离乐谱太远。如果能找到更精确的方法来记录乐曲，这个问题或许能在一定程度上得到解决。但即便如此，音乐仍然有多种不同的诠释方式。

Most first-rate interpretive artists today possess a technical equipment that is more than sufficient for any demands made upon them. So that in most cases we can take technical proficiency for granted. The first real interpretive problem is presented by the notes themselves. Musical notation, as it exists today, is not an exact transcription of a composer’s thought. It cannot be, for it is too vague; it allows for too great a leeway in individual matters of taste and choice. Because of that, the interpreter is forever confronted with the problem of how literally he is expected to keep to the printed page. Composers are only human—they have been known to put notes down inexactly, to overlook important omissions. They have also been known to change their opinions in regard to their own indications of tempo or dynamics. Interpreters, therefore, must use their musical intelligence before the printed page. There is, of course, the possibility of exaggeration in both directions—keeping too strictly to the notes or straying too far away from them. The problem would probably be solved, up to a certain point, if a more exact way of noting down a composition were available. But, even so, music would still be open to a number of different interpretations.

因为作品毕竟是一个有机体。它是活的，而不是静止的。这就是为什么不同的诠释者，甚至同一个诠释者在不同时期，都能从不同的角度、用不同的眼光来看待它。诠释在很大程度上是一个侧重点的问题。每首曲子都有其本质特质，诠释不能背叛它。它的特质源于音乐本身的本质，而音乐的本质又源于作曲家的个性和创作时期。换句话说，每首作品都有其独特的风格，诠释者必须忠实于它。但每个诠释者也有自己的个性，因此，我们听到的作品风格是通过诠释者个性所折射出来的。

For a composition is, after all, an organism. It is a living, not a static, thing. That is why it is capable of being seen in a different light and from different angles by various interpreters or even by the same interpreter at different times. Interpretation is, to a large extent, a matter of emphasis. Every piece has an essential quality which the interpretation must not betray. It takes its quality from the nature of the music itself, which is derived from the personality of the composer himself and the period in which it was written. In other words, every composition has its own style which the interpreter must be faithful to. But every interpreter has his own personality, too, so that we hear the style of a piece as refracted by the personality of the interpreter.

因此，演奏者与其所创作作品之间的关系十分微妙。当诠释者将自己的个性过度地融入表演时，就会引发误解。近年来，“诠释”一词本身已声名狼藉。一些作曲家，以斯特拉文斯基为首，对“首席女高音”式诠释者的夸张和伪造感到沮丧和不满，他们实际上说：“我们不希望对我们的音乐进行任何所谓的诠释；只需演奏音符；不添加，也不删除。” 虽然这种告诫的理由显而易见，但在我看来，它代表了作曲家们一种不切实际的态度。因为任何一位完美的诠释者都不可能在不融入自身个性的情况下演奏出一首乐曲，甚至一个乐句。否则，诠释者就只能像机器人一样。他们演奏音乐时，不可避免地会以自己的方式进行。在这样做时，他们不需要歪曲作曲家的意图；他们只是用自己的声音的语调来“阅读”它。

The relation of the performer to the composition that he is recreating is therefore a delicate one. When the interpreter injects his personality into a performance to an unwarranted degree, misunderstandings arise. In recent years, the mere word “interpretation” has fallen into disrepute. Discouraged and disgruntled by the exaggerations and falsifications of “prima donna” interpreters, a certain number of composers, with Stravinsky as ringleader, have, in effect, said: “We do not wish any so-called interpretations of our music; just play the notes; add nothing, and take nothing away.” Though the reason for this admonishment is clear enough, it seems to me to represent a nonrealistic attitude on the part of composers. For no finished interpreter can possibly play a piece of music or even a phrase, for that matter, without adding something of his or her own personality. To have it otherwise, interpreters would have to be automatons. Inevitably, when they perform music, they perform it in their own way. In doing so, they need not falsify the composer’s intentions; they are merely “reading” it with the inflections of their own voice.

但诠释上的差异背后还有更深层次的原因。毫无疑问，一部勃拉姆斯交响曲，如果由两位一流指挥家演绎，即使不违背勃拉姆斯的意图，效果也可能大相径庭。思考一下其中的原因，或许会很有意思。

But there are further, and more profound, reasons for differences in interpretation. There is no doubt that a Brahms symphony, interpreted by two first-rate conductors, may be different in effect without being unfaithful to Brahms’s intentions. It is interesting to ruminate on why that should be true.

以当代两位杰出的音乐诠释家——阿尔图罗·托斯卡尼尼和谢尔盖·库塞维茨基为例。14 他们性格迥异——思维方式不同，对事物的情感表达方式也不同，人生哲学也截然不同。因此，在处理同一张乐谱时，他们的诠释必然大相径庭，这在意料之中。

Take, for example, two of the outstanding interpreters of our day—Arturo Toscanini and Serge Koussevitzky.14 They are two entirely different personalities—men who think differently, who emotionalize about things in a different way, whose philosophy of life is different. It is only to be expected that in handling the same notes their interpretations will vary considerably.

这位意大利指挥家天生是一位古典主义者。某种超然物外之感是古典主义者气质中不可或缺的一部分。托斯卡尼尼给人的第一印象颇为奇特——他似乎对音乐毫无所动。只有聆听片刻之后，才能感受到一种艺术中蕴藏的艺术感。他对待音乐如同一件物品，仿佛存在于舞台的后方——在那里我们可以尽情地凝视它，享受其中的乐趣。音乐中透着一种奇妙的超然感。然而，它始终是音乐，是所有艺术中最富激情的。托斯卡尼尼的重点始终在于整体，在于整体结构——而非细节或单个小节。音乐为了自身而律动、为了自身而存在，我们能够如此凝视音乐，也算是一种幸运。

The Italian conductor is a classicist by nature. A certain detachment is an essential part of the classicist’s make-up. One’s first impression is a curious one—Toscanini seems to be doing nothing at all to the music. It is only after one has listened for a while that the sense of an art concealing art begins to take hold of one. He treats the music as if it were an object. It seems to exist at the back of the stage—where we can contemplate it for our pleasure. There is a wonderful sense of detachment about it. Yet all the time it is music, the most passionate of all the arts. The emphasis with Toscanini is always on the line, on the structure as a whole—never on detail or on the separate measure. The music moves and lives for its own sake, and we are considered fortunate in being able to contemplate it living thus.

另一方面，这位俄罗斯指挥家天生浪漫主义。他全身心地投入到他所诠释的音乐中。他身上几乎没有什么精打细算。他拥有真正浪漫主义者的热情、激情、戏剧性的想象力和感性。对库塞维茨基来说，每一部杰作都是他指挥的战场，而你可以肯定，人类精神最终会从中胜出。当他“心情好”的时候，效果是压倒性的。

The Russian conductor, on the other hand, is a romanticist by nature. He is involved, body and soul, in the music that he interprets. There is little of the calculative about him. He possesses the true romanticist’s fire, passion, dramatic imagination, and sensuosity. With Koussevitzky every masterpiece is a battleground on which he captains the great fight, and out of which, you may be sure, the human spirit will emerge triumphant. When he is “in the mood,” the effect is overwhelming.

当这两位性格迥异的作曲家将各自的天赋运用到同一部勃拉姆斯交响曲中时，结果必然截然不同。一位深谙德国音乐的作曲家被一位俄罗斯人和一位意大利人诠释，这本身就是一个典型案例。两位作曲家都不可能演绎出德国人能听出的“纯正德语”（echt deutsch）音质。在俄罗斯人手中，勃拉姆斯的管弦乐队将焕发出意想不到的光芒，交响曲中蕴含的每一丝浪漫戏剧性都将在曲终时被充分展现。而意大利人则将强调勃拉姆斯作品中结构古典主义的一面，并以最纯粹的抒情风格刻画旋律。正如你所见，在这两种情况下，问题仅仅在于侧重点的不同。或许，这两位作曲家都不是你心目中完美的勃拉姆斯交响曲诠释者。但这不是重点。关键在于，为了明智地聆听翻译，您必须能够识别翻译人员在重新创作作品时究竟对作品做了什么。

When these two opposite personalities apply their gifts to the same Brahms symphony, the result is bound to be different. This case of a profoundly German composer’s being interpreted by a Russian and an Italian is typical. Neither one is likely to produce a quality of sound from his orchestra that a German would recognize as echt deutsch. In the Russian’s hands, Brahms’s orchestra will glow with an unsuspected luster, and every ounce of romantic drama that the symphony contains will be extracted by the time the end has been reached. With the Italian, on the other hand, the structural-classical side of Brahms will be stressed, and the melodic lines will be etched in the purest of lyrical styles. In both cases, as you see, it is simply a question of emphasis. It may be that neither of these men is your idea of the perfect interpreter of a Brahms symphony. But that is not the point. The point is that in order to hear an interpretation intelligently, you must be able to recognize what, exactly, the interpreter is doing to the composition at the moment that he recreates it.

换句话说，你必须更加了解诠释者在你聆听的演奏中所扮演的角色。要做到这一点，需要做到两点：你必须对作曲家的风格有一个或多或少理想的理解，以此为参考；并且你必须能够感受到诠释者在其自身个性的框架内，在多大程度上再现了这种风格。无论我们中任何人在聆听中距离达到这一理想境界还有多远，我们都应该牢记这一点，将其作为目标。

In other words, you must become more aware of the interpreter’s part in the performance you are hearing. To do that, two things are necessary: You must have, as point of reference, a more or less ideal conception of the style that is proper to the composer in question; and you must be able to sense to what degree the interpreter is reproducing that style, within the sphere of his own personality. However short any of us may fall from attaining this ideal in listening, it is well that we keep it in mind as an objective.

至此，听众在整个过程中的作用的重要性不言而喻。作曲家和诠释者的共同努力，只有传达给一群睿智的听众才有意义。这意味着听众负有责任。但一个人在理解音乐之前，必须真正热爱音乐。最重要的是，作曲家和诠释者希望听众能够全身心地投入到他们所听到的音乐中。维吉尔·汤姆森曾将理想的听众描述为“一个热烈鼓掌的人”。毫无疑问，他用这句名言的意思是，只有真正投入其中的听众，对音乐或音乐创作者来说才是重要的。

By now, the importance of the listener’s role in this whole process must be self-evident. The combined efforts of composer and interpreter have meaning only in so far as they go out to an intelligent body of hearers. That bespeaks a responsibility on the part of the hearer. But before one can understand music, one must really love it. Above all things, composers and interpreters want listeners who lend themselves fully to the music that they are hearing. Virgil Thomson once described the ideal listener as “a person who applauds vigorously.” By that bon mot he meant to imply, no doubt, that only a listener who really involves himself is of importance to music or the makers of music.

全身心投入音乐，必然意味着拓宽个人的品味。仅仅热爱音乐中较为传统的方面是不够的。品味，如同敏感度，在某种程度上是一种与生俱来的品质，但两者都可以通过理性的实践得到显著发展。这意味着聆听所有流派、所有时期的音乐，无论新旧，无论保守与现代。这意味着以不带偏见的心态去聆听，这才是真正意义上的聆听。

To lend oneself completely inevitably means, for one thing, the broadening of one’s taste. It is insufficient to love music only in its more conventional aspects. Taste, like sensitivity, is, to a certain extent, an inborn quality, but both can be considerably developed by intelligent practice. That means listening to music of all schools and all periods, old and new, conservative and modern. It means unprejudiced listening in the best sense of the term.

认真对待你作为听众的责任。我们所有人，无论专业人士还是门外汉，都在永远努力加深对艺术的理解。你也不例外，无论你作为听众的自尊心多么卑微。由于我们作为听众的共同反应对作曲和诠释的艺术有着最深远的影响，因此可以说，音乐的未来掌握在我们手中。

Take seriously your responsibility as listener. All of us, professionals and laymen alike, are forever striving to make our understanding of the art more profound. You need be no exception, no matter how modest your pretensions as listener may be. Since it is our combined reaction as listeners that most profoundly influences both the art of composition and interpretation, it may truthfully be said that the future of music is in our hands.

只有当听众真正活跃起来时，音乐才能真正鲜活起来。为了弘扬人类最辉煌的艺术之一，我们至少应该做到：专心聆听，自觉聆听，倾注全部智慧。

Music can only be really alive when there are listeners who are really alive. To listen intently, to listen consciously, to listen with one’s whole intelligence is the least we can do in the furtherance of an art that is one of the glories of mankind.

结语：“从那时起”

Epilogue: “Since Then”

纵观本世纪音乐界的创新精神所探索的众多路径，1945年无疑是一个便捷的标记。二战的结束，让许多艺术界——以及其他各行各业——的人们热衷于开辟新的起点，渴望从零开始，发明新的表达方式。如果要用一句话来概括过去半个世纪的音乐历程，那就是：艺术已经彻底重新定义了自己。

The year 1945 provides a convenient place-marker in any overview of the many pathways that music’s creative spirits have explored in this century. The end of World War II left many people in the arts—and in other walks of life as well—with an obsession to form new beginnings, to invent new modes of expression starting virtually from point zero. If it’s possible to coin a single phrase applicable to the course of music in the past half century, it’s that the art has totally redefined itself.

战争本身也提供了一些动力。美国和德国在战时的技术研究催生了以电子方式创作音调的机制，从而通过一系列振荡器、合成器等设备创作整首乐曲，以及将声音录制到磁带上。尤其是磁带录音机，它彻底改变了音乐创作、录制以及最终被听众接收的方式。作曲家只需一台台式录音机、一片刀片和几条胶带，就能编辑未完成的作品；录音师只需剪掉错误的音符。听众可以录制商业唱片中没有的音乐广播；唱片制作人只需一小箱设备，就能录制世界任何地方的现场表演，并将其制作成商业唱片。一卷磁带（或后来的盒式录音带）可以播放长达一小时，而没有老式 78 rpm 唱片每四分钟一次的停顿，这一事实推动了唱片业本身的进一步发展：1949 年首次推出的长时间播放唱片，以及 20 世纪 80 年代初开发出来的今天的数字光盘。

The war itself provided some of the impetus. From wartime technical research in both the United States and Germany came the mechanisms for creating musical tones electronically and, therefore, entire compositions through an array of oscillators, synthesizers and the like—and of recording sound on magnetic tape. The tape recorder, in particular, brought about a spectacular change in the way music was created, recorded, and ultimately received by the listener. With nothing more than a table-top recorder, a razor blade and some sticky tape, a composer could edit a work in progress; a recording engineer could cut out wrong notes. A listener could tape broadcasts of music not available on commercial recordings; a record producer, with only a small suitcaseful of equipment, could tape live performances anywhere in the world and produce them on commercial discs. The fact that a reel of tape (or, later, a cassette) could last as long as an hour without the once-every-four-minutes breaks of the old 78-rpm discs, led to further developments in the record industry itself: the long-playing record, first introduced in 1949, and today’s digital compact disc, developed in the early 1980s.

自1939年本书问世以来，音乐的视野，以及敏锐的音乐听众的视野，都被推后了，达到了当时难以估量、难以想象的程度。1939年，阿隆·科普兰在讨论阿诺德·勋伯格的钢琴曲集（作品19）时指出，当时“没有可用的录音”。而截至撰写本文时，已有五首。

Music’s horizons, and the horizons of the alert music listener as well, have been pushed back since this book was new in 1939, to a point immeasurable and inconceivable back then. In 1939 Aaron Copland noted, in his discussion of the set of Piano Pieces, Opus 19, by Arnold Schoenberg, that there was “no recording available.” At this writing, there are five.

旧有的藩篱崩塌。1939年的音乐世界由几大欧洲音乐中心——德国、奥地利、法国、意大利、英国和苏联——以及美国本土音乐风格初露锋芒的组成部分。这些风格源自本土作曲家，他们的视野因丰富的欧洲教育而更加丰富。

The old barriers crumbled. The musical world in 1939 consisted of a heritage from several specific European music centers—Germany, Austria, France, Italy, Great Britain, and the Soviet Union—and the promising beginnings of something like an indigenous style in the United States, from native composers whose outlooks had been enriched with a generous dose of European education.

由于新技术的发展——尤其是可以随时随地轻松录制任何事物——到 20 世纪 50 年代中期，美国的唱片购买者不仅可以轻松获得数十场竞争性演出中贝多芬的九部交响曲，还可以获得美国和国外新创作的音乐，如非洲乡村鼓乐、印度尼西亚甘美兰音乐、阿巴拉契亚偏远村庄的美国民歌手、牙买加钢鼓演奏家的音乐——换句话说，全世界的音乐。

Thanks to the new technologies—most of all the ease with which recordings could be made of everything, everywhere—it was possible by the mid-1950s for the record buyer in the U.S. to claim easy access not only to the nine Beethoven symphonies in dozens of competing performances but also to newly composed music from the United States and abroad, to the music of African village drumming, the gamelans of Indonesia, American folksingers in isolated Appalachian villages, the steel-drum virtuosos of Jamaica—the world, in other words.

与莫扎特和海顿时代的维也纳，或德彪西时代的巴黎相比，美国的音乐传统显得微不足道，因此，美国作曲家们尤其热衷于探索新的音乐源泉，仔细记录其独特之处，然后热切地将这些发现融入自己的音乐中，力求弥合文化差异。阿隆·科普兰早已在所谓的“流行”文化和“严肃”文化之间架起了桥梁，他借鉴了传统的美国牛仔音乐，或对其进行了精妙的模仿，并将其融入到自己的芭蕾舞剧《比利小子》和《牛仔竞技》中；1946年，他创作了大师级的舞曲《阿巴拉契亚之春》，同样借鉴了美国民间传统的音乐。

With their paltry musical tradition—compared to the Vienna of Mozart and Haydn, say, or the Paris of Debussy—composers in the United States were particularly eager to explore these new musical sources, carefully note their distinguishing features, then avidly set about incorporating these discoveries into their own music, seeking to bridge cultural gaps. Aaron Copland had already created that kind of bridge between so-called “pop” and “serious” culture by borrowing traditional American cowboy tunes—or creating his own masterful imitations—for his ballet scores Billy the Kid and Rodeo; in 1946 he created his masterful dance score Appalachian Spring, again using tunes from America’s folk traditions.

作曲家卢·哈里森（Lou Harrison）对印尼甘美兰（Gamelan）丰富的音乐结构深感兴趣——甘美兰是由一群演奏者组成的乐团，敲击各种打击乐器，这些乐器的设计旨在相互配合，形成一种理想化的室内乐。他自己制作了甘美兰，为其创作了兼具加州和巴厘岛风情的音乐，并将他的技巧传授给了一代又一代的学生。另一位西海岸作曲家特里·莱利（Terry Riley）听到了印度蜿蜒曲折、令人着迷的音乐，并受到启发，创作了自己的变奏曲。

The composer Lou Harrison, fascinated by the richly patterned music of the Indonesian gamelan—the ensemble of players striking a vast panoply of percussion instruments that had been designed to match one another in a kind of idealized chamber music—built gamelans of his own, composed music for them that, indeed, managed to sound both Californian and Balinese, and taught his techniques to generations of students. Another West Coast composer, Terry Riley, heard the sinuous, hypnotic music of India and was induced to create his own variations.

史蒂夫·莱奇的音乐通常被描述为“极简主义”的作曲家，他的风格——短促的节奏或旋律模式不断重复，并在很长一段时间内逐渐变化——源于对非洲鼓乐的深入研究。我们聆听莱奇的《鼓乐》 ——一部长达七十分钟的精湛合奏作品，或聆听特里·莱利的《C大调》，一部以“C”音为中心的一系列短促旋律模式——可以用手边的任何乐器演奏，演奏者可以随意选择演奏时长——仿佛置身于一种恍惚状态，与我们在上世纪海顿或贝多芬交响曲中期待的有序主题、发展和再现相去甚远。

Steve Reich, a composer whose music is usually described as “minimalist,” derived his style—short rhythmic or melodic patterns repeated and, over long time spans, gradually changing—from extensive studies of African drumming. We hear a work like Reich’s Drumming, seventy minutes of virtuosic ensemble performance, or Terry Riley’s In C, a series of short melodic patterns centered on the note ʺCʺ—to be played by whatever instruments are at hand and at whatever length the players choose—in something of a trance, far removed from the orderly sequence of themes, developments, and recapitulations we’d expect in a Haydn or Beethoven symphony of the previous century.

要正确地聆听这样的音乐，我们必须抛开从小养成的关于“新”与“旧”的偏见；我们也必须暂时抛开阿隆·科普兰关于在古典交响乐形式中应该听什么的教诲。极简主义者和卢·哈里森的音乐植根于这样一种观念：音乐是一种仪式，一种催眠，一种作曲家引诱我们加入其中的流动。贝多芬可能会用从一个调到另一个调的迅速而剧烈的跳跃吓到他的听众，而赖希和莱利作品中的变化几乎是潜意识的；你会突然注意到，比如说，在C大调中间出现了一个陌生的升F音，但你完全不知道它是什么时候、如何出现的。

To hear such music properly, we have to set aside whatever prejudices we’ve grown up with concerning “new” and “old”; we also have to set aside for the moment Aaron Copland’s teaching of what to listen for in classic symphonic forms. The music of the minimalists, and of Lou Harrison, has its roots in the notion of music as ritual, as a form of hypnosis, of a flow that the composer beguiles us to join. Where Beethoven might terrify his listeners with a swift and violent leap from one key to another far removed, the changes in Reich’s and Riley’s works are almost subliminal; you notice suddenly that there’s now an alien F-sharp, say, in the middle of In C, but you aren’t at all sure when it got there, or how.

大部分极简主义曲目——名单上还包括拉蒙特·扬和约翰·亚当斯，前者曾创作过一首持续两周的单和弦乐曲，后者根据理查德·尼克松的首次访华创作了一部成功的歌剧，其中的人物包括毛泽东和亨利·基辛格——意味着赋予表演者一定程度的自由，在一定限度内即兴创作的自由，甚至可以自发地决定作品何时结束。（C 调音阶的一个现有录音为 20 分钟，另一个为 76 分钟！）也许是约翰·凯奇将这种做法发挥到了极致，他为钢琴家“创作”了一首在特定时间静静坐在钢琴前的乐曲。但正如凯奇小心解释的那样，他4:33中的“音乐”不是寂静，而是特定时间特定房间内的环境声音。他声称：“音乐就是音乐家所说的一切”，从而赋予作曲家和演奏家不可剥夺的创作和演奏的自由，让他们能够随心所欲地创作和演奏。对凯奇而言，偶然性是音乐创作的主导力量之一，这与古典主义和浪漫主义时期音乐中优美而严谨的逻辑形成了鲜明对比。凯奇曾一度参考中国古代神谕《易经》来补充自己的创作思路。

Most of the minimalist repertory—the roster also includes La Monte Young, who once fashioned a piece lasting two weeks consisting of a single sustained chord, and John Adams, who composed a successful opera based on Richard Nixon’s first voyage to China, with a list of characters that included Mao Tse-Tung and Henry Kissinger—implied a certain amount of liberty accorded the performer, a freedom to improvise within certain limits or even to decide by spontaneous agreement when a work has run its course. (One available recording of In C runs twenty minutes; another runs seventy-six!) Perhaps it was John Cage who carried the practice to extremes when he “composed” a piece for pianist sitting silently at his instrument for a specified time. But, as Cage was careful to explain, the “music” in his 4:33 was not silence, but the ambient sounds in a particular room at a particular time. “Music,” he claimed, “is whatever musicians say it is,” thus establishing an undissolvable license to the composer and performer to create and perform as the spirit moves. To Cage the element of chance was one of the governing forces in music-making, in sharp opposition to the beautiful controlled logic of the music of the classical and romantic eras. At one point Cage turned to the ancient Chinese oracular text I Ching to supplement his own compositional decisions.

但“解体”——或者更确切地说，音乐脱离传统做法和根深蒂固的原则，尤其是旋律与和声的至高无上性，结构的统一性以及乐曲展开方式的对比多样性——早在上个世纪末就已开始。理查德·瓦格纳1864 年的《特里斯坦与伊索尔德》强调了其受挫的单恋主题，其中充斥着一种不安的、难以捉摸的和声，这种和声从未完全按照我们预期的方式进行。1899 年，25 岁​​的阿诺德·勋伯格创作了他的第一部杰作，一部名为《升华之夜》的室内乐作品，其和声的流动显然受到了《特里斯坦》的启发，从而进入了一个正常的和声规则——不和谐音有序地产生和谐音——不再是创作音乐的唯一公式的领域。

But the “disintegration”—or, better stated, the departure of music from traditional practices and ingrained principles, especially the supremacy of melody and harmony, of structural unity and contrasting variety in the way a piece unfolds—had already begun late in the previous century. Richard Wagner’s Tristan and Isolde of 1864 underlined its theme of frustrated, unrequited love with a wash of disturbed, elusive harmony that never quite proceeds where we expect it to. In 1899 the twenty-five-year-old Arnold Schoenberg produced his first masterpiece, a chamber work called “Transfigured Night,” with its flow of harmony clearly inspired by “Tristan” and, thus, moving into a realm where the normal rules of harmony—dissonance begetting consonance in an orderly progression—were no longer the only formula for creating music.

两股看似截然相反的力量，填满了20世纪中叶音乐版图的很大一部分。一方面，是约翰·凯奇、极简主义者以及偶然借鉴其他文明影响的人们所倡导的极端自由。另一方面，勋伯格的旋律与和声概念——本书先前讨论过的“无调性”——遵循一套严格组织的体系，以防止音阶中任何一个音符比其他音符更重要（例如，C音是C大调音阶中最重要的音符）。勋伯格体系严密的组织结构与他的德国和奥地利追随者颇为契合；他的弟子安东·冯·韦伯恩在其为少数几种乐器创作的极小而紧凑的作品中，不仅找到了系统化乐曲中音符与和声的方法，还找到了系统化音色、节奏、强弱音的有序序列的方法。他的《管弦乐曲》（作品 10）中的一些乐曲时长不到一分钟；在这短短的时间内，它们似乎释放出巨大的五彩火花云。

Two major forces, pulling in what seem to be exact opposite directions, fill in a large portion of the musical map as it stood at mid-century. On the one hand there was the extreme freedom advocated by John Cage, the minimalists and the serendipitous borrowers of influences from other civilizations. On the other, Schoenberg’s conception of melody and harmony—the “atonality” previously discussed in this book—followed a system strictly organized to prevent any one note in a scale from being more important than any other (in the way the note C is the most important note in the C-major scale). Something about the intense organization of the Schoenbergian systems proved congenial to his German and Austrian followers; his disciple Anton von Webern, in his legacy of extremely small, compact works for few instruments, worked out ways of systematizing not only the notes and harmonies of a composition but also the orderly sequence of tone-colors and rhythms, louds and softs. Some of his set of “Pieces for Orchestra” (Opus 10) last less than a minute; in that little time, they seem to give off enormous clouds of multicolored sparks.

两位二十世纪的巨匠，伊戈尔·斯特拉文斯基和阿诺德·勋伯格，在战争年代搬到洛杉矶，住的地方仅相隔几个街区；他们彼此从未交谈过。在以《春之祭》引起轰动之后，伊戈尔·斯特拉文斯基的音乐风格找到了多种表达方式，但他的作品，就像勋伯格学派的作品一样，除了严格遵循乐谱的字面意思外，不允许任何其他形式。斯特拉文斯基声称自己不喜欢无调性风格；然而，在勋伯格去世后不久，他尝试了勋伯格的作曲风格，并发现它很合得来。他一些风格鲜明、图案复杂的晚期乐谱——例如强有力的《安魂曲》——将曾经被认为不相容的风格进行了迷人的融合。

Two twentieth-century giants, Igor Stravinsky and Arnold Schoenberg, came to live only a few blocks apart in Los Angeles during the War years; they never spoke to one another. After the sensational launch of his career with The Rite of Spring, Igor Stravinsky’s musical manner found many modes of expression, but his works, like those of the Schoenberg school, allowed no room for anything but the exact letter of the score. Stravinsky claimed to have no use for the atonal style; yet, shortly after Schoenberg’s death, he tried out the Schoenbergian style of composition and found it congenial. Some of his stark, intricately patterned late scores—the powerful “Requiem Canticles” for one—bring about a fascinating synthesis between styles once regarded as incompatible.

安东·冯·韦伯恩于 1945 年逝世，在奥地利米特西尔村被一名美国哨兵误杀。在他去世后的几年里，他的音乐很少被听到；他的作品如珠宝般精妙绝伦，只有最敬业的演奏家才能驾驭。然而到了 20 世纪 50 年代中期，韦伯恩的音乐构想在各个方面都严密组织，引起了痴迷于探索新表达方式的一代欧洲年轻人的重新发现。西德广播电台在科隆设立了一个实验室，研究通过振荡器和其他音调生成设备以电子方式生成并通过磁带编辑进行电子处理的音乐的潜力。年轻的作曲家卡尔海因茨·施托克豪森看到了通过按下电子控制台上的正确按钮来完全控制音乐作品的内容和结构的可能性。在科隆，他曾与一位同样具有革命思想的法国人皮埃尔·布列兹一起共事过一段时间，几年后，布列兹就说服法国政府资助他在巴黎建立自己的工作室（IRCAM，声学和音乐研究与协调研究所）。

Anton von Webern died in 1945, shot by mistake by an American sentry in the Austrian village of Mittersill. For years after his death little of his music was heard; the microscopic precision of his jewel-like pieces defied any but the most dedicated performer. By the mid-1950s, however, Webern’s vision of a music tightly organized in all aspects brought about his rediscovery by a generation of young Europeans obsessed with exploring new modes of expression. At Cologne the West German Radio had set up a laboratory to investigate the potential of music electronically produced through oscillators and other tone-generating devices and electronically processed through tape editing. The young composer Karlheinz Stockhausen saw the possibilities of maintaining total control over the substance and structure of a musical work by pressing the right buttons on an electronic console. At Cologne he was joined for a time by a similarly revolution-minded Frenchman, Pierre Boulez—who within a few years would convince the French government to finance a studio of his own in Paris (IRCAM, the Institute for Research and Coordination of Acoustics and Music).

到了20世纪80年代，电子音乐实验室已成为大多数大学的标准附属设施，电子音乐也走出了音效阶段，成为一种更为严肃的音乐形式。纽约拥有一个由哥伦比亚大学、普林斯顿大学和贝尔实验室联合维护的中心；其最著名的作曲家米尔顿·巴比特成功地证明了，以电子方式创作的作品（《Philomel》，为女高音和四轨磁带而作）可以被认为有资格获得久负盛名的普利策奖。在洛杉矶北部的加州艺术学院，莫顿·萨博特尼克研究出了现场音乐家和计算机程序互动的方式，从而创作出比凡人或机器单独创作的更美妙、更复杂的音乐。

By the 1980s electronic-music laboratories had become a standard adjunct to most universities, and electronic music had moved out of its sound-effects stage and into a more serious kind of music. New York boasted a center maintained jointly by Columbia and Princeton Universities and Bell Laboratories; its most renowned composer, Milton Babbitt, triumphantly demonstrated that a work electronically conceived (Philomel, for soprano and four-track tape) could be deemed worthy of the prestigious Pulitzer prize. At the California Institute of the Arts, north of Los Angeles, Morton Subotnick worked out ways in which live musicians and a computer program could interact to produce music more fantastic, more complex, than mere mortals or mere machines could do on their own.

电子音乐无限的声音潜力似乎以一种令人愉悦却又充满好奇的方式，激励着一些作曲家去拓展他们可以用“常规”或至少是非电子手段创作的音乐。出生于希腊的伊安尼斯·泽纳基斯（Iannis Xenakis）从事双重职业：作曲家和建筑师；他一些最引人注目的音乐作品中，其曲线、旋转、起伏的轮廓，确实暗示着他所参与设计的建筑形状。出生于匈牙利的乔治·利盖蒂（György Ligeti）曾在科隆与斯托克豪森合作过一段时间，但后来创作了一套奇特而迷人的曲目，其中需要“现场”机械乐器：一首由100个节拍器组成的“交响诗”，所有节拍器都上紧发条，滴答作响，但最终会放慢到各自不同步的速率；还有一些乐曲，则使用手摇风琴或陶笛合奏等简陋的乐器演奏。利盖蒂的一些音乐被用作斯坦利·库布里克的《2001：太空漫游》的背景音乐；将宇宙飞船穿过星际灯光秀并降落到木星的怪异、旋转、嗡嗡的音乐来自利盖蒂的杰作《安魂曲》。

The limitless sound potential of electronic music seemed, in a delightful if curious way, to stimulate some composers into expanding what they might do with “normal,” or, at least, nonelectronic means. The Greek-born Iannis Xenakis pursues two careers, as both composer and architect; the curving, swirling, undulating outlines of some of his most striking music does, indeed, suggest the shape of buildings he is known to have worked on. The Hungarian-born György Ligeti worked with Stockhausen at Cologne for a time, but later created a strange, enchanting repertory that called for “live” mechanical instruments: a “Poème Symphonique” for an assemblage of 100 metronomes all wound up and ticking but eventually slowing down to individual, out-of-synch rates, and other pieces for such humble means as a barrel-organ or an ensemble of ocarinas. Some of Ligeti’s music found its way into the background score for Stanley Kubrick’s 2001: A Space Odyssey; the eerie, swirling, buzzing music that brings the spaceship through the interplanetary light show and onto Jupiter is from Ligeti’s masterful Requiem.

 

 

这些革命性的潮流——文化折衷主义、极简主义、约翰·凯奇的美学、勋伯格体系、斯特拉文斯基看似的妥协、电子革命——是否构成了本世纪下半叶严肃音乐的全貌？绝非如此。正如阿隆·科普兰在其关于音乐形式的宝贵章节中所指出的，本世纪的许多作曲家仍在创作交响曲、协奏曲、歌剧和室内乐。当然，在这些音乐形式中，音乐语言发生了变化；同样，构成一部名副其实的交响曲的理念也发生了变化。

Were these revolutionary trends—the cultural eclecticism, the minimalism, John Cage’s aesthetic, the Schoenbergian systems and Stravinsky’s seeming capitulation, the electronic revolutions—the entire panorama of serious music in the second half of this century? By no means. As Aaron Copland noted in his invaluable chapter on form, many composers in this century still create symphonies and concertos, operas and chamber music. Within these forms, of course, the musical language changed; so did the very idea of what might constitute a symphony worthy of the name.

德米特里·肖斯塔科维奇留下了十五部交响曲，但其中一部（第13号）实际上是叶夫图申科诗歌《巴比亚尔》的合唱版，另一部（第14号）则是一系列为歌手和一支小型管弦乐队创作的悲剧歌曲。1976年，美国极简主义者菲利普·格拉斯与先锋派舞台导演罗伯特·威尔逊合作创作了——或者说，你可以称之为歌剧——一部名为《海滩上的爱因斯坦》的大型舞台作品，完全以隐喻的方式展现了这位伟大的科学家，并在作品进行到大约五个小时时，高潮迭起，以宇宙飞船上的场景为背景。

Dimitri Shostakovich left a legacy of fifteen symphonies, but one of them (No. 13) is actually a choral setting of the Yevtushenko poem “Babi Yar,” and another (No. 14) is a series of tragic songs for vocalists and a small orchestra. In 1976 the American minimalist Philip Glass joined with the avant-garde stage director Robert Wilson to create—well, you might call it an opera—a huge stage work called Einstein on the Beach, dealing with the great scientist entirely in metaphor and climaxing, about five hours into the piece, with action aboard a spaceship.

在百老汇音乐剧领域，到1976年，人们有理由担心这种特殊形式的音乐剧已经走到了尽头；就在那一年，美国最著名的音乐家伦纳德·伯恩斯坦的一场大型、令人眼花缭乱的演出未能演出满一周。另一方面，斯蒂芬·桑德海姆为百老汇创作的音乐剧《理发师陶德》则探讨了谋杀、食人和淫乱，与其说是一部戏剧音乐剧，不如说更像是一部歌剧，事实上，这部剧已经被多家歌剧公司制作过。

In the realm of the Broadway musical, there was reason by 1976 to fear that this particular form had run its course; that was the year that a big, dazzling show by the best known of all American musicians, Leonard Bernstein, failed to run a full week. On the other hand, Stephen Sondheim’s Sweeney Todd, a musical created for Broadway and dealing with murder, cannibalism, and lechery, seemed more like an opera than a theatrical musical, and has in fact been produced by several opera companies.

英国的本杰明·布里顿是近代最成功的歌剧作曲家，他创作的剧目范围广泛，从老式宏伟的歌剧（《彼得·格莱姆斯》）到具有同等情感冲击力但力度小得多的作品（因此，更有可能上演，如《螺丝在拧紧》、《卢克丽霞受辱记》、《魂断威尼斯》）。

By far the most successful operatic composer of recent times, England’s Benjamin Britten produced a repertory that ranges from grand opera on an old-fashioned grandiose scale (Peter Grimes) to works of comparable emotional impact but using far smaller forces (and, therefore, with better chance of being performed, such as The Turn of the Screw, The Rape of Lucretia, Death in Venice).

在共产主义统治下的苏联，像阿尔弗雷德·施尼特凯和索菲亚·古拜杜丽娜这样的先锋作曲家在黑暗的角落里创作出极具挑战性的新音乐，远离那些曾让肖斯塔科维奇和普罗科菲耶夫焦虑不安的政委们的注视。随着苏联政权的垮台，这些作曲家及其同事创作的一系列生动活泼的音乐作品占据了应有的地位。在阿尔弗雷德·施尼特凯迄今为止创作的八部交响曲中，《第一交响曲》是一部滑稽的自由形式作品，在某一时刻甚至需要一支摇滚乐队闯入音乐厅进行表演；他的《第四交响曲》则采用了合唱，吟唱古老的俄罗斯教堂圣歌。他的《第三弦乐四重奏》是一锅精彩的音乐大杂烩，巴赫、贝多芬和其他大师的经典之作融入其中，并以施尼特凯自身语言中令人敬畏的不和谐音进行调味。

In the Soviet Union under Communism, avant-garde composers like Alfred Schnittke and Sofia Gubaidulina wrote their challenging new music in dark corners, away from the eyes of the disapproving commissars that had given Shostakovich and Prokofieff many anxious moments. With the collapse of Soviet power a repertory of vivid music by these and their colleagues has taken its rightful place. Of Alfred Schnittke’s eight symphonies (so far), the First is a hilarious free-form work that at one point requires a rock band to invade the concert hall and set up shop; his Fourth Symphony employs a chorus, intoning ancient Russian church chants. His Third String Quartet is a splendid musical stew, into which quotations from Bach, Beethoven, and other past masters are stirred in and seasoned with the fearsome dissonances of Schnittke’s own language.

 

 

那么，在我们这个时代如此浩瀚的音乐中，我们究竟在聆听什么呢？对于我们最常在音乐厅或收音机里听到的那些熟悉的音乐，我们运用记忆的力量来维系聆听体验；我们记住交响乐开头的旋律，在作曲家对旋律进行些许调整时欣喜若狂，并在之后音乐恢复原样时享受重新发现的兴奋。其他聆听工具也发挥了作用，正如阿隆·科普兰（Aaron Copland）的著作所解释的那样，比我认识或曾经认识的任何人都更透彻。

What, then, do we listen for in this vast array of music of our own time? In the familiar music we’re most likely to hear in concert halls or on the radio, we use our powers of memory to bind a listening experience; we remember the tune at the beginning of the symphony, smile with pleasure as the composer tweaks that tune here and there, and enjoy the thrill of rediscovery when it later returns as it was before. Other listening tools come into play, as Aaron Copland’s book explains better than anyone I know or have known.

科普兰在为本书1957年修订版撰写的关于当代音乐的简短章节中，将新音乐分为四类：非常容易、相当平易近人、相当困难和非常难。四十年后，没有真正的理由去改变这些陈旧的套路，或者改变那些被困在里面的鸟儿。阿诺德·勋伯格的第四弦乐四重奏和罗杰·塞申斯的第三交响曲——两部属于“非常难”级别的作品——需要听众付出一定的努力去理解。

In his short chapter on contemporary music, written for the 1957 revision of this book, Copland divides the realm of new music into four categories: very easy, quite approachable, fairly difficult, and very tough. Forty years later there is no real reason to change those pigeonholes or the birds cooped up in them. Arnold Schoenberg’s Fourth String Quartet and the Third Symphony of Roger Sessions—two inhabitants on the “very tough” level—demand a certain effort from listeners.

如果说有什么安慰的话，那就是在我第一次聆听勋伯格第四四重奏半个世纪后，我发现它仍然“非常难”——只不过现在我开始能辨认出这部作品主要旋律的轮廓，并注意到它们何时再次出现，就像我聆听莫扎特四重奏一样。贝多芬的晚期四重奏也“非常难”，古斯塔夫·马勒的第九交响曲也是如此。我坚信，一旦我们克服了对新体验的恐惧——我再说一遍，是我们的，而不仅仅是你的——我们就已经在与那些“非常难”的作品建立合一的道路上迈出了一大步。

If it’s any comfort, half a century after my first hearing of the Schoenberg Fourth Quartet, I find that it’s still “very tough”—except that now I begin to make out the outlines of the work’s principal melodies and to note when they reappear, as I do with a Mozart quartet. The late quartets of Beethoven are also “very tough,” and so is the Ninth Symphony of Gustav Mahler. I firmly believe that, once we conquer our fear of new experiences—and I repeat, our, not just your—we’re more than halfway toward establishing a oneness with those “very tough” pieces out there.

不要听莫扎特交响曲中简单的和声和熟悉的旋律，而是聆听巴托克的《管弦乐协奏曲》中令人惊叹的管弦乐音色；听史蒂夫莱奇的《鼓声》中音乐从一个模式缓慢过渡到另一个模式的重复，让人着迷；让莫顿苏博特尼克用合成器创作的《月亮银苹果》带你回到“很久以前，在一个遥远的星系”。

Instead of the simple harmonies and recognizable tunes of a Mozart symphony, listen to the amazing swoosh of orchestral tone-color in Béla Bartók’s Concerto for Orchestra; be hypnotized by the repetitions in Steve Reich’s Drumming as the music oozes ever so slowly from one pattern to the next; let Morton Subotnick’s synthesizer-created Silver Apples of the Moon transport you to “long ago, in a galaxy far, far away.”

面对一部你毫无预知的全新作品，请坚持自己的立场。或许它并不好，你周围的每个人都在等着别人评价。然而，或许它还不错；伟大的音乐家兼作家尼古拉斯·斯洛尼姆斯基不久前编著的《音乐谩骂词典》或许能让你清醒一些。书中，我们可以看到一位评论家在柴可夫斯基那首耳熟能详的小提琴协奏曲首演时写道：“它听起来很刺耳。”

Confronted with a brand-new work you have no foreknowledge of, hold your ground. Perhaps it isn’t any good, and everybody around you is waiting for someone to say so. Perhaps, however, it is any good; be sobered by a book called A Lexicon of Musical Invective compiled some time ago by the great musician/author Nicolas Slonimsky, in which we can read the critic who, at the first performance of Tschaikovsky’s thrice-familiar Violin Concerto, wrote that “it stinks in the ear.”

令人敬畏的评论家和不太严厉的作曲家维吉尔·汤姆森（Virgil Thomson）曾经为聆听不熟悉的作品制定了一套规则；其中最后一条是我参加每一次新音乐活动时都会问的问题：“这只是一个好的钟表，还是它真的报时？”真的，这就是你所需要的：这个问题，以及与一双同样优质的耳朵相连的开放的心态。

The fearsome critic and not-very-tough composer Virgil Thomson once drew up a set of rules for hearing an unfamiliar work; the last of those is the question I take with me to every new-music event: “Is this just a good piece of clockwork, or does it actually tell time?” Really, that’s all you need: that question, and an open mind connected to a pair of ears of like quality.

 

 

—艾伦·里奇

—Alan Rich
