附录一

APPENDIX I

典型变异公式

Typical Variation Formulas

啊！你的爱人奥古斯丁

Ach! du lieber Augustin

主题

THEME

1. 谐波变体：

1. Harmonic variants:

a. 旋律基本保留，但伴奏的和声完全改变：

a. The melody is retained literally, but the accompanying harmonies are completely transformed:

b. 保留了旋律和原有的和弦伴奏，但织体变得更加丰富：

b. The melody and original chordal accompaniment are retained, but the texture becomes enriched:

c. 旋律的所有痕迹都消失了。只保留了底层的和声骨架（在《Ach! du loveber Augustin》中，只涉及两个和弦——主和弦和属和弦）：

c. All trace of the melody is lost. Only the underlying harmonic skeleton is kept (in the case of Ach! du lieber Augustin, only two chords are involved—tonic and dominant):

d. 和弦骨架本身是变化的。这里与其说是主题的变奏，不如说是主题伴奏和弦的变奏：

d. The chordal skeleton itself is varied. Here it is not so much a variation of the theme as a variation of the accompanying chords of a theme:

2. 旋律变体：

2. Melodic variants:

a. 旋律本身富有变化。外轮廓得以保留，但线条更加华丽。这种类型基于音乐中的一个基本概念：如果从C调升至D调，也可以通过升C调（CC#-D）进行，而无需改变旋律的任何基本元素：

a. The melody itself is varied. The outer contours are kept, but the line is more florid. This type is based on the fundamental concept in music that if you pass from C to D, you can also go by way of C sharp (C-C#-D) without changing anything essential to the line:

b. 第二种旋律类型与前者相反——通过专注于最基本的音符，使旋律线不那么华丽。换句话说，如果原主题从C调过渡到升C调再到D调，那么旋律线可以直接从C调过渡到D调：

b. The second melodic type is the opposite of the foregoing—making the melodic line less florid than it is, by concentrating on the barest essential notes. In other words, if the original theme passes from C to C sharp to D, the line may go directly from C to D:

c. 保留主题，但其位置从上部移到下部或中部，或反之：

c. The theme is retained, but its position is changed from upper to lower or middle part, or vice versa:

3.节奏变体：

3. Rhythmic variant:

a. 所有类型的节奏变奏都可以归为一个类别——节奏变化。例如：如果将《啊！你的爱人奥古斯丁》的三四拍华尔兹节奏改为非常快的四四拍，主题的性质就会完全改变：

a. All types of rhythmic variation may be grouped under one heading—rhythmic change. One example: if the three-quarter, waltz character of Ach! du lieber Augustin is changed to four-quarter in very fast tempo, the nature of the theme is completely transformed:

4. 对位变体：

4. Contrapuntal variants:

a. 一种简单的对位变奏是在原曲中添加一个新主题，强调新主题，同时保留原曲的背景：

a. A simple type of contrapuntal variation consists of adding a new theme to the original, giving emphasis to the new one while retaining the original in the background:

b. 第二种方案更为巧妙，即从原主题中抽取一个乐句，并对其进行对位处理。这种方案很难让听众理解，除非乐句的出处从一开始就清晰明确：

b. A second, more subtle, scheme consists of extracting a single phrase from the original theme and subjecting it to contrapuntal treatment. This type is difficult for the listener to follow unless the derivation of the fragment is clear from the start:

5. 上述类型的任意组合。

5. Any combination of the foregoing types.

附录二

APPENDIX II

对位装置

Contrapuntal Devices

1. 模仿（巴赫——小调赋格，平均律古钢琴，第一册）

1. Imitation (Bach— Minor Fugue, Well-Tempered Clavichord, Book I)

2. 卡农（大纲）（巴赫—Erchienen ist der herrliche Tag）

2. Canon (outline) (Bach—Erchienen ist der herrliche Tag)

3. 转位（贝多芬——钢琴奏鸣曲，作品110）

3. Inversion (Beethoven—Piano Sonata, Op. 110)

4. 增广（巴赫——C小调赋格，《平均律古钢琴曲》第二册）

4. Augmentation (Bach—C minor fugue, Well-Tempered Clavichord, Book II)

5. 减音（谐谑曲——F小调交响曲——沃恩·威廉姆斯）

5. Diminution (Scherzo—Symphony in F minor—Vaughan-Williams)

插图 5 已获得伦敦牛津大学出版社的许可。

Permission for illustration 5 granted by Oxford University Press, London.

6. Cancrizans（钢琴帕萨卡利亚—科普兰）

6. Cancrizans (Passacaglia for Piano—Copland)

7. 倒置巨蟹座四重奏（第三弦乐四重奏——勋伯格）

7. Cancrizans Inverted (String Quartet No. III—Schoenberg)

插图 6 经版权所有者 Maurice Senart（巴黎）和 Elkan-Vogel Company, Inc.（费城）授权使用。版权归 Salabert & Co.（纽约）所有。

附录三

APPENDIX III

贝多芬的“瓦尔德斯坦”奏鸣曲分析，作品。 53

Analysis of Beethoven’s “Waldstein” Sonata, Op. 53

我在此尝试的分析必然无法令人满意，因为我们缺乏音符本身的声音。我将基于一个可能毫无根据的假设：读者可以获得印刷版乐谱或录音。

An analysis such as I shall attempt here must always be unsatisfactory, since we lack the sound of the notes themselves. I shall proceed on the assumption, possibly unwarranted, that the reader can secure either the printed score or the recording.

用这首奏鸣曲来阐释这一曲式，其优势之一在于第一和第二主题组之间的鲜明对比。如果只从旋律的角度思考，第一主题几乎称不上是一个主题。它由三个独立的细小声部组成，营造出一种悬念与神秘的氛围。这种氛围源于八分音符重复的底层节奏，或许可以算作第一要素。第二要素则无伤大雅：

One of the advantages of using this particular sonata as illustration of the form is the utter contrast between the first and second thematic groups. If you think only in terms of melody, the first theme is hardly a theme at all. It is made up of three separate tiny parts, producing an atmosphere of suspense and mysteriousness. It is the underlying rhythm in repeated eighth notes which is responsible for this and may be accounted the first element. The second element is harmless enough:

没有人会怀疑它在后续发展阶段将扮演的角色。第三个小片段也是如此，它的内容如下：

No one could possibly suspect the role it is to play later in the development section. The same is true of the third tiny fragment, which is as follows:

前四小节立即重复了一个低于原音的音调，然后不停顿地向前推进，在 G 音上完全停顿（第 13 小节）。现在，所有内容再次从头开始重复，重要的区别在于，开头重复的八分音符被分解成十六分音符（花型音），并且调性略有变化。这些重复的重要目的在于将重要的主题素材牢牢地植入听众的意识中。这一次没有停顿；音乐通过一系列的延长，不知不觉地进入了桥段部分（第 23 小节，有关该术语的解释见第 156 页）。这里听到的不是旋律，而是跑音和琶音——所谓的乐段。即使你以前从未听过这首奏鸣曲，从素材的性质也能清楚地看出，这首曲子正在从第一组元素过渡到第二组元素。

The first four measures are immediately repeated a tone below and without stopping rush forward to a complete pause on the note G (measure 13). Now, once again, everything is repeated from the start, with the important difference that the repeated eighth notes of the beginning are broken up into sixteenths (figurated) and slightly changed in tonality. These repetitions serve the important purpose of placing essential thematic material firmly in the listener’s consciousness. This time there is no pause; the music, through a series of elongations, imperceptibly moves into the bridge section (measure 23, see page 156 for explanation of this term). What one finds here is not melody but runs and arpeggios—so-called passage work. Even if you never heard this sonata before, it would be clear from the nature of the material that the piece was moving on from a first to a second grouping of elements.

此处的过渡真是精彩绝伦！音乐仿佛放慢了节奏，以便开启性质完全相反的第二主题（35小节）。缓慢移动的持续和弦营造出一种类似圣歌般的、近乎宗教般的平静与轻松。这些持续和弦立即重复（43小节），并在上方添加了一条华丽的旋律线。（尽管重复次数在所有音乐中都很常见，但其特点是很少出现逐字重复，而是重复的部分有所变化。）

The transition in this case is really brilliantly accomplished! The music seems to slow itself up, in order to begin a second theme (measure 35) of a completely opposed nature. The slowly moving, sustained chords produce a choralelike, almost religious feeling of calm and ease. These sustained chords are repeated immediately (measure 43), with the addition of a single florid melodic line above. (It is characteristic that despite the amount of repetition, so usual in all music, there is seldom literal repetition but repeated sections varied.)

编织在持续和弦之上的那段华丽旋律，成了回归第一过渡段（第50小节）更具象征意味特征的“借口”。这里，我们正经历着一个令人着迷的时刻，分析家在对曲式的不同解读之间左右为难。显然，这段新的乐段要么是b的第二部分，人们不愿承认这一点，因为它的性质与b的第一部分截然不同；要么是通往c的第二座桥梁，但这不太可能，因为它过于繁琐。作曲家在这方面很幸运——如果最终结果是合乎逻辑的，他永远不需要为自己创造的曲式给出有意识的解释。但可怜的理论家，如果他想解释这种曲式，除非下定决心，否则很难做到。因此，我选择了前者，更倾向于将这段较长的乐段视为某种b-2，它引向了结尾主题。

That extra florid melody, woven above the sustained chords, acts as an “excuse” for returning to the more figurated character of the first transition section (measure 50). Here we have one of those tantalizing moments when the analyst is torn between different interpretations of the form. Obviously, this new passage work is one of two things: Either it is a second part of b, which one is reluctant to admit, because it is so very different in nature from the first part of b; or it is a second bridge leading to c, which is rather unlikely because of its overelaborate nature. That is where the composer is fortunate—he never need give conscious reasons to himself for the form that he creates, if the end result is a logical one. But the poor theorist, if he wishes to explain the form, cannot very well do so without making up his mind. Therefore, I elect the first of these alternatives, preferring to consider this long passage-work section as a kind of b-2 which leads to the closing theme.

c部分，即结尾部分（第 74 小节），比其他部分更短，与充满歌声的第二主题的联系比与激动人心的第一主题的联系更紧密。它的作用是将情绪带回一种宁静的感觉，从而强调了结尾的感觉，同时为发展部分开头第一个素材的重新进入做好了准备。

The c, or closing, section (measure 74), shorter than the others, has more affinity with the songlike second theme than with the agitated first theme. It serves to bring the mood back to a feeling of quietude, thereby emphasizing the sense of conclusion and at the same time preparing the way for the renewed entrance of the first material at the head of the development section.

事实也确实如此。作曲家所做的第一件事就是提醒你他从哪里开始——可以说，给你一个参照点。这几乎是在贝多芬离开之前完成的！事实上，这个特定的展开部分既不是很长，也不是很复杂。对于展开，它只选择了前一页引用的两个片段和我选择称为b-2 的部分。没有提及类似众赞歌的主题、结束主题或开头重复的八分音符。但有一种普遍的运动感和内心的兴奋，贯穿了整个第一乐章的大部分内容。

That is exactly what happens. The first thing that the composer does is to remind you of where he began—to give you a point of reference, as it were. This is hardly done, before Beethoven is off! As a matter of fact, this particular development section is neither very long nor very elaborate. For development, it chooses only the two fragments quoted on the previous page and the section I elected to call b-2. No reference is made to the choralelike theme or the closing theme or the opening repeated eighth notes. But there is a general feeling of movement and inner excitement, which pervades most of the whole first movement.

发展部分分为两部分。作曲家首先将上文引用的第一主题的两个片段并置（第92小节）。然后，他专注于第一个片段，将原本只是一个小乐句发展成一个快速抒情的小声部。这直接引出了下一个素材——b -2乐段的开头小节。在此基础上，音乐以这样的方式依次展开：在到达G音之前，大量的外来调性被反复使用。在这个属音（第142小节）上，贝多芬回归了乐章开头的神秘感，为第一主题的回归做好心理准备。这种重新过渡非常引人注目，因为在海顿或莫扎特的音乐中不可能找到与之相媲美的东西。低音中神秘的隆隆声和高潮的逐渐升华是贝多芬的典型风格。

The development section is divided into two parts. First the composer juxtaposes the two fragments of the first theme quoted above (measure 92). Then he concentrates on the first of the two fragments, developing what was originally only a tiny phrase into a swiftly lyrical little part. This leads directly to the development of the next material—the opening measures of the b-2 passage work. On that basis, the music works itself out sequentially in such a way that a great many foreign tonalities are passed through before the dominant note G is reached. On this dominant (measure 142), Beethoven returns to the mysterious feeling of the very beginning in order to prepare psychologically for the return of the first theme. This retransition is quite remarkable, if only because it would be impossible to find anything comparable to it in the music of Haydn or Mozart. The misterioso rumblings in the bass and the gradual piling up of climax is typically Beethoven’s touch.

随着突然回到极弱，再现部开始（156小节）。这次的重复几乎是逐字逐句的，除了一些非常细微的变化，主要是调性的变化。接下来是两页半的尾声（249小节）。开头几乎与第一发展部相似，之后进一步发展了之前使用的两个片段，但现在并列的方式略有不同。在两个持续和弦之后，这又回到了类似众赞歌的主题，由于新低音的加入，主题变得更加富有表现力（284小节）。看似不愿离开这片新发现的宁静，却被急促的结尾所打破。奏鸣曲的快板就此完成。

With a sudden return to pianissimo, the recapitulation starts (measure 156). The repetition in this case is almost literal, except for a few very minor changes, mostly of tonalities. A two-and-a-half-page coda follows (measure 249). After beginning almost like the first development section, it goes on to a further development of the same two fragments used there but now juxtaposed in a somewhat different fashion. This leads back, after two held chords, to the choralelike theme, made newly expressive by the addition of a new bass (measure 284). The seeming reluctance to leave this newfound quietude is broken off by an impetuous rush to the end. The sonata allegro is completed.

建议进一步阅读的参考书目

克里斯托弗·哥伦布（米约）

Christopher Columbus (Milhaud)

Chromatic Fantasy and Fugue (Bach), Prelude

半音阶

单簧管

Clarinet

低音单簧管

bass clarinet

在爵士乐队中

in jazz band

1

1

编者注：《音乐中应该聆听什么》已有德语、意大利语、西班牙语、瑞典语、希伯来语和波斯语的译本。

EDITOR’S NOTE: Translations of What to Listen for in Music have appeared in German, Italian, Spanish, Swedish, Hebrew, and Persian.

2

2

威廉·舒曼对此说法提出质疑。他声称，通过与业余爱好者进行实践，这种方法在帮助那些原本音盲的人识别旋律素材方面取得了良好的效果。

William Schuman contests this statement. As a result of practical work with amateurs he claims good results in aiding those previously held tone-deaf to recognize melodic materials.

3

3

然而，最近对电子音乐制作的实验表明，一种受过科学训练的新型作曲家将成为我们这个时代的先驱。

Recent experiments with electronically produced music, however, point to a new species of scientifically trained composer as the pioneer type of our own time.

4

4

版权所有 1924 年 12 月 12 日，Harms, Inc. 经许可使用。

Copyright Dec. 12, 1924, by Harms, Inc. Used by permission.

Reprinted from New Music (Vol. 9, No. 3, April, 1936), quarterly publication of the New Music Society of California. Used by permission of Roy Harris.

6

6

勋伯格并不赞同“无调性”这一术语。尽管如此，这个词仍然被继续使用，更多的是出于方便，而非其准确性。

Schoenberg did not approve of the term “atonality.” The word continues to be used nonetheless, more out of convenience than because of its exactitude.

7

仅适用于 78 rpm 录音。

Available only on 78-rpm recording.

From Das Marienleben (original version) by Paul Hindemith. Used by permission of Associated Music Publishers, Inc.

From the Land of a Thousand Lakes, by Jean Sibelius. Used by permission of The Boston Music Company.

This schematic description is meant to indicate nothing more than the conventional framework as usually outlined, textbook fashion.

14

这种性格特征的比较是在他们作为交响乐文学的活跃诠释者期间写的。

This comparison of personality traits was written during their years as active interpreters of symphonic literature.
